codeMetadata.name: seo
codeMetadata.typeSignature: const seo: (_complex_param: { title: string; description?: string; image?: string; keywords?: string }) => any

semanticData.summary: Generates an array of SEO meta tags for a given page, including Open Graph and Twitter card data.
semanticData.description: This seo constant provides a utility function to generate a standardized array of HTML meta tags for Search Engine Optimization (SEO). It consolidates common Open Graph and Twitter Card metadata based on provided page details like title, description, keywords, and an optional image. This simplifies the process of making web pages discoverable and shareable across various platforms by automatically creating the necessary <meta> elements.

commonUseCases: Dynamically setting page metadata for a blog post or article.
Configuring SEO properties for a product detail page.
Ensuring consistent social media sharing previews for website pages.
Implementing site-wide default SEO settings.

examples.description: Demonstrates how to generate basic SEO meta tags for a page, including title, description, and keywords. The output array can then be used to populate the document's <head> section, typically within a frontend framework.

Shows how to include an image URL to automatically generate Twitter Card and Open Graph image tags, crucial for rich previews when the page is shared on social media platforms like Twitter and Facebook.

limitations: Does not automatically fetch or validate image dimensions or types; developers must ensure the image URL points to a valid and appropriately sized image for optimal social sharing previews.
Only generates a fixed set of common meta tags; custom or highly specialized meta tags (e.g., schema.org JSON-LD) would need to be added separately.
Requires manual integration with the specific frontend framework's method for injecting meta tags into the <head> (e.g., SvelteKit's <svelte:head>, React Helmet, VueUse's useHead).
bestPractices: Always provide a unique and descriptive title for each page.
Keep description concise (under 160 characters) and compelling to encourage clicks from search results.
Use a relevant image for better visual representation on social media shares, ensuring it meets typical Open Graph/Twitter card image dimensions (e.g., 1200x630 pixels).
Integrate this function with a framework's head management system (e.g., SvelteKit's $lib/seo.ts usage implies integration with SvelteKit's <svelte:head>).
antiPatterns: Hardcoding meta tags directly into every HTML file instead of using this utility for dynamic content, leading to maintenance overhead.
Providing excessively long or irrelevant description or keywords which can negatively impact SEO ranking or be ignored by search engines.
Omitting the title parameter, as it's the only required field and critical for basic SEO and browser tabs.

semanticData.summary: Defines the maximum screen width (in pixels) for what is considered a 'mobile' device in responsive design.
semanticData.description: This constant defines the numerical pixel width threshold used to differentiate between mobile and non-mobile screen sizes within the application's responsive design. It serves as a single source of truth for the mobile breakpoint, ensuring consistency across various responsive logic implementations, such as the `useIsMobile` hook. Utilizing this constant helps eliminate 'magic numbers' in the codebase, making breakpoint adjustments and overall maintainability significantly easier.

commonUseCases: Determining content layout based on current screen size
Conditionally rendering UI components optimized for mobile or desktop views
Applying specific CSS classes or styles based on device type
Implementing JavaScript logic that behaves differently on mobile devices

examples.code: import * as React from "react";const MOBILE_BREAKPOINT = 768;export function useIsMobile() {  const [isMobile, setIsMobile] = React.useState<boolean | undefined>(    undefined,  );  React.useEffect(() => {    const mql = window.matchMedia(`(max-width: ${MOBILE_BREAKPOINT - 1}px)`);    const onChange = () => {      setIsMobile(window.innerWidth < MOBILE_BREAKPOINT);    };    mql.addEventListener("change", onChange);    setIsMobile(window.innerWidth < MOBILE_BREAKPOINT);    return () => mql.removeEventListener("change", onChange);  }, []);  return !!isMobile;}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how `MOBILE_BREAKPOINT` is utilized within a React hook (`useIsMobile`) to dynamically determine if the current viewport is considered 'mobile'. It highlights its application in `window.matchMedia` for CSS media query emulation and direct `window.innerWidth` comparisons.

limitations: A single, fixed numerical breakpoint may not be sufficient for highly complex responsive designs that require multiple tiers (e.g., tablet, small desktop, large desktop).
It defines a breakpoint solely by width, not considering device pixel ratio, touch capabilities, or other factors that might define a 'mobile' experience for certain devices.
Relies on JavaScript for dynamic checks, which might cause a brief flickering on initial page load before the JavaScript executes and determines the mobile state.
bestPractices: Centralize all breakpoint definitions in a single file or constant for easy management and consistency across the application.
Utilize named constants like MOBILE_BREAKPOINT to significantly improve code readability and maintainability.
When using in `max-width` media queries (e.g., `(max-width: ${MOBILE_BREAKPOINT - 1}px)`), subtract 1 pixel to prevent overlaps with `min-width` queries that start at the breakpoint value.
Consider combining this constant with CSS custom properties (variables) for a unified approach to managing responsive styles.
antiPatterns: Using different hardcoded numerical values for mobile breakpoints across various parts of the codebase instead of referencing MOBILE_BREAKPOINT, leading to inconsistent responsive behavior.
Embedding breakpoint values directly into CSS or inline JavaScript without a shared constant, making global updates tedious and error-prone.
Assuming this single breakpoint fits all user needs without considering multiple breakpoints for more nuanced responsive layouts.

semanticData.summary: Detects if the current viewport width is below a defined mobile breakpoint using `window.matchMedia`.
semanticData.description: This React hook provides a reactive boolean state indicating whether the current viewport width is considered "mobile" (less than 768px). It automatically updates on window resize events, leveraging `window.matchMedia` for efficient and performant responsiveness detection. This hook simplifies conditional rendering or behavior based on device size in React applications.

commonUseCases: Conditionally rendering UI components optimized for mobile or desktop layouts
Adjusting component props or behavior based on screen size
Displaying mobile-specific navigation or menus
Triggering different interactions for touch-enabled vs. mouse-enabled devices

examples.description: Demonstrates how to conditionally render different parts of a UI or content based on whether the user's device is detected as mobile, allowing for adaptive user experiences.
Shows how to switch between entirely different component implementations, such as mobile-specific versus desktop-specific navigation menus, based on the `isMobile` status.

limitations: Relies on the `window` object and `matchMedia` API, meaning it will not work during server-side rendering (SSR) without specific environmental checks or mocks.
The mobile breakpoint is fixed internally at 768px; if custom or multiple breakpoints are required, a more flexible hook (e.g., one accepting a breakpoint argument) would be necessary.
Only distinguishes based on viewport width; it does not differentiate between various mobile devices (e.g., phone vs. tablet) or device types beyond screen size.
bestPractices: Define breakpoints consistently across your application (e.g., using shared constants or a design system) for unified responsiveness
Combine with CSS media queries for styling adjustments, reserving the hook for significant conditional component rendering or logic
Use it for logical branching in component trees rather than just applying different styles
antiPatterns: Overusing the hook for minor style changes that can be efficiently handled with pure CSS media queries
Relying on it in server-side rendering (SSR) environments without proper window object checks, as it's browser-specific

semanticData.summary: A utility function for conditionally joining CSS class names and intelligently merging Tailwind CSS classes to resolve conflicts.
semanticData.description: The cn function streamlines the process of building dynamic className strings in React/Next.js applications, especially when using Tailwind CSS. It combines the functionality of clsx for conditional class application with tailwind-merge for resolving conflicting Tailwind utility classes, ensuring the correct final style. This eliminates common issues with overriding styles and simplifies className logic, making UI styling more robust and maintainable.

commonUseCases: Dynamically applying classes to UI elements based on component state or props
Combining multiple Tailwind CSS utility classes, some of which might conflict
Building reusable UI components where different variants apply distinct sets of classes
Integrating with component libraries that expect a single className string

examples.description: This example demonstrates combining static classes, conditional classes based on `isActive` prop, and an additional conditional class for `size`. It also shows how `cn` automatically resolves Tailwind conflicts, like `p-4` and `p-6`, ensuring `p-6` is the final padding applied without manual intervention.

Here, `cn` is used to combine base styles for a Card component with any additional classes passed via the `className` prop. This allows for easy extensibility and overriding of default styles while ensuring proper Tailwind merging.

limitations: Primarily designed for string-based CSS classes (like those used with `className` in React/HTML) and specifically for Tailwind CSS conflict resolution, not for other styling approaches (e.g., CSS-in-JS objects, inline styles).
Does not validate if the provided class names are actual CSS classes or valid Tailwind utility classes; it only processes them as strings.
bestPractices: Always use `cn` for all `className` props in projects utilizing Tailwind CSS to ensure consistent merging and conflict resolution.
Group related conditional classes for readability, e.g., `cn('text-white', isActive && 'bg-blue-500', isLarge ? 'text-lg' : 'text-sm')`.
Pass all class fragments directly to `cn` instead of concatenating parts before passing, to leverage the full power of `clsx` and `tailwind-merge`.
antiPatterns: Manually concatenating class strings: `const className = 'base ' + (isActive ? 'active' : '') + ' some-other-class';` This makes conditional logic messy and doesn't handle Tailwind conflicts.
Attempting to manually resolve Tailwind CSS conflicts by ordering: `className='p-4 p-6'` expecting `p-6` to win. `tailwind-merge` (via `cn`) handles this reliably.

semanticData.summary: Renders a UI component that maintains a fixed aspect ratio for its content, based on Radix UI's AspectRatio primitive.
semanticData.description: The AspectRatio component wraps Radix UI's AspectRatioPrimitive.Root to provide a simple way to maintain consistent aspect ratios for elements like images, videos, or embeds. It automatically calculates and applies padding to ensure the specified width-to-height ratio is preserved as the container scales. This is essential for responsive layouts where content dimensions need to be strictly controlled without distorting the content itself.

commonUseCases: Displaying images or videos that need to maintain specific proportions.
Embedding maps or external content that should not distort upon resizing.
Creating responsive containers for dynamic content where content height depends on width.
Ensuring consistent spacing and alignment in grid layouts.

examples.description: Demonstrates how to wrap an image in `AspectRatio` to ensure it always maintains a 16:9 ratio, scaling proportionally within its parent container. The `ratio` prop is crucial here, and `object-cover` ensures the image fills the space without distortion.

Shows how to embed a YouTube video while enforcing a specific aspect ratio (e.g., 21:9 for ultrawide videos), preventing the player from stretching or squashing on different screen sizes. The iframe is styled to fill the AspectRatio container.

limitations: Requires a specified `ratio` prop to function correctly; otherwise, it behaves like a standard `div`.

The content inside `AspectRatio` should typically be an `img`, `video`, or `iframe` with `object-cover` or `object-fit` applied to prevent distortion if the aspect ratio of the content itself doesn't match the container.
Only controls the aspect ratio of the *container*; it does not resize the content itself. The content should be styled to fill the container (e.g., `width: 100%; height: 100%; object-fit: cover;`).
bestPractices: Always specify the `ratio` prop explicitly (e.g., `16 / 9`, `4 / 3`, `1`).
For images and videos, use CSS properties like `object-fit: cover;` or `object-fit: contain;` on the child element to control how the media fills or fits within the maintained aspect ratio.
Combine with `width` or `max-width` on the parent container to control the overall size of the aspect-ratio element.
Consider using `overflow: hidden;` on the child content if it might exceed the bounds of the aspect ratio container due to `object-fit: cover;`.
antiPatterns: Not providing the `ratio` prop, which nullifies its primary purpose.
Placing content inside that cannot intrinsically scale (e.g., fixed-size text blocks) without considering how it will interact with the container's forced dimensions, leading to overflow.
Expecting the AspectRatio component to automatically resize or crop its children; this must be handled by CSS on the child elements.

semanticData.summary: Provides the root context for an accessible and customizable alert dialog, built on Radix UI primitives.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialog component serves as the foundational root for building accessible and highly customizable alert dialogs. Built on Radix UI primitives, it provides the necessary context and state management for critical user prompts that require explicit confirmation or acknowledgment. Its primary purpose is to ensure that disruptive or impactful actions are clearly communicated and confirmed by the user, handling essential accessibility features like focus management and keyboard navigation.

commonUseCases: Confirming destructive user actions like deleting data or accounts.
Notifying users of critical system errors or unrecoverable states.
Prompting users to save changes before navigating away from a form or page.
Requiring user agreement to terms and conditions before proceeding with an action.

examples.description: This example demonstrates a typical use case for AlertDialog: prompting a user to confirm a destructive action like deleting an account. It shows how to structure the AlertDialog with its trigger, content, header, title, description, footer, cancel, and action buttons, providing a clear and accessible confirmation flow.

limitations: As a client-side component (due to 'use client'), it will not render on the server, which means it requires client-side JavaScript to be interactive.
Relies heavily on Radix UI primitives, requiring familiarity with their API and concepts for deeper customization or troubleshooting.
While flexible, excessive customization beyond basic styling might require overriding Radix UI's default behaviors, which can be complex.
bestPractices: Always pair AlertDialog with its sub-components like Trigger, Content, Title, Description, Action, and Cancel for a complete and accessible experience.
Ensure the title and description clearly articulate the purpose of the dialog and the consequences of the user's choices.
Place destructive actions (e.g., 'Delete', 'Permanently Remove') as the primary action and style them distinctively.
Use the 'data-state' attributes provided by Radix UI for custom animations and transitions based on the dialog's open/closed state.
antiPatterns: Using AlertDialog for non-critical information, simple notifications, or general user input (a standard Dialog or Toast would be more appropriate).
Overloading the dialog with excessive text or too many interactive elements, making it difficult for users to quickly grasp the implications.
Omitting a clear 'Cancel' or 'Dismiss' option, which can trap users and lead to frustration.
Displaying AlertDialogs too frequently or without clear user initiation, leading to a disruptive user experience.

semanticData.summary: Renders a trigger element that opens a Radix UI-based AlertDialog component.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialogTrigger component is a wrapper around the Radix UI `AlertDialogPrimitive.Trigger` that serves as the interactive element, typically a button, which opens the `AlertDialog`. It is responsible for controlling the open state of the dialog and ensures proper accessibility attributes are applied. Developers use it to initiate important user confirmations or alerts.

commonUseCases: Opening a confirmation dialog before a destructive action (e.g., deleting an account)
Displaying an important alert that requires user acknowledgment
Triggering a modal for user input in a critical workflow

examples.code:
import { AlertDialog, AlertDialogTrigger, AlertDialogContent, AlertDialogHeader, AlertDialogTitle, AlertDialogDescription, AlertDialogFooter, AlertDialogAction, AlertDialogCancel } from "@repo/web/components/ui/alert-dialog";
import { Button } from "@repo/web/components/ui/button";

function DeleteAccountButton() {
  return (
    <AlertDialog>
      <AlertDialogTrigger asChild>
        <Button variant="destructive">Delete Account</Button>
      </AlertDialogTrigger>
      <AlertDialogContent>
        <AlertDialogHeader>
          <AlertDialogTitle>Are you absolutely sure?</AlertDialogTitle>
          <AlertDialogDescription>
            This action cannot be undone. This will permanently delete your
            account and remove your data from our servers.
          </AlertDialogDescription>
        </AlertDialogHeader>
        <AlertDialogFooter>
          <AlertDialogCancel>Cancel</AlertDialogCancel>
          <AlertDialogAction>Continue</AlertDialogAction>
        </AlertDialogFooter>
      </AlertDialogContent>
    </AlertDialog>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `AlertDialogTrigger` to open a confirmation dialog. The `asChild` prop is used to pass the `Button` component as the trigger element, allowing it to inherit the trigger's behavior while maintaining its own styling and functionality.

limitations: The `AlertDialogTrigger` component must be rendered within an `AlertDialog` context, as it relies on the parent component's state management from Radix UI.

It inherently opens the `AlertDialog` without direct control over the dialog's content or actions; those are handled by other `AlertDialog` sub-components like `AlertDialogContent`, `AlertDialogAction`, etc.
bestPractices: Always nest AlertDialogTrigger directly within the AlertDialog component to ensure proper context and state management.
Provide clear and concise text for the trigger element itself, indicating what action it will initiate (e.g., 'Delete Account', 'Confirm Order').
For accessibility, ensure the triggered AlertDialog content provides sufficient context and instructions for the user.
antiPatterns: Using AlertDialogTrigger without wrapping it inside an AlertDialog component, which will lead to a non-functional dialog and accessibility issues.
Placing multiple AlertDialogTrigger components directly within the same AlertDialog context that control unrelated dialogs; each AlertDialog should typically have its own trigger.

semanticData.summary: Provides a React Portal for AlertDialog components, ensuring their content renders outside the normal DOM hierarchy to prevent clipping and manage layering.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialogPortal component acts as a React Portal for the AlertDialog content, effectively rendering the dialog's overlay and content directly into the document body or another specified container. This is crucial for managing z-indexing, preventing the dialog from being clipped by parent elements with overflow: hidden, and ensuring it appears above all other page content. It's an internal building block of the AlertDialog system, primarily used by AlertDialogContent to ensure proper display and accessibility.

commonUseCases: Internally facilitating the correct rendering of AlertDialogContent and AlertDialogOverlay.
Ensuring AlertDialog components are not clipped by parent overflow styles.
Centralizing the dialog's position in the DOM for proper z-indexing and global event handling.

examples.code:
import { AlertDialog, AlertDialogTrigger, AlertDialogContent, AlertDialogHeader, AlertDialogTitle, AlertDialogDescription, AlertDialogFooter, AlertDialogAction, AlertDialogCancel } from "./alert-dialog";

function MyComponent() {
  return (
    <AlertDialog>
      <AlertDialogTrigger asChild>
        <button>Open Dialog</button>
      </AlertDialogTrigger>
      <AlertDialogContent>
        {/* AlertDialogPortal is implicitly used here by AlertDialogContent */}
        <AlertDialogHeader>
          <AlertDialogTitle>Are you absolutely sure?</AlertDialogTitle>
          <AlertDialogDescription>
            This action cannot be undone. This will permanently delete your
            account and remove your data from our servers.
          </AlertDialogDescription>
        </AlertDialogHeader>
        <AlertDialogFooter>
          <AlertDialogCancel>Cancel</AlertDialogCancel>
          <AlertDialogAction>Continue</AlertDialogAction>
        </AlertDialogFooter>
      </AlertDialogContent>
    </AlertDialog>
  );
}
examples.description: This example shows the typical usage of the AlertDialog component, where AlertDialogPortal is implicitly utilized by AlertDialogContent. Developers usually do not interact directly with AlertDialogPortal, as its role is to manage the rendering location of the dialog's content and overlay to ensure proper display and z-indexing, abstracted away by AlertDialogContent.

limitations: Not intended for direct consumption or customization by application developers; its functionality is primarily internal to the AlertDialog composition.
Does not expose the 'container' prop of the underlying Radix Portal, limiting custom placement of the portal root.
bestPractices: Allow the higher-level AlertDialogContent component to implicitly use AlertDialogPortal as intended.
Understand that AlertDialogPortal is a foundational component for correct layering and accessibility, rather than a directly configurable UI element.
antiPatterns: Attempting to render AlertDialogPortal directly as a standalone component without its corresponding AlertDialogContent or AlertDialogOverlay children, as it's a structural element for the dialog.
Applying significant visual styling directly to AlertDialogPortal, as it's meant to be an invisible DOM positioning helper.

semanticData.summary: Renders a modal overlay for AlertDialogs, dimming background content to focus user attention.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialogOverlay component renders a semi-transparent, full-screen overlay that appears behind an AlertDialog. Its purpose is to dim the background content, visually signaling to the user that the dialog is modal and requires interaction before proceeding. This helps focus user attention on the alert dialog, enhancing accessibility and user experience.

commonUseCases: Creating a modal alert dialog that blocks interaction with the background content.
Providing a clear visual indication that a critical user action or decision is required within an AlertDialog.

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of the AlertDialog component. The AlertDialogOverlay is a sub-component managed internally by `AlertDialogContent` and `AlertDialogPortal`. Developers should not typically render `AlertDialogOverlay` directly but rely on its automatic inclusion when using `AlertDialogContent`.

limitations: This component is tightly coupled with Radix UI's AlertDialog primitives; it is not designed for standalone use outside of this specific AlertDialog composition.
Its visual behavior and accessibility features depend on being rendered within an `AlertDialogPortal` and `AlertDialogContent`.
Custom animations beyond the built-in fade-in/fade-out require overriding the default `className` with custom CSS or animation frameworks.
bestPractices: Always use AlertDialogOverlay as part of a complete AlertDialog composition (it's implicitly rendered by AlertDialogContent in this library's structure) to ensure proper modal behavior and accessibility.
Utilize the `className` prop for custom styling via Tailwind CSS classes if the default overlay appearance needs modification (e.g., changing opacity or color).
Ensure that the z-index of other page elements does not conflict with the z-index (z-50) of the overlay to maintain correct visual layering.
antiPatterns: Manually rendering AlertDialogOverlay outside of AlertDialogContent: This component is intrinsically managed by AlertDialogContent via AlertDialogPortal; explicit direct usage in most application code is not necessary and may lead to unexpected behavior or redundant overlays.

Attempting to manually control its visibility or state: Its display is automatically tied to the parent AlertDialog's open/closed state, so manual manipulation is redundant and can interfere with the component's lifecycle.

semanticData.summary: Renders the styled content container for an alert dialog, including portal and overlay management.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialogContent component renders the main content area of an alert dialog. It wraps the Radix UI `AlertDialogPrimitive.Content` and applies a consistent set of styles for positioning (fixed, centered), animation (fade and zoom), and responsiveness. This component automatically includes `AlertDialogPortal` and `AlertDialogOverlay` to ensure the dialog appears above other content and has a dismissible background, solving the problem of overlay management and styling for modal dialogs.

commonUseCases: Displaying critical user messages that require immediate attention or confirmation
Presenting forms or information that temporarily block user interaction
Implementing modal warning or error dialogs
Collecting user input in a focused, isolated context

examples.code:
import { AlertDialog, AlertDialogAction, AlertDialogCancel, AlertDialogContent, AlertDialogDescription, AlertDialogFooter, AlertDialogHeader, AlertDialogTitle, AlertDialogTrigger } from "./components/ui/alert-dialog";

function DeleteAccountDialog() {
  return (
    <AlertDialog>
      <AlertDialogTrigger asChild>
        <button>Delete Account</button>
      </AlertDialogTrigger>
      <AlertDialogContent>
        <AlertDialogHeader>
          <AlertDialogTitle>Are you absolutely sure?</AlertDialogTitle>
          <AlertDialogDescription>
            This action cannot be undone. This will permanently delete your account
            and remove your data from our servers.
          </AlertDialogDescription>
        </AlertDialogHeader>
        <AlertDialogFooter>
          <AlertDialogCancel>Cancel</AlertDialogCancel>
          <AlertDialogAction>Continue</AlertDialogAction>
        </AlertDialogFooter>
      </AlertDialogContent>
    </AlertDialog>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `AlertDialogContent` to structure a confirmation dialog. It includes a header, title, description, and footer with action and cancel buttons, providing a complete and accessible user experience for a destructive action.

limitations: Requires the `AlertDialog` context from Radix UI; it cannot be used standalone as a generic modal.
The styling applied is opinionated and based on the project's design system; extensive customization requires overriding default classes.
Automatically renders an overlay and uses a portal, so these elements cannot be individually disabled or configured via direct props on `AlertDialogContent`.
bestPractices: Always use AlertDialogContent as a child of the AlertDialog component.
Nest AlertDialogHeader, AlertDialogTitle, AlertDialogDescription, and AlertDialogFooter components within AlertDialogContent for structured and accessible dialog content.
Keep dialog content concise and focused on the primary action or information to avoid overwhelming users.
Ensure that the primary action within the dialog (e.g., 'Confirm', 'Delete') is clearly distinguishable and aligns with the dialog's purpose.
antiPatterns: Using AlertDialogContent for non-critical notifications that don't block user interaction, which could be handled by a Toast or Popover.
Placing non-dialog-specific interactive elements (e.g., global navigation) directly within the content, violating the dialog's modal nature.
Neglecting to provide a clear title and description, hindering accessibility and user understanding.

semanticData.summary: A React component that acts as a styled header container for an alert dialog, typically housing the title and description.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialogHeader component serves as a styled container for the title and description within an alert dialog. It provides consistent spacing and alignment for these critical elements, ensuring the dialog's header area is clearly defined and visually appealing. This helps organize the dialog's content, making it easier for users to comprehend the purpose and impact of the alert.

commonUseCases: Structuring the top section of an alert or confirmation dialog
Grouping the title and description within an AlertDialogContent
Applying consistent styling to the header area of a dialog

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use AlertDialogHeader to group the title and description within a confirmation dialog, providing a clear and semantically correct header section.

limitations: AlertDialogHeader is a simple `div` wrapper and does not provide any interactive functionality itself.
It is primarily for structural and styling purposes; complex content should generally reside outside of it in the main AlertDialogContent or other designated areas.
bestPractices: Always include AlertDialogTitle and AlertDialogDescription within AlertDialogHeader for proper semantic structure and styling.
Utilize the `className` prop to extend or override default header styles using Tailwind CSS or other CSS classes.
antiPatterns: Placing interactive elements (like buttons or inputs) directly inside AlertDialogHeader, as it's meant for static content like title/description.
Using AlertDialogHeader outside of an AlertDialogContent, as it's a structural part of the dialog's composition.

semanticData.summary: A UI component that styles and lays out content within the footer section of an alert dialog, typically for action buttons.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialogFooter component serves as a styled container for the action buttons or supplementary content at the bottom of an alert dialog. It automatically applies responsive flexbox styling, arranging elements vertically in reverse order on small screens and horizontally aligned to the end on larger screens. This ensures a consistent and user-friendly layout for interactive elements within the dialog's footer.

commonUseCases: Arranging 'Confirm' and 'Cancel' buttons within an alert dialog
Providing a consistent layout for interactive elements at the bottom of a dialog
Ensuring responsive button placement in dialogs

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of AlertDialogFooter to contain both a 'Cancel' and 'Continue' button within a standard alert dialog. The footer component handles their responsive layout.

limitations: The component primarily provides layout and styling; it does not add any interactive logic or state management for the buttons it contains.
It assumes a flexbox layout and might not be suitable for highly custom, non-flex-based footer arrangements without overriding its default styles.
bestPractices: Always wrap AlertDialogAction and AlertDialogCancel components (or other button-like elements) inside AlertDialogFooter for proper alignment and spacing.
Utilize the `className` prop to extend or override default styling when specific visual adjustments are needed for the footer itself.
antiPatterns: Placing non-actionable content directly inside the footer without proper semantic wrapping, as it's primarily designed for buttons or related controls.
Using it outside of an AlertDialogContent, as its styling is specifically tailored for that context.

semanticData.summary: Renders the styled title element for an alert dialog, based on Radix UI's primitive.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialogTitle component provides a semantically appropriate and styled heading for alert dialogs within your application. It acts as a wrapper around the Radix UI `AlertDialogPrimitive.Title`, applying default styling for consistency and ensuring accessibility. This component helps developers quickly define clear, prominent titles for various dialog types, ensuring users understand the immediate context or action required.

commonUseCases: Setting the primary heading for a user confirmation dialog
Defining the title for a modal displaying critical system information
Providing a concise summary for an action prompt requiring user input

examples.code:
import { AlertDialog, AlertDialogAction, AlertDialogCancel, AlertDialogContent, AlertDialogDescription, AlertDialogFooter, AlertDialogHeader, AlertDialogTitle, AlertDialogTrigger } from "./alert-dialog";

function DeleteConfirmationDialog() {
  return (
    <AlertDialog>
      <AlertDialogTrigger asChild>
        <button>Delete Account</button>
      </AlertDialogTrigger>
      <AlertDialogContent>
        <AlertDialogHeader>
          <AlertDialogTitle>Are you absolutely sure?</AlertDialogTitle>
          <AlertDialogDescription>
            This action cannot be undone. This will permanently delete your account
            and remove your data from our servers.
          </AlertDialogDescription>
        </AlertDialogHeader>
        <AlertDialogFooter>
          <AlertDialogCancel>Cancel</AlertDialogCancel>
          <AlertDialogAction>Continue</AlertDialogAction>
        </AlertDialogFooter>
      </AlertDialogContent>
    </AlertDialog>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates using AlertDialogTitle within a complete alert dialog component. It shows how the title clearly asks a confirmation question, setting the context for the user before displaying the detailed description and action buttons.

limitations: AlertDialogTitle is a presentational component and does not handle any interactive logic or state management itself.
Its core accessibility features are inherited from the Radix UI primitive, requiring proper integration within the overall AlertDialog structure to be effective.
It is designed for use within the AlertDialog system and is not intended for standalone use as a general-purpose heading.
bestPractices: Always include AlertDialogTitle within AlertDialogHeader for proper structural hierarchy and accessibility.
Keep the title concise and highly descriptive, clearly indicating the dialog's main purpose or question.
Combine with AlertDialogDescription to provide detailed context, ensuring accessibility for screen readers and clarity for all users.
antiPatterns: Using AlertDialogTitle outside of an AlertDialogHeader or AlertDialogContent, as it loses its semantic and visual context.
Placing lengthy or overly verbose content in the title; titles should be concise and to the point.
Skipping AlertDialogDescription when the title alone is insufficient to convey the dialog's full purpose or implications.

semanticData.summary: Renders the accessible description text within an AlertDialog, applying default styling for clarity.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialogDescription component is a styled wrapper for the Radix UI AlertDialog.Description primitive, designed to provide a clear, secondary message within an alert dialog. It automatically applies consistent styling for text appropriate for a description, ensuring visual hierarchy and enhancing accessibility by associating explanatory text with the alert. Developers should use this component to give users additional context or details about the action or information presented in the alert dialog.

commonUseCases: Providing detailed context for a destructive action confirmation.
Explaining the implications of a user's choice in a modal.
Adding a subtitle or explanatory text to an alert or prompt.

examples.description: This example demonstrates using AlertDialogDescription to provide crucial additional context for a 'Delete Account' confirmation dialog. It informs the user about the irreversible nature and consequences of the action, helping them make an informed decision.

limitations: This component is purely presentational and does not manage state or logic; it simply renders text within the AlertDialog structure.
Its styling is opinionated, inheriting from Radix UI and extended with Tailwind CSS via 'cn' utility; custom styles should be passed via the `className` prop.
bestPractices: Keep the description brief and to the point, complementing the title without being redundant.
Ensure the description clearly explains the consequence or details of the alert to aid user decision-making.
Always include an AlertDialogDescription when the AlertDialogTitle alone might not provide enough context, especially for actions with significant impact.
antiPatterns: Using AlertDialogDescription for the main action or critical information; use AlertDialogTitle for the primary heading.
Placing long, paragraph-like content in the description; keep it concise and to the point to avoid overwhelming users.
Using it outside of an AlertDialogContent component, as it relies on the parent's context and styling for proper display.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled action button for an AlertDialog that performs the primary confirmation or affirmative action.
semanticData.description: This component serves as the primary action button within an AlertDialog, wrapping the `Radix UI AlertDialog.Action` primitive. It automatically applies base button styling using `buttonVariants` for a consistent look and feel within the application. Developers should use this component to represent the main affirmative action a user can take, such as confirming a decision or proceeding with a destructive operation, ensuring proper accessibility and visual consistency.

commonUseCases: Confirming a user's decision in an alert dialog (e.g., 'Save', 'Submit')
Initiating a destructive action (e.g., 'Delete', 'Remove')
Proceeding to the next step in a multi-stage process presented in a dialog

examples.description: This example demonstrates using `AlertDialogAction` as the primary 'Continue' button for a user account deletion confirmation dialog. When clicked, it triggers the `handleDelete` function, which would typically contain the logic for performing the deletion. The action button is placed within the `AlertDialogFooter` for correct positioning and interaction.

limitations: The default styling of `AlertDialogAction` is determined by the `buttonVariants` utility; significant deviations from standard button styles may require custom styling via `className` or direct use of the Radix primitive.
This component is tightly coupled with the Radix UI AlertDialog system and is not intended for standalone use outside of an AlertDialog context.
bestPractices: Always place AlertDialogAction within AlertDialogFooter, typically alongside AlertDialogCancel, to ensure proper layout and accessible keyboard navigation.
Provide clear and concise text for the action button that accurately describes the outcome of clicking it (e.g., 'Confirm Deletion', 'Proceed to Checkout').

For destructive actions, consider applying a specific destructive variant to the button if your `buttonVariants` utility supports it (e.g., `className={cn(buttonVariants({ variant: 'destructive' }), className)}`).
antiPatterns: Using AlertDialogAction for dismissive or secondary actions; AlertDialogCancel should be used instead for 'Cancel' or 'Close' buttons.
Placing AlertDialogAction outside of AlertDialogFooter, which can lead to incorrect layout and accessibility issues.
Overriding core styling in a way that breaks consistency with other buttons, unless absolutely necessary and justified.

semanticData.summary: Renders a pre-styled cancel button for dismissing an AlertDialog, leveraging Radix UI primitives.
semanticData.description: The AlertDialogCancel component provides a styled button specifically designed to dismiss an alert dialog. It wraps the Radix UI `AlertDialogPrimitive.Cancel` component, inheriting its accessibility and behavior, while applying a default `outline` button style. This component ensures a consistent visual and interactive experience for cancel actions within a user interface's alert dialog system, clearly indicating a non-committing or dismissive action.

commonUseCases: Providing a 'Cancel' option in a confirmation dialog (e.g., 'Are you sure you want to delete this?')
Offering a dismissive action in an informational alert that requires user acknowledgment but no 'action'
Allowing users to close an alert dialog without proceeding with a potentially destructive action

examples.code:
import { AlertDialog, AlertDialogAction, AlertDialogCancel, AlertDialogContent, AlertDialogDescription, AlertDialogFooter, AlertDialogHeader, AlertDialogTitle, AlertDialogTrigger } from "./alert-dialog";

function DeleteConfirmationDialog() {
  return (
    <AlertDialog>
      <AlertDialogTrigger>Open Dialog</AlertDialogTrigger>
      <AlertDialogContent>
        <AlertDialogHeader>
          <AlertDialogTitle>Are you absolutely sure?</AlertDialogTitle>
          <AlertDialogDescription>
            This action cannot be undone. This will permanently delete your
            account and remove your data from our servers.
          </AlertDialogDescription>
        </AlertDialogHeader>
        <AlertDialogFooter>
          <AlertDialogCancel>Cancel</AlertDialogCancel>
          <AlertDialogAction>Continue</AlertDialogAction>
        </AlertDialogFooter>
      </AlertDialogContent>
    </AlertDialog>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates a typical use case where AlertDialogCancel is used alongside AlertDialogAction within an AlertDialog.Footer. It provides users with a clear 'Cancel' option to dismiss the destructive confirmation dialog, preventing the 'Continue' action.

limitations: AlertDialogCancel must be rendered as a direct child of an AlertDialog.Content or within a component that is a child of AlertDialog.Content (e.g., AlertDialog.Footer) to function correctly with the Radix UI dialog system.
Its primary purpose is to close the dialog; it is not intended for initiating other non-dialog-closing actions.
bestPractices: Always place AlertDialogCancel within an AlertDialog.Footer to maintain standard UI patterns for dialog buttons.
For dialogs with both a primary action and a cancel option, pair AlertDialogCancel with AlertDialogAction.
Use clear, concise text for the cancel button (e.g., 'Cancel', 'No', 'Dismiss') to ensure its purpose is immediately understood.
Consider the order of buttons in the footer (e.g., 'Cancel' on the left, primary action on the right for most Western UIs).
antiPatterns: Using AlertDialogCancel outside of an AlertDialog.Content or AlertDialog.Footer, as it relies on the dialog's context for proper functionality.
Attempting to use AlertDialogCancel for an action that should *not* dismiss the dialog; it is exclusively for closing the dialog without committing an action.
Customizing its appearance so heavily that it no longer visually signals a 'cancel' or dismissive action, confusing users.

semanticData.summary: Provides the semantic navigation container for a set of pagination UI components.
semanticData.description: The Pagination component serves as the semantic 'nav' container for a set of pagination controls. It provides the foundational structure and common styling for a pagination interface, ensuring proper accessibility attributes for navigation. This component acts as a wrapper for its associated sub-components (like PaginationContent, PaginationLink, PaginationPrevious, PaginationNext, and PaginationEllipsis), which handle the individual pagination elements.

commonUseCases: Displaying page navigation for data tables
Implementing pagination for search results pages
Navigating through blog posts or articles
Building a paginated list of items

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to compose a full pagination component using 'Pagination' as the root. It includes 'PaginationPrevious', 'PaginationLink' for page numbers, and 'PaginationNext'. It also shows how to manage active state and handle page changes externally, which is typical for a paginated UI.

limitations: This component is purely presentational; it does not handle any pagination logic (e.g., current page, total pages, page range calculation, API calls). Consumers must provide this logic externally.
Relies on the consumer to manage and pass active page state and event handlers for navigation.

Requires the use of its companion components ('PaginationContent', 'PaginationLink', 'PaginationPrevious', 'PaginationNext', 'PaginationEllipsis') to build a complete and functional pagination interface.
bestPractices: Always use 'Pagination' as the root element for your pagination UI, providing a consistent and accessible structure
Combine with 'PaginationContent', 'PaginationLink', 'PaginationPrevious', 'PaginationNext', and 'PaginationEllipsis' for a complete and accessible pagination solution
Ensure that the 'aria-label' attribute on the 'Pagination' component is meaningful for screen readers, describing the purpose of the navigation
Implement the actual pagination logic (e.g., calculating page ranges, handling 'onClick' for page changes, managing current page state) outside of these purely presentational components
antiPatterns: Using 'Pagination' without its intended sub-components, leading to an incomplete or unstyled UI
Attempting to embed complex page number calculation or data fetching logic directly within these presentational components instead of managing state externally
Neglecting to pass 'aria-label' or other accessibility attributes to the 'nav' element, reducing usability for assistive technologies

semanticData.summary: Renders an unordered list (ul) to act as the primary container for individual pagination items within a pagination component.
semanticData.description: This component serves as the ul element within the Pagination navigation, designed to group and lay out the various pagination controls such as page numbers, "previous", "next", and ellipsis indicators. It centralizes styling for the content block, applying flexbox properties to arrange its child PaginationItem components in a row with consistent spacing. Developers use it to structure the visual representation of page navigation.

commonUseCases: Structuring the clickable page numbers and navigation links for a data table
Organizing pagination controls for blog posts or article listings
Displaying page navigation for search results

examples.code:
import { Pagination, PaginationContent, PaginationEllipsis, PaginationItem, PaginationLink, PaginationNext, PaginationPrevious } from "./pagination";

function MyPaginatedComponent() {
  return (
    <Pagination>
      <PaginationContent>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationPrevious href="#" />
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationLink href="#">1</PaginationLink>
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationLink href="#" isActive>
            2
          </PaginationLink>
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationLink href="#">3</PaginationLink>
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationEllipsis />
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationLink href="#">10</PaginationLink>
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationNext href="#" />
        </PaginationItem>
      </PaginationContent>
    </Pagination>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how PaginationContent is used as the central wrapper for all individual pagination elements, ensuring they are laid out correctly within the overall Pagination component. It shows a typical structure including previous/next buttons, page links, and an ellipsis.

limitations: Does not manage pagination state or logic: PaginationContent is purely a presentational component and does not handle current page, total pages, or fetching data.
Relies on other Pagination* components for full functionality: Its effectiveness depends on being populated with PaginationItem and related sub-components.
bestPractices: Always use PaginationContent as a direct child of the Pagination component to ensure correct ARIA roles and accessibility.
Nest PaginationItem, PaginationLink, PaginationPrevious, PaginationNext, and PaginationEllipsis components directly within PaginationContent to maintain the intended structure.
Utilize the className prop to apply custom styling or adjust spacing without losing the base layout.
antiPatterns: Using PaginationContent for arbitrary lists: It's specifically designed for pagination items; using it for unrelated li elements might lead to semantic confusion or unexpected styling.

Placing non-pagination components directly inside PaginationContent without PaginationItem: Always wrap individual pagination elements (like PaginationLink) with PaginationItem for proper semantic structure and styling.

semanticData.summary: Renders a list item (<li>) component specifically for use within a pagination content list.
semanticData.description: The "PaginationItem" component serves as a fundamental building block for the "PaginationContent" list. It is a simple wrapper around a standard HTML "<li>" element, designed to correctly structure individual pagination elements like page numbers, 'previous', 'next', or ellipsis. This component ensures proper semantic HTML for accessibility and consistent styling within the pagination system.

commonUseCases: Wrapping individual page links or control buttons within a pagination list
Structuring 'previous', 'next', or ellipsis elements in a pagination UI

examples.code:
import { Pagination, PaginationContent, PaginationItem, PaginationLink, PaginationEllipsis, PaginationPrevious, PaginationNext } from './pagination';

function MyPaginationBlock() {
  return (
    <Pagination>
      <PaginationContent>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationPrevious href="#" />
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationLink href="#" isActive>1</PaginationLink>
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationLink href="#">2</PaginationLink>
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationEllipsis />
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationLink href="#">10</PaginationLink>
        </PaginationItem>
        <PaginationItem>
          <PaginationNext href="#" />
        </PaginationItem>
      </PaginationContent>
    </Pagination>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how PaginationItem is used to wrap individual pagination links and control elements (previous, next, ellipsis) within a PaginationContent block, forming a complete pagination sequence. Each interactive element or placeholder occupies its own PaginationItem.

limitations: It's a purely structural component and does not provide any interactive logic or complex styling on its own beyond accepting standard li props.
Relies on its parent PaginationContent and sibling components (PaginationLink, etc.) for full functionality and visual presentation.
bestPractices: Always use PaginationItem as a direct child of PaginationContent to maintain correct HTML structure and styling.
Nest PaginationLink, PaginationPrevious, PaginationNext, or PaginationEllipsis components directly within PaginationItem.
antiPatterns: Using PaginationItem outside of PaginationContent: It's designed to be a child of PaginationContent for proper structure and styling.
Placing non-pagination related content directly inside PaginationItem: It should only contain pagination controls like PaginationLink or PaginationEllipsis.

codeMetadata.name: PaginationLinkProps
codeMetadata.typeSignature: type = { isActive?: boolean } & Pick<React.ComponentProps<typeof Button>, "size"> & React.ComponentProps<"a">

semanticData.summary: Defines props for a pagination link, combining standard HTML anchor attributes with `isActive` status and inherited button size properties.
semanticData.description: PaginationLinkProps is a type definition that specifies the properties accepted by a single pagination link component. It combines standard HTML <a> element attributes, allowing full control over link behavior (like `href` and `onClick`), with an `isActive` boolean prop to visually denote the current page. Additionally, it incorporates the `size` prop from a `Button` component, enabling consistent sizing for pagination items, ensuring flexibility while maintaining a unified UI/UX.

commonUseCases: Rendering individual page numbers within a pagination control
Creating 'Next' and 'Previous' navigation buttons for pagination
Highlighting the currently active page in a series of pagination links
Customizing the visual size of pagination links to match design requirements

examples.code:
<PaginationLink href="/products?page=1" isActive>1</PaginationLink>
<PaginationLink href="/products?page=2">2</PaginationLink>
<PaginationLink href="/products?page=3">3</PaginationLink>
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to render a series of page links, with the first page marked as active using the `isActive` prop. Other links are rendered without the active state.

examples.code:
<PaginationLink href="/previous-page" size="default">
  Previous
</PaginationLink>
<PaginationLink href="/next-page" size="default">
  Next
</PaginationLink>
examples.description: Shows how to create 'Previous' and 'Next' navigation links using PaginationLink, specifying a consistent `default` size and appropriate `href` values for navigation.

examples.code: <PaginationLink href="/admin/dashboard" size="lg">Dashboard</PaginationLink>
examples.description: Illustrates how to customize the visual size of a pagination link by leveraging the inherited `size` prop from the underlying Button component, making it visually larger.

limitations: This type primarily defines props for a presentational component; it does not directly handle routing logic (e.g., client-side navigation with React Router, Next.js). It expects `href` for standard browser navigation.
The `size` prop is limited to the predefined sizes available in the underlying `Button` component, offering a constrained set of visual dimensions.

Relies on the `buttonVariants` for styling the active/inactive states; highly custom visual states beyond `outline` and `ghost` for active/inactive may require additional `className` overrides or custom styling.
bestPractices: Always provide a valid `href` for PaginationLink components that are meant to navigate, ensuring accessibility and correct browser behavior.
Utilize the `isActive` prop to visually distinguish the current page, enhancing user experience and clarity.
Prefer using the `size` prop for consistent sizing across pagination links, rather than overriding dimensions via `className` if the desired size aligns with available button sizes.

When integrating with client-side routing libraries (e.g., React Router), adapt PaginationLink to pass props correctly (e.g., by using an `asChild` pattern or custom rendering) to ensure proper navigation.
antiPatterns: Using PaginationLink for non-navigation purposes (e.g., as a generic button) when a standard <a> or Button component would be more semantically appropriate.
Hardcoding styles to mimic active/inactive states instead of leveraging the `isActive` prop and the integrated `buttonVariants` for consistent styling.
Omitting the `href` prop when the link is intended for navigation, leading to inaccessible or non-functional links.

semanticData.summary: Renders an individual pagination link, styled like a button, with an optional active state for the current page.
semanticData.description: The PaginationLink component renders an interactive link for pagination controls, styled to resemble a button. It conditionally applies an 'outline' style when the 'isActive' prop is true, effectively highlighting the current page, while using a 'ghost' style otherwise. This component standardizes the appearance and behavior of individual page number links, contributing to a consistent user experience within any pagination UI.

commonUseCases: Displaying individual page numbers within a pagination sequence
Highlighting the current active page in a pagination UI
Creating clickable navigation elements for 'previous' or 'next' pages

examples.code:
<PaginationItem>
  <PaginationLink href="/products?page=1" isActive>1</PaginationLink>
</PaginationItem>
<PaginationItem>
  <PaginationLink href="/products?page=2">2</PaginationLink>
</PaginationItem>
<PaginationItem>
  <PaginationLink href="/products?page=3">3</PaginationLink>
</PaginationItem>
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to render a series of page number links. Page '1' is marked as the currently active page using the 'isActive' prop, while '2' and '3' are regular, navigable links.

examples.code:
<PaginationItem>
  <PaginationLink
    href="/search?query=example&page=2"
    aria-label="Go to previous page"
  >
    Previous
  </PaginationLink>
</PaginationItem>
examples.description: Illustrates creating a 'Previous' pagination link. Although 'PaginationPrevious' is a dedicated component, this shows how PaginationLink can be directly used for similar purposes with custom content and an accessibility label.

limitations: This component is purely for presentation and does not implement any pagination logic (e.g., managing current page state, calculating total pages, or data fetching).
Its styling is inherently tied to the 'buttonVariants' utility, meaning its appearance is dictated by the project's design system for buttons.
The default 'size' prop is 'icon', which might require explicit override to 'default' or other sizes if full text buttons are desired.
bestPractices: Always provide a valid 'href' prop or an 'onClick' handler to ensure the link is navigable
Utilize the 'isActive' prop strictly to denote the currently viewed page for correct visual and accessibility cues
Nest PaginationLink components within PaginationItem to maintain semantic HTML structure for lists of pagination elements
Ensure text content or appropriate 'aria-label' is provided for accessibility, especially when using 'icon' size or custom content
antiPatterns: Using PaginationLink without providing an 'href' or 'onClick' handler, making it non-functional
Applying the 'isActive' prop for purposes other than marking the current page, as it impacts styling and accessibility
Placing PaginationLink directly without wrapping it in PaginationItem, which can lead to improper semantic structure for lists

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled and accessible link to navigate to the previous page in a pagination component.
semanticData.description: The PaginationPrevious component is a specialized PaginationLink designed to represent the 'previous page' button within a pagination control. It automatically includes a left arrow icon and a 'Previous' label, along with appropriate ARIA attributes for accessibility. This component streamlines the creation of a consistent and navigable previous page control within a pagination interface.

commonUseCases: Implementing standard page-by-page navigation in data lists or tables.
Providing a 'back' link for paginated search results or blog archives.
Creating a consistent navigation control for step-by-step forms or wizards.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to integrate PaginationPrevious into a complete pagination control. It shows how to conditionally provide a 'href' prop based on the 'currentPage' state, effectively disabling the 'Previous' button when on the first page, and how it fits alongside other pagination components like PaginationLink and PaginationNext.

limitations: Does not include pagination logic (e.g., fetching data, managing current page state); external state management is required to determine the previous page URL and disable the button when on the first page.
Relies on the 'href' prop (inherited from PaginationLink) to provide navigation functionality; it is primarily a visual and accessible element, not a functional router itself.
The 'Previous' text label is hidden on smaller screens by default, making the icon the primary visual cue. Customizing this visibility requires overriding the component's default CSS.
bestPractices: Dynamically disable the PaginationPrevious component (e.g., by omitting 'href' or conditionally rendering) when the user is on the first page to prevent invalid navigation.
Ensure the 'href' prop points to the correct previous page URL, typically calculated based on the current page state.
Integrate with client-side routing (e.g., React Router, Next.js Link) or server-side navigation to ensure the link performs the intended page transition.
antiPatterns: Rendering PaginationPrevious without a 'href' or 'onClick' prop, as it will appear but not function as a navigation link.
Failing to conditionally render or disable PaginationPrevious when the current page is the first, leading to a confusing or non-functional button.
Attempting to use PaginationPrevious as a generic 'back' button outside of a clear pagination context, as its styling and accessibility roles are specific.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled 'Next' button with an arrow icon for navigating to the subsequent page in a pagination component.
semanticData.description: The PaginationNext component renders a pre-styled link specifically designed for navigating to the subsequent page within a pagination control. It wraps the core PaginationLink component, adding a right arrow icon and 'Next' text, along with appropriate ARIA attributes for accessibility. This component simplifies the creation of a standard 'next page' button in pagination UIs.

commonUseCases: Displaying a 'Next' button for paginated data lists, such as search results or product catalogs
Implementing navigation controls for multi-page forms or wizards
Providing clear navigation in blog archives or article lists

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to integrate PaginationNext within a complete pagination component. It shows conditional rendering of the 'Next' button based on whether there's a subsequent page, and how to pass the `href` for navigation.

limitations: This component is purely presentational; it does not manage pagination state (e.g., current page, total pages) or handle navigation logic itself.
Requires external state management to determine if a next page exists and to construct the appropriate `href` or `onClick` handler.
Relies on the `PaginationLink` component for its core functionality and styling.
bestPractices: Always wrap PaginationNext within a PaginationContent component, which itself should be inside a Pagination component for proper structure and accessibility.
Ensure the `href` prop points to the correct URL for the next page, or provide an `onClick` handler that updates the application's page state.
Combine with PaginationPrevious and numbered PaginationLink components to create a complete and intuitive pagination interface.
Dynamically disable or hide the PaginationNext button when on the last page to prevent invalid navigation.
antiPatterns: Using PaginationNext outside of a PaginationContent wrapper, as it's designed to be a child of an unordered list of pagination items.
Not providing a valid `href` or `onClick` handler, making the 'Next' button non-functional.
Manually applying `gap-1` or `px-2.5` styles directly to PaginationLink when using PaginationNext, as these are already integrated.

semanticData.summary: Renders a visual ellipsis icon and screen-reader text to indicate skipped pages in a pagination component.
semanticData.description: The PaginationEllipsis component is a visual indicator used within a pagination series to signify that there are more pages available that are not currently displayed. It renders a horizontal ellipsis icon (`...`) and includes screen-reader-only text for accessibility. This component helps maintain a compact pagination display while still informing users that page numbers have been skipped, improving UX for navigations with many pages.

commonUseCases: Displaying a break in a long list of page numbers within a pagination control
Indicating omitted intermediate pages to keep the pagination UI concise

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use PaginationEllipsis to indicate skipped pages in a pagination control. It's conditionally rendered based on the current page and total pages, showing ellipses when there are non-adjacent page numbers. The ellipsis itself is wrapped in a `PaginationItem`.

limitations: This component is purely presentational and does not offer any interactive functionality (e.g., clicking to reveal hidden pages).
It should only be used as part of a larger pagination component structure and is not intended for standalone use.

The `aria-hidden` attribute on the main span means the ellipsis icon itself is hidden from assistive technologies, relying on the `sr-only` text and the overall `aria-label` of the pagination component for context.
bestPractices: Integrate PaginationEllipsis within a dynamic pagination logic that calculates when to show ellipses based on the total number of pages and the current page.
Ensure proper placement within `PaginationContent` as a `PaginationItem` sibling to `PaginationLink` components for correct structure and styling.
Combine with `aria-label` attributes on the parent `Pagination` component for a comprehensive accessibility experience, especially when the ellipsis hides specific page numbers.
antiPatterns: Using PaginationEllipsis as an interactive element; it is purely presentational and not clickable.
Placing PaginationEllipsis outside of a PaginationContent component, as it expects to be part of a list of pagination items.

semanticData.summary: Creates the root container for a tabbed interface component, providing layout and base styling.
semanticData.description: The Tabs component serves as the foundational root for building accessible and styled tabbed navigation interfaces. It wraps Radix UI's TabsPrimitive.Root, applying default Tailwind CSS classes for vertical flex layout and spacing, while allowing full customization through additional props. It solves the problem of structuring and presenting content in distinct, navigable sections within an application, ensuring proper accessibility and visual consistency.

commonUseCases: Organizing application content into multiple, distinct sections (e.g., 'Settings', 'Profile', 'Notifications')
Creating in-page navigation that toggles between different sub-views or data displays
Building a multi-step form or wizard where each step is a clearly defined tab

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic structure of a tabbed interface. The Tabs component acts as the root, wrapping the TabsList for navigation and individual TabsContent components for the associated content. The 'defaultValue' prop sets the initially active tab.

limitations: The core functionality and accessibility are inherited from Radix UI's TabsPrimitive, so its limitations (e.g., controlled vs. uncontrolled component behavior) apply.
This component primarily styles the root container; it does not directly manage tab state or content display logic beyond what Radix UI provides.
Primarily for static tab content; dynamic addition or removal of tabs requires careful state management in the parent component.
bestPractices: Always use Tabs in conjunction with TabsList, TabsTrigger, and TabsContent for a complete, accessible, and functional tabbed interface.
Ensure each TabsTrigger has a corresponding TabsContent with the same 'value' prop to maintain correct content association.
Prefer declarative rendering of all TabsContent components, even if some are initially hidden, to leverage Radix UI's built-in accessibility and state management features.
antiPatterns: Using Tabs for simple toggle buttons or single content display when only one option is needed, as it's designed for multiple, mutually exclusive content panes.
Overloading a Tabs component with an excessive number of tabs, which can hurt usability and navigation clarity.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled container for tab triggers within a Radix UI-based Tabs component.
semanticData.description: The TabsList component serves as a container for individual TabsTrigger components, defining the visual bar where tab headers are displayed. It wraps the Radix UI TabsPrimitive.List, applying a default styled layout that groups the triggers horizontally. Developers use this to organize and present the selectable tabs within a larger Tabs component, ensuring consistent styling and accessibility.

commonUseCases: Creating a navigation bar for switching between different content sections
Building a settings panel with multiple categories
Implementing a multi-step form where each step is a tab

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of TabsList within a Tabs component, containing multiple TabsTrigger elements. It showcases how TabsList visually groups the individual tab buttons for a clean interface.

limitations: Primarily designed for use with Radix UI's Tabs components, relying on its internal state management and structure.
The default styling is opinionated (Tailwind CSS-based); significant visual changes may require overriding many default classes.
Does not manage tab state itself; it's a presentational component that receives props from the parent Tabs component.
bestPractices: Always wrap TabsList within a Tabs (or TabsPrimitive.Root) component to ensure proper functionality and context.
Only place TabsTrigger components as children of TabsList for correct visual and behavioral grouping.
Leverage the `className` prop for custom styling, applying Tailwind CSS classes or custom CSS to extend or override default appearances while maintaining the base layout.
Ensure the number of TabsTrigger children corresponds to the number of TabsContent children for a complete and functional tab interface.
antiPatterns: Using TabsList outside of a Tabs component: It relies on the context provided by TabsPrimitive.Root and will not function correctly or visually integrate.
Placing non-TabsTrigger elements directly inside TabsList: While technically possible, it breaks the intended component composition and can lead to unexpected styling or accessibility issues.
Overriding essential layout styles without careful consideration: Directly applying conflicting flexbox or sizing styles might break the intended horizontal layout and spacing of triggers.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled, interactive trigger button for selecting and displaying a specific tab's content.
semanticData.description: The TabsTrigger component renders a clickable element within a TabsList that, when activated, displays its associated tab content. It acts as a styled wrapper around Radix UI's TabsPrimitive.Trigger, applying a set of default Tailwind CSS classes for consistent appearance and behavior. Developers use this component to create the interactive buttons users click to navigate between different tab panels, providing a clear visual indication of the currently active tab.

commonUseCases: Creating interactive navigation buttons for a tabbed interface
Switching between different content sections within a single view
Implementing multi-step forms where each step is a tab
Organizing complex information into digestible, segmented views

examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic implementation of a tabbed interface for a user profile page. Three TabsTrigger components are used within a TabsList to allow users to switch between 'Account', 'Password', and 'Notifications' sections.

limitations: Requires being a child of a TabsList component, which itself must be a child of a Tabs Root component, to function correctly.
Primarily a styling wrapper; its core functionality (tab switching, accessibility) is provided by the underlying Radix UI primitive.
While it accepts standard HTML button attributes, overuse of non-Radix props might lead to unexpected behavior if they conflict with Radix's internal logic.
bestPractices: Always nest TabsTrigger inside a TabsList component to ensure correct functionality and accessibility hierarchy.
Provide meaningful text or icons within the TabsTrigger to clearly indicate the content of the associated tab.
Utilize the `value` prop to uniquely identify each trigger and link it to its corresponding TabsContent component.
Leverage the `disabled` prop when a tab should not be selectable, for example, based on user permissions or data availability.
antiPatterns: Using TabsTrigger outside of a TabsList component: This will break its functionality and accessibility features, as it relies on the Radix UI Tab components' context.
Attempting to use TabsTrigger for general-purpose buttons: While it looks like a button, its primary role is within the tab system; use a standard button for non-tab actions.
Overriding critical Radix UI data attributes (e.g., 'data-state'): This can interfere with the component's internal state management and accessibility.

semanticData.summary: Renders the content panel for a specific tab, inheriting accessibility and behavior from Radix UI's Tabs.Content.
semanticData.description: The TabsContent component serves as a styled wrapper around Radix UI's Tabs.Content primitive, designed to display the actual content associated with a selected tab trigger. It automatically applies base styling for content containers and allows for easy customization via the `className` prop. This component is crucial for structuring user interfaces where different sections of content need to be conditionally displayed based on tab selection, ensuring a clean and accessible tabbed navigation experience.

commonUseCases: Displaying different sections of content within a tabbed interface
Organizing complex forms or data into logical, switchable panels
Building multi-step wizards where each step is a tab content
Creating settings or profile pages with various configurable sections

examples.code:
import { Tabs, TabsList, TabsTrigger, TabsContent } from "./tabs"; function MyTabbedInterface() { return ( Account Password

Account Settings

Make changes to your account here.

Change your password

Update your password settings.

 ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use TabsContent to display distinct content panels for different tabs. Each TabsContent component's `value` prop corresponds to a TabsTrigger, ensuring that selecting a tab reveals its associated content. This is the fundamental pattern for building tabbed interfaces.

limitations: Relies on Radix UI's Tabs.Content component, inheriting its behavior and any underlying limitations.

By default, all TabsContent components are rendered in the DOM, with only the active one being visible. This means content for inactive tabs is present but hidden, which can be a performance consideration for very complex or numerous tabs.
Requires client-side rendering due to its dependency on React hooks and DOM manipulation.
bestPractices: Always ensure the `value` prop of TabsContent matches the `value` prop of its corresponding TabsTrigger for correct association.
Keep the content within each TabsContent focused and, for complex layouts, encapsulate it within separate sub-components for better maintainability.
Utilize the `className` prop for custom styling via Tailwind CSS classes or other CSS frameworks, leveraging the `cn` utility for conditional styling.
Consider lazy loading content within TabsContent if the content is very heavy and only needed when its tab is active, to improve performance.
antiPatterns: Using TabsContent outside of a Tabs component heirarchy, which will break functionality.
Forgetting to assign a unique `value` prop to each TabsContent that corresponds to a TabsTrigger, leading to incorrect content display.

Placing extremely performance-heavy components directly within every TabsContent without lazy loading, as all content is typically rendered in the DOM, potentially impacting initial page load or responsiveness.

semanticData.summary: Renders a foundational UI card component with predefined styling and prop-forwarding for a div element.
semanticData.description: The Card component serves as a foundational UI element, providing a styled container for grouping related content into a distinct block. It encapsulates common visual attributes like borders, background color, shadow, and spacing, ensuring a consistent card-like appearance across an application. This component solves the problem of repetitive styling for content sections, enabling developers to quickly build organized and visually appealing layouts.

commonUseCases: Displaying discrete pieces of information such as product details, user profiles, or dashboard widgets.
Creating consistent visual containers for forms or interactive elements.
Structuring content into visually distinct blocks on a page.

examples.description: Demonstrates the simplest way to use the Card component as a container for content, typically combined with CardContent.
Shows how to create a more structured card by combining Card with CardHeader and CardTitle, along with an example of applying custom width using the className prop.

limitations: Primarily designed for visual presentation; it does not inherently provide interactivity or state management.
Relies heavily on Tailwind CSS for its default styling, which means custom styling without Tailwind requires careful overriding of its predefined classes.
bestPractices: Combine Card with its companion components (CardHeader, CardTitle, CardContent, etc.) to build rich, structured cards.
Use the className prop for minor style adjustments or responsive variations, leveraging the default styles as a baseline.
Pass standard div attributes (e.g., onClick, id, aria-label) directly to the Card component.
antiPatterns: Overriding all default styles: If a component requires completely different styling, it's better to create a new component rather than fighting the Card's default aesthetics.
