Using Card for non-card-like elements: Avoid using it as a generic div if its visual semantics don't align with a card, as it adds unnecessary styling overhead.

semanticData.summary: Renders the header section of a Card component, designed to house titles, descriptions, and actions.
semanticData.description: CardHeader acts as a structural container for the top section of a Card, providing a pre-defined layout for elements like CardTitle, CardDescription, and CardAction. It handles spacing and alignment for these elements, ensuring a consistent visual presentation across various card types. This component is crucial for organizing the primary information and interactive elements at the beginning of a card.

commonUseCases: Structuring the top section of a display card with a title and an optional subtitle/description
Including an action button or icon alongside the main title of a card
Creating a consistent header layout for a series of cards in a dashboard or list

examples.description: This example demonstrates a typical usage of CardHeader within a Card, enclosing a CardTitle, CardDescription, and a CardAction that holds a Button. This setup provides a well-structured and visually organized header with both textual information and an interactive element.

limitations: Primarily a presentational component; does not contain any state or complex logic
Designed specifically for a card context; re-using it outside of a Card might lead to unexpected layouts or require significant overriding of styles
The internal layout (grid-based with specific slots for title, description, action) is opinionated and might not suit highly custom header structures without additional CSS
bestPractices: Always use CardHeader as a direct child of the Card component
For optimal layout and styling, place CardTitle, CardDescription, and CardAction directly within CardHeader
Leverage the className prop for minor custom styling, but generally rely on the component's default styling for consistency
antiPatterns: Placing CardHeader directly outside a Card component, as its styling and purpose are tied to the Card structure
Using CardHeader for complex, non-header-related content (e.g., long paragraphs, full forms) that should rather go into CardContent
Nesting multiple CardHeader components within a single Card

semanticData.summary: Renders a semantically appropriate and styled title for a Card component.
semanticData.description: The CardTitle component is a UI primitive designed to render the primary heading or title within a Card component. It provides consistent styling for card titles, ensuring visual hierarchy and readability within the card's context. Developers should use this to semantically mark and style the main title of a card, contributing to a cohesive and predictable user interface.

commonUseCases: Displaying the main heading of a dashboard widget card
Setting the title for an informational or status card
Providing a descriptive title for a product or service card in an e-commerce listing
Creating a title for a form or input section within a card

examples.description: This example demonstrates typical usage of CardTitle within a Card and CardHeader to define the primary heading of a financial details card. It shows how it integrates with other card sub-components.

limitations: CardTitle itself renders a div, so for true semantic heading structure (e.g., h1, h2), you might need to wrap its content or use a component that renders the appropriate heading tag.
It is primarily a presentational component; it does not add any interactive functionality.
bestPractices: Always nest CardTitle within a CardHeader component for proper layout and semantic structure.
Keep the title concise and descriptive to improve readability and user experience.
For accessibility, consider wrapping CardTitle in an appropriate heading tag (h1-h6) if the visual element serves as a page or section heading.
antiPatterns: Using CardTitle for general paragraph text or descriptions, which should use CardDescription or CardContent instead.
Overriding its base styling excessively, which can break the consistent look and feel of the card system.

semanticData.summary: Renders a muted, descriptive text element for a Card component.
semanticData.description: The CardDescription component is designed to render a secondary, muted text element within a Card, typically used to provide supplementary information or context to a CardTitle. It semantically styles a `div` element with a smaller font size and muted color, ensuring consistency across card UIs. This component helps structure card content by clearly separating primary titles from their accompanying descriptive text, enhancing readability and visual hierarchy.

commonUseCases: Providing a subtitle or contextual information below a card's main title
Adding brief explanatory text to an item in a list rendered within a card
Displaying metadata or additional details associated with a card's primary content

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use CardDescription to provide a brief subtitle for a card's main title, 'Project X'. It is nested within CardHeader alongside CardTitle to establish a clear content hierarchy.

limitations: CardDescription is primarily a presentational component and does not inherently provide interactivity.
Its styling is optimized for brief, secondary text; it may not be suitable for large blocks of text which could lead to poor readability.
Relies on the surrounding Card context for its intended visual appearance and semantic role.
bestPractices: Always use CardDescription in conjunction with CardTitle within a CardHeader for proper semantic and visual hierarchy.
Keep the text within CardDescription concise and to the point, typically a sentence or two.
Utilize the `className` prop to apply additional styling when necessary, ensuring it complements the existing card design.
antiPatterns: Using CardDescription for primary headings or titles; CardTitle should be used for this purpose.
Placing long paragraphs or complex content within CardDescription; it's intended for concise descriptions, with CardContent being more suitable for extensive text.
Using it as a standalone component outside of a Card structure, as its styling and purpose are tied to the Card ecosystem.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled container for an action element, typically positioned in the top-right corner of a CardHeader.
semanticData.description: The "CardAction" component provides a designated area within a "CardHeader" for interactive elements such as buttons, icons, or links. It applies specific styling to automatically position its content, usually in the top-right, aligning seamlessly with the card title and description. This helps maintain consistent layout for actionable items across different cards.

commonUseCases: Placing an "Edit" or "Delete" button in a card's header.
Adding an overflow menu (kebab icon) to a card title.
Including a "View Details" link next to a card's main title.
Displaying a status indicator or badge within the header.

examples.description: Demonstrates how to place a simple "Edit" button in the top-right corner of a card's header using "CardAction".
Illustrates using "CardAction" to house an icon (e.g., a "more options" icon) that acts as a trigger for a menu, positioned neatly in the header.

limitations: Primarily designed for visual placement within "CardHeader"'s grid layout; its utility is limited outside of this context.
Not intended for complex layouts or large interactive forms within the header due to its constrained positioning.
Relies on the "CardHeader"'s styling (e.g., "grid-cols-[1fr_auto]") to achieve its intended layout, which might not be obvious if "CardHeader" styles are overridden.
bestPractices: Nest small interactive elements (e.g., <Button>, <Link>, <DropdownMenuTrigger>) directly inside "CardAction".
Use it for actions that pertain to the entire card or its header content.
Keep the content within "CardAction" minimal and focused on a single action or a small group of related actions.
antiPatterns: Using "CardAction" outside of a "CardHeader" as it relies on parent styling for positioning.
Placing large blocks of content inside "CardAction"; it's intended for small, concise actions.
Applying conflicting positioning styles (e.g., "absolute") directly to "CardAction" as it might interfere with its intrinsic grid/flex alignment.

semanticData.summary: Renders a content area for a card component with default horizontal padding for its children.
semanticData.description: The CardContent component is a dedicated container designed to encapsulate the primary body content within a Card component. It automatically applies consistent horizontal padding to its children, ensuring a clean and structured layout. Developers use it to visually separate the main information of a card from other sections like headers, titles, or footers, promoting better readability and organization.

commonUseCases: Displaying the main textual content or detailed information within a UI card.
Wrapping interactive elements like forms, charts, or images inside a card's body.
Structuring a card's primary content area, distinct from its header or footer sections.

examples.description: This example demonstrates using CardContent to display multiple lines of profile information within a user profile card. It shows how the content is neatly padded horizontally and separated from the header and footer sections.

limitations: Primarily a presentational wrapper; it doesn't provide complex layout features beyond basic horizontal padding. Nested layouts may require additional divs or flex/grid containers.

Assumes standard div element behavior and accepts div-specific props. While flexible, it might not be suitable for semantic elements like <section> or <article> if strict HTML semantics are required without an additional wrapper.
bestPractices: Always nest CardContent directly within the Card component to ensure proper styling and hierarchy.
Use CardContent to house the core informational elements of the card, such as paragraphs, lists, forms, or embedded components.
Leverage the className prop to add custom styling that complements, rather than conflicts with, the component's default padding.
Keep the content within CardContent concise and focused to maintain card readability and responsiveness.
antiPatterns: Placing header-specific elements like titles or action buttons inside CardContent; these belong in CardHeader or CardAction/CardFooter.
Overriding the default horizontal padding (px-6) with conflicting inline styles or utility classes, leading to inconsistent UI.
Using CardContent as a standalone component outside of a parent Card, as its styling and purpose are context-dependent within the card structure.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled container for the footer section of a Card component, typically used for actions or supplementary information.
semanticData.description: The CardFooter component provides a dedicated structural area at the bottom of a Card component, designed to house supplementary information, action buttons, or navigation links. It automatically applies consistent styling, including padding and alignment, ensuring that content within a card's footer is visually distinct and well-organized. Developers should use this to create clear divisions within their UI cards, improving readability and user interaction by segregating primary content from associated actions or metadata.

commonUseCases: Placing action buttons (e.g., 'Save', 'Cancel', 'Close') at the bottom of a form or display card.
Displaying pagination controls for content contained within a card.
Including supplementary text like timestamps, authors, or short status messages related to the card's content.
Adding social share buttons or quick links relevant to the card's subject.

examples.description: This example demonstrates a typical use case where CardFooter holds two action buttons, 'Cancel' and 'Confirm', aligned to the end (right) of the footer. This is common for dialogs or forms.
This example shows CardFooter being used to display supplementary metadata, such as a publication date, at the bottom of an article card, providing context without cluttering the main content area.

limitations: CardFooter is primarily a presentation component and does not inherently provide any interactive behavior beyond rendering a div element.
Its styling is designed to work within the specific Card component system; using it outside of a Card might result in inconsistent appearance.
It does not enforce any specific content structure, leaving it up to the developer to ensure accessible and meaningful content is placed within it.
bestPractices: Always use CardFooter in conjunction with a parent Card component to ensure proper styling and hierarchy.
Keep the content within the footer concise and relevant to the card's main purpose.
Group related actions (e.g., two buttons for 'Confirm' and 'Cancel') together within the footer for better UX.
Consider using the .border-t selector if a top border is desired for visual separation from the CardContent.
antiPatterns: Using CardFooter to contain the primary content of the card; this should reside in CardContent.
Nesting a CardHeader or CardTitle directly inside CardFooter, as they serve different structural purposes.
Overloading the footer with too much text or too many unrelated actions, which can lead to visual clutter.

semanticData.summary: A customizable React UI slider component built on Radix UI primitives, styled with Tailwind CSS, supporting single or multi-thumb configurations.
semanticData.description: The Slider component is a highly customizable and accessible range input, wrapping the `radix-ui` `SliderPrimitive`. It provides a pre-styled UI element that allows users to select a single value or a range of values within a defined minimum and maximum. This component solves the problem of implementing interactive numerical input sliders with consistent styling and built-in accessibility, integrating seamlessly into applications using Tailwind CSS for styling.

commonUseCases: Allowing users to adjust a numerical setting like volume or brightness
Filtering data within a specific range, such as price or date
Selecting a single value from a continuous scale
Implementing interactive progress indicators that can also be manipulated

examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic controlled single-thumb slider used for a volume control. The `value` prop is bound to a state variable, and `onValueChange` updates the state, allowing the component to react to user input.

This example shows a controlled two-thumb slider for selecting a price range. By passing an array to the `value` prop, the Slider component automatically renders multiple thumbs, enabling range selection.

limitations: While it supports vertical orientation via Radix, default styling might require additional `className` adjustments for optimal visual appearance.

The current implementation renders generic circular thumbs. Customizing thumb content (e.g., adding text inside the thumb) would require modifying the component to pass custom children to `SliderPrimitive.Thumb`.
Requires `@repo/web/lib/utils` for the `cn` utility and `radix-ui` as peer dependencies, making it not entirely standalone.
bestPractices: Always define explicit 'min' and 'max' values relevant to your use case for clarity and correct behavior.
For dynamic or application-controlled sliders, use the 'value' prop along with an 'onValueChange' handler to manage its state in your component.
For simple, uncontrolled sliders that manage their own state, use the 'defaultValue' prop.
Leverage the 'className' prop for all custom styling via Tailwind CSS, ensuring consistent design and easy overrides.
Consider adding an 'aria-label' to the surrounding context if the slider's purpose isn't immediately clear from its visual placement.
antiPatterns: Mixing 'value' and 'defaultValue' props: This can lead to unpredictable behavior; choose one for controlled or uncontrolled usage.
Not providing 'min' or 'max' props when the default range (0-100) is not suitable, which might lead to an unhelpful or broken slider range.
Attempting to directly manipulate Radix's internal state outside the provided props: Stick to 'value' or 'defaultValue' for state management.
Overriding core Radix styles with '!important': Use the 'className' prop and Tailwind utilities for overrides to maintain readability and avoid specificity wars.

semanticData.summary: Provides the foundational root component for a Radix UI-based popover, serving as the container for its trigger and content.
semanticData.description: The Popover component serves as the foundational root wrapper for a floating UI element, displaying content on top of other page elements. It directly leverages Radix UI's `PopoverPrimitive.Root` to inherit robust accessibility features and sophisticated positioning logic. Developers utilize this component as the essential top-level container for creating diverse interactive overlays, such as contextual dropdowns, informational tooltips, or dynamic settings panels.

commonUseCases: Displaying custom dropdown menus from buttons or icons
Showing detailed information or controls on hover or click (e.g., tooltips, info bubbles)
Creating small, interactive settings panels that appear contextually
Implementing dynamic forms or filters that pop up without navigating away

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to set up a basic popover with a button trigger and a simple content panel. The `Popover` component acts as the parent, wrapping the `PopoverTrigger` (which uses `asChild` to render the `Button` directly) and the `PopoverContent`, which contains the menu items. This illustrates the fundamental structure for creating interactive popovers.

limitations: Requires `PopoverTrigger` and `PopoverContent` components (and optionally `PopoverAnchor`) from the same component family to function correctly, as they rely on the Popover's context.
While flexible, complex custom positioning scenarios might require a deeper understanding of Radix UI's `PopoverPrimitive` props and options.
The automatic positioning and collision detection work best when the popover content is not excessively large or unpredictable in size.
bestPractices: Always include a PopoverTrigger and PopoverContent as direct or indirect children of the Popover component for a complete and functional popover experience.
For existing interactive elements (like a Button) that should trigger the popover, use the `asChild` prop on PopoverTrigger to ensure proper focus management and event handling.
For advanced use cases or external control, manage the popover's open/closed state using the `open` and `onOpenChange` props provided by the Radix Primitive.
Ensure all content within PopoverContent is accessible, providing appropriate labels, semantic HTML, and supporting keyboard navigation.
antiPatterns: Using the Popover component without including both a PopoverTrigger and PopoverContent as its children, as this will result in a non-functional popover.
Placing interactive elements or the main popover content directly inside the Popover root instead of within PopoverTrigger or PopoverContent, which can break functionality and accessibility.
Overloading popovers with excessive or complex content, potentially degrading user experience and performance on smaller screens.

semanticData.summary: Renders the interactive element that controls the open/closed state of a Popover component.
semanticData.description: The PopoverTrigger component acts as a wrapper around Radix UI's PopoverPrimitive.Trigger, providing the interactive element that controls the visibility of an associated PopoverContent. It handles click or other interaction events to toggle the popover's open/closed state. Developers use this to define how users will activate the popover, ensuring proper accessibility and state management within the Popover composite component.

commonUseCases: Opening a tooltip-like information box on a button click
Displaying a small menu or options panel when an icon is clicked
Activating a form or filter popover from an input field

examples.description: Demonstrates a basic PopoverTrigger using a 'button' element to open the PopoverContent. The 'asChild' prop is used to ensure the 'button' receives the necessary accessibility and event props from PopoverTrigger.

limitations: Cannot be used independently; it must be a child of a Popover component.
Its functionality is entirely dependent on the underlying Radix UI PopoverPrimitive.Trigger.
Does not inherently provide any visual styling; styling is applied externally or via 'className'.
bestPractices: Always wrap PopoverTrigger within a Popover component to establish the necessary context.
For custom trigger elements (e.g., a specific icon or styled div), use the asChild prop on PopoverTrigger to pass props to the child element directly.
Ensure the trigger's content clearly indicates its purpose to the user.
antiPatterns: Using PopoverTrigger outside of a Popover component, which will lead to a non-functional or error state
Attempting to manually control the popover's open state via a separate state variable without using Popover's open and onOpenChange props, bypassing Radix's state management

semanticData.summary: Renders the content panel for a Radix UI Popover, including default styling, animation, and portal rendering.
semanticData.description: This component serves as the visual container for the content displayed within a popover. It leverages Radix UI's PopoverPrimitive.Content and PopoverPrimitive.Portal to ensure correct layering and accessibility. It comes with opinionated default styling for animations, positioning, and visual appearance, simplifying the creation of consistent popovers in an application.

commonUseCases: Displaying detailed information on hover or click of an element
Providing a small form or interactive element in a temporary overlay
Showing contextual menus or options for an item
Implementing custom tooltips with rich content

examples.code:
import { Popover, PopoverTrigger, PopoverContent } from "@/components/ui/popover"; import { Button } from "@/components/ui/button"; // Assuming a Button component function MyComponent() { return (

Dimensions

Set the dimensions for the layer.

); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic usage of `PopoverContent` to display a small form with input fields when a button is clicked. It shows how to pass a custom `className` to adjust the width and includes common UI elements within the content.

This example illustrates how to customize the positioning of the popover content using the `align` prop to align it to the end of the trigger and `sideOffset` to add extra spacing. This is useful for precise UI layouts like dropdown menus.

limitations: Due to `PopoverPrimitive.Portal`, the content is rendered outside the trigger's DOM hierarchy, which can make debugging CSS or layout issues slightly more complex.
The fixed `z-50` `z-index` might conflict with other highly-layered elements in very complex UI structures, potentially requiring custom `className` overrides.
While it provides animations, further customization of these animations requires overriding the extensive `className` string or using Radix's lower-level APIs.
bestPractices: Keep the content concise and focused, as popovers are meant for temporary information.
Utilize the `align` and `sideOffset` props to fine-tune positioning relative to the trigger.
Ensure any interactive elements within the popover content are fully accessible via keyboard navigation.
Combine with `PopoverTrigger` and `Popover` for a complete and accessible popover experience.
antiPatterns: Using PopoverContent for complex, full-screen dialogs instead of a dedicated dialog/modal component, as popovers are designed for transient, small content.
Overriding all default styling without understanding the underlying Radix primitives, potentially breaking accessibility or animations.
Placing interactive elements that require persistent user interaction (e.g., a large form with multiple steps) inside, as popovers close on outside click.

semanticData.summary: Wraps Radix UI Popover.Anchor to provide a designated anchor point for a popover, inheriting all its original properties.
semanticData.description: PopoverAnchor serves as a component wrapper for Radix UI Popover.Anchor, allowing developers to explicitly define the element to which a popover should be anchored. This is crucial for precise positioning when the popover's trigger is not the desired anchor, such as when a popover needs to appear relative to an icon within a button. It ensures correct spatial relationship and visual alignment of the popover content.

commonUseCases: Anchoring a popover to a specific element within a complex trigger component
Positioning a popover relative to an icon or sub-element inside a button
Creating custom popover layouts where the trigger and anchor are distinct

examples.description: This example demonstrates how PopoverAnchor can be used to anchor the popover specifically to the InfoIcon within a larger button component, rather than the entire button, providing precise positioning control.

limitations: Only one PopoverAnchor can be active within a given Popover instance at a time
Requires careful placement within the DOM relative to the PopoverContent and PopoverTrigger to ensure correct behavior, although Radix UI handles much of the complexity
bestPractices: Only use PopoverAnchor when the popover's position needs to be independent of the trigger element
Ensure the PopoverAnchor component is a direct child or descendant within the Popover context to function correctly
Leverage Radix UI's other positioning props on PopoverContent for fine-grained control when using PopoverAnchor
antiPatterns: Using PopoverAnchor when the PopoverTrigger itself is the intended anchor, which adds unnecessary complexity
Placing PopoverAnchor outside of a Popover component, as it must be a child of Popover.Root (or the Popover component in this setup) to function correctly

semanticData.summary: A React component for displaying customizable and accessible progress indicators, built on Radix UI's Progress primitive with default Tailwind CSS styling.
semanticData.description: The `Progress` component provides a visually styled and accessible progress bar, built atop the Radix UI `ProgressPrimitive`. It solves the problem of displaying completion status in a user-friendly manner by wrapping the low-level Radix primitive with default Tailwind CSS styling. Developers can use it to indicate loading states, task completion, or any numerical progress, benefiting from Radix's robust accessibility features while requiring minimal styling effort.

commonUseCases: Displaying the loading status of data fetching operations
Showing the completion percentage of a multi-step form or wizard
Visualizing the progress of file uploads or downloads
Indicating the elapsed time in a media player or recording tool

examples.description: Demonstrates a basic progress bar indicating 75% completion. The `className` prop is used to customize its width within the layout.
Illustrates how to use the `Progress` component with a dynamically updated `value` to show real-time progress, such as during a data synchronization process. The `value` state is updated every 200ms.

limitations: Primarily designed for determinate progress (where the `value` is known and updates towards a maximum). For indeterminate progress (e.g., a spinner while waiting for an unknown duration), a different component might be more suitable.
Relies on Radix UI's `ProgressPrimitive` for core functionality and accessibility, meaning any breaking changes or specific behaviors of Radix will be inherited.

Default styling is opinionated using Tailwind CSS classes. Customizing it significantly without Tailwind knowledge might require overriding many utility classes or providing entirely new `className` strings.
bestPractices: Always provide a `value` prop to ensure the progress bar accurately reflects the current state and is accessible to screen readers.
Consider adding a textual representation (e.g., '50% loaded') alongside the visual bar for improved clarity and accessibility, especially for users who may not perceive the visual indicator.
Ensure the `value` prop is updated smoothly and frequently enough during long-running operations to provide continuous feedback to the user.
Utilize the `max` prop if your progress is not out of 100, though the default styling assumes a 0-100 range for the `value`.
antiPatterns: Using the component for purely decorative purposes without any actual progress data, as it implies a dynamic state to the user.
Providing a static `value` of 0 or 100 in scenarios where indeterminate progress (e.g., a spinner) would be more appropriate for an unknown duration.
Overriding critical Radix UI attributes (like `role`, `aria-valuenow`) unless absolutely necessary for specific accessibility patterns, as this can break built-in accessibility.

codeMetadata.name: InputOTP
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof OTPInput> & { containerClassName?: string }): any

semanticData.summary: A styled wrapper component for creating flexible and theme-consistent one-time password (OTP) input fields.
semanticData.description: The InputOTP component acts as a styled wrapper around the `input-otp` library's `OTPInput` component, providing a pre-configured and theme-consistent UI for one-time password inputs. It automatically applies base Tailwind CSS styles for flex layout and disabled states, while allowing developers to further customize the container and input elements via `containerClassName` and `className` props. This simplifies the integration of OTP functionality, ensuring a consistent look and feel within the application's design system.

commonUseCases: Implementing two-factor authentication (2FA) flows
Phone number or email verification processes
Login screens requiring a one-time code
Passwordless authentication via short-lived codes

examples.description: This example demonstrates a typical usage of `InputOTP` for a 6-digit code. It integrates `InputOTPGroup` to group slots, `InputOTPSlot` for individual digits, and `InputOTPSeparator` to visually divide the code. The `value` and `onChange` props manage the input's state, providing a complete and functional OTP field.

limitations: As a wrapper, its core functionality (e.g., input validation, cursor behavior) is inherited from the `input-otp` library, not provided directly by `InputOTP`.
Requires the `input-otp` library as a peer dependency for its core functionality.
The styling provided is based on a specific design system (likely Radix UI and Tailwind CSS) and may require adjustment if used in a different styling environment.
bestPractices: Always use `InputOTP` in combination with `InputOTPGroup`, `InputOTPSlot`, and `InputOTPSeparator` to fully leverage the styling and functionality.
Utilize the `containerClassName` and `className` props for outer container and inner input styling respectively, ensuring separation of concerns.
Handle OTP state management (e.g., value, onChange) using the underlying `OTPInput` props, as `InputOTP` simply passes them through.
antiPatterns: Not using `InputOTPGroup`, `InputOTPSlot`, and `InputOTPSeparator` in conjunction with `InputOTP` for a complete and styled OTP field, as `InputOTP` is primarily a container for these.
Attempting to directly style individual input elements within the `InputOTP` without using the provided slot components, which can lead to style conflicts or breakage.

semanticData.summary: A presentational component that visually groups InputOTPSlot components within an InputOTP input.
semanticData.description: The InputOTPGroup component serves as a visual container for individual InputOTPSlot components, which represent each digit of an OTP. It helps structure the layout of the OTP input field, ensuring proper alignment and spacing of the slots. This component is an essential part of the composite InputOTP pattern, providing the foundational grouping for the user interface.

commonUseCases: Grouping individual OTP digits within an InputOTP field.
Creating a structured visual block for entering multi-digit codes like 2FA or verification codes.

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of InputOTPGroup to wrap InputOTPSlot components. It shows how groups can be used to visually segment the OTP input, for instance, into two blocks of three digits separated by InputOTPSeparator.

limitations: Acts purely as a presentational wrapper (a div); does not contain any input logic or state.
Its primary purpose is to style and group InputOTPSlots, making it less useful outside the InputOTP component ecosystem.
Does not render any content itself besides its children; relies on InputOTPSlot for actual digit display.
bestPractices: Always nest InputOTPGroup directly inside InputOTP.
Place InputOTPSlot components as children of InputOTPGroup to ensure correct styling and layout.
Use the className prop to apply custom styling to the group container, such as different spacing or background.
antiPatterns: Using InputOTPGroup without InputOTPSlot components or outside of the InputOTP context, as it provides no functional benefit on its own and is purely for visual grouping within the OTP component system.
Attempting to manage OTP input state or logic directly within InputOTPGroup, as it is a presentational component and delegates state management to InputOTP.

semanticData.summary: Renders an individual, styled slot for a single digit in an OTP input field, showing its value and an animated caret when active.
semanticData.description: The InputOTPSlot component is a sub-component of the InputOTP system, designed to render an individual digit slot within a multi-digit One-Time Password (OTP) input field. It fetches its character and active state from the OTPInputContext, allowing it to display the current digit and an animated fake caret when active. This component is crucial for building user interfaces that require secure and visually clear OTP entry.

commonUseCases: Creating a multi-digit one-time password (OTP) input field for authentication
Building forms that require verification codes sent via SMS or email
Implementing security features where users enter temporary codes

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic usage of InputOTPSlot within an InputOTPGroup and InputOTP component to create a 6-digit OTP input. Each slot is given a unique `index` prop to correspond to its position in the OTP sequence.

limitations: The InputOTPSlot component is tightly coupled to the `input-otp` library and its `OTPInputContext`; it cannot function as a standalone input field.
It is primarily a presentation component; value handling and validation are managed by the parent `InputOTP` component.
Its visual appearance for active/inactive/filled states is dependent on the CSS classes applied internally and via the `cn` utility; deep customization may require overriding these styles.
bestPractices: Always nest InputOTPSlot components within an InputOTPGroup, which in turn should be nested inside an InputOTP component, to ensure proper context and styling.
Ensure the `index` prop for each InputOTPSlot is unique and sequential (0, 1, 2, ...) to correctly map to the input-otp library's internal state.
Leverage the styling props (`className`, `data-*`) to customize the appearance without breaking its core functionality or accessibility.
Integrate with form libraries (e.g., React Hook Form, Formik) by passing the `value` from the parent `InputOTP` component.
antiPatterns: Using InputOTPSlot directly without wrapping it in InputOTPGroup and InputOTP, as it relies on OTPInputContext for its state.
Attempting to manually manage the character or active state of the slot; these are managed automatically by the parent InputOTP component via context.
Providing an incorrect or out-of-bounds `index` prop, which will lead to incorrect character display or errors as it won't map to a slot in the context.

semanticData.summary: Renders a visual separator, typically a hyphen, within an OTP input field to group digits.
semanticData.description: This component provides a visual divider for grouping digits within an OTP (One-Time Password) input field. It renders a MinusIcon by default, effectively creating a hyphen-like separator to improve readability and user experience when entering multi-part codes. Developers should use it between InputOTPSlot components or InputOTPGroup components to visually structure the input.

commonUseCases: Visually separating groups of digits in an OTP input (e.g., "123-456").
Improving readability for multi-part authentication codes.

examples.description: Demonstrates how to use InputOTPSeparator to divide a 6-digit OTP into two groups of three, enhancing readability for the user. It's placed directly between two InputOTPGroup components within the main InputOTP component.

limitations: Primarily designed for visual separation; it does not affect the underlying OTP value's logic or parsing.
Its default visual (`MinusIcon`) is fixed; replacing it with a different character or custom element requires providing child elements or custom styling via className.
bestPractices: Place it strategically between InputOTPSlot components or InputOTPGroup components to match the expected format of the OTP code (e.g., after every 3rd or 4th digit).
Utilize its className prop to customize the appearance if the default MinusIcon or styling is not desired (e.g., change the icon or add custom spacing).
antiPatterns: Using InputOTPSeparator outside of an InputOTPGroup: It's designed to be a child within the OTP input structure and doesn't function meaningfully standalone.
Using it for non-OTP related visual separation: Its styling and role are specific to OTP contexts; use generic divider components elsewhere.

semanticData.summary: Maps theme names to CSS selectors for dynamic chart styling based on light/dark mode.
semanticData.description: THEMES is a constant object that maps theme names (like 'light' or 'dark') to their corresponding CSS selectors. This declaration's primary purpose is to facilitate dynamic styling of charts, specifically within the `ChartStyle` component, by allowing the generation of theme-dependent CSS variables. It solves the problem of adapting chart colors to the application's current theme, ensuring visual consistency across different UI modes.

commonUseCases: Defining theme-specific CSS selectors for dynamic styling of UI components
Enabling charts and other components to adapt colors based on the application's active theme (e.g., light/dark mode)
Generating runtime CSS variables that are scoped to specific themes

examples.description: This example demonstrates how `THEMES` is utilized within the `ChartStyle` component. It iterates over the entries in `THEMES`, using each `prefix` (e.g., `.dark`) to scope generated CSS variables like `--color-key` to a specific theme. This allows the chart's colors to dynamically adjust based on whether the `.dark` class is present on an ancestor element, ensuring charts visually integrate with the current UI theme.

limitations: The functionality relies on the presence of the corresponding CSS class (e.g., `.dark`) on an ancestor element (typically `html` or `body`) for the theme-specific styles to apply.
Directly tied to the implementation of the `ChartStyle` component for dynamic CSS variable generation; its utility outside this specific pattern is limited.
New themes require a manual update to the `THEMES` constant; it does not dynamically discover themes.
bestPractices: Treat `THEMES` as a static, read-only configuration for theme-to-selector mapping.
Ensure that the CSS selectors defined in `THEMES` accurately correspond to the theme classes applied to your document's root or relevant ancestor elements (e.g., `html` or `body`).
Extend `THEMES` with new entries if your application introduces additional themes, maintaining a clear mapping for each.
antiPatterns: Modifying the `THEMES` object at runtime: It is declared as `const` and meant to be a static mapping; dynamic changes can lead to unpredictable styling or errors.
Using `THEMES` for CSS prefixes unrelated to actual UI themes: Its purpose is explicitly for theme-based selectors, using it otherwise would be confusing and against its intent.

codeMetadata.name: ChartConfig
codeMetadata.typeSignature: type = { [k in string]: { label?: React.ReactNode; icon?: React.ComponentType } & ({ color?: string; theme?: never } | { color?: never; theme: Record<keyof typeof THEMES, string> }) }

semanticData.summary: Defines a flexible configuration object for chart series, enabling custom labels, icons, and theme-aware colors for chart elements.
semanticData.description: ChartConfig provides a structured way to customize the appearance and labels of individual data series or elements within a chart. It allows developers to specify human-readable labels and optional icons for each chart key, which are then used in components like tooltips and legends. Crucially, it supports dynamic theming by allowing colors to be defined per theme (e.g., light/dark mode) or as a single static color, generating CSS variables for consistent styling across chart components.

commonUseCases: Customizing the display names and icons for lines/bars in a Recharts graph
Providing different series colors for light and dark themes in a chart
Centralizing chart series metadata for use in tooltips, legends, and styling
Defining accessible labels for chart data points for improved user experience

examples.description: Demonstrates defining ChartConfig for a chart with three data series (desktop, mobile, tablet), providing a label and a static color for each. The colors are defined using CSS hsl(var(--chart-X)) variables, common in modern UI libraries for theme integration.

Shows how to use the 'theme' property to specify different colors for light and dark modes, ensuring chart colors adapt to the user's theme settings. It also demonstrates the use of a custom 'icon' component for each series.

limitations: Requires defining colors either globally or per-theme; mixing 'color' and 'theme' properties for a single key is disallowed by the type signature.

Color definitions within 'theme' must explicitly cover all keys present in the global THEMES constant ('light', 'dark'), making it less flexible if new themes are introduced without updating the config.
The dynamic styling relies on CSS variables generated by ChartStyle, meaning the ChartContainer must be used to apply these styles correctly.
bestPractices: Use hsl(var(--chart-X)) or similar CSS variables for 'color' to ensure colors are consistent with the application's overall theme system.
Provide meaningful 'label' values for all chart keys to enhance readability in tooltips and legends.
For complex applications, consider deriving ChartConfig from a centralized theme or design token system to maintain consistency.
Prefer using the 'theme' property over 'color' when your application supports light/dark modes to ensure a consistent visual experience across themes.
antiPatterns: Defining both 'color' and 'theme' for the same key in ChartConfig (will result in a type error due to 'never' constraints).
Hardcoding raw color values like '#FF0000' directly in 'color' when a theme system is in place, as this bypasses theme consistency.
Omitting 'label' for critical chart series, leading to generic or unhelpful text in tooltips and legends.

semanticData.summary: Defines the shape of the chart configuration object made available through React context within charting components.
semanticData.description: ChartContextProps defines the data structure for the React context used by chart components. It encapsulates a ChartConfig object, which provides essential metadata such as labels, icons, and theme-specific colors for various chart data series. This centralizes chart configuration, preventing prop drilling and enabling descendant components like tooltips and legends to consistently retrieve and display relevant information for each data point or series.

commonUseCases: Providing chart-specific configuration (colors, labels, icons) to all child components within a ChartContainer
Dynamically retrieving chart item labels and colors for tooltips and legends
Centralizing chart data series metadata for consistent rendering across chart elements

examples.description: This example demonstrates how ChartContextProps (via its 'config' property) is implicitly provided by ChartContainer. The 'salesChartConfig' object, which adheres to the ChartConfig type, becomes accessible to all components rendered within the ChartContainer through the ChartContext. This enables chart elements like 'Line' to dynamically pick up colors using CSS variables generated from 'config', and 'ChartTooltipContent' to retrieve appropriate labels and colors for its display.

This example (simplified to highlight the consumption pattern) illustrates how components like 'ChartTooltipContent' or 'ChartLegendContent' internally leverage the 'useChart' hook to access the 'config' object from ChartContextProps. This allows them to dynamically retrieve configuration details (such as labels or custom icons) for specific data keys provided by the recharts payload, ensuring consistency with the chart's overall configuration.

limitations: The 'config' object within ChartContextProps is designed to be immutable once set by 'ChartContainer'; direct modifications will not trigger updates in consuming components. A new 'config' object must be passed to 'ChartContainer' for changes to take effect.

Designed for a single chart configuration per 'ChartContainer' instance; it's not suitable for charts that require multiple distinct, active configurations simultaneously within the same immediate hierarchy without nesting 'ChartContainer's.
bestPractices: Define ChartConfig objects outside of component renders to prevent unnecessary re-creations and optimize performance.
Utilize the 'label' and 'icon' properties within ChartConfig to enhance the clarity and visual representation of chart elements in tooltips and legends.
Leverage the 'theme' property in ChartConfig to provide distinct colors for light and dark modes, ensuring consistent branding across themes.
antiPatterns: Avoid directly manipulating ChartContext.Provider outside of ChartContainer, as ChartContainer manages the proper setup and styling.
Do not attempt to directly modify the 'config' object after it's passed to ChartContainer; instead, pass a new 'config' object if updates are needed to ensure reactivity.

semanticData.summary: Provides chart configuration data to descendant React components using React's Context API.
semanticData.description: ChartContext is a React Context that holds the ChartConfig object, which defines the labels, icons, and colors for different data keys within a chart. It allows chart-related components (like tooltips and legends) to access consistent styling and metadata without prop drilling. This context is typically provided by the ChartContainer component and consumed via the useChart hook.

commonUseCases: Providing a centralized configuration for a chart's data series, including labels, icons, and colors.
Enabling chart sub-components (e.g., tooltips, legends) to display custom labels and colors based on a global config.
Dynamically styling chart elements using CSS variables derived from the configured colors.
Creating reusable chart components that automatically inherit styling and metadata.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how `ChartContainer` wraps your Recharts components and provides the `ChartConfig` to its children via the `ChartContext`. This `config` is then accessible by sub-components like tooltips and legends, centralizing chart metadata.

This example shows how the `useChart` hook is used within a component (like a custom tooltip) to access the `ChartConfig` object. This allows components to dynamically render labels, colors, or icons based on the configuration defined at the `ChartContainer` level, ensuring consistency.

limitations: The context primarily provides a static `config` object; while changes to the `config` prop on `ChartContainer` will re-render consumers, the context itself is not optimized for frequent, granular updates of individual config items.
ChartContext is specifically designed for ChartConfig data and is not a generic data context, meaning it should only be used for chart-related metadata and styling.

Context consumers (like useChart) will trigger re-renders of components when the context value changes, which could impact performance if the ChartConfig is very large or updated frequently in the parent.
bestPractices: Always consume the ChartContext via the useChart hook to benefit from its built-in error handling for cases where the context is not provided.
Ensure ChartContainer (which wraps the context provider) is used at a high enough level in the component tree to encompass all chart-related sub-components that need access to the configuration.
Define comprehensive ChartConfig objects to centralize chart presentation logic, making charts easier to maintain and theme.
Utilize the color definitions in ChartConfig to generate CSS variables for consistent styling across chart elements.
antiPatterns: Directly importing ChartContext and using React.useContext(ChartContext) without the ChartContainer provider or the useChart hook. This bypasses the built-in error handling and ensures the context is always populated.
Attempting to modify the ChartConfig directly via the context consumer, as context is primarily for read-only data flow for shared state.

semanticData.summary: Provides access to the chart's global configuration object from a parent ChartContainer.
semanticData.description: The useChart hook provides a convenient way for descendant components of a ChartContainer to access the global chart configuration. This configuration, defined by ChartConfig, holds crucial metadata such as labels, icons, and theme-specific colors for various data series within the chart. It's designed to ensure consistent data presentation and styling across all chart sub-components, solving the problem of passing props deeply or duplicating configuration logic.

commonUseCases: Retrieving dynamic labels for chart tooltips or legends based on data keys
Accessing custom icons associated with specific chart data series
Applying theme-aware colors to chart elements (e.g., lines, bars, dots)
Building highly customizable and data-driven chart sub-components

examples.description: This example shows how ChartTooltipContent uses useChart to retrieve the chart's configuration. It then leverages this configuration to dynamically determine labels, colors, and icons for the tooltip's content based on the active payload data. This ensures tooltips are consistent with the overall chart's configured appearance.

limitations: The hook is dependent on React's Context API, meaning it can only access configuration provided by an ancestor ChartContext.Provider (which is part of ChartContainer).
Configuration changes made directly to the config object returned by useChart will not reflect in the ChartContainer, as it provides a stable reference from its props.
bestPractices: Always wrap components that use useChart within a ChartContainer to ensure the context is provided.
Define a comprehensive ChartConfig at the ChartContainer level to centralize all chart-specific metadata.
Memoize components or derived values that depend on the chart config if the config is large or consumer components are complex, to optimize performance.
Use useChart primarily for reading configuration data to inform rendering logic, not for state management.
antiPatterns: Calling useChart outside of a ChartContainer component, which will throw a runtime error.
Attempting to modify the chart configuration directly through the hook; the returned config is read-only.
Over-fetching data or performing heavy computations within components that consume useChart, as context changes can trigger re-renders.

codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<"div"> & { config: ChartConfig; children: React.ComponentProps<typeof RechartsPrimitive.ResponsiveContainer>["children"] }): any

codeMetadata.name: ChartStyle
codeMetadata.typeSignature: const ChartStyle: (_complex_param: { id: string; config: ChartConfig }) => any

semanticData.summary: Injects theme-aware CSS variables for chart colors based on a ChartConfig, scoping them to a specific chart instance.
semanticData.description: The ChartStyle component is responsible for dynamically injecting CSS variables into the DOM based on a provided chart configuration and the current theme. It processes a `ChartConfig` object to extract color definitions, generating `--color-<key>: <value>;` CSS variables that are scoped to a specific chart ID and theme (light/dark mode). This allows Recharts components within the associated `ChartContainer` to consume these colors via CSS variables, enabling centralized and theme-aware color management for charts.

commonUseCases: Applying dynamic colors to data series in Recharts charts based on a centralized configuration.
Ensuring chart elements automatically adapt their colors when the application theme (light/dark mode) changes.
Centralizing the definition of chart-specific colors to improve maintainability and consistency.
Providing a mechanism for chart components to access themed colors without prop drilling.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how `ChartStyle` is implicitly used within `ChartContainer`. The `ChartConfig` defines colors for 'desktop' and 'mobile' data series, including theme-specific overrides. `ChartStyle` then generates `--color-desktop` and `--color-mobile` CSS variables, which are consumed by the `Line` components for their `stroke` property, allowing them to automatically adapt to the theme defined in `ChartConfig`.

limitations: Relies on injecting a `<style>` tag using `dangerouslySetInnerHTML`, which should be used with caution and validated inputs (handled internally by `ChartStyle`).
Only affects color styling via CSS variables; other chart styling (e.g., line thickness, dot size) must be handled through other Recharts props or global CSS.
The CSS variables are scoped using `data-chart` attributes and theme prefixes (e.g., `.dark [data-chart=id]`), so chart elements must be descendants of the `ChartContainer` and respect this scoping.
bestPractices: Always use `ChartStyle` as a child of `ChartContainer` to ensure it receives the correct `id` and `config` for proper styling scope.
Define all relevant chart series colors within the `ChartConfig` object to leverage the centralized styling provided by `ChartStyle`.
Utilize the `theme` property within `ChartConfig` for colors that need to differ between light and dark modes.
Prefer CSS variables (e.g., `var(--color-mySeries)`) in your Recharts components or other chart elements to consume the colors injected by `ChartStyle`.
antiPatterns: Manually defining static colors for individual Recharts series or elements when they should be driven by the `ChartConfig`, leading to redundant styling.
Using `ChartStyle` outside of a `ChartContainer` or without a valid `id` and `config`, as it relies on the `data-chart` attribute for scoping.

semanticData.summary: Provides the base Recharts Tooltip component for displaying interactive data details on charts.
semanticData.description: ChartTooltip is a direct re-export of the Recharts.Tooltip component, serving as the foundation for interactive tooltips within the custom chart system. It is designed to be used in conjunction with ChartTooltipContent to leverage the ChartConfig for consistent styling, color mapping, and custom content rendering when users hover over chart elements. This separation allows for flexible tooltip customization while maintaining a cohesive look and feel across all charts.

commonUseCases: Displaying specific data values, labels, and associated icons when a user hovers over a data point on a line, bar, or area chart
Providing a pop-up summary of aggregated data for a particular segment or category in charts like pie or radial bar charts
Showing additional context, such as units or comparisons, alongside the primary data value in an interactive chart

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to integrate ChartTooltip with ChartTooltipContent within a ChartContainer. The ChartTooltip is rendered as a child of the LineChart, and its content prop is set to ChartTooltipContent to ensure consistent styling and data display, picking up colors and labels from the chartConfig.

limitations: ChartTooltip itself offers minimal direct customization beyond what Recharts.Tooltip provides; extensive visual and content customization must be managed via its content prop, typically ChartTooltipContent
Its functionality is tightly coupled with ChartTooltipContent for integration into the ChartContainer's theming and configuration system
Inherits any performance characteristics or rendering quirks directly from the underlying Recharts Tooltip component
bestPractices: Always nest ChartTooltipContent inside ChartTooltip to benefit from ChartConfig integration and consistent styling defined by the ChartContainer
Utilize the formatter and labelFormatter props of ChartTooltipContent to precisely control how data values and labels are presented
Leverage ChartConfig to define colors, labels, and icons for your data series, which ChartTooltipContent will automatically pick up for a unified tooltip appearance
Adjust hideLabel, hideIndicator, and indicator props in ChartTooltipContent to fine-tune the visual presentation of the tooltip based on chart type and data complexity
antiPatterns: Using ChartTooltip directly without ChartTooltipContent if you need to integrate with ChartConfig or apply custom styling defined by the ChartContainer system, as it will lack the system's styling and data interpretation
Attempting to pass ChartConfig related props directly to ChartTooltip; these should be handled by ChartTooltipContent

semanticData.summary: Renders customizable content for Recharts tooltips, applying chart-specific configurations for labels, icons, and colors.
semanticData.description: The `ChartTooltipContent` component is a customizable React component designed to render the detailed content within a Recharts tooltip. It dynamically displays data points on hover, leveraging a shared `ChartConfig` context to apply consistent styling, labels, and icons for different data series. This component helps developers create rich, informative chart tooltips that integrate seamlessly with the overall chart theme and data visualization.

commonUseCases: Displaying detailed data points when hovering over a chart element in Recharts
Customizing the appearance of tooltip labels and indicators
Integrating chart data with predefined `ChartConfig` for consistent styling
Providing specific formatting for numerical values or labels within a tooltip

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `ChartTooltipContent` within a Recharts `Tooltip` component. It passes the `indicator` prop to change the visual indicator for data points in the tooltip. The `chartConfig` object provides custom labels and colors for the 'uv' and 'pv' data keys, which `ChartTooltipContent` automatically picks up.

This example showcases advanced customization of `ChartTooltipContent`. It hides the default label (`hideLabel={true}`), sets the indicator to a dot, and uses `formatter` to customize the display of individual data point values (e.g., adding ' views'). The `labelFormatter` is used to prepend 'Month: ' to the tooltip's main label.

limitations: Primarily designed for use with Recharts library; compatibility with other charting libraries is not guaranteed.
Relies on the internal structure of Recharts' `payload` prop, which might change in future Recharts versions (though typically stable).
Custom styling beyond `ChartConfig` or direct Tailwind classes requires manual DOM manipulation or additional CSS.
bestPractices: Always wrap `ChartTooltipContent` inside a `ChartContainer` to ensure `ChartConfig` is available via context.
Define all series-specific labels, colors, and icons within the `ChartConfig` for centralized management and consistency.
Use the `formatter` prop for complex value formatting and `labelFormatter` for custom label rendering to keep the component focused on presentation.
Leverage `nameKey` and `labelKey` props when data keys in the payload differ from the keys used in `ChartConfig`.
antiPatterns: Not wrapping `ChartTooltipContent` within a `ChartContainer` or `ChartContext.Provider`, leading to `useChart` errors.
Directly manipulating Recharts' internal payload structure without using `nameKey` or `labelKey`, which can lead to incorrect data display.
Overriding styles with hardcoded values instead of utilizing the `ChartConfig` for theme consistency.

semanticData.summary: Renders the Recharts chart legend, typically integrated with ChartLegendContent for custom display logic.
semanticData.description: ChartLegend is a direct re-export of the `Recharts.Legend` component, specifically adapted for use within the `ChartContainer` ecosystem. Its primary purpose is to display a legend for the data series in a chart, often utilizing the `ChartLegendContent` component to leverage the `ChartConfig` for custom labels, colors, and icons. This component helps users understand what each visual element (line, bar, etc.) on the chart represents, ensuring clarity and interpretability of data visualizations.

commonUseCases: Displaying a legend for line charts, bar charts, or area charts
Customizing legend items with specific icons or labels defined in ChartConfig
Providing interactive legend entries to toggle series visibility (when combined with Recharts features)

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `ChartLegend` with `ChartLegendContent` inside a `ChartContainer`. The `chartConfig` defines the labels and colors for 'desktop' and 'mobile' data keys, which are then automatically picked up and displayed by the `ChartLegendContent` component, providing a consistent legend with the chart's theme.

limitations: As a direct re-export of `Recharts.Legend`, it inherits all the limitations of the Recharts Legend component, including its rendering behavior and available props.

Customization beyond what's offered by `ChartLegendContent` (e.g., highly dynamic item reordering or complex user interactions) might require building a completely custom legend component or extending `ChartLegendContent` further.
Relies on `ChartConfig` for enhanced functionality; if `ChartConfig` is not properly defined, the legend might show generic labels or no icons.
bestPractices: Always nest ChartLegend directly inside Recharts components (e.g., LineChart, BarChart) and within a ChartContainer.
Utilize the `ChartLegendContent` component as the `content` prop of `ChartLegend` to automatically integrate with the `ChartConfig` for consistent styling and labeling.
Ensure your `ChartConfig` accurately defines `label` and `icon` properties for each data key that you want to appear in the legend.
Position the legend effectively using `verticalAlign` and `align` props to avoid obscuring chart data.
antiPatterns: Using ChartLegend outside of a ChartContainer: It relies on ChartContext for configuration, which is provided by ChartContainer, leading to runtime errors.
Not providing ChartLegendContent when custom labels or icons are desired: Without ChartLegendContent, the legend will use default Recharts rendering which might not align with the ChartConfig.
Hardcoding legend items instead of using ChartConfig: This defeats the purpose of centralized chart configuration and makes the legend less dynamic.

semanticData.summary: Renders a customizable legend content for Recharts, displaying series names, colors, and optional icons based on chart configuration.
semanticData.description: ChartLegendContent is a custom React component designed to render the content of a Recharts legend. It takes the legend payload (series data) and the global chart configuration to display interactive and styled legend items, including custom labels and icons. This component helps solve the problem of customizing legend appearance beyond Recharts' default capabilities, providing a unified look and feel consistent with the overall chart theme defined in ChartConfig.

commonUseCases: Displaying custom series labels and icons in a chart legend
Integrating chart legends with a centralized chart configuration for consistent styling
Overriding default Recharts legend rendering for enhanced UI/UX

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use ChartLegendContent within a Recharts LineChart. It's passed as the 'content' prop to RechartsPrimitive.Legend, enabling the custom legend rendering based on the provided 'chartConfig'.
This example shows how to customize the appearance of the legend content using props like 'hideIcon' and 'className'. This allows for fine-grained control over the legend's visual representation.

limitations: It requires the presence of a 'ChartContainer' component higher in the component tree to access the 'ChartConfig' context.
Relies on the 'payload' structure provided by Recharts' Legend component, so direct manual invocation might require careful payload construction.
Icon rendering is limited to React Components defined in 'ChartConfig', not arbitrary SVG or image paths.
bestPractices: Always wrap ChartLegendContent within a RechartsPrimitive.Legend component inside a Recharts chart.
Ensure the 'ChartContainer' component is properly configured with a 'ChartConfig' to leverage custom labels and icons.
Use the 'nameKey' prop if your payload items use a different key for identifying the series name than the default 'dataKey' or 'name'.
antiPatterns: Using ChartLegendContent outside of a ChartContainer, as it relies on the ChartContext for configuration.
Providing an empty or malformed 'payload' prop, which will result in an empty legend.
Not defining items in 'ChartConfig' for legend keys, leading to generic labels or missing icons.

codeMetadata.name: getPayloadConfigFromPayload
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(config: ChartConfig, payload: unknown, key: string): any

semanticData.summary: Extracts the appropriate chart configuration for a given Recharts payload item using a flexible key lookup.
semanticData.description: This helper function resolves the correct chart item configuration from the ChartConfig based on a Recharts payload item and a provided key. It intelligently searches for the relevant label key within the payload itself or its nested 'payload.payload' property, making it robust against varying Recharts payload structures. This ensures that tooltips and legends can display custom labels and icons defined in the ChartConfig.

commonUseCases: Dynamically fetching custom labels and icons for Recharts tooltips based on payload data.
Resolving chart legend item details from a centralized ChartConfig for display.
Mapping complex Recharts payload data keys (e.g., nested or aliased) to simplified ChartConfig keys.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how 'getPayloadConfigFromPayload' is used within a Recharts tooltip content component ('ChartTooltipContent'). It retrieves the specific configuration (label, icon) for both the tooltip's main label and each individual payload item, ensuring custom styling and data display based on the centralized 'ChartConfig'.

limitations: This function assumes the 'payload' input is an object (or can be treated as such) and is structured in a way that allows the 'key' (or a resolved 'configLabelKey') to be found either directly or within a nested 'payload.payload' property.
It is primarily designed for the specific Recharts 'payload' structures found in components like Tooltip or Legend, and its behavior with other types of 'unknown' inputs might be unpredictable.

The function falls back to using the direct 'key' if a more specific 'configLabelKey' cannot be resolved from the payload. If the direct 'key' is not present in 'ChartConfig', it will return undefined.
bestPractices: Always use this function when mapping Recharts payload items (from tooltips, legends, etc.) to a ChartConfig entry to ensure consistent and correct data presentation across chart components.
Design your ChartConfig keys to align as much as possible with your chart's 'dataKey's or expected 'name's for clarity, even though this function provides flexibility in key resolution.
Ensure the 'key' argument passed to this function accurately reflects the intended lookup key within the payload for robust configuration retrieval.
antiPatterns: Directly accessing 'payload.dataKey' or 'payload.name' without this helper if the ChartConfig uses different keys or needs nested payload inspection, which can lead to incorrect or missing configuration.
Hardcoding display logic for individual chart series in tooltips or legends instead of leveraging the centralized ChartConfig via this function, resulting in repetitive and less maintainable code.

semanticData.summary: Provides the root context and state for Radix UI's Hover Card component.
semanticData.description: The HoverCard component serves as the root provider for the Radix UI Hover Card primitive. It encapsulates the core state and context for the hover card interaction, enabling its trigger and content components to function correctly. This component establishes the foundational structure for displaying supplementary information or controls when a user hovers over an element, solving the problem of presenting non-intrusive, on-demand details.

commonUseCases: Displaying user profile summaries on avatar hover
Showing detailed product information previews in e-commerce listings
Providing definitions or explanations for terms in an article
Revealing additional actions or menu options on icon hover

examples.code:
import { HoverCard, HoverCardContent, HoverCardTrigger } from "@/components/ui/hover-card"; import { Button } from "@/components/ui/button"; function UserProfileHoverCard() { return (

@shadcn

Creator of shadcn/ui. Open source developer and front-end enthusiast.

Joined December 2021
); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of HoverCard as the root element, wrapping a HoverCardTrigger (a button) and a HoverCardContent that displays a user's profile information when the trigger is hovered. It illustrates how the three components work together to form a complete hover card interaction.

limitations: Relies heavily on Radix UI for its core functionality and accessibility features; extensive custom behavior beyond standard Radix props might require deeper integration or re-implementation.

While it provides the structure, the actual visual styling and layout within `HoverCardContent` are dependent on the provided `className` and developer's CSS knowledge (e.g., Tailwind CSS utility classes used in the source).
Not suitable for touch-only devices unless combined with click or long-press interactions, as hover states are not natively supported.
bestPractices: Always wrap HoverCardTrigger and HoverCardContent within HoverCard to ensure proper context and functionality.
Ensure the content inside HoverCardContent is concise, relevant, and adds value without overwhelming the user.
Provide clear visual feedback for the trigger element (e.g., underlines, subtle color changes) to indicate it is interactive.
Consider using `asChild` prop on the trigger to compose with existing elements without introducing extra DOM nodes.
For critical information, use alternative components like modals or popovers that require explicit user action to close.
antiPatterns: Using HoverCard for essential navigation or critical actions that require a click, as hover interactions can be less reliable and accessible for crucial tasks.
Placing overly large or complex content inside HoverCardContent that obscures the page or requires extensive scrolling, leading to a poor user experience.
Nesting multiple hover cards deeply, which can create confusing visual clutter and make it difficult for users to understand interaction flows.

semanticData.summary: Renders the styled content panel for a Radix UI Hover Card, including default animations and positioning via a Portal.
semanticData.description: This component renders the actual content panel that appears when a HoverCardTrigger is hovered over. It wraps Radix UI's HoverCardPrimitive.Content, applying a default set of robust styles for smooth entrance/exit animations, precise positioning, and consistent visual appearance. It leverages a Portal to ensure the content renders correctly without clipping issues, providing a ready-to-use and aesthetically pleasing hover experience.

commonUseCases: Displaying concise user profile previews on avatar hover.
Showing brief tooltips or contextual information for UI elements.
Providing quick previews of linked content, like article summaries or image details.
Offering supplemental data for charts or graphs when hovering over data points.

examples.code:
import { HoverCard, HoverCardTrigger, HoverCardContent } from '@/components/ui/hover-card'; import { Button } from '@/components/ui/button'; function ProfileHoverCard() { return (

@johndoe

Frontend developer building accessible UI components.

Joined October 2023
); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `HoverCardContent` to display a user profile preview when hovering over a username. The `className` prop is used to customize the width of the content panel, while `align` and `sideOffset` (which default to 'center' and 4 respectively) ensure proper positioning.

limitations: Primarily designed for mouse/pointer hover interactions; alternative mechanisms for keyboard navigation for the information displayed might be needed depending on context.
Best suited for displaying short, supplementary information; not ideal for complex forms or extensive content that requires sustained interaction.
Relies on a styling framework (like Tailwind CSS for the `cn` utility) for the default classes to render correctly; without it, only basic structural rendering from Radix UI will occur.
The content disappears when the mouse leaves the trigger or content area, making it unsuitable for information that needs to persist on screen for user interaction.
bestPractices: Keep the content concise and focused on supplementary information.
Utilize the `align` and `sideOffset` props to fine-tune the content's position relative to its trigger for optimal user experience.
Ensure sufficient contrast for text and background within the content for readability.
Design the content to be dismissible easily, reinforcing its transient nature.
antiPatterns: Placing complex interactive forms or critical action buttons inside the hover card, as it's meant for transient display, not primary interaction.
Overloading the content with excessive text or too many intricate components, which can hinder readability and cause unexpected layout shifts.
Relying on hover card for essential navigation or information that needs to be permanently accessible, as it disappears when the mouse moves away.

semanticData.summary: Provides the root context for a Radix UI-based sheet (side panel/drawer) component.
semanticData.description: The "Sheet" component serves as the foundational wrapper for creating a "sheet" or "drawer" UI element, leveraging Radix UI's Dialog.Root primitive. It manages the overall open/closed state and accessibility, providing the necessary context for all nested sheet components. Developers use this as the top-level container to build interactive, dismissible side panels or full-screen overlays.

commonUseCases: Implementing side navigation menus or drawers.
Displaying detailed forms or supplementary information in a sliding panel.
Creating modal-like experiences that slide in from an edge instead of popping up.
Building mobile-specific filters or settings panels.

examples.code:
import { Sheet, SheetClose, SheetContent, SheetDescription, SheetFooter, SheetHeader, SheetTitle, SheetTrigger } from "./ui/sheet"; function ProfileSheet() { return ( Edit Profile Make changes to your profile here. Click save when you're done.
); }
examples.description: This example illustrates the basic structure of a Sheet component, demonstrating how to combine `Sheet` with `SheetTrigger`, `SheetContent`, `SheetHeader`, `SheetTitle`, `SheetDescription`, `SheetFooter`, and `SheetClose` to create a functional side panel for profile settings.

limitations: Inherits core limitations and configuration complexities of the underlying Radix UI Dialog primitive.
The component itself doesn't provide inherent visual styling; appearance is determined by Tailwind CSS classes applied within the associated sub-components like `SheetOverlay` and `SheetContent`.
Default sheet side behavior is `right`; custom side (top, left, bottom) must be explicitly passed to `SheetContent`.
bestPractices: Always use `Sheet` as the top-level container for any sheet implementation.
Combine `Sheet` with its sub-components (`SheetTrigger`, `SheetContent`, `SheetClose`, etc.) for a fully accessible and functional sheet experience.
Utilize the `open` and `onOpenChange` props on `Sheet` for controlled sheet behavior when programmatic control is needed.
For custom trigger elements, use `SheetTrigger` with `asChild` to properly wrap your element and maintain accessibility.
antiPatterns: Attempting to render `SheetContent` directly without nesting it under `Sheet` (which implies the `SheetPortal` and `SheetOverlay` components provided by this library).
Manually managing the sheet's open state without utilizing the `open` and `onOpenChange` props on `Sheet` or the provided `SheetTrigger` and `SheetClose` components.

semanticData.summary: Renders a button or element that toggles the open/closed state of the parent Sheet component.
semanticData.description: The SheetTrigger component serves as the interactive element that controls the visibility of an associated Sheet (dialog/drawer). It's a thin wrapper around Radix UI's Dialog.Trigger, inheriting all its capabilities and props. Developers use it to provide a clickable element (e.g., a button, icon) that, when activated, automatically opens the Sheet. It seamlessly integrates into the Sheet component system to manage the open/closed state.

commonUseCases: Opening a side navigation menu on mobile devices or smaller screens.
Displaying a filter panel that slides in from the side of a data table.
Triggering a form or information panel that appears as an overlay.
Implementing an 'Add to Cart' confirmation drawer.

examples.description: Demonstrates the basic usage of SheetTrigger with a custom Button component, using `asChild` to correctly pass props and behaviors for opening the Sheet.
Shows how to use SheetTrigger with an icon button to open a side navigation menu, specifying the sheet to slide in from the left using `side="left"` on `SheetContent`.

limitations: SheetTrigger does not directly expose props for controlling the Sheet's open/closed state. For programmatic control, manage the `open` prop on the `Sheet` (Root) component.
