semanticData.description: The DrawerTrigger component is a wrapper around Vaul's DrawerPrimitive.Trigger, designed to initiate the opening of a Drawer when clicked or activated. It acts as the interactive element that controls the drawer's visibility, typically a button or icon, and inherits all standard HTML element properties, ensuring seamless integration and accessibility. Developers use this to create the primary user interaction point for revealing drawer content.

commonUseCases: Opening a mobile navigation menu or sidebar.
Triggering a settings panel or configuration options from an icon.
Displaying a product detail view or item information from a list.
Invoking a form or filter options panel on user action.

examples.code:
import { Drawer, DrawerTrigger, DrawerContent, DrawerHeader, DrawerTitle, DrawerDescription, DrawerFooter, DrawerClose } from './drawer'; function MyDrawerExample() { return ( Welcome to the Drawer This is a flexible panel for additional content.

You can place any content here.

For example, a form, detailed information, or navigation links.

 ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic usage of DrawerTrigger within a complete Drawer setup. The DrawerTrigger wraps a standard HTML <button> (using 'asChild' to correctly pass props), which, when clicked, will open the associated DrawerContent. This illustrates how to integrate the trigger with other drawer components to create a functional UI pattern.

limitations: DrawerTrigger is primarily for user-initiated actions; it does not provide direct programmatic control over the drawer's open/closed state. For controlled state, manage the 'open' prop on the parent Drawer component.
Its functionality is dependent on being a child of a Drawer (or Drawer.Root) component from the 'vaul' library, meaning it cannot be used as a standalone trigger for other types of modals or panels.
bestPractices: Always wrap DrawerTrigger within a Drawer (or Drawer.Root) component to ensure proper context and functionality.
Pass standard button or anchor props (e.g., 'onClick', 'disabled', 'aria-label') directly to DrawerTrigger as it forwards them to the underlying primitive, enhancing accessibility.
Utilize the 'asChild' prop when wrapping a custom component or HTML element to correctly merge properties and maintain accessibility attributes from the primitive trigger.
Ensure the trigger's visual content clearly communicates its purpose, such as 'Open Menu' text or a recognizable icon.
antiPatterns: Using DrawerTrigger outside of a Drawer component hierarchy, as it relies on the DrawerRoot context to function correctly.
Attempting to programmatically control the drawer's open/close state directly through this component; use the Drawer component's 'open' prop or 'onOpenChange' callback for state management instead.
Placing multiple interactive elements directly inside DrawerTrigger without using 'asChild' appropriately, which can lead to nested interactive elements and accessibility issues.

semanticData.summary: Renders a drawer component's content and overlay outside the main DOM tree using a React Portal for correct layering and z-index management.
semanticData.description: This `DrawerPortal` component acts as a wrapper around `vaul`'s `DrawerPrimitive.Portal`. It leverages React Portals to render its children, typically the drawer's content and overlay, into a different DOM node (usually `document.body`). This mechanism is crucial for managing z-index, preventing clipping issues, and ensuring that the drawer components consistently appear on top of other page elements, regardless of their parent's styling or stacking context.

commonUseCases: Ensuring drawer components (like content and overlay) always render on top of all other page elements to prevent visual clipping.
Handling z-index issues when a drawer component is deeply nested within a complex DOM structure.
Centralizing the mounting point for modal-like UI elements to simplify z-index and event handling.

examples.description: This example, derived from the provided source, shows how `DrawerContent` internally utilizes `DrawerPortal` to ensure the drawer's content and overlay are rendered outside the main DOM tree. This is the primary intended usage pattern, where developers consume `DrawerContent` and `DrawerPortal` works behind the scenes to manage rendering location.

limitations: As a direct wrapper around `vaul`'s Portal, `DrawerPortal` provides no inherent visual styling or animation capabilities; these must be applied to its children.

It is a low-level component primarily designed for internal use within the `DrawerContent` in this specific UI library setup. Direct standalone usage by application developers is generally not required or recommended.
bestPractices: Rely on `DrawerContent` to implicitly use `DrawerPortal` as designed within this UI library for consistent and correct behavior.
Understand that `DrawerPortal` facilitates proper layering and z-index but does not contribute to the visual appearance or animation of the drawer itself.
antiPatterns: Directly using `DrawerPortal` as a standalone visual component; its purpose is purely for DOM rendering hierarchy, not visual presentation. It's intended to wrap `DrawerContent`.
Attempting to apply visual layout styles (e.g., width, height, position) directly to `DrawerPortal`, as it's a structural component for DOM insertion.

semanticData.summary: Renders a component that, when interacted with, closes the associated drawer.
semanticData.description: The DrawerClose component acts as a wrapper around Vaul's DrawerPrimitive.Close, providing a designated interactive element (e.g., a button) to dismiss an open drawer. It automatically handles the closing mechanism when clicked or activated, inheriting all standard DOM and DrawerPrimitive.Close props. This component is crucial for user experience, allowing users to explicitly close the drawer.

commonUseCases: Creating a close button inside the drawer header.
Adding an 'X' icon or text link within the drawer content to dismiss it.

examples.description: This example demonstrates placing DrawerClose components inside a DrawerContent and DrawerHeader. The first DrawerClose wraps a button with an 'X' icon, commonly used in headers. The second shows a standard button at the bottom of the drawer for closing.

limitations: Requires DrawerClose to be a descendant of DrawerPrimitive.Root (via Drawer component) to function correctly.
Does not provide any visual styling by default; styling must be applied via `className` or by wrapping another component with `asChild`.
Cannot be used to open the drawer; its sole purpose is to close it.
bestPractices: Always include at least one DrawerClose element within the DrawerContent for user convenience and accessibility.
Ensure the DrawerClose element is visually distinct and clearly indicates its purpose (e.g., using a cross icon or 'Close' text).
Consider adding `aria-label` to DrawerClose buttons for improved accessibility, especially for icon-only buttons.
antiPatterns: Placing DrawerClose outside of a DrawerContent without a clear visual association, leading to user confusion.
Using DrawerClose for actions other than closing the drawer, violating the principle of single responsibility.
Not providing visual feedback (e.g., a button style) for DrawerClose elements, making them undiscoverable.

semanticData.summary: A React component that provides a styled, animated overlay for a drawer, dimming the background when the drawer is open.
semanticData.description: The DrawerOverlay component renders a semi-transparent backdrop that covers the screen behind an open drawer. It visually dims the content below the drawer, enhancing focus on the drawer's content and providing a clear visual separation. This component automatically applies CSS for fixed positioning, background color, and fade-in/fade-out animations based on the drawer's state, while allowing for custom styling via the className prop.

commonUseCases: Providing a visual backdrop for a drawer or sheet component
Creating a modal-like experience where the background is dimmed
Enhancing user focus on drawer content by obscuring underlying elements

examples.description: This example shows the typical usage of DrawerOverlay. It is usually rendered automatically as a child of DrawerContent, so you don't explicitly import or use it unless you need to directly manipulate its properties (which is rare).

This demonstrates how to create a custom overlay component directly using Vaul's primitive, allowing for direct control and custom styling, such as a darker background and a blur effect, while retaining the base animation logic.

limitations: Relies on the `vaul` library's context for its state-driven animations, making it less useful as a standalone component without a `DrawerPrimitive.Root` or similar parent.
Its default styling uses Tailwind CSS classes (`fixed`, `inset-0`, `z-50`, etc.) and `cn` utility, requiring a compatible CSS setup for proper rendering and animation.
bestPractices: Nest DrawerOverlay within DrawerContent to ensure it's correctly positioned and animated relative to the drawer's state.
Utilize the `className` prop to extend or override default styles (e.g., changing background color, adding blur) while preserving its core functionality.
Ensure proper z-indexing if other fixed elements are present to avoid overlap issues with the overlay.
antiPatterns: Using DrawerOverlay independently without a parent DrawerPortal or DrawerContent, as it relies on the drawer's state and context for its behavior and animations.
Overriding essential positioning styles (fixed, inset-0, z-50) via `className` without understanding the implications, which can break the overlay's intended layout.

semanticData.summary: Renders the main content area of a drawer component, handling its positioning, sizing, and styling based on the drawer's direction.
semanticData.description: The DrawerContent component serves as the primary container for a drawer's visual and interactive elements, automatically positioning and sizing itself based on the drawer's direction (top, bottom, left, right). It applies comprehensive styling using Tailwind CSS, including rounded corners, borders, and a draggable handle for bottom/top drawers. This component simplifies presenting overlay content within a structured and styled container, allowing developers to easily populate a drawer with any desired UI.

commonUseCases: Displaying detailed information or settings panels as an overlay
Implementing dynamic navigation menus accessible from the edge of the screen
Presenting forms for data input without navigating away from the main view
Showing filter options for lists or search results

examples.code:
import { Drawer, DrawerTrigger, DrawerContent, DrawerHeader, DrawerTitle, DrawerDescription, DrawerFooter, DrawerClose } from "./drawer"; import { Button } from "./button"; // Assuming a Button component function MyDrawerComponent() { return ( Are you absolutely sure? This action cannot be undone.

This is the main content area of your drawer. You can put any React elements here.

); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to integrate DrawerContent within a Drawer and DrawerTrigger, populating it with a header, title, description, custom content, and footer with action buttons. It shows typical usage for a confirmation dialog or a detail view.

limitations: Relies heavily on Tailwind CSS for its default styling; custom CSS might require careful overrides.
The maximum height (max-h-[80vh]) is fixed by default; large amounts of content might require internal scrolling or careful design.
Its directional styling (data-[vaul-drawer-direction]) is determined by the parent DrawerPrimitive.Root from vaul, limiting direct control over positioning without changing the root configuration.
The visual "handle" for dragging is only shown for bottom drawer directions, not for top, left, or right by default in this component's styling.
bestPractices: Always wrap DrawerContent within a DrawerPortal to ensure correct overlay rendering and accessibility.
Utilize DrawerHeader, DrawerFooter, DrawerTitle, and DrawerDescription components within DrawerContent for structured and semantically rich content.
Ensure the content placed inside DrawerContent is responsive and fits within the defined max-h-[80vh] or other dimension constraints to prevent overflow issues.
Leverage the className prop for custom styling overrides while respecting the component's base styling provided by cn.
antiPatterns: Placing DrawerContent directly without DrawerPortal: This will cause the drawer content to not render correctly as an overlay, breaking its positioning and interaction.
Attempting to override fundamental vaul or direction-based styles directly without cn: Leads to inconsistent UI and potential conflicts with the component's internal styling logic.
Using DrawerContent for fixed, non-overlay content: It is designed for transient, overlay content, not for static page sections.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled header container for Vaul-based drawer components, handling padding and responsive text alignment.
semanticData.description: The DrawerHeader component provides a styled container for the top section of a drawer, typically used to house the DrawerTitle and DrawerDescription. It ensures consistent spacing, padding, and responsive text alignment based on the drawer's direction (e.g., centering text for bottom/top drawers). This component helps developers maintain a uniform look and feel across different drawer instances by abstracting common header styling.

commonUseCases: Displaying a title and description within a drawer
Organizing header content for a modal-like drawer
Providing a consistent top section for various drawer types (bottom, top, left, right)

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use DrawerHeader within a DrawerContent, typically alongside DrawerTitle and DrawerDescription, to create a well-structured header for a user profile editing drawer.

limitations: Primarily a presentational component; it does not manage drawer state or interactivity.
Its default styling relies heavily on the presence of a parent `DrawerContent` and its `data-vaul-drawer-direction` attribute for directional text alignment.
bestPractices: Always nest DrawerHeader directly inside DrawerContent.
Use DrawerTitle and DrawerDescription components within DrawerHeader for semantic and consistent typography.
Keep the content of the DrawerHeader concise and focused on summary information for the drawer's purpose.
Utilize the `className` prop for minor custom styling adjustments without altering the core layout properties.
Ensure any custom styling respects the `group-data` attributes for proper directional rendering.
antiPatterns: Placing complex interactive elements (e.g., forms, extensive navigation) directly within DrawerHeader; it's primarily for static header content.
Using DrawerHeader outside of a DrawerContent component, as its styling relies on parent `group-data-[vaul-drawer-direction]` classes.
Overriding core layout classes excessively, which may break the intended responsive behavior.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled container element for the footer section of a drawer component, automatically positioned at the bottom.
semanticData.description: The DrawerFooter component provides a dedicated, styled area at the bottom of a DrawerContent to house supplementary information or action buttons. It automatically positions itself at the bottom and applies default spacing, simplifying the layout of interactive elements or closing actions within a drawer. Developers use it to ensure a consistent look and feel for drawer footers across an application.

commonUseCases: Placing action buttons such as 'Save', 'Cancel', or 'Submit' at the bottom of a drawer.
Displaying disclaimers, legal text, or secondary information within a drawer.
Housing a dedicated 'Close' button for the drawer.

examples.code:
import { Drawer, DrawerContent, DrawerDescription, DrawerFooter, DrawerHeader, DrawerTitle, DrawerTrigger, DrawerClose } from "./drawer"; import { Button } from "./button"; function MyFormDrawer() { return ( Edit Profile Make changes to your profile here.

Your form fields go here...

 ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates using DrawerFooter to contain action buttons ('Save changes' and 'Cancel') at the bottom of a form within a drawer. The `mt-auto` styling ensures the footer is always pushed to the bottom, providing a clear call-to-action area for the user.

limitations: DrawerFooter is primarily a layout helper and does not inherently provide complex interactive logic beyond containing other components.
Its proper positioning relies on being a direct child of `DrawerContent` or a similar flex container that can utilize `mt-auto` effectively.
bestPractices: Always place primary actions relevant to the drawer's content within the footer.
Keep the footer content concise and focused on actions or critical secondary information.
Utilize other Drawer components like DrawerClose within the footer for consistent behavior and accessibility.
Pass additional styling via the `className` prop for custom adjustments without overriding core positioning.
antiPatterns: Using DrawerFooter for primary content or sections that are not logically part of a footer, which can lead to layout confusion.
Overriding its `mt-auto` (margin-top auto) or other essential positioning styles, which may break its intended bottom alignment.
Nesting large or complex components that are not intended for a footer within it.

semanticData.summary: Renders the accessible title for a vaul-based drawer component with default styling.
semanticData.description: The DrawerTitle component is responsible for rendering the primary heading or title within a DrawerContent component. It acts as a styled wrapper around vaul's DrawerPrimitive.Title, automatically applying default font styling (font-semibold, text-foreground) for consistent UI. This ensures accessibility by properly associating the title with the drawer's content, making it easier for users and assistive technologies to understand the drawer's purpose.

commonUseCases: Providing a clear heading for a modal-like drawer
Labeling the purpose of a side panel or sheet
Setting the title for a user settings or profile drawer

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use DrawerTitle within a DrawerHeader to set the main heading for a profile editing drawer. It's typically paired with DrawerDescription for additional context, providing a clear and accessible label for the drawer's purpose.

limitations: Primarily designed for use within DrawerHeader components; using it outside a DrawerContent context might not provide the intended accessible association or visual styling.
Its default styling is opinionated; extensive custom styling should be applied via the className prop or by wrapping it in a custom component.
bestPractices: Always nest DrawerTitle inside DrawerHeader for proper layout and semantic structure within the drawer.
Keep the title concise and descriptive of the drawer's primary function to aid user comprehension.
Pair with DrawerDescription when more context or a subtitle is needed, ensuring the title remains brief and to the point.
antiPatterns: Using DrawerTitle as a general heading element (e.g., h1 or h2) outside of a DrawerContent, as it relies on the vaul context for correct accessibility roles and styling specific to drawers.
Placing complex interactive elements or large blocks of text directly within the title, as it's intended for a concise primary label.

semanticData.summary: Renders an accessible, styled description for a drawer component, forwarding all vaul DrawerPrimitive.Description props.
semanticData.description: This component acts as a styled wrapper around vaul's DrawerPrimitive.Description. Its primary purpose is to provide an accessible description for the content within a drawer, enhancing user experience for screen readers and assistive technologies. It applies default muted-foreground styling and a small font size, while allowing further customization via the className prop.

commonUseCases: Providing a brief explanation or context for the drawer's content
Improving accessibility by associating descriptive text with the drawer's main title or content
Displaying secondary information related to the drawer's primary purpose

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use DrawerDescription within a DrawerHeader to provide a clear, concise explanation of the drawer's purpose ("Edit Profile"). It enhances user understanding and accessibility.

limitations: Primarily a presentational component for text; not intended for complex interactive content.
Its default styling is small and muted; extensive custom styling might override its intended descriptive purpose.
bestPractices: Keep the description concise and to the point.
Use it in conjunction with DrawerTitle to provide clear context for the drawer.
Ensure the text meaningfully adds information for users, especially those using screen readers.
antiPatterns: Using it for primary content or lengthy paragraphs; it's designed for concise descriptions.
Placing interactive elements or complex layouts inside, as it's primarily a text container.
Omitting it when the drawer's purpose isn't immediately clear from the title.

semanticData.summary: Provides context for Radix UI tooltips, allowing global configuration of settings like delay duration for all tooltips within its scope.
semanticData.description: This component wraps the Radix-ui TooltipPrimitive.Provider, serving as the necessary context provider for all tooltip components within its scope. It allows for global configuration of tooltip behavior, such as the delayDuration before a tooltip appears, ensuring a consistent user experience across multiple tooltips. Developers use it to initialize and manage tooltip states and settings.

commonUseCases: Initializing a Radix UI tooltip system in a React application
Setting a consistent delay for all tooltips within a specific application section
Providing global tooltip accessibility features

examples.description: Demonstrates the minimal setup required to render a functional tooltip, showing TooltipProvider at the root of the tooltip usage.
Shows how to override the default delayDuration for a specific section of the application, making tooltips appear almost instantly.

limitations: Only one TooltipProvider is typically needed per logical group of tooltips. While nesting is possible, it might lead to unexpected behavior if not carefully managed regarding prop inheritance/overrides.
delayDuration set on a TooltipProvider applies globally to all tooltips within its scope; it cannot be overridden on individual Tooltip components without another TooltipProvider wrapping them.
bestPractices: Place TooltipProvider high in your application's component tree (e.g., in _app.tsx or a top-level layout) to ensure all tooltips have access to the necessary context.
Utilize the delayDuration prop to fine-tune the user experience, balancing immediate feedback with avoiding intrusive pop-ups.
Ensure all Tooltip related components (Root, Trigger, Content) are descendants of a TooltipProvider.
antiPatterns: Not wrapping Tooltip and other related components with TooltipProvider: This will cause tooltips to not function correctly as they rely on the context provided by TooltipProvider.

Placing TooltipProvider deep within the component tree unnecessarily: For most applications, it's best placed higher up to provide context to all potential tooltips, simplifying state management and avoiding redundant providers.

semanticData.summary: A UI component wrapping Radix UI's Tooltip.Root, automatically including the TooltipProvider for basic tooltip functionality.
semanticData.description: The Tooltip component serves as the root element for a Radix UI-based tooltip, simplifying its setup by automatically incorporating the TooltipProvider internally. It provides the foundational structure for displaying supplementary information on hover or focus, abstracting away the need to manually add TooltipProvider in the component tree. This makes it easier to manage tooltip states and ensure consistent behavior across the application.

commonUseCases: Displaying short, contextual information on hover over an interactive element.
Providing additional details for icons or buttons that have limited space for text.
Enhancing user experience by giving immediate feedback or explanation for UI elements.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to create a basic tooltip. The Tooltip component serves as the root, wrapping TooltipTrigger (which makes the Button interactive for the tooltip) and TooltipContent which holds the text to be displayed. The asChild prop on TooltipTrigger ensures the trigger styles are applied correctly to the button.

limitations: Tooltips are primarily for non-essential, supplementary information; they should not be the sole means of conveying critical details.
Content within tooltips is not easily selectable or copyable, so avoid putting text that users might need to interact with.

The TooltipProvider's delayDuration is set to 0 by default internally, which might not be suitable for all use cases (e.g., complex hover effects where a slight delay is desired to prevent accidental tooltips). For custom delays, wrap with a TooltipProvider explicitly.
bestPractices: Keep tooltip content concise and to the point, typically a single sentence or a few words.
Always pair Tooltip with TooltipTrigger and TooltipContent for a complete and functional tooltip.
Ensure the trigger element provides sufficient visual cues that it has a tooltip.
Consider the sideOffset on TooltipContent for optimal positioning relative to the trigger to prevent content overlap.
antiPatterns: Using tooltips for critical information that requires user interaction or long-form content, as they disappear easily and are not keyboard navigable for content interaction.
Nesting multiple tooltips without a clear hierarchy, leading to a confusing user experience.
Placing interactive elements (buttons, links, forms) inside a tooltip, as they are not easily accessible or interactive.

semanticData.summary: Renders the interactive element that triggers the display of a Radix UI tooltip.
semanticData.description: The TooltipTrigger component serves as a wrapper around Radix UI's TooltipPrimitive.Trigger, providing the interactive element (e.g., a button, icon) that, when hovered or focused, activates and displays its associated tooltip content. It seamlessly forwards all standard HTML and React props to the underlying Radix trigger, making it easy to integrate while allowing for custom styling and behavior.

commonUseCases: Providing explanatory text for icons or buttons on hover.
Displaying additional information for form fields or data points.
Showing names or roles when hovering over avatars.

examples.description: Demonstrates how to use TooltipTrigger to make a button trigger a tooltip. The `asChild` prop ensures the trigger's behavior is applied to the button without rendering an extra DOM element.
Shows applying TooltipTrigger directly to an icon component, providing a tooltip on hover for quick contextual help.

limitations: It is primarily a pass-through component for Radix UI's TooltipPrimitive.Trigger, so its direct functional limitations are those inherited from the underlying Radix component.
Does not manage the tooltip's open/close state directly; this is handled by the parent Tooltip (Radix Root) component.
Cannot be used in isolation; it requires being a child of a Tooltip component (or TooltipPrimitive.Root).
bestPractices: Ensure the content within TooltipTrigger is simple and clearly indicates its purpose (e.g., an icon, a short text label).
For accessibility, provide a meaningful `aria-label` or `title` attribute on the element wrapped by TooltipTrigger if the visual content isn't self-explanatory.
Combine with TooltipContent to ensure a consistent and accessible tooltip experience.
antiPatterns: Nesting TooltipTrigger directly inside another TooltipTrigger, which can lead to unpredictable behavior or accessibility issues.
Using TooltipTrigger for critical information that needs to be permanently visible, as tooltips are ephemeral and not accessible to all users without explicit interaction.
Applying complex interactive elements as children of TooltipTrigger that require focus management within the tooltip itself, as this can conflict with the tooltip's default focus behavior.

semanticData.summary: Renders and styles the content area of a tooltip, including animation, positioning, and an optional arrow, leveraging Radix UI's primitives.
semanticData.description: The TooltipContent component serves as the visual container for the actual tooltip message, building upon Radix UI's `TooltipPrimitive.Content`. It applies a set of default Tailwind CSS classes for consistent styling, including animations for enter/exit, positioning adjustments, and a visually integrated arrow. This component handles portal rendering to ensure the tooltip appears correctly over other elements, solving the problem of overlay positioning and styling without manual intervention.

commonUseCases: Displaying a short descriptive text when hovering over an icon or button
Providing additional context for form fields or interactive elements
Showing full text for truncated labels or names upon user interaction

examples.description: Basic usage demonstrating how to combine `Tooltip`, `TooltipTrigger`, and `TooltipContent` to create a functional tooltip. The `sideOffset` prop is used to slightly distance the content from the trigger.
Example showing a tooltip attached to an icon, providing a brief explanation for a feature. The `className` prop is used to customize the max-width and text wrapping of the tooltip content.

limitations: Not suitable for displaying complex interactive elements or forms within the tooltip itself.
Performance might be affected if an excessive number of tooltips are rendered simultaneously, though Radix UI handles much of the optimization.
The default styling provided is opinionated; significant visual changes may require custom CSS that overrides the utility classes.
bestPractices: Keep tooltip content concise and to the point to avoid cluttering the UI.
Utilize the `sideOffset` prop to fine-tune the tooltip's distance from its trigger for better visual alignment.
Ensure the content is purely informative and non-interactive to maintain accessibility standards and expected tooltip behavior.
Leverage the `className` prop for custom styling if default styles are insufficient, but be mindful of overriding animation classes.
antiPatterns: Using TooltipContent to display large blocks of text or complex layouts, as it's designed for brief, contextual information.
Embedding interactive elements (like buttons or input fields) directly within the tooltip content, as these can interfere with accessibility and user experience.
Overriding core styling without understanding the Radix UI primitives, potentially breaking animations or positioning.

semanticData.summary: Defines a set of Tailwind CSS class variants for an Alert component using class-variance-authority.
semanticData.description: The alertVariants constant utilizes class-variance-authority (cva) to define the base styles and appearance variations for an Alert component. It provides a structured way to apply consistent Tailwind CSS classes for different alert types, such as 'default' and 'destructive', dynamically handling layout and color based on the chosen variant. This allows developers to easily style alerts with a clean, prop-driven interface, ensuring consistent UI across the application.

commonUseCases: Creating visually distinct alert messages (e.g., info, error, success).
Implementing a reusable Alert component with customizable styling.
Standardizing the look and feel of notifications and status messages.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how alertVariants is used internally by an Alert React component to apply dynamic Tailwind CSS classes based on the 'variant' prop. It showcases both the default and destructive alert styles, illustrating how the component consumes the variant definition to render different visual states.

limitations: Requires class-variance-authority and Tailwind CSS to function correctly.
Relies on specific HTML structure (e.g., has-[>svg]) for icon positioning, which needs to be maintained in the Alert component.
Only supports the predefined 'variant' options ('default', 'destructive'); custom styles beyond these must be applied via 'className' prop or by extending alertVariants.
bestPractices: Always use the 'variant' prop with the Alert component to leverage the predefined styles.
Extend alertVariants with new types or custom styles using cn if highly specialized, non-standard variants are needed, rather than bypassing it.
Ensure the base styles in cva are generic enough to apply to all variants, with variant-specific overrides handling differences.
antiPatterns: Directly applying styles that should be managed by alertVariants to the Alert component, leading to style conflicts or inconsistencies.
Creating redundant cva definitions for similar component variants instead of extending or reusing alertVariants where applicable.

semanticData.summary: Creates a styled, accessible alert component with customizable variants for displaying important messages.
semanticData.description: This React component renders a visually distinct alert message, designed to draw user attention to important information. It supports different visual "variants" (e.g., "default", "destructive") for conveying various severities or types of messages, leveraging `class-variance-authority` for flexible styling. Intended to be used with `AlertTitle` and `AlertDescription` for structured content, it also includes ARIA `role="alert"` for accessibility.

commonUseCases: Displaying success or error messages to users
Showing warnings or informational notices
Providing context-specific feedback within a UI
Notifying users about critical system events

examples.description: Demonstrates a standard informational alert with a title and description, using the default styling to convey general information.
Shows how to use the `destructive` variant for error messages, including a React icon for enhanced visual emphasis and clarity about the error type.

limitations: Primarily a presentational component; it does not include built-in state management for dismissal, complex interactions, or dynamic content loading.
Relies on companion components (`AlertTitle`, `AlertDescription`) for structured content, requiring them to be nested directly within the Alert.
Styling is opinionated by default through `cva` variants, requiring the use of the `className` prop or direct theme overrides for significant visual changes beyond the defined variants.
bestPractices: Always provide a clear, concise AlertTitle for a summary and detailed information in AlertDescription.
Utilize the `variant` prop to visually communicate the message's urgency or type (e.g., `destructive` for errors, `default` for general info).
Ensure alerts are dismissible if they are not persistently relevant or are blocking user interaction.
Position alerts strategically so they are visible but don't disrupt user flow unnecessarily.
Pair with an icon inside the Alert component for enhanced visual recognition of the alert type (e.g., a warning icon for destructive alerts).
antiPatterns: Using Alert for purely decorative purposes without meaningful content, as it's semantically an alert and can interfere with accessibility tools.
Overusing alerts, leading to "alert fatigue" where users ignore important messages or dismiss them without reading.
Placing complex interactive elements (like forms or navigation) directly inside AlertDescription, as its purpose is for static text and can lead to poor UX.

semanticData.summary: Renders a semantically styled title for an Alert component, providing a distinct heading for the alert message.
semanticData.description: The AlertTitle component is a dedicated sub-component of the Alert UI element. It's responsible for displaying the main heading or title of an alert message. It automatically applies specific styling, including font weight, text truncation for single lines, and grid column positioning, ensuring it integrates seamlessly within the Alert's layout. This helps provide clear, concise context to the user about the alert's purpose.

commonUseCases: Providing a headline for a success or error message within an Alert.
Structuring alert content with a clear, concise title.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use AlertTitle within an Alert component to provide a clear, styled heading. It shows the typical co-location with AlertDescription for a complete alert message.

limitations: Primarily designed for single-line titles due to line-clamp-1 styling.
Its layout is tightly coupled with the Alert component's internal CSS Grid structure; not suitable for independent use.
bestPractices: Always use AlertTitle as a direct child of the Alert component to ensure correct styling and layout.
Keep the title concise and to the point, as it's designed for single-line headings.
Pair AlertTitle with AlertDescription for more detailed content.
antiPatterns: Using AlertTitle outside of an Alert component: It relies on the Alert's grid layout for proper positioning and styling, appearing malformed if used standalone.
Placing multi-paragraph or lengthy text directly inside AlertTitle: The line-clamp-1 styling will truncate content, leading to information loss.

semanticData.summary: Renders the primary descriptive content area for an Alert component, providing styled text for detailed messages.
semanticData.description: AlertDescription is a React component designed to display the detailed message or descriptive content within an Alert UI element. It automatically applies appropriate styling for muted text and line-height, ensuring the message is clearly readable and visually distinct from the alert's title. This component helps structure alert messages, making them accessible and maintainable.

commonUseCases: Displaying detailed error explanations within a 'destructive' Alert
Providing additional context or instructions for a success message
Showing warning details that accompany an alert title
Presenting informational details below a concise alert title

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of AlertDescription nested within an Alert component, alongside an AlertTitle, to display a standard informational message with structured content using paragraphs and a code snippet.

limitations: Primarily intended for text-based descriptive content; complex interactive elements or very dynamic content might require custom rendering within the Alert.
Relies on the parent Alert component and its associated CSS for correct visual presentation and layout within the alert structure.
While it accepts any React.ComponentProps<'div'>, its default styling is optimized for text content, so visual results for highly custom children might vary.
bestPractices: Always nest AlertDescription within an Alert component for correct styling and accessibility roles.
Use it in conjunction with AlertTitle to provide a clear hierarchy for alert messages, with the title summarizing and the description providing details.
Keep the content concise and focused on the key information relevant to the user's current context.

Utilize standard HTML tags like

inside AlertDescription for block-level text to benefit from its default styling for paragraphs.
antiPatterns: Using AlertDescription as a standalone component without an Alert parent, as it relies on the parent's context for proper styling and layout.
Placing highly interactive elements (like complex forms or multiple buttons) directly within AlertDescription, as its primary purpose is for static descriptive text.
Adding excessive, lengthy content that exceeds 2-3 sentences, which can make the alert difficult to read.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled and accessible toggle switch UI component based on Radix UI's primitive.
semanticData.description: This Switch component provides a visually appealing and accessible toggle control, leveraging Radix UI's `SwitchPrimitive` for core functionality and utility classes for flexible styling. It allows users to easily toggle between two states (on/off, checked/unchecked), making it ideal for boolean inputs in forms or settings. The component comes with built-in accessibility features and supports custom styling via the `className` prop.

commonUseCases: Toggling application settings like dark mode or notifications
Controlling feature flags within an application
Representing boolean inputs in forms (e.g., 'Remember me')
Switching between display modes or options on a dashboard

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use the `Switch` component to control a boolean state, such as enabling or disabling notifications. It shows external state management using `useState`, linking the switch to a label via `id` and `htmlFor`, and handling state changes with `onCheckedChange`.

limitations: Designed specifically for boolean (on/off) states; not suitable for selecting multiple options or values from a range.
Relies on Radix UI for core functionality and expects a compatible CSS setup (e.g., Tailwind CSS) for its predefined styles.
The visual appearance is tightly coupled with the provided Tailwind CSS classes; significant visual customization may require overriding or extending these classes.
bestPractices: Always associate the Switch with a clear `label` element using `id` and `htmlFor` for improved accessibility and user experience.
Manage the `checked` state externally using React's `useState` or a form library to maintain control over component state.
Utilize the `onCheckedChange` prop to react to state changes and update application logic or external state.
Ensure sufficient contrast for all states (checked, unchecked, disabled, focus) to meet accessibility guidelines.
antiPatterns: Using for multi-state selection where a radio group or dropdown would be more appropriate, as a switch is strictly binary.
Omitting an associated label, which impairs accessibility for screen reader users and can be confusing for sighted users.
Applying complex state logic directly within the component; external state management is preferred for clarity and testability.

codeMetadata.name: Calendar
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof DayPicker> & { buttonVariant?: React.ComponentProps<typeof Button>["variant"] }): any

semanticData.summary: Wraps `react-day-picker` to provide a highly customizable and styled calendar component with enhanced accessibility and theming, designed for date selection in UI.
semanticData.description: This Calendar component is a wrapper around `react-day-picker`, providing a pre-styled and opinionated date picker solution for web applications. It leverages Tailwind CSS and custom UI components to offer a consistent look and feel, while exposing most of `DayPicker`'s props for flexible configuration. It solves the problem of integrating a fully-featured, accessible, and theme-compliant calendar into applications without extensive manual styling.

commonUseCases: Selecting a single date for a form field
Picking a date range for booking systems or reports
Displaying a calendar view for event management
Implementing date-based filtering in data tables

examples.description: Demonstrates how to use the `Calendar` component for selecting a single date, managing the selected date state using React's `useState` hook.
Shows how to configure the calendar for selecting a date range, useful for booking or scheduling features. It also demonstrates how to display the selected range.
Illustrates how to change the visual style of the month navigation buttons by using the `buttonVariant` prop, aligning them with other UI buttons.

limitations: Relies heavily on Tailwind CSS for styling; using it in a project without Tailwind might require significant CSS overrides.
While customizable, it's primarily a date picker; complex scheduling UI beyond basic date selection might require a different library.
The custom `buttonVariant` only applies to the navigation buttons; the individual day buttons are styled by `CalendarDayButton` and are not directly controlled by this prop.
bestPractices: Utilize the `buttonVariant` prop to match the calendar's navigation buttons with your application's button styling.
Leverage the `classNames` and `components` props for granular styling and structural overrides, respectively, to maintain consistency.
Pass through standard `react-day-picker` props like `mode` (e.g., "single", "multiple", "range") and `selected` to manage date selection state effectively.
Ensure proper state management for selected dates when integrating into forms, typically using `useState` or a form library.
antiPatterns: Overriding default `classNames` or `components` without understanding the underlying `react-day-picker` structure, which might break layout or accessibility.
Directly manipulating the DOM elements rendered by `Calendar` instead of using its props for customization, leading to brittle code.
Using it for very complex scheduling or resource management tasks that require more advanced features than a pure date picker provides, where a more specialized library might be better suited.

semanticData.summary: Custom React component for rendering and styling individual day buttons within a react-day-picker calendar, applying dynamic styles based on day modifiers.
semanticData.description: The CalendarDayButton component serves as a highly customizable render prop for individual day cells within a react-day-picker calendar. It takes the default DayButton properties, applying extensive dynamic styling via Tailwind CSS based on day modifiers (e.g., selected, focused, part of a range) and manages focus for improved keyboard navigation. This component solves the problem of visually representing various day states in a calendar, enhancing user experience and allowing for a branded aesthetic.

commonUseCases: Customizing the visual appearance of individual days in a calendar, such as styling for selected dates, date ranges, or today's date.
Implementing custom focus management for calendar day cells to enhance accessibility and keyboard navigation.
Integrating a custom button component for calendar days that aligns with a design system's existing button styles.

examples.description: This example shows how CalendarDayButton is passed to the "components" prop of "react-day-picker". This tells DayPicker to use our custom component for rendering each day's button instead of its default one, allowing for comprehensive custom styling and behavior.

limitations: This component is tightly coupled with "react-day-picker" and cannot be used independently for general-purpose buttons or date selections not managed by "react-day-picker".
Relies heavily on a specific Tailwind CSS setup and utility classes ('cn'), which might require adjustments if integrated into a project with a different styling methodology.

Complex custom date logic beyond basic visual state (e.g., intricate holiday highlighting) might still require pre-processing before being passed to "modifiers" or handled by the parent Calendar component.
bestPractices: Leverage the "modifiers" prop provided by react-day-picker to apply conditional styling efficiently and accurately.
Use 'cn' (or a similar utility) for conditionally applying Tailwind CSS classes to maintain readability and avoid verbose string concatenations.
Ensure accessibility by correctly handling focus (as demonstrated with 'useRef' and 'useEffect') and semantic HTML attributes.
Keep styling logic focused on visual presentation rather than re-implementing date selection logic.
antiPatterns: Implementing complex date logic or business rules directly within CalendarDayButton; this logic should primarily reside in the parent Calendar component or react-day-picker's props.
Overriding essential "modifiers" props or "data-*" attributes in a way that breaks react-day-picker's internal state management or accessibility.
Adding excessive, non-styling related functionality to the button that could lead to performance issues or violate the single responsibility principle.

semanticData.summary: Renders the main navigation container for a breadcrumb trail.
semanticData.description: The `Breadcrumb` component serves as the root container for a breadcrumb navigation system. It semantically wraps a list of hierarchical links, providing context to the user's current location within an application or website. It is built upon a standard HTML `nav` element, ensuring proper accessibility with an `aria-label`.

commonUseCases: Displaying the current page's location within a site's hierarchy
Providing clear navigation paths for users in complex applications
Enhancing user experience by indicating depth in nested content

examples.code:
import { Breadcrumb, BreadcrumbEllipsis, BreadcrumbItem, BreadcrumbLink, BreadcrumbList, BreadcrumbPage, BreadcrumbSeparator } from './breadcrumb';

function MyPage() {
  return (
    <Breadcrumb>
      <BreadcrumbList>
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbLink href="/">Home</BreadcrumbLink>
        </BreadcrumbItem>
        <BreadcrumbSeparator />
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbLink href="/components">Components</BreadcrumbLink>
        </BreadcrumbItem>
        <BreadcrumbSeparator />
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbEllipsis />
        </BreadcrumbItem>
        <BreadcrumbSeparator />
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbLink href="/components/ui">UI Library</BreadcrumbLink>
        </BreadcrumbItem>
        <BreadcrumbSeparator />
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbPage>Breadcrumb</BreadcrumbPage>
        </BreadcrumbItem>
      </BreadcrumbList>
    </Breadcrumb>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates a typical breadcrumb navigation, showing a hierarchical path from 'Home' to 'Breadcrumb'. It includes `BreadcrumbLink` for clickable items, `BreadcrumbPage` for the current page, and `BreadcrumbSeparator` for visual distinction. `BreadcrumbEllipsis` is also included to show how to handle omitted intermediate steps.

limitations: The `Breadcrumb` component itself provides only the `nav` wrapper; its full functionality and appearance depend on the correct nesting and usage of its sibling components (`BreadcrumbList`, `BreadcrumbItem`, etc.).
It primarily focuses on visual presentation and accessibility attributes; complex routing logic must be handled externally by the application.
Styling relies heavily on the `cn` utility and Tailwind CSS classes; customization beyond these requires overriding predefined styles.
bestPractices: Always nest `BreadcrumbList` and `BreadcrumbItem` components within `Breadcrumb` for correct structure and styling.
Ensure the final item in the breadcrumb path uses `BreadcrumbPage` to correctly indicate the current page.
Utilize `BreadcrumbLink` for all clickable elements to maintain consistent styling and behavior.
Use `BreadcrumbSeparator` between items to visually separate them, usually with an arrow or slash.
antiPatterns: Using `Breadcrumb` for non-hierarchical navigation elements; it's specifically for path-like structures.
Placing non-breadcrumb related content directly inside `Breadcrumb` without using `BreadcrumbList` or `BreadcrumbItem`.
Omitting the `aria-label` or providing a non-descriptive one, which impairs accessibility for screen reader users.

semanticData.summary: Renders an ordered list (`<ol>`) container for breadcrumb navigation items, handling layout and basic styling.
semanticData.description: The "BreadcrumbList" component serves as the ordered list container for all "BreadcrumbItem" components within a breadcrumb navigation. It provides the necessary flexbox layout and basic styling to arrange breadcrumb links and pages horizontally, ensuring a consistent visual and structural foundation for site navigation trails. This component is crucial for visually representing the user's location within a hierarchical structure.

commonUseCases: Structuring a hierarchical navigation path on a web page
Creating a visual representation of the user's current location within a site
Implementing accessible breadcrumb trails for improved UX
Displaying dynamic navigation based on content hierarchy

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic structure of a breadcrumb trail. 'BreadcrumbList' acts as the container for 'BreadcrumbItem' components, which in turn hold 'BreadcrumbLink' or 'BreadcrumbPage' elements, separated by 'BreadcrumbSeparator'. This setup provides a complete and semantically correct navigation path.

limitations: Primarily a structural and styling component; it does not handle navigation logic, routing, or state management directly.
Relies heavily on its sibling components ('BreadcrumbItem', 'BreadcrumbLink', etc.) for full functionality and meaningful content.
Default styling is opinionated (flexbox, gap, text sizes) and may require overrides for highly custom designs.
bestPractices:
Always nest 'BreadcrumbList' inside a 'Breadcrumb' component for correct semantic structure (
    ...
) and accessibility.
Use 'BreadcrumbItem' as direct children to ensure proper spacing and alignment, leveraging the component's designed layout.
Keep the number of breadcrumb items manageable to prevent visual clutter and improve readability, especially on mobile devices.
antiPatterns: Using non-BreadcrumbItem children directly: This can break the intended layout, styling, and accessibility of the breadcrumb trail.
Placing BreadcrumbList outside a Breadcrumb component: While it functions, it loses the semantic '<nav>' context and ARIA attributes provided by the parent.
Overloading with too many items: Can lead to line wrapping or poor readability on smaller screens.

semanticData.summary: Renders a list item element (<li>) specifically for a single item within a breadcrumb navigation component.
semanticData.description: The BreadcrumbItem component serves as a structural wrapper for individual items within a breadcrumb navigation list. It is designed to be used as a child of BreadcrumbList and typically contains BreadcrumbLink or BreadcrumbPage components, along with optional BreadcrumbSeparator elements. This component ensures proper styling and accessibility attributes for each segment of the navigational path.

commonUseCases: Defining each step or page in a hierarchical navigation path
Structuring a breadcrumb trail in a user interface
Containing links or plain text labels within a breadcrumb

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of BreadcrumbItem within a Breadcrumb and BreadcrumbList structure. It shows how it wraps BreadcrumbLink and BreadcrumbPage components, separated by BreadcrumbSeparator, to form a complete navigation path.

limitations: BreadcrumbItem itself is not interactive; its children (like BreadcrumbLink) provide the interactive functionality.
It inherits standard HTML `<li>` element behavior, so custom styles should be applied carefully to maintain consistency with the breadcrumb system.
bestPractices: Always use BreadcrumbItem as a direct child of BreadcrumbList.
Nest BreadcrumbLink or BreadcrumbPage components inside BreadcrumbItem to provide interactive or current page indicators.
Include BreadcrumbSeparator components between BreadcrumbItem instances for visual separation, typically after each item except the last one.
antiPatterns: Using BreadcrumbItem outside of a BreadcrumbList: It's designed to be a direct child of BreadcrumbList, otherwise, it loses its contextual styling and accessibility role.
Placing non-breadcrumb related content directly inside BreadcrumbItem without proper wrapping: Content should typically be wrapped by BreadcrumbLink or BreadcrumbPage for correct semantics.
Applying interactive handlers directly to BreadcrumbItem when interaction is expected on its children: Interaction should be handled by BreadcrumbLink or other interactive children.

semanticData.summary: Renders a link within a breadcrumb navigation, optionally acting as a child for composition with other components.
semanticData.description: BreadcrumbLink is a React component designed to represent a clickable link within a breadcrumb navigation path. It accepts standard HTML anchor tag props and an optional 'asChild' prop. When 'asChild' is true, it leverages Radix UI's Slot primitive to pass its props to a child component, enabling highly flexible composition and styling while maintaining accessibility.

commonUseCases: Creating clickable items in a breadcrumb trail
Linking to previous pages or sections within a website's hierarchy
Allowing custom component rendering within a breadcrumb link while preserving styling and accessibility

examples.description: Demonstrates the typical usage of BreadcrumbLink to create a standard <a> element for navigation within a breadcrumb.

Shows how to use BreadcrumbLink with asChild to compose with a router's Link component (e.g., Next.js or React Router), ensuring BreadcrumbLink's styling and accessibility props are passed down, while the Link handles the actual routing.

limitations: When asChild is used, the responsibility for rendering the underlying HTML element (e.g., <a>, <span>) and handling its behavior (e.g., navigation) falls entirely to the child component provided. BreadcrumbLink only passes props and applies styling in this scenario.
bestPractices: Always ensure the href prop is provided for standard links, or that the asChild component properly handles navigation.
Use asChild when integrating with routing libraries (like Next.js Link or React Router Link) to prevent nested <a> tags and leverage the router's client-side navigation.
Ensure the text content of the link is descriptive and concise for accessibility.
antiPatterns: Nesting BreadcrumbLink directly inside another interactive element (e.g., another <a> tag or button), as this creates invalid HTML and accessibility issues; use asChild if you need to wrap a custom interactive component.
Not providing a meaningful href when asChild is false, making the link non-functional.

semanticData.summary: Renders the non-interactive, current page item within a breadcrumb navigation trail.
semanticData.description: The BreadcrumbPage component is used to display the final, active page in a breadcrumb navigation. Unlike BreadcrumbLink, it is non-interactive and semantically marked as "aria-current=page" and "aria-disabled=true" to indicate the user's current location, ensuring proper accessibility. It provides clear visual styling for the current page without allowing navigation, solving the problem of clearly indicating the user's position within a website hierarchy.

commonUseCases: Displaying the final, current page in a website's breadcrumb navigation.
Indicating the user's current location within a multi-level section of an application.

examples.code: import {Breadcrumb,BreadcrumbList,BreadcrumbItem,BreadcrumbLink,BreadcrumbSeparator,BreadcrumbPage,} from "@repo/web/components/ui/breadcrumb";function MyComponent() {return (<Breadcrumb><BreadcrumbList><BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbLink href="/">Home</BreadcrumbLink></BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbSeparator /><BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbLink href="/products">Products</BreadcrumbLink></BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbSeparator /><BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbPage>Product Details</BreadcrumbPage></BreadcrumbItem></BreadcrumbList></Breadcrumb>);}
examples.description: This example demonstrates a typical breadcrumb structure where "Product Details" is the current, active page. BreadcrumbPage is correctly used as the final, non-interactive element in the trail, visually and semantically indicating the user's current location.

limitations: Cannot be made interactive or clickable; it's designed specifically for displaying the current, non-navigable page.
Only suitable for the final element in a breadcrumb trail to maintain proper navigation semantics and user experience.
bestPractices: Always position BreadcrumbPage as the final element within a BreadcrumbList to accurately reflect the current location.
Ensure no interactive handlers (like onClick) are directly applied to BreadcrumbPage, as it is intentionally disabled for accessibility and semantic correctness.
antiPatterns: Using BreadcrumbPage for a clickable item: This component is explicitly non-interactive; use BreadcrumbLink if the item should lead to another page.
Placing BreadcrumbPage in the middle of a breadcrumb trail: It should always be the last item, representing the destination page, not an intermediate step.

semanticData.summary: Renders a decorative separator element between breadcrumb items, defaulting to a right arrow icon.
semanticData.description: The BreadcrumbSeparator component is designed to visually divide individual items within a breadcrumb navigation trail. By default, it renders a 'ChevronRight' icon, but it can be customized with any child element. It helps to visually guide users through the hierarchy of pages and maintains proper accessibility roles by being marked as purely decorative.

commonUseCases: Separating BreadcrumbItem components within a BreadcrumbList
Creating a standard visual flow for navigation paths

examples.code: import {Breadcrumb,BreadcrumbList,BreadcrumbItem,BreadcrumbLink,BreadcrumbPage,BreadcrumbSeparator} from "./breadcrumb";function MyPage(){return(<Breadcrumb><BreadcrumbList><BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbLink href="/">Home</BreadcrumbLink></BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbSeparator /><BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbLink href="/docs">Docs</BreadcrumbLink></BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbSeparator /><BreadcrumbItem><BreadcrumbPage>Components</BreadcrumbPage></BreadcrumbItem></BreadcrumbList></Breadcrumb>);}
examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of BreadcrumbSeparator to visually separate BreadcrumbLink and BreadcrumbPage components within a Breadcrumb navigation structure. The default ChevronRight icon will be rendered between "Home" and "Docs", and between "Docs" and "Components".

limitations: Intended for use exclusively within Breadcrumb components; its styles and accessibility attributes are tailored for this context
Not designed to be an interactive element or carry semantic meaning beyond visual separation
bestPractices: Always place BreadcrumbSeparator between BreadcrumbItem components within a BreadcrumbList for correct structure and styling
Leverage the default ChevronRight icon for consistency unless a specific design requires a different separator
Ensure custom children used as separators are also purely decorative to maintain accessibility standards
antiPatterns: Using BreadcrumbSeparator as an interactive element or assigning click handlers, as it's designed to be purely decorative (role="presentation")
Placing it directly next to BreadcrumbLink or BreadcrumbPage without an intervening BreadcrumbItem, which might break the expected component structure and styling

semanticData.summary: Renders an ellipsis icon and screen reader text within a breadcrumb to indicate truncated or hidden navigation items.
semanticData.description: The BreadcrumbEllipsis component serves as a visual indicator within a breadcrumb trail, signifying that there are hidden or truncated items. It renders a 'MoreHorizontal' icon along with screen-reader-only text to enhance accessibility. This component helps manage space in long navigation paths by providing a clear cue that more items can be revealed, improving user experience on various screen sizes.

commonUseCases: Implementing responsive breadcrumbs that truncate long paths on smaller screens
Providing a visual cue for expandable sections in a breadcrumb navigation
Creating accessible breadcrumb patterns where hidden items are still discoverable

examples.code:
import { Breadcrumb, BreadcrumbList, BreadcrumbItem, BreadcrumbLink, BreadcrumbSeparator, BreadcrumbEllipsis } from './ui/breadcrumb';

function MyPageBreadcrumb() {
  return (
    <Breadcrumb>
      <BreadcrumbList>
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbLink href="/">Home</BreadcrumbLink>
        </BreadcrumbItem>
        <BreadcrumbSeparator />
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbLink href="/products">Products</BreadcrumbLink>
        </BreadcrumbItem>
        <BreadcrumbSeparator />
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbEllipsis />
        </BreadcrumbItem>
        <BreadcrumbSeparator />
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbLink href="/products/electronics/smartphones">Smartphones</BreadcrumbLink>
        </BreadcrumbItem>
        <BreadcrumbSeparator />
        <BreadcrumbItem>
          <BreadcrumbLink href="/products/electronics/smartphones/latest-model">Latest Model</BreadcrumbLink>
        </BreadcrumbItem>
      </BreadcrumbList>
    </Breadcrumb>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to include BreadcrumbEllipsis within a breadcrumb list to represent omitted intermediate steps. In a real-world scenario, the ellipsis would typically be wrapped in a button or combined with a popover to reveal the hidden items upon interaction.

limitations: BreadcrumbEllipsis is a purely presentational component; it does not provide any inherent logic for truncation or revealing hidden items. This logic must be implemented separately.
Its visual representation is fixed to an ellipsis icon; customization requires overriding its internal styling or providing custom children to BreadcrumbSeparator.
bestPractices: Always pair BreadcrumbEllipsis with interactive functionality (e.g., a button or a menu) that allows users to expand and view the omitted breadcrumb items.
Ensure the interactive element associated with the ellipsis provides clear accessible labels to screen readers, explaining what happens when activated.
Integrate with responsive design logic to automatically show or hide the ellipsis based on available space, rather than always displaying it.
antiPatterns: Using BreadcrumbEllipsis without an accompanying mechanism (e.g., a dropdown or modal) to reveal the hidden breadcrumb items, as it would mislead users.
Placing BreadcrumbEllipsis outside of a BreadcrumbItem, as it relies on the breadcrumb structure for proper styling and accessibility context.

semanticData.summary: A styled wrapper component for Radix UI's `RadioGroup.Root` component, providing a base for accessible radio button groups.
semanticData.description: This `RadioGroup` component serves as the container for a set of `RadioGroupItem` components, enabling users to select a single option from a predefined list. It leverages `Radix-UI` primitives for accessibility and core functionality, while adding opinionated styling via `tailwind-merge` and `cn` utility. Developers use it to create accessible and visually consistent radio button groups in their UIs.

commonUseCases: Allowing users to select a single option from a list, such as preferred language or payment method.
Building gender selection or age range inputs in registration forms.
Implementing user preferences or settings where only one choice is valid at a time.
Creating simple survey questions requiring a single answer from a set of choices.

examples.description: Demonstrates a basic controlled `RadioGroup` used for selecting a theme. The selected value is managed by React state, and each `RadioGroupItem` is paired with a `Label` for accessibility.

limitations: This component is a styled wrapper around Radix UI's primitives; it does not introduce new core radio group behavior beyond what Radix UI provides.
Requires manual integration with `RadioGroupItem` and `Label` components for full functionality and accessibility, as they are not bundled within the `RadioGroup` itself.
The styling is opinionated (based on Tailwind CSS); significant custom styling may require overriding `className` props or modifying the component's internal styles.
bestPractices: Always pair `RadioGroup` with `RadioGroupItem` and ensure each item has a unique `value` prop for proper functionality and accessibility.
Provide clear `Label` elements for each `RadioGroupItem` to ensure accessibility for screen reader users.
Manage the `value` and `onValueChange` props externally using React state to create controlled radio groups.
Utilize the `disabled` prop on `RadioGroup` to disable all items within the group, or on individual `RadioGroupItem`s for specific disabled options.
antiPatterns: Using `RadioGroup` when multiple selections are allowed (use checkboxes instead).
Nesting `RadioGroup` components directly, which can lead to accessibility issues or unexpected behavior.
Applying complex interactive logic directly to the `RadioGroup` container; logic should typically be managed via the `onValueChange` prop or on individual `RadioGroupItem`s.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled and accessible individual radio button item within a RadioGroup.
semanticData.description: The RadioGroupItem component serves as an individual selectable option within a RadioGroup. It wraps the Radix UI `RadioGroupPrimitive.Item` and applies pre-defined styling, including visual states for focus, disabled, and invalid states. This component is crucial for building accessible and visually consistent radio button groups, ensuring proper styling and behavior for each selectable choice.

commonUseCases: Allowing users to select a single option from a predefined list, like choosing a payment method.
Creating survey questions where only one answer is permissible.
Implementing filter options where only one filter can be active at a time.
Building configuration settings where users select one mode or preference.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use RadioGroupItem within a RadioGroup to create a simple payment method selection form. It shows how to manage the selected state using `onValueChange` on the parent group and how to disable an individual item.

limitations: RadioGroupItem is designed to be a child of `RadioGroup` and is not intended for standalone use.
Its visual appearance and accessibility are tightly coupled with the `RadioGroupPrimitive.Item` from Radix UI; extensive custom styling might require deeper overrides.
Does not manage its own state; state management (which item is selected) is handled by the parent `RadioGroup` component.
bestPractices: Always wrap RadioGroupItem components within a RadioGroup to ensure correct behavior and accessibility.

Pair each RadioGroupItem with a descriptive label for improved user experience and accessibility, typically using a separate `<label>` element with a `htmlFor` matching the item's `id` or using Radix's `RadioGroupPrimitive.Label` if available.
Manage the selected value using the `value` and `onValueChange` props of the parent `RadioGroup` component.
Utilize the `disabled` prop on RadioGroupItem to visually indicate and prevent interaction with certain options.
antiPatterns: Using RadioGroupItem outside of a RadioGroup: It will not function correctly or provide the expected accessibility features without being a child of RadioGroup.
Not providing a unique `value` prop for each RadioGroupItem: This prevents the RadioGroup from properly tracking the selected item.
Overriding core accessibility attributes: Avoid directly manipulating ARIA attributes unless you deeply understand Radix UI's implementation, as it might break accessibility.

semanticData.summary: A styled React component wrapper around `cmdk.CommandPrimitive` that provides the base container for command palettes and search interfaces.
semanticData.description: The Command component serves as the foundational styled container for building interactive command palettes and search UIs using `cmdk`. It applies essential base styles for a consistent visual appearance (e.g., rounded corners, background, text colors, flex layout) and exposes all props of the underlying `cmdk.CommandPrimitive`. Developers use Command as the root element to compose functional and visually integrated command interfaces.

commonUseCases: Building a global command palette for keyboard-driven navigation within an application
Implementing a searchable dropdown or combobox component
Creating a quick-access search interface for specific data or actions

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic structure of a `Command` component integrated with its common sub-components (`CommandInput`, `CommandList`, `CommandGroup`, `CommandItem`) to create a simple inline search interface. It shows how the `Command` component acts as the root container.

limitations: The `Command` component itself is primarily a styling wrapper; the core command logic (e.g., filtering, command execution) is handled by the underlying `cmdk` library or custom logic built around it.
Its features and capabilities are inherently limited to what the `cmdk` library provides, as it's a direct wrapper around `cmdk.CommandPrimitive`.
bestPractices: Always use `Command` with its companion components (`CommandInput`, `CommandList`, `CommandItem`, etc.) to construct a complete and styled command palette.
Pass the `className` prop for additional custom styling, but be mindful not to override the core visual theme unless intended.
For global command palettes, integrate `Command` within a modal or dialog component (like `CommandDialog`) for better user experience and focus management.
antiPatterns: Using the `Command` component directly without its associated `cmdk`-based child components (e.g., `CommandInput`, `CommandList`), as this will result in an unfunctional shell.
Overriding critical internal `cmdk` styles excessively through the `className` prop without understanding `cmdk`'s internal structure, leading to inconsistent UI or broken layouts.

codeMetadata.name: CommandDialog
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof Dialog> & { title?: string; description?: string; className?: string; showCloseButton?: boolean }): any

parameters.name: _complex_param
parameters.type: React.ComponentProps<typeof Dialog> & { title?: string; description?: string; className?: string; showCloseButton?: boolean }

semanticData.summary: A React component that renders a command palette within a dialog, providing an accessible and interactive search interface.
semanticData.description: The "CommandDialog" component provides a modal overlay for presenting a command palette, enabling users to quickly search and trigger actions or navigate. It wraps the "Dialog" and "Command" primitives, abstracting away the boilerplate for creating a full-screen or centered command interface. This component is ideal for applications requiring a unified search and command execution experience, similar to VS Code's command palette.

commonUseCases: Implementing a global search and command palette for an application
Providing quick access to common application actions or features
Enabling rapid navigation to different sections or routes
Creating a fuzzy-search interface for large datasets or options

examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic `CommandDialog` implementation, showing how to control its open state, add a global keyboard shortcut (Cmd+K) for quick access, and populate it with searchable items categorized into groups. It includes common elements like input, list, empty state, and keyboard shortcuts, providing a full command palette experience.

limitations: Requires client-side rendering due to the 'use client' directive.
Relies on the 'cmdk' library for its core command functionality; understanding 'cmdk''s API is beneficial for advanced usage.
The 'title' and 'description' props are exclusively for screen reader accessibility and will not be visually rendered, which might be unexpected for developers expecting visible text.
bestPractices: Always associate the CommandDialog with a global keyboard shortcut (e.g., Cmd+K or Ctrl+K) for quick user access.
Populate the CommandList with relevant CommandItems and consider grouping them with CommandGroup for better organization and user experience.
Utilize the 'title' and 'description' props to provide meaningful context for screen reader users, even if they are visually hidden.
For very large datasets, consider implementing debouncing for the CommandInput to optimize search performance, especially if fetching results asynchronously.
antiPatterns: Do not neglect to manage the 'open' and 'onOpenChange' props, as CommandDialog is a controlled component and will not open/close without them.
Avoid expecting the 'title' or 'description' props to be visibly rendered; they are solely for accessibility purposes via 'sr-only' styles.

Refrain from placing non-cmdk related components directly within the CommandDialog's children without understanding how cmdk processes its children; stick to CommandInput, CommandList, CommandGroup, CommandItem, etc., for proper functionality.

semanticData.summary: A styled input component for command palettes, including a search icon, designed for user query input.
semanticData.description: The CommandInput component provides the interactive search field for the Command palette. It wraps the cmdk library's CommandPrimitive.Input and enhances it by adding a leading search icon and applying consistent styling. This component is essential for allowing users to type search queries within a command menu, facilitating quick navigation and action discovery.

commonUseCases: Implementing a global command palette for application navigation and actions.
Creating a searchable dropdown or combobox component.
Building an in-app search functionality within a modal or dedicated view.

examples.description: This example demonstrates CommandInput as the primary interactive element within a basic Command component structure. It allows users to type and search for items listed in the CommandList.

limitations: Requires the cmdk library to be installed and correctly configured as it wraps CommandPrimitive.Input.
Primarily designed for text input and search within a command palette context; not a general-purpose form input replacement for standard HTML inputs.
bestPractices: Ensure CommandInput is always rendered as a direct child or within the hierarchy of a Command component to leverage its context.
Utilize the className prop for custom styling to maintain consistency with the application's design system without clashing with base styles.
Leverage the placeholder prop to provide clear, concise instructions to the user about what to search for or what kind of input is expected.
antiPatterns: Using CommandInput outside of a Command or CommandDialog component, as it relies on the cmdk context and will not function correctly.
Overriding core cmdk styling in a way that breaks accessibility or expected behavior for input focus and interaction.

semanticData.summary: Renders the scrollable list container for command items within a command palette component.
semanticData.description: The "CommandList" component serves as the scrollable container for displaying command items or groups within a command palette. It wraps `cmdk`'s `CommandPrimitive.List` and applies default styling, including a maximum height and scroll behavior, to ensure a user-friendly display of search results.
