This is essential for ensuring that dialogs appear correctly over all other page elements, prevent z-index conflicts, and maintain proper accessibility by managing focus within the modal context. It effectively 'teleports' its children to another part of the DOM, usually the document.body.

commonUseCases: Ensuring dialogs render on top of all other page content without z-index issues
Achieving proper accessibility for modal overlays by placing them outside the main document flow
Customizing the rendering location of a dialog, though typically used internally by DialogContent

examples.description: This example demonstrates how DialogPortal would be used to encapsulate custom dialog content along with the necessary overlay. Note that in most applications, the exported DialogContent component already handles the portal internally, making direct usage of DialogPortal less common for end-users.

limitations: Cannot be styled for positioning or visibility directly; these concerns are managed by the children rendered within the portal (e.g., DialogOverlay, DialogContent).
Does not provide any visual styling or behavior itself; it's purely a structural component for DOM placement.
bestPractices: Always use DialogPortal within the context of a Dialog root component to ensure proper context and behavior, although it's often handled implicitly by DialogContent.
Rely on DialogContent which already includes DialogPortal for standard dialog implementations, minimizing manual portal management.
antiPatterns: Attempting to style DialogPortal directly for visual layout: Its primary role is rendering location, not visual presentation. Styling should apply to the content *inside* the portal.
Using DialogPortal without DialogOverlay and DialogContent: It is meant to encapsulate the entire dialog content, not just a part of it, and relies on sibling components for full functionality.

semanticData.summary: Renders a UI component that closes an open Radix UI dialog when activated.
semanticData.description: The DialogClose component is a styled wrapper around Radix-UI's DialogPrimitive.Close component. Its primary purpose is to provide an accessible and semantically correct way to close an open dialog when activated, typically by a user click. It solves the problem of needing a dedicated UI element to dismiss modal dialogs, fitting seamlessly into the larger custom Dialog component system by inheriting all base Radix-UI properties and behaviors.

commonUseCases: Implementing a standard close 'X' button in the header of a modal dialog
Creating a 'Cancel' button in the footer of a dialog form
Allowing an action within the dialog, such as 'Discard Changes', to also close the dialog

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to place a DialogClose component within DialogContent to create a standard 'X' button for closing the dialog. The button is wrapped by DialogClose, allowing it to inherit the necessary close functionality.

This example shows DialogClose being used to create a 'Cancel' button within the DialogFooter. Clicking this button will close the dialog. The `asChild` prop is used to pass the close behavior to a custom button component.

limitations: DialogClose relies on context from its parent Radix Dialog components; it cannot close an arbitrary or non-Radix dialog.
It does not provide any visual styling by default; styling must be applied through `className` or by wrapping it around a styled component.
bestPractices: Always place DialogClose inside a DialogContent or a component rendered within DialogContent to ensure it can correctly trigger the parent dialog's close state.
For custom buttons or elements that should close the dialog, wrap them with DialogClose.
Ensure the DialogClose component is visually identifiable and accessible (e.g., using an X icon and an `sr-only` span for screen readers).
antiPatterns: Using DialogClose outside of a DialogContent or Dialog component hierarchy, as it requires a parent dialog context to function.
Trying to use DialogClose to programmatically open a dialog; it only handles closing.
Applying custom event handlers to DialogClose that prevent its default closing behavior, unless explicitly intended for custom logic before closing.

semanticData.summary: Renders a semi-transparent, full-screen overlay to dim the background when a dialog is open.
semanticData.description: The "DialogOverlay" component provides a styled backdrop that covers the entire viewport, visually dimming content behind an open dialog. It leverages Radix UI's "DialogPrimitive.Overlay" for accessibility and behavior, adding default styling with Tailwind CSS for smooth fade-in/out animations and a semi-transparent black background. This helps focus user attention on the dialog by clearly separating it from the underlying page content.

commonUseCases: Creating a modal dialog with a dimmed background
Implementing accessible dialogs where the user focus should be directed

examples.description: Demonstrates the typical usage of DialogOverlay as part of a complete dialog composition. While often rendered internally by DialogContent, it can be explicitly included within DialogPortal to ensure the background dims when the dialog is active and to control its specific props.

limitations: Requires a DialogPortal to render correctly outside the main DOM flow, typically managed by DialogContent or explicitly placed.
Relies on Radix UI DialogPrimitive for its underlying behavior and accessibility features; cannot be used independently as a generic overlay without the Radix UI context.
bestPractices: Always render DialogOverlay as a direct child of DialogPortal or within DialogContent (as DialogContent itself typically renders it) to ensure proper layering and accessibility.
Utilize the 'className' prop to extend or override default styles while preserving core functionality.
antiPatterns: Manually styling the overlay instead of relying on the component's provided classes, which might disrupt animations or accessibility.
Placing interactive elements directly within the DialogOverlay component, as it's intended as a visual backdrop, not a container for active content.

codeMetadata.name: DialogContent
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof DialogPrimitive.Content> & { showCloseButton?: boolean }): any

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled dialog content area with optional close button functionality, built on Radix UI.
semanticData.description: This component renders the main content area of a dialog, wrapping Radix UI's DialogPrimitive.Content. It applies a set of default styles for positioning, animation, and appearance, ensuring a consistent look and feel. It also provides an optional `showCloseButton` prop to easily include a standard 'X' close icon, simplifying common dialog implementations.

commonUseCases: Displaying forms or complex interactive elements within a modal
Presenting detailed information or media that requires user focus
Showing confirmation prompts or alert messages that require user action

examples.code:
import { Dialog, DialogTrigger, DialogContent, DialogHeader, DialogTitle, DialogDescription, DialogFooter, DialogClose } from './dialog'; import { Button } from '../button'; function MyDialog() { return ( Are you absolutely sure? This action cannot be undone. This will permanently delete your account and remove your data from our servers.
Your dialog content goes here!
 ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use DialogContent as the primary container for a dialog's body, including a header, description, custom content, and footer. It shows the use of the `showCloseButton` prop to automatically include the 'X' close icon.

limitations: The component's default positioning (`fixed`, `top-[50%]`, `left-[50%]`, `translate-x-[-50%]`, `translate-y-[-50%]`) makes it centered on the viewport, which might require overriding for custom positioning needs.
Relies on Radix UI's internal state management for open/closed states and focus trapping.
The `showCloseButton` only adds a visual 'X' icon; custom close behaviors (e.g., on outside click for specific elements) must be handled at the `Dialog` root level.
bestPractices: Always wrap `DialogContent` within `DialogPortal` and include `DialogOverlay` for proper modal behavior, accessibility, and background dimming.
Utilize the `showCloseButton` prop for a standard, accessible close mechanism rather than implementing a custom one unless absolutely necessary.
Place interactive elements like buttons for primary actions within `DialogFooter` to maintain consistent layout and user experience.
antiPatterns: Using `DialogContent` without `DialogPortal` and `DialogOverlay` components, which can lead to incorrect stacking context and accessibility issues.
Attempting to manually position `DialogContent` with custom CSS when its built-in `fixed` and `translate` styles are active, causing layout conflicts.
Implementing a custom close button when `showCloseButton` is `true`, leading to redundant UI elements.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled header container for dialog components, typically holding the title and description.
semanticData.description: The `DialogHeader` component serves as a dedicated container for the top section of a dialog, typically housing the `DialogTitle` and `DialogDescription`. It applies default styling (flex column layout, centered text on small screens, left-aligned on larger) to ensure consistent visual presentation across dialogs. Developers should use it to semantically group header-related content within a dialog for better structure and accessibility.

commonUseCases: Structuring the top section of a modal dialog
Grouping a dialog's title and description elements
Providing a consistent header layout for various dialog types (e.g., alert, form, info)

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of `DialogHeader` nested within `DialogContent`, containing a `DialogTitle` and `DialogDescription`. This structure provides a clear, semantically correct header for the dialog.

limitations: This component is purely presentational and does not manage any state or provide interactive functionality (like closing the dialog).
It inherits standard `div` element properties, but its primary purpose is layout for dialog headers, not general-purpose container use.
bestPractices: Always nest `DialogTitle` and `DialogDescription` components inside `DialogHeader` for proper semantic structure and styling.
Utilize the `className` prop to apply additional Tailwind CSS classes for custom styling adjustments without overriding the base layout.
Ensure `DialogHeader` is placed at the beginning of the `DialogContent` to maintain standard dialog structure.
antiPatterns: Using `DialogHeader` for content that isn't part of the dialog's top section (e.g., form inputs, action buttons), as it's meant for header content.
Placing non-header elements directly inside `DialogHeader` if they don't semantically belong there, leading to confusing structure.
Attempting to add interactive elements like buttons directly inside `DialogHeader` when `DialogFooter` or other sections are more appropriate.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled footer container for dialog components, arranging child elements responsively.
semanticData.description: The DialogFooter component provides a styled container specifically designed for the footer section of a dialog. It automatically arranges its children, typically action buttons, to appear in a row at the end (right side) on larger screens, while stacking them vertically in reverse order on smaller screens. This ensures a consistent and responsive layout for dialog actions, promoting a clear user interaction pattern.

commonUseCases: Placing primary and secondary action buttons within a dialog
Displaying supplementary text or links at the bottom of a dialog
Ensuring consistent button alignment across different dialogs

examples.description: This example demonstrates using `DialogFooter` to contain 'Cancel' and 'Confirm' buttons within a dialog. The buttons will be aligned to the right on larger screens and stacked vertically on smaller ones, as per the component's default styling.

limitations: Its primary purpose is for layout of footer-specific elements; it's not a general-purpose flexible container.
The default `flex-col-reverse` and `sm:flex-row sm:justify-end` styling might need to be overridden if a different button order or justification is required on specific screen sizes.
bestPractices: Always use `DialogFooter` as a direct child within `DialogContent` to maintain the intended structure and styling of the dialog.
Typically place action buttons (e.g., 'Save', 'Cancel', 'Confirm') inside `DialogFooter` for proper alignment and visual hierarchy.
Utilize the `className` prop to apply additional custom styling or override default layout behaviors when necessary, but prefer using standard button components within it.
antiPatterns: Using DialogFooter for content that is not part of the dialog's action area or bottom section, as it applies specific layout styling that may not be suitable.
Placing too many disparate elements inside the footer that do not logically belong together, leading to a cluttered UI.

semanticData.summary: Renders the main title for a dialog, applying default styling for consistent appearance.
semanticData.description: The DialogTitle component is a styled wrapper around Radix UI's `DialogPrimitive.Title` component, designed to display the primary heading within a dialog. It applies default styling for font weight, size, and line height to ensure consistent visual presentation. This component helps structure dialog content by clearly identifying the dialog's purpose, improving user comprehension and accessibility.

commonUseCases: Providing a descriptive header for a modal dialog
Setting the main text for a confirmation prompt
Labeling a form or information display within a dialog

examples.description: Demonstrates the typical usage of DialogTitle within a DialogHeader, alongside a DialogDescription, to structure the content of a dialog. This ensures the title is clearly identifiable and semantically correct.

limitations: Primarily a presentational component; it does not handle state or complex logic beyond rendering its children and applying styles.
Relies on its parent Radix UI Dialog components (e.g., DialogContent) for proper behavior and accessibility attributes like `aria-labelledby`.
bestPractices: Always include a concise and descriptive title that accurately reflects the dialog's purpose.
For optimal structure and accessibility, use DialogTitle within a DialogHeader component.
Ensure the title is succinct to avoid overwhelming users, especially on smaller screens.
antiPatterns: Using DialogTitle for general body text or descriptions; it should only contain the main heading.
Placing interactive elements (buttons, inputs) directly inside DialogTitle, which can lead to accessibility issues and confusing UX.

semanticData.summary: Renders an accessible, styled description for a dialog, based on Radix UI's Dialog.Description primitive.
semanticData.description: The DialogDescription component provides an accessible description for a dialog box, enhancing user understanding for both visual users and those relying on assistive technologies. It wraps Radix UI's DialogPrimitive.Description and applies default styling (muted foreground, small text) to ensure consistency with the application's design system. This component helps to clarify the dialog's purpose or provide additional context beneath the dialog title.

commonUseCases: Providing additional context or details for a dialog's purpose
Ensuring accessibility for dialog content by associating descriptive text with the dialog

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `DialogDescription` within a dialog to provide important contextual information for a destructive action, ensuring users understand the full implications before proceeding. It's typically placed directly after `DialogTitle`.

limitations: Primarily for textual descriptions; not suitable for complex interactive content within the description itself.
Inherits styling and accessibility behaviors from Radix UI's Description component, meaning its primary role is semantic rather than dictating complex layout.
bestPractices: Keep the description concise and focused on clarifying the dialog's purpose or implications.
Always use DialogDescription in conjunction with DialogTitle to provide a complete and accessible dialog heading structure.
antiPatterns: Using DialogDescription for primary actions or critical information that should be in the main content or title, as it's intended for supplementary text.
Placing overly long or complex content in the description, which can make dialogs difficult to scan and understand.

semanticData.summary: Defines a set of pre-configured Tailwind CSS class variants for a badge component using `class-variance-authority`.
semanticData.description: The `badgeVariants` constant uses `class-variance-authority` to define the styling logic for a UI badge component. It encapsulates a base set of Tailwind CSS classes and specific visual variants like 'default', 'secondary', 'destructive', and 'outline'. This enables developers to consistently apply themeable and reusable styles to badges throughout an application by simply passing a `variant` prop to the consuming `Badge` component.

commonUseCases: Displaying status indicators (e.g., 'Active', 'Pending', 'Archived')
Categorizing items with small visual tags or labels
Showing counts or short, descriptive labels next to interactive elements
Providing visual feedback for action outcomes (e.g., 'Success', 'Error', 'Warning')
Tagging content for filtering or organization purposes

examples.description: This example demonstrates the simplest usage of the `Badge` component, which automatically applies the 'default' variant as defined in `badgeVariants`. It's suitable for general informational display.
This example shows how to apply a specific variant, 'destructive', to the badge. This leverages `badgeVariants` to render a badge indicating a critical or error state with predefined styling.

This example illustrates how `badgeVariants` works in conjunction with the `asChild` prop. The badge's styles are applied to a custom child element (here, an `<a>` tag containing a `<span>`), allowing for semantic HTML while maintaining the visual consistency defined by `badgeVariants`.

limitations: The `badgeVariants` constant is tightly coupled with `class-variance-authority` and Tailwind CSS, making it unsuitable for projects not using these styling utilities.
It primarily focuses on visual styling and does not inherently handle complex interactive behaviors or advanced accessibility beyond basic ARIA attributes for invalid states.
While flexible for adding variants, deeply custom styling that deviates significantly from the base structure might still require direct CSS overrides or a separate component.
bestPractices: Always use the provided `Badge` component (which utilizes `badgeVariants`) for consistent styling and accessibility.
Define any new visual styles as additional variants within `badgeVariants` for reusability and maintainability.
Ensure that the 'default' variant is visually distinct and appropriate for general use cases.
Utilize the `cn` utility function when combining the output of `badgeVariants` with any additional `className` props.
antiPatterns: Hardcoding badge styles directly in JSX or external CSS, bypassing the `badgeVariants` and leading to inconsistent UI.
Overriding `badgeVariants` with excessive inline styles or `!important` declarations, defeating the purpose of centralized variant management.
Creating new, redundant badge styling logic instead of extending or adding variants to the existing `badgeVariants` constant.

codeMetadata.name: Badge
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<"span"> & VariantProps<typeof badgeVariants> & { asChild?: boolean }): any

semanticData.summary: A React UI component for displaying small, styled informational badges with variant support and composable children.
semanticData.description: The "Badge" component is a flexible React UI element designed to display small, styled informational labels. It leverages "class-variance-authority" to offer various predefined visual styles (e.g., default, destructive, outline), ensuring consistency and easy customization. This component solves the problem of needing distinct visual indicators for statuses, categories, or counts, by providing a reusable and accessible solution that integrates seamlessly into larger UIs.

commonUseCases: Indicating status (e.g., 'Draft', 'Published', 'Active')
Categorizing content or items in a list
Displaying counts for notifications or items in a cart
Labeling form fields or sections with additional context

examples.code: <Badge>New Feature</Badge>
examples.description: A basic badge demonstrating the default variant for general informational display.

examples.code: <Badge variant="destructive">Error</Badge><Badge variant="secondary">Warning</Badge>
examples.description: Utilizing different `variant` props to convey specific meanings, such as error states or secondary information.

examples.code: View Profile
examples.description: Using `asChild` to apply badge styling to an underlying HTML element (like an `<a>` tag) while retaining its semantic meaning and behavior. The badge's styles are merged onto the child component.

limitations: Primarily intended for short, static text or icons; not designed for rich interactive content.
The number of predefined variants is limited; custom styles beyond these variants require direct `className` overrides or extending `badgeVariants`.
Does not provide inherent interactivity; relies on the wrapped element (when `asChild` is used) or external handlers for click/hover actions.
bestPractices: Always choose the `variant` that best reflects the semantic meaning of the badge's content (e.g., `destructive` for errors, `secondary` for less critical info).
Keep badge content concise and to the point to maintain readability and avoid clutter.
Ensure sufficient color contrast between the badge background and text for accessibility, especially when customizing `className`.
Utilize the `asChild` prop when integrating the badge's styling with an existing interactive element (like a link or button) to preserve its native behavior and accessibility.
antiPatterns: Avoid using badges for long sentences or paragraphs, as their design is optimized for short, impactful labels.
Do not create custom styles via `className` if a suitable `variant` already exists or could be added to `badgeVariants`.
Refrain from wrapping interactive elements (like `<a>` or `<button>`) with `Badge` without using `asChild`, as this can break native element behavior and accessibility.
Using too many badges in close proximity, which can lead to visual clutter and make the UI difficult to parse.

semanticData.summary: Defines the name of the browser cookie used to store and retrieve the sidebar's open/collapsed state.
semanticData.description: This constant specifies the string literal name, "sidebar_state", used for the browser cookie that persists the user's sidebar state (expanded or collapsed). It ensures that the sidebar's visibility preference is remembered across page loads or subsequent visits. This helps provide a consistent user experience by restoring the sidebar to its last-known state, solving the problem of a fluctuating UI element and fitting into the overall persistence mechanism of the sidebar component.

commonUseCases: Defining a consistent name for storing UI component states in browser cookies
Ensuring the sidebar's expanded/collapsed state persists across user sessions
Referencing the cookie name when reading or writing sidebar state programmatically

examples.code: document.cookie = `${SIDEBAR_COOKIE_NAME}=${openState}; path=/; max-age=${SIDEBAR_COOKIE_MAX_AGE}`;
examples.description: This example shows how `SIDEBAR_COOKIE_NAME` is used to construct the cookie string for persisting the sidebar's `openState`. It's essential for ensuring the sidebar's state is remembered across sessions.

limitations: As a simple string constant, it only defines the cookie name and does not handle the underlying cookie setting or parsing logic.
State persistence relies entirely on browser cookie support; it will not work if cookies are disabled or blocked by the user.
Not suitable for storing complex data structures or highly sensitive information, as standard browser cookie limitations and security considerations apply.
bestPractices: Always use this constant when setting or retrieving the sidebar state cookie to ensure consistency.
Pair this constant with `SIDEBAR_COOKIE_MAX_AGE` to manage cookie expiration and ensure long-term state persistence.
For applications with multiple sidebars or user-specific configurations, consider dynamic or prefixed cookie names to prevent clashes, although this specific constant is fixed.
Ensure proper cookie security attributes (e.g., `path`, `SameSite`) are set when using the cookie name, even for UI state.
antiPatterns: Hardcoding the cookie name directly in multiple places, leading to inconsistent updates and potential bugs if the name needs to change.
Using a generic or easily clashing cookie name like 'state' or 'open', which could conflict with other scripts or components.
Attempting to change the constant's value at runtime, which is against the nature of a constant and can lead to unpredictable state persistence.

semanticData.summary: Defines the maximum age (in seconds) for the sidebar state cookie to persist its expanded or collapsed state for one week.
semanticData.description: This constant specifies the expiration time, in seconds, for the 'sidebar_state' cookie. By setting it to 7 days (60 * 60 * 24 * 7 seconds), the sidebar's last known state (expanded or collapsed) is preserved across browser sessions for a week. This improves user experience by remembering their preference without requiring server-side storage.

commonUseCases: Persisting UI preferences like sidebar state across user sessions.
Controlling the lifetime of client-side configuration cookies.
Ensuring consistent user experience for UI components without server-side state management.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how SIDEBAR_COOKIE_MAX_AGE is used in conjunction with SIDEBAR_COOKIE_NAME to persist the sidebar's expanded/collapsed state in a client-side cookie for a duration of one week. The `path=/` ensures the cookie is available across the entire application, and `SameSite=Lax` adds a security measure against CSRF attacks.

limitations: Relies on client-side cookies, which users can manually clear or block, leading to loss of preference.
Not suitable for storing sensitive data, as client-side cookies are inherently less secure.
Cannot guarantee persistence if users consistently block cookies, use incognito/private browsing modes, or switch browsers/devices.
Does not synchronize state across multiple devices; the preference is tied to the specific browser instance where the cookie was set.
bestPractices: Define cookie expiration times as constants for readability, consistency, and easy modification across the codebase.
Choose a max-age value that aligns with the expected persistence needs of the UI preference (e.g., 7 days for general preferences, shorter for more temporary states).
Document the purpose of the cookie and its max-age for clarity for future developers.
Consider user privacy and data security implications when setting long cookie durations, especially for any potentially personal data.
antiPatterns: Using excessively long max-age values for volatile UI states, leading to stale preferences if the UI or default behavior changes.
Setting a very short max-age for preferences intended to be persistent, causing frequent resets and poor user experience.
Hardcoding max-age values directly in cookie setting logic instead of using a named constant, hindering maintainability and consistency.

semanticData.summary: Defines the default expanded width for the desktop sidebar component.
semanticData.description: This constant defines the default, expanded width for the desktop sidebar component. It is used to establish a consistent visual dimension across the application's layout, specifically for the main sidebar element. By centralizing this value, it simplifies global adjustments to the sidebar's size, ensuring uniform styling and responsiveness based on the '--sidebar-width' CSS custom property.

commonUseCases: Defining the standard width for an application's primary navigation sidebar on desktop.
Ensuring consistent visual dimensions for the expanded state of a UI sidebar component.
Customizing the overall width of the desktop sidebar without modifying component logic directly.

examples.description: This example shows how `SIDEBAR_WIDTH` is used within the `SidebarProvider` to set a CSS custom property `--sidebar-width`. This allows child components to consistently reference the sidebar's width via CSS variables, promoting maintainability and themeability.

This example demonstrates how the `--sidebar-width` CSS custom property, set from `SIDEBAR_WIDTH`, is consumed directly within the `Sidebar` component's Tailwind CSS classes (e.g., `w-(--sidebar-width)`). This links the component's styling directly to the defined constant.

limitations: This constant is specifically for the default, expanded width of the *desktop* sidebar. It does not apply to mobile-specific widths or the reduced width when the sidebar is in an icon-only (collapsed) state.
Directly changing this constant will affect all instances where `--sidebar-width` is used, requiring careful consideration of its impact on the overall layout.
bestPractices: Always use `rem` units for responsive and scalable UI dimensions.
Utilize CSS custom properties (e.g., `--sidebar-width`) within components to consume this constant, allowing for dynamic styling and overriding.
Group UI dimension constants in a dedicated file or section for better organization and easier global adjustments.
antiPatterns: Hardcoding sidebar widths in multiple places instead of referencing this constant, leading to inconsistencies and difficult maintenance.
Attempting to use this constant for mobile sidebar widths or collapsed icon-only widths, as dedicated constants (`SIDEBAR_WIDTH_MOBILE`, `SIDEBAR_WIDTH_ICON`) exist for those purposes.

semanticData.summary: Defines the fixed width for the application's sidebar when displayed on mobile breakpoints.
semanticData.description: SIDEBAR_WIDTH_MOBILE is a constant string defining the default width of the sidebar component specifically when it's displayed on mobile devices. It ensures the mobile sidebar, typically rendered as a sheet or drawer, maintains a consistent and appropriate visual dimension. This constant helps maintain design consistency for responsive layouts by differentiating mobile-specific widths from desktop counterparts.

commonUseCases: Setting the fixed width for a responsive mobile sidebar or drawer component.
Ensuring consistent visual dimensions for mobile-first UI elements.
Applying a specific width to a SheetContent component when acting as a mobile sidebar.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how SIDEBAR_WIDTH_MOBILE is used within the Sidebar component. When the `isMobile` flag is true, the `SheetContent` (which acts as the mobile sidebar) is styled to explicitly use SIDEBAR_WIDTH_MOBILE via a CSS custom property, ensuring it has the correct mobile-specific width.

limitations: The value is a fixed string, meaning it cannot be dynamically calculated or adjusted based on complex runtime conditions (e.g., screen density or user preferences).
Only specifies a single fixed width; complex responsive requirements might necessitate more sophisticated width calculation logic or fluid units.
bestPractices: Assign this constant to a CSS custom property (e.g., `--sidebar-width`) within mobile-specific UI components for easy styling via Tailwind or other CSS-in-JS solutions.
Maintain separate constants for desktop and mobile widths to clearly delineate responsive design values.
If design system tokens are in use, consider deriving this value from or aligning it with established design tokens for responsive widths.
antiPatterns: Hardcoding mobile sidebar widths directly in CSS or components; this constant centralizes the value for consistency.
Using SIDEBAR_WIDTH_MOBILE for non-mobile sidebar contexts, which would lead to incorrect desktop layouts.
Attempting to dynamically adjust this constant at runtime, as it's a fixed string literal.

semanticData.summary: Specifies the fixed CSS width for the sidebar when it is collapsed to display only icons.
semanticData.description: The `SIDEBAR_WIDTH_ICON` constant defines the fixed width for the sidebar component when it is in a collapsed state, displaying only icons. This value is applied as a CSS custom property `--sidebar-width-icon` within the `SidebarProvider`. This ensures that the `Sidebar` component's styling accurately reflects the intended compact dimensions when the `collapsible` prop is set to 'icon', providing consistent visual sizing for the compact UI.

commonUseCases: Setting the exact pixel width for a compact, icon-only sidebar view
Maintaining consistent dimensions for collapsed sidebar states across the application
Providing a centralized configuration point for the visual appearance of the sidebar in icon mode

examples.description: This example shows the declaration of `SIDEBAR_WIDTH_ICON` and how it is passed as a CSS custom property `--sidebar-width-icon` to the sidebar wrapper. This makes the width available for styling child components via CSS variables.

This code snippet demonstrates how the `--sidebar-width-icon` CSS variable is consumed by Tailwind CSS classes within the `Sidebar` component. It dynamically adjusts the width of the sidebar (and its gap) when the `data-collapsible` attribute is set to 'icon', ensuring the sidebar shrinks to the defined icon width.

limitations: Since it's a fixed string constant, `SIDEBAR_WIDTH_ICON` does not inherently support dynamic or responsive adjustments without additional JavaScript logic to change the CSS variable value.
Modifying this constant requires recompilation of the application; it's not a runtime configuration value.
bestPractices: Group related width constants (like `SIDEBAR_WIDTH`, `SIDEBAR_WIDTH_MOBILE`) in a single file for easy configuration and overview.
Use consistent CSS units (e.g., `rem` or `px`) across all width definitions to ensure predictable scaling.
Expose this value via a theming system or context if there's a need for dynamic adjustments or user customization of sidebar dimensions.
antiPatterns: Hardcoding the icon sidebar width directly into multiple CSS classes instead of using the defined CSS variable, leading to inconsistent updates and difficult maintenance.
Using this constant for non-sidebar elements, violating separation of concerns and making future refactoring harder.

semanticData.summary: Defines the character key used in combination with modifier keys to toggle the sidebar's visibility.
semanticData.description: The SIDEBAR_KEYBOARD_SHORTCUT constant defines the specific single-character key that, when combined with either the Ctrl or Meta (Command) key, triggers the toggling of the application sidebar. This constant provides a global keyboard shortcut, enhancing user experience by offering an accessible and efficient way to control the sidebar's visibility without needing to interact with a UI button. It solves the problem of needing to click a specific element to show/hide the sidebar, fitting into the larger system as part of the accessibility and navigation layer for the Sidebar component.

commonUseCases: Defining a global keyboard shortcut for a UI element
Enhancing accessibility by providing alternative navigation methods
Configuring application-wide key bindings for core features

examples.description: This example demonstrates how the SIDEBAR_KEYBOARD_SHORTCUT constant is used within a `React.useEffect` hook to register a global keyboard event listener. When the 'b' key is pressed simultaneously with either the Command (Meta) or Control key, the default browser action is prevented, and the `toggleSidebar` function is called, changing the sidebar's visibility. This setup provides a simple yet effective way to manage UI state via keyboard.

limitations: The constant's value is fixed at compile time, meaning it cannot be changed dynamically at runtime by users without a code redeployment.
Potential for keyboard shortcut conflicts if not carefully chosen, especially in complex web applications or when integrated with third-party tools.
Accessibility can be limited if the user's keyboard layout does not easily support the chosen character.
bestPractices: Always combine keyboard shortcuts for critical UI toggles with modifier keys (Ctrl, Meta) to prevent accidental triggers.
Thoroughly test chosen shortcuts across different browsers and operating systems to avoid conflicts with native key bindings.
Document the keyboard shortcut clearly within the application's UI or help section to inform users.
Consider centralizing keyboard shortcut definitions if multiple shortcuts are present, potentially allowing user customization.
Ensure the chosen key is mnemonic and related to the action (e.g., 'b' for 'sidebar' or 'panel').
antiPatterns: Using a common character (e.g., 'a', 's') without modifier keys, which could lead to accidental sidebar toggles during normal typing.
Choosing a shortcut that conflicts with existing browser or operating system shortcuts (e.g., Ctrl+S for save, Ctrl+F for find).
Hardcoding frequently changed values: While 'b' for sidebar might be intuitive, for a more complex application, such constants might better reside in a configuration object or be user-configurable.

codeMetadata.name: SidebarContextProps
codeMetadata.typeSignature: type = { state: "expanded" | "collapsed"; open: boolean; setOpen: (open: boolean) => void; openMobile: boolean; setOpenMobile: (open: boolean) => void; isMobile: boolean; toggleSidebar: () => void }

semanticData.summary: Defines the properties and methods for interacting with a responsive UI sidebar's state and behavior via a React Context.
semanticData.description: This type declaration defines the shape of the context object provided by the `SidebarContext`. It centralizes the state and actions for a responsive sidebar component, making its properties and methods globally accessible to child components. Developers use this to query the sidebar's current display state and programmatically control its visibility and behavior across desktop and mobile views.

commonUseCases: Accessing the sidebar's current open/collapsed state within deeply nested components
Programmatically toggling the sidebar's visibility from a header or external button
Conditionally rendering or styling parts of the application based on sidebar state (e.g., expanded, collapsed, or mobile open)
Implementing custom keyboard shortcuts or gesture-based controls to manage sidebar visibility

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use the `toggleSidebar` function from the `SidebarContext` to control the sidebar's visibility with a simple button click. This is a common pattern for integrating sidebar control into a header or navigation bar.

This code snippet illustrates how to consume `state` and `isMobile` from the `SidebarContext` to dynamically adjust content layout or render different messages based on the sidebar's current status and device type. This is crucial for creating adaptive UIs.

limitations: Requires the `SidebarProvider` component to be rendered higher in the React tree than any component using `useSidebar`; otherwise, it will throw an error.

The `setOpen` function directly manipulates a client-side cookie for persistence, which might not be ideal for applications requiring server-side control over initial sidebar state or strict cookie management.

The `isMobile` property's accuracy depends on the underlying `useIsMobile` hook's implementation, typically relying on media queries, which might have edge cases on certain devices or browser resizes.
bestPractices: Always consume the sidebar state and actions via the `useSidebar` hook for consistency and built-in error handling.
Utilize `state`, `open`, and `isMobile` properties for responsive conditional rendering or styling of UI elements.
Prefer using `toggleSidebar` for simple show/hide functionality and `setOpen` for explicit control over the sidebar's visibility.
Leverage CSS classes and data attributes (e.g., `data-state='expanded'`) to style the sidebar and adjacent content based on context values.
antiPatterns: Attempting to use the `useSidebar` hook outside of a `SidebarProvider`, which will result in a runtime error.
Directly manipulating DOM elements to change sidebar visibility instead of using `setOpen` or `toggleSidebar`, leading to state desynchronization.
Over-complicating logic within components consuming the context; `SidebarContextProps` is intended for straightforward state access and modification.

semanticData.summary: Provides a React Context for managing the state and behavior of a collapsible sidebar component across its children.
semanticData.description: The SidebarContext is a React Context object used to share the state and control functions of the sidebar component tree. It provides access to the sidebar's 'expanded' or 'collapsed' state, open/close functions for both desktop and mobile, and a 'toggleSidebar' utility. This centralizes sidebar logic, enabling child components like SidebarTrigger or custom elements to interact with the sidebar's visibility and responsiveness.

commonUseCases: Implementing a responsive and collapsible navigation sidebar in a web application.
Synchronizing sidebar state and toggling behavior across various UI elements.
Providing a consistent user experience for sidebar interaction, including keyboard shortcuts and mobile-specific sheets.
Accessing the current sidebar state (expanded/collapsed, mobile/desktop) from any descendant component.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to wrap your application or a section of it with `SidebarProvider` to enable sidebar functionality. `MySidebarContent` consumes the `SidebarContext` via the `useSidebar` hook to display the current state and provide a button to toggle the sidebar. `SidebarTrigger` (a component provided by the sidebar system) is used in the main content area to also control the sidebar, showing how different parts of the UI can interact with the centralized state.

limitations: Designed primarily for a single, global sidebar instance due to its centralized context-based state management. Multiple independent sidebars might require separate context instances or a different approach.
The `useSidebar` hook, like all React hooks, can only be used within functional components and cannot be called inside class components or outside of React's render cycle.
Relies on client-side cookies for state persistence, which means its state might not be immediately available or correctly hydrated during server-side rendering (SSR) without additional setup.
bestPractices: Always wrap components that need to interact with the sidebar state within the `SidebarProvider` at a sufficiently high level in your component tree.
Utilize the `useSidebar` hook for convenient and type-safe access to the context values and methods within functional components.
Leverage the `toggleSidebar` function for a unified way to control sidebar visibility, as it handles both desktop and mobile logic.
For controlled component scenarios, pass `open` and `onOpenChange` props to `SidebarProvider` to manage the sidebar state from an external parent component.
Consider using `SidebarProvider`'s `defaultOpen` prop for initial state or `open`/`onOpenChange` for controlled behavior.
antiPatterns: Attempting to use the `useSidebar` hook outside of the `SidebarProvider`'s rendered tree, which will result in a runtime error.
Manually managing sidebar open/close state in multiple components instead of leveraging the centralized context for consistency.
Directly manipulating DOM elements for sidebar visibility rather than using the provided `setOpen` or `toggleSidebar` functions from the context.
Using the context for entirely different UI elements that are not part of the sidebar system, leading to misuse and lack of clarity.

semanticData.summary: A React hook that provides access to the sidebar's state and control functions from the `SidebarProvider` context.
semanticData.description: The `useSidebar` hook provides access to the global state and control functions of the sidebar component. It consumes the `SidebarContext`, enabling any descendant component within a `SidebarProvider` to query the sidebar's open/collapsed state, determine mobile responsiveness, and programmatically toggle or set its visibility. This hook is crucial for building interactive UI elements that control or react to the sidebar's behavior.

commonUseCases: Creating a button in the application header to toggle the sidebar's visibility.
Conditionally rendering content or applying styles based on whether the sidebar is expanded or collapsed.
Programmatically opening or closing the sidebar based on application logic (e.g., after login).
Building responsive layouts that adapt based on the sidebar's mobile state.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `useSidebar` to retrieve the `toggleSidebar` function and the current `state` of the sidebar, enabling a button to both trigger the toggle and update its text based on the sidebar's status.

This example shows how a component can consume the `state` and `isMobile` properties from `useSidebar` to dynamically apply CSS classes or render content based on the sidebar's current visibility and the device type.

limitations: This hook must be used within a React component tree where `SidebarProvider` is an ancestor, otherwise, it will throw an error.
bestPractices: Always ensure that components utilizing `useSidebar` are rendered as children of a `SidebarProvider` to prevent errors.
Prefer using the `toggleSidebar` function for user-initiated interactions to ensure consistent behavior across desktop and mobile.
Leverage the `state` ('expanded' | 'collapsed') and `isMobile` properties for responsive design and conditional UI rendering.
antiPatterns: Using `useSidebar` outside of a `SidebarProvider` component, which will result in a runtime error.
Attempting to directly manipulate the sidebar's DOM elements instead of using the provided state setters or toggle function.

codeMetadata.name: SidebarProvider
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<"div"> & { defaultOpen?: boolean; open?: boolean; onOpenChange?: (open: boolean) => void }): any | () => any

parameters.name: _complex_param

semanticData.summary: Manages and provides the global state and functionality for a responsive, persistent, and keyboard-toggleable sidebar component via React Context.
semanticData.description: The SidebarProvider component establishes and manages the global state for a responsive sidebar, handling its open/collapsed status, mobile adaptation, and persistence. It provides a React Context that enables descendant components to interact with the sidebar's state, offering both internal state management and external control via props. This component solves the problem of consistent and accessible sidebar behavior across an application, including cookie-based state persistence and a keyboard shortcut for toggling.

commonUseCases: Implementing a persistent navigation sidebar in a web application
Creating a responsive layout where a sidebar adapts between desktop (expand/collapse) and mobile (off-canvas sheet)
Providing a global toggle mechanism for a sidebar, including a keyboard shortcut
Centralizing sidebar state for various sidebar-related components (e.g., SidebarTrigger, SidebarMenu)

examples.description: Demonstrates the basic setup of `SidebarProvider` wrapping a main layout, enabling the sidebar and its associated components. The `defaultOpen` prop sets the initial state.
Illustrates how to use `SidebarProvider` as a controlled component by passing `open` and `onOpenChange` props. This allows external components or state managers to dictate the sidebar's state.

limitations: Relies on browser cookies for persistence, which might not be suitable for server-side rendered (SSR) contexts without additional handling to manage cookie state server-side.
The global keyboard shortcut (Cmd/Ctrl + B) might conflict with other application-level shortcuts if not managed carefully within the application's overall keyboard accessibility strategy.
State persistence is limited to the client-side cookie; no server-side or user-specific persistence is included out-of-the-box.
bestPractices: Wrap your entire application or the main layout section with `SidebarProvider` to ensure all sidebar-related components have access to the context
Utilize the `open` and `onOpenChange` props for controlled sidebar behavior when integrating with external state management systems (e.g., Redux, Zustand)
Prefer using the `useSidebar` hook and components like `SidebarTrigger` to interact with the sidebar state rather than direct DOM manipulation
Ensure proper accessibility by leveraging the built-in WAI-ARIA attributes and keyboard shortcuts provided by the sidebar components
antiPatterns: Directly manipulating sidebar visibility or state outside of the provided context or props, which can lead to desynchronized UI
Attempting to use the `useSidebar` hook outside of the `SidebarProvider`'s subtree, as it will throw an error
Overriding the persistence cookie directly instead of using `onOpenChange` when the sidebar is controlled, as this can lead to unpredictable behavior

codeMetadata.name: Sidebar
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<"div"> & { side?: "left" | "right"; variant?: "sidebar" | "floating" | "inset"; collapsible?: "offcanvas" | "icon" | "none" }): any

semanticData.summary: A versatile React component for creating responsive, collapsible sidebars with various layout options and state management.
semanticData.description: The "Sidebar" component provides a flexible and opinionated way to build application sidebars. It supports different visual styles like fixed, floating, or inset layouts, and offers several collapse behaviors including offcanvas and icon-based states. It intelligently adapts to mobile environments, persisting its state via cookies and integrating with a rich set of sub-components to facilitate structured navigation and content display within the sidebar.

commonUseCases: Implementing main application navigation menus
Displaying contextual information panels or settings
Creating filter or search sidebars for data views
Building dashboards with persistent or collapsible left/right layouts

examples.code:
import { Sidebar, SidebarProvider, SidebarHeader, SidebarContent, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuButton, SidebarSeparator, SidebarFooter, SidebarTrigger } from './sidebar'; import { HomeIcon, SettingsIcon, UsersIcon } from 'lucide-react'; function AppLayout() { return (
My App
 Home Users Settings
Main Application Content
 ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic application layout using `SidebarProvider` and `Sidebar` with a `left` side, `sidebar` variant, and `offcanvas` collapse. It includes typical sections like `SidebarHeader`, `SidebarContent` with `SidebarMenu` items, and `SidebarFooter`.

This example shows a dashboard layout using the `inset` variant and `icon` collapse, where the main content (`SidebarInset`) adjusts its margin based on the sidebar's state. It also demonstrates how to place the `SidebarTrigger` outside the sidebar itself, typically in the main content header.

limitations: Sidebar state persistence relies on `document.cookie`, which might not be ideal or available in all server-side rendering (SSR) environments without additional configuration to manage cookies.
The mobile sidebar implementation uses Radix UI's Sheet component, which has its own animation and overlay behavior, differing from the desktop collapse animations.
Extensive customization beyond the provided variants and CSS variables may require overriding internal styles, potentially leading to increased complexity.
bestPractices: Always wrap your application's root or relevant layout with `SidebarProvider` to enable state management and keyboard shortcuts.
Utilize the provided sub-components (e.g., `SidebarHeader`, `SidebarContent`, `SidebarMenuButton`) to ensure consistent styling and accessibility.
Choose the appropriate `variant` (`sidebar`, `floating`, `inset`) and `collapsible` (`offcanvas`, `icon`, `none`) props to match your desired UI/UX.
Provide meaningful `tooltip` props for `SidebarMenuButton` when `collapsible` is set to `icon` to aid user understanding when the sidebar is collapsed.
Use `SidebarInset` for the main content area when using `variant="inset"` to correctly handle the layout shift.
antiPatterns: Failing to wrap the `Sidebar` component and its children within a `SidebarProvider`, leading to context errors.
Attempting to manually control sidebar open/collapsed state without using the `useSidebar` context methods (e.g., `toggleSidebar`, `setOpen`).
Ignoring the responsiveness, leading to a suboptimal experience on mobile devices, especially when not using the default mobile behavior.

semanticData.summary: Creates a button component that toggles the visibility of the parent Sidebar component.
semanticData.description: This component provides a dedicated button to control the open/collapsed state of the Sidebar. It leverages the useSidebar hook to access the toggleSidebar function, ensuring seamless integration with the sidebar's state management. Developers should use SidebarTrigger to offer a user-friendly way for users to expand or collapse the navigation sidebar, often placed in a header or main content area.

commonUseCases: Adding a toggle button in the application header to show/hide the main navigation sidebar
Providing a dedicated UI element to control sidebar visibility on desktop and mobile

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic integration of SidebarTrigger within an application layout, typically placed inside a header component to provide a visible toggle for the sidebar.
Shows how to extend the SidebarTrigger functionality by adding a custom onClick handler, which will execute before the sidebar's toggle action.

limitations: Must be a descendant of SidebarProvider to function correctly, as it relies on the useSidebar context
Its visual appearance and default size are opinionated; significant styling changes might require overriding internal styles
bestPractices: Always wrap SidebarTrigger within a SidebarProvider to ensure the necessary context is available
Consider placing the trigger in a prominent and intuitive location, such as the top-left or top-right of the application header
Leverage the className prop for additional styling or onClick for custom side effects while retaining the toggle functionality
antiPatterns: Using a generic Button and manually calling toggleSidebar() instead of SidebarTrigger, which bypasses consistent styling and accessibility features provided by SidebarTrigger
Placing the trigger in a location where it's not clear it controls the sidebar, leading to a poor user experience

semanticData.summary: Renders an interactive, visually distinct button designed as a rail to toggle the parent sidebar's expanded/collapsed state.
semanticData.description: The SidebarRail component renders a subtle, interactive button designed to act as a visual 'rail' or handle along the edge of a collapsible sidebar. Its primary purpose is to toggle the parent sidebar's expanded or collapsed state upon user interaction. This component is integral to providing an intuitive user experience for managing sidebar visibility and works seamlessly with the `Sidebar` and `SidebarProvider` to facilitate width transitions.

commonUseCases: Providing an interactive visual handle for expanding or collapsing a desktop sidebar.
Offering an alternative, subtle toggle mechanism for sidebar visibility.
Creating a unified user experience for collapsible navigation systems.

examples.code:
import { SidebarProvider, Sidebar, SidebarRail, SidebarContent, SidebarHeader } from '@repo/web/components/ui/sidebar'; import { PanelLeftIcon } from 'lucide-react'; function AppLayout() { return (

Application

Your main sidebar navigation and content goes here.

Welcome to the Dashboard

Interact with the sidebar rail to toggle its state.

 ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic integration of `SidebarRail` within a `SidebarProvider` and `Sidebar` setup. The `SidebarRail` component is rendered directly inside the `Sidebar`, providing a clickable area (the 'rail') that toggles the sidebar's expanded/collapsed state. The `collapsible="icon"` prop on `Sidebar` allows the sidebar to collapse to an icon-only state, which the rail helps manage.

limitations: SidebarRail strictly relies on the `SidebarContext` provided by `SidebarProvider` and `Sidebar`, making it unusable as a standalone component.
It is designed solely for toggling the sidebar's state (expanded/collapsed) and does not inherently support drag-to-resize or custom resizing functionalities.
Its visual appearance is heavily dictated by a comprehensive set of Tailwind CSS classes, which might make extensive aesthetic customization challenging without overriding core styles.
The `tabIndex={-1}` makes it not focusable via keyboard navigation, expecting the primary toggle mechanism to be the `SidebarTrigger` or keyboard shortcut.
bestPractices: Always ensure SidebarRail is nested within a `Sidebar` component, which is itself wrapped by `SidebarProvider` to ensure correct context and functionality.
Leverage its default, highly opinionated styling for a consistent and integrated sidebar appearance.
Ensure its visibility and interactive nature are clear to users, providing a discoverable method for sidebar control.
Consider its placement carefully to avoid overlapping with other interactive elements or content within the sidebar or main layout.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarRail outside of a `SidebarProvider` or `Sidebar` component, as it relies on their context for functionality.
Attempting to use SidebarRail for dynamic resizing (e.g., drag-to-resize) instead of simple state toggling, as it only triggers predefined expanded/collapsed states.
Applying conflicting custom styles that break its intended visual role as a 'rail' or an interactive edge.

semanticData.summary: Renders the main content area of an application, specifically designed to visually integrate with an 'inset' variant of the Sidebar component.
semanticData.description: The SidebarInset component serves as the primary content wrapper for applications utilizing the Sidebar component, particularly when the sidebar is configured with the 'inset' variant. It provides dynamic styling, such as responsive margins, rounded corners, and shadows, to ensure a seamless visual layout that adapts as the 'inset' sidebar collapses or expands. This component helps maintain the overall structure and aesthetic coherence of the application's main view alongside the sidebar.

commonUseCases: Defining the primary content region next to an 'inset' type application sidebar.
Creating a responsive layout where the main content visually shifts or resizes based on sidebar state (collapsed/expanded).
Applying consistent theming and spacing for the main application area within a sidebar-driven UI.

examples.code:
import { Sidebar, SidebarContent, SidebarHeader, SidebarInset, SidebarProvider, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuButton } from './ui/sidebar'; import { HomeIcon } from 'lucide-react'; function AppLayout() { return (

My App

 Dashboard {/* More menu items */}

Welcome to the Main Content Area!

This area dynamically adjusts its layout based on the sidebar's state and variant.

 ); }
examples.description: This example shows SidebarInset being used as the main content area alongside an 'inset' variant Sidebar. The SidebarInset component automatically applies styling to create a visually integrated content panel that adjusts its margins and appearance when the sidebar collapses or expands.

limitations: Primarily designed for use with Sidebar component with variant='inset'; its dynamic styling may not be relevant or desirable with other Sidebar variants.
Assumes Sidebar is a sibling in the DOM structure for its CSS peer selectors to work correctly.
bestPractices: Always wrap Sidebar and SidebarInset components within a SidebarProvider to ensure context is available for proper functionality and styling.
Place the SidebarInset as a direct sibling to the Sidebar component to leverage the peer styling effectively.
Use standard HTML semantics within SidebarInset (e.g., section, article, div) as appropriate for the content structure.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarInset without a parent SidebarProvider will lead to runtime errors or incorrect behavior due to missing context.
Applying extensive custom margins or positioning directly to SidebarInset that could conflict with its internal, responsive styling.

semanticData.summary: Renders a pre-styled input component optimized for use within the sidebar.
semanticData.description: The SidebarInput component is a specialized `Input` field designed for seamless integration within a sidebar. It provides a pre-styled input element that fits the sidebar's aesthetic and layout, ideal for search, filtering, or quick entry within the navigation or settings panel. Developers should use this when they need a text input specifically positioned within the sidebar structure.

commonUseCases: Adding a search bar to filter sidebar navigation items
Implementing a quick filter for lists displayed in the sidebar
Providing a text input for user preferences or settings within a sidebar panel

examples.code:
import { Sidebar, SidebarHeader, SidebarInput, SidebarContent, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuButton, SidebarProvider } from './path/to/sidebar'; import { SearchIcon } from 'lucide-react'; function MyAppComponent() { return (

Main Content Area

This is where your primary application content goes.

 ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to integrate `SidebarInput` into a `SidebarHeader` for a search functionality within a typical sidebar layout. It shows the component's position relative to other sidebar elements.

limitations: SidebarInput is a wrapper around a basic HTML input element and does not include any search, validation, or form handling logic. This must be implemented externally.
Its styling is opinionated and optimized for the sidebar context, making it less suitable for general-purpose input fields elsewhere in the application.
bestPractices: Place SidebarInput within SidebarHeader or SidebarContent for proper layout and visual hierarchy.
Always provide a meaningful `placeholder` text to guide users on its purpose (e.g., 'Search...', 'Filter items').
Integrate with state management and search/filter logic from the parent component or a custom hook.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarInput outside of a Sidebar component, as it's styled specifically for that context and might look out of place.
Expecting SidebarInput to provide search or filtering logic; it's a purely presentational component for input.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled header section for the Sidebar component, providing a consistent top layout.
semanticData.description: The "SidebarHeader" component serves as a dedicated container for the topmost section of a sidebar. It applies default styling to arrange its children vertically with consistent spacing and padding, providing a structured area for header-related content. This component is crucial for organizing elements like titles, search inputs, or user profiles within a larger sidebar layout, ensuring visual consistency and proper structural hierarchy.

commonUseCases: Structuring the top section of a navigation sidebar for a web application.
Containing a company logo, application title, or user profile information at the top of a sidebar.
Grouping a search bar and a toggle button within the header area of a collapsible sidebar.

examples.description: This example demonstrates using `SidebarHeader` to contain a title, a search input field, and a menu button. It shows how the component helps structure the top part of the sidebar, applying default flex column styling to its children.

limitations: SidebarHeader is a purely presentational component; it does not manage state or implement complex behavior itself.
Its default styling assumes a flex column layout. Significant changes to this layout might require overriding base styles via the `className` prop.
bestPractices: Use SidebarHeader exclusively for elements that logically belong in the header of the sidebar.
Nest `SidebarInput`, `Button`, or other UI elements directly as children within SidebarHeader to utilize its default layout.
Leverage the `className` prop to extend or override default Tailwind CSS classes for custom styling needs.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarHeader for content that is not part of the sidebar's top section or header, which can lead to semantic confusion and inconsistent styling.
Placing complex business logic directly within SidebarHeader; it should primarily be a presentation component for layout.

semanticData.summary: Renders a customizable footer section within a sidebar component, designed for static or persistent elements.
semanticData.description: The SidebarFooter component serves as a dedicated container for content positioned at the bottom of a sidebar. It allows developers to place elements such as action buttons, copyright information, or settings links in a consistent, non-scrolling area. This ensures that important footer elements are always visible, complementing the main sidebar content and enhancing user experience.

commonUseCases: Displaying settings or account management buttons at the base of a sidebar
Showing application version or copyright information
Including persistent navigation links or actions that should always be accessible

examples.description: This example demonstrates embedding action buttons and version information within a `SidebarFooter`. The footer is styled with a top border to visually separate it from the main content, making it a clear, consistent area for user actions and static details.

limitations: Primarily a presentational component, it does not manage complex state or business logic itself.
Its visual behavior and responsiveness are dependent on the parent `Sidebar` component's configuration and overall layout.
Not designed for content that needs to scroll independently or that changes frequently based on user interaction.
bestPractices: Keep the footer content concise and relevant to avoid clutter.
Utilize it for static or rarely updated information and primary actions.
Leverage the `className` prop for custom styling to match the application's design system.
antiPatterns: Placing highly dynamic or frequently changing content that might distract from the main sidebar content
Using it for large, complex forms or interactive elements that would be better suited for the main content area or dedicated dialogs
Adding scrollable content within the footer, as it's intended for fixed, visible elements

semanticData.summary: Renders a visually styled separator for use within a sidebar component, inheriting properties from Radix UI's Separator.
semanticData.description: This component provides a styled horizontal separator specifically designed for use within the Sidebar layout. It acts as a visual divider, improving the organization and readability of sidebar content such as menu items, groups, or headers. It extends Radix UI's Separator component by applying custom Tailwind CSS classes to match the sidebar's theming and layout.

commonUseCases: Separating distinct sections within a sidebar menu, like navigation links from utility links.
Visually dividing the sidebar header from the main content area.
Creating clear breaks between functional groups in the sidebar footer.
Enhancing the visual hierarchy and readability of complex sidebar layouts.

examples.code:
import { Sidebar, SidebarContent, SidebarHeader, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuItem, SidebarSeparator, SidebarMenuButton } from "@repo/web/components/ui/sidebar"; import { HomeIcon, SettingsIcon, UserIcon, FolderIcon } from "lucide-react"; function MySidebarLayout() { return (

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `SidebarSeparator` to visually divide different logical sections of a sidebar menu. Here, it separates the 'Dashboard' and 'Profile' links from the 'Projects' and 'Settings' links, making the navigation more organized and easier to scan.

limitations: Primarily designed for horizontal separation within the sidebar's vertical content flow; it is not intended for general-purpose horizontal or vertical separation outside of the sidebar context.
Relies on the parent `Sidebar` context and its associated styling for correct visual appearance and spacing.
bestPractices: Place SidebarSeparators strategically to enhance content readability and logical grouping within the sidebar.
Combine SidebarSeparator with other sidebar components like SidebarHeader, SidebarContent, SidebarFooter, and SidebarGroup to structure the layout effectively.
Ensure proper accessibility by considering how visual separators are perceived by screen readers (the underlying Separator component from Radix UI handles much of this).
antiPatterns: Using SidebarSeparator outside of a Sidebar component: Its styling is optimized for the sidebar context and may not render or behave correctly elsewhere.
Placing multiple SidebarSeparators consecutively without content in between: This creates unnecessary visual clutter and serves no functional purpose.

semanticData.summary: Renders the main scrollable content area within a sidebar component, managing overflow and filling available space.
semanticData.description: SidebarContent is a React component designed to contain the primary scrollable elements of a sidebar, such as navigation links, forms, or status information. It ensures that its content fills the available space and manages overflow, allowing vertical scrolling when the content exceeds the sidebar's height. This component is crucial for structuring the sidebar's internal layout and ensuring proper scrolling behavior, especially when the sidebar transitions between expanded and icon-only (collapsed) states.

commonUseCases: Housing navigation menus within a sidebar that might exceed vertical height
Displaying lists of items or forms that require scrolling within the sidebar
Structuring the primary interactive area of a collapsible sidebar component

examples.code:
import { Sidebar, SidebarContent, SidebarFooter, SidebarHeader, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuItem, SidebarMenuButton, SidebarProvider, SidebarTrigger, SidebarGroup, SidebarGroupLabel, SidebarInput } from './sidebar'; import { HomeIcon, SettingsIcon, UsersIcon, SearchIcon } from 'lucide-react'; function AppLayout() { return (

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to integrate `SidebarContent` within a `Sidebar` component, showcasing its role in containing a scrollable navigation menu and other interactive elements. It illustrates placing multiple `SidebarGroup` and `SidebarMenu` components inside `SidebarContent` to enable scrolling when the content, such as a long list of menu items, exceeds the available height.

limitations: Primarily designed for vertical scrolling content; complex horizontal scrolling within the sidebar might require additional custom solutions.
Its proper rendering and functionality are dependent on being a child of the `Sidebar` component, and using it outside this context may lead to unexpected layout issues.
bestPractices: Always use SidebarContent within a Sidebar component to ensure correct layout and styling context.
Combine SidebarContent with SidebarHeader and SidebarFooter to create a complete and well-structured sidebar layout with distinct, non-scrolling top and bottom sections.
Populate SidebarContent with logical UI groups using components like SidebarGroup, SidebarMenu, or SidebarInput to organize interactive elements and content.
Leverage the component's default styling for overflow management, and only apply custom `className` for additional visual adjustments.
antiPatterns: Placing fixed elements like headers or footers directly within SidebarContent; use SidebarHeader or SidebarFooter instead to maintain proper scrolling behavior for fixed sections.
Nesting SidebarContent directly inside another SidebarContent, as this component is intended for the primary scrollable area, not as a sub-container.
Applying explicit fixed heights or `overflow: hidden` to direct children that are expected to scroll, as SidebarContent already manages its own scroll behavior for its children.

semanticData.summary: Renders a structural container for grouping related items within a sidebar.
semanticData.description: The "SidebarGroup" component serves as a flexible container designed to logically organize related content within a sidebar. It applies specific styling and structural attributes to ensure proper spacing and visual separation for distinct sections. Developers should use this component to improve the readability and navigation of complex sidebars by grouping related items, such as navigation links or settings.

commonUseCases: Grouping navigation links under a common heading in a sidebar.
Organizing settings or configuration options into distinct sections.
Creating logical divisions for different feature areas within a large sidebar.
Structuring content within collapsible sidebar sections.

        <SidebarGroupLabel>Projects</SidebarGroupLabel>
        <SidebarMenu>
          <SidebarMenuButton>All Projects</SidebarMenuButton>
          <SidebarMenuButton>New Project</SidebarMenuButton>
        </SidebarMenu>
      </SidebarGroup>
    </SidebarContent>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical use of `SidebarGroup` to create two distinct sections ('General' and 'Projects') within a sidebar. Each group contains a label (`SidebarGroupLabel`) and a list of menu items (`SidebarMenu`, `SidebarMenuButton`), showcasing the structured organization of sidebar content.

limitations: Primarily intended for use within the larger Sidebar component system; its styling and semantic purpose are optimized for this context.
Assumes the presence and configuration of Tailwind CSS and the `cn` utility for its default styling to function correctly.
bestPractices: Always use SidebarGroup as a direct child of SidebarContent to ensure proper layout and styling integration.
Combine SidebarGroup with SidebarGroupLabel and SidebarGroupContent for a complete and semantically clear group structure.
Keep the content within each SidebarGroup focused on a single logical area to enhance user experience.
Leverage the className prop to apply additional custom styling or overrides using Tailwind CSS utilities.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarGroup as a general-purpose div outside the Sidebar component hierarchy, leading to inconsistent styling.
Nesting SidebarGroup components excessively deep, which can complicate layout debugging and maintainability.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled label for a group of items within a sidebar, adapting visibility based on sidebar state.
semanticData.description: The SidebarGroupLabel component serves as a distinct label for logically grouping related items within the sidebar, such as navigation links or settings sections. It provides visual structure and improves readability within complex sidebars. When the sidebar is in a 'collapsed' state (e.g., in icon mode), the label is automatically hidden, ensuring a clean and compact interface.

commonUseCases: Categorizing navigation links in an application sidebar
Labeling different sections within a settings or configuration panel
Organizing content in a collapsed or expanded sidebar view

examples.code:
<SidebarProvider>
  <Sidebar>
    <SidebarContent>
      <SidebarGroup>
        <SidebarGroupLabel>Application</SidebarGroupLabel>
        <SidebarMenu>
          <SidebarMenuItem>
            <SidebarMenuButton>Dashboard</SidebarMenuButton>
          </SidebarMenuItem>
          <SidebarMenuItem>
            <SidebarMenuButton>Projects</SidebarMenuButton>
          </SidebarMenuItem>
        </SidebarMenu>
      </SidebarGroup>
      <SidebarGroup>
        <SidebarGroupLabel>Settings</SidebarGroupLabel>
        <SidebarMenu>
          <SidebarMenuItem>
            <SidebarMenuButton>Profile</SidebarMenuButton>
          </SidebarMenuItem>
          <SidebarMenuItem>
            <SidebarMenuButton>Billing</SidebarMenuButton>
          </SidebarMenuItem>
        </SidebarMenu>
      </SidebarGroup>
    </SidebarContent>
  </Sidebar>
</SidebarProvider>
examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of SidebarGroupLabel to visually separate and label distinct sections ('Application' and 'Settings') within a sidebar. It's placed inside SidebarGroup components, which are themselves within SidebarContent, creating a clear hierarchical structure for navigation.

limitations: The label is designed to be hidden when the parent Sidebar is in a 'collapsed' (icon) state, meaning it's not visible when space is constrained.
It should primarily contain text or simple inline elements; complex JSX or interactive components are not recommended inside the label.
Its appearance and behavior are tightly coupled with the `Sidebar` and `SidebarGroup` components; using it outside this context may result in unexpected styling or functionality.
bestPractices: Keep labels concise and descriptive for better readability.
Always use SidebarGroupLabel inside a SidebarGroup component to maintain proper structural hierarchy and styling.
Leverage the `asChild` prop when integrating with other Radix UI components or custom elements that need to inherit its styling.
Avoid placing interactive elements directly inside the label; use sibling components for actions.
Ensure the label text remains legible in both expanded and collapsed sidebar states (even if hidden in collapsed, consider the user experience for transition).

semanticData.summary: Renders a small, absolutely positioned action button designed for supplementary actions within a sidebar group.
semanticData.description: The `SidebarGroupAction` component renders a small, absolutely positioned action button typically found within a `SidebarGroup`. It is designed for supplementary actions related to a group of sidebar items, such as 'add new' or 'settings' buttons. The component automatically adjusts its hit area for better mobile usability and is hidden when the sidebar is in a collapsed, icon-only state, ensuring a clean collapsed view.

commonUseCases: Adding an 'add item' or 'configure group' button next to a sidebar group label.
Providing a quick action relevant to a section of navigation links.
Including a 'more options' button for a sidebar category.

examples.code:
