import { Sidebar, SidebarGroup, SidebarGroupAction, SidebarGroupLabel, SidebarContent, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuButton, SidebarProvider } from './ui/sidebar';
import { PlusIcon } from 'lucide-react';

function AppSidebar() {
  return (
    <SidebarProvider>
      <Sidebar>
        <SidebarContent>
          <SidebarGroup>
            <SidebarGroupLabel>
              Projects
            </SidebarGroupLabel>
            <SidebarGroupAction>
              <PlusIcon />
            </SidebarGroupAction>
            <SidebarMenu>
              <SidebarMenuButton>My Project 1</SidebarMenuButton>
              <SidebarMenuButton>My Project 2</SidebarMenuButton>
            </SidebarMenu>
          </SidebarGroup>
          <SidebarGroup>
            <SidebarGroupLabel>Teams</SidebarGroupLabel>
            <SidebarGroupAction asChild>
              <button aria-label="Add Team">
                <PlusIcon />
              </button>
            </SidebarGroupAction>
            <SidebarMenu>
              <SidebarMenuButton>Team Alpha</SidebarMenuButton>
            </SidebarMenu>
          </SidebarGroup>
        </SidebarContent>
      </Sidebar>
    </SidebarProvider>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `SidebarGroupAction` within a `SidebarGroup`. It shows two groups, 'Projects' and 'Teams', each with a `PlusIcon` button. The second example uses `asChild` to render a native button while still applying `SidebarGroupAction` styles and behavior, which is useful when integrating with other UI libraries or custom button components.

limitations: The component is hidden (`display: none`) when the parent `Sidebar` is in `collapsible="icon"` mode, meaning it won't be visible in the collapsed state.
It relies on the `SidebarGroup` for its absolute positioning context, so it should always be a direct or indirect child of `SidebarGroup` to function correctly.
bestPractices: Always include an icon within the `SidebarGroupAction` for clear visual indication of its purpose.

Utilize the `asChild` prop to compose `SidebarGroupAction` with other Radix-UI compatible components (e.g., `TooltipTrigger`, `DropdownMenuTrigger`) for enhanced functionality while maintaining styling.
Keep the action concise and specific to the `SidebarGroup` context to avoid confusion.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarGroupAction for primary navigation links or large interactive elements, as it's styled for small, supplementary actions and relies on absolute positioning.
Placing SidebarGroupAction outside of a `SidebarGroup` component, as its absolute positioning depends on the `SidebarGroup` as its relative parent.

semanticData.summary: Renders a content container for items within a sidebar group, providing default styling for width and text size.
semanticData.description: The SidebarGroupContent component serves as a flexible container for content within a `SidebarGroup`. It provides default styling for text size and width, ensuring consistent presentation of grouped items in the sidebar. This component helps structure the sidebar's internal layout, allowing for logical grouping of related navigation links or controls.

commonUseCases: Organizing a list of sub-navigation links under a group label in the sidebar
Containing settings or filter options related to a specific category in the sidebar
Structuring content within expandable sections of a sidebar

examples.code:
import { Sidebar, SidebarProvider, SidebarGroup, SidebarGroupLabel, SidebarGroupContent, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuItem, SidebarMenuButton } from './sidebar'; import { SettingsIcon, UserIcon } from 'lucide-react'; function MyAppComponent() { return (
Settings General Account Users All Users Roles

Main Content Area

This is where your main application content goes.

 ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `SidebarGroupContent` to wrap menu items within distinct groups in the sidebar. It showcases grouping 'Settings' and 'Users' related navigation links, improving organization and user experience within a complex sidebar.

limitations: Primarily a structural component; it doesn't offer complex layout logic beyond basic width and text styling. For more intricate layouts within the group, nested components or custom CSS will be needed.
Relies on its parent `SidebarGroup` for proper context and visual alignment within the sidebar system.

semanticData.summary: Renders an unordered list (<ul>) styled as a menu container within the Sidebar component system.
semanticData.description: The "SidebarMenu" component serves as a flexible container for navigation items within the "Sidebar". It renders a standard HTML "ul" element, applying default flexbox styling to arrange its children (typically "SidebarMenuItem" components) vertically with a small gap. Developers use this to structure the main navigation sections of a sidebar, ensuring consistent layout and styling.

commonUseCases: Structuring the primary navigation links in a sidebar
Grouping related menu items within a larger sidebar structure

examples.code: <SidebarMenu><SidebarMenuItem><SidebarMenuButton>Dashboard</SidebarMenuButton></SidebarMenuItem><SidebarMenuItem><SidebarMenuButton>Settings</SidebarMenuButton></SidebarMenuItem></SidebarMenu>
examples.description: This example shows how to use "SidebarMenu" to wrap a list of "SidebarMenuItem" components, creating a basic navigation menu within the sidebar.

limitations: It is a presentational component and does not manage menu state (e.g., active items, collapsed/expanded sub-menus) directly; that logic should be handled by parent components or individual menu items.
Relies heavily on the "SidebarProvider" and other "Sidebar" sub-components for proper styling and functionality within the system.
bestPractices: Always use "SidebarMenuItem" and other "SidebarMenu*" sub-components as direct children to ensure consistent styling and expected behavior.
Nest "SidebarMenuSub" components for hierarchical navigation structures.
antiPatterns: Using raw "li" or "a" tags directly inside "SidebarMenu" without wrapping them in "SidebarMenuItem" or "SidebarMenuButton", as this bypasses the intended styling and accessibility features of the sidebar system.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled list item to be used as a container for individual menu items within a sidebar.
semanticData.description: The SidebarMenuItem component renders a styled list item (`<li>`) intended for use within a sidebar navigation menu. It serves as a container for individual menu entries, ensuring consistent styling and proper hierarchical structure within the `SidebarMenu`. This component helps developers build robust and visually cohesive sidebar navigation by providing the foundational list item for interactive elements.

commonUseCases: Structuring individual items within a sidebar navigation list
Providing a container for interactive elements like buttons or links inside a sidebar menu

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use SidebarMenuItem to wrap SidebarMenuButton components, creating a list of navigation items within a SidebarMenu. It shows the typical structure for a simple sidebar navigation.

limitations: The component is primarily a styled wrapper for an `<li>` element; it does not provide interactive logic itself. Interaction should be handled by its children, such as `SidebarMenuButton`.
bestPractices: Always use SidebarMenuItem as a direct child of the SidebarMenu component to maintain correct styling and structural hierarchy.
Nest interactive components like SidebarMenuButton or SidebarMenuSubItem within SidebarMenuItem to provide actionable elements.
Utilize the `className` prop for minor custom styling, but rely on the Sidebar component system for primary layout and appearance.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarMenuItem outside of a SidebarMenu component, as it relies on parent context for certain styles and structure.
Placing complex, non-interactive content directly inside SidebarMenuItem without an appropriate interactive child component (e.g., SidebarMenuButton).

semanticData.summary: Defines the base and variant-specific Tailwind CSS classes for the `SidebarMenuButton` component using `class-variance-authority`.
semanticData.description: This `cva` declaration provides a flexible way to style the `SidebarMenuButton` component based on its `variant` and `size` props. It encapsulates common styling for menu items within a sidebar, ensuring consistency and responsiveness to sidebar state changes like collapse/expand. This helps developers easily apply different visual styles to sidebar menu buttons without writing repetitive Tailwind classes.

commonUseCases: Styling primary navigation items within a sidebar.
Creating different visual states for interactive menu buttons (e.g., outlined vs. filled).
Adjusting the size of sidebar menu buttons for different layouts or density requirements.
Ensuring menu buttons adapt correctly when the sidebar collapses to an icon-only view.

examples.description: Demonstrates the basic usage of `SidebarMenuButton` within a `SidebarMenu` and `SidebarMenuItem`, using the default `variant` and `size`.
Shows how to apply `outline` variant and `sm` size to a `SidebarMenuButton`, along with the `isActive` prop for an active state.

limitations: Primarily designed for the `SidebarMenuButton` component and its specific context within the `Sidebar` structure.
The styling relies heavily on `data-*` attributes (e.g., `data-[collapsible]`, `data-[active]`) which might not be present or behave as expected outside the `Sidebar` component family.
Limited to the predefined `variant` and `size` options; custom styling beyond these variants requires direct class overrides or extending the CVA.
bestPractices: Always pass `variant` and `size` props to `SidebarMenuButton` to leverage the defined styles.
Use the `cn` utility function when combining `sidebarMenuButtonVariants` with additional custom class names to ensure proper merging.
Test the `SidebarMenuButton` in both expanded and collapsed sidebar states to verify visual consistency.
Consider adding new variants to this `cva` if new distinct visual styles are needed for sidebar menu buttons, rather than adding conditional logic in components.
antiPatterns: Hardcoding styles on `SidebarMenuButton` directly instead of using `variant` and `size` props: This defeats the purpose of centralized styling and leads to inconsistent UI.
Ignoring the `group-data-[collapsible=icon]` styles when customizing: Overriding these might break the intended responsive behavior when the sidebar collapses.

Using this CVA for non-sidebar-menu buttons: It is specifically tailored for `SidebarMenuButton` and relies on parent context, so using it elsewhere might result in unexpected styling or require complex overrides.

codeMetadata.name: SidebarMenuButton
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<"button"> & { asChild?: boolean; isActive?: boolean; tooltip?: string | React.ComponentProps<typeof TooltipContent> } & VariantProps<typeof sidebarMenuButtonVariants>): any

parameters.name: _complex_param
parameters.type: React.ComponentProps<"button"> & { asChild?: boolean; isActive?: boolean; tooltip?: string | React.ComponentProps<typeof TooltipContent> } & VariantProps<typeof sidebarMenuButtonVariants>

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled button component for sidebar menu items, supporting visual variants, sizes, active states, and conditional tooltips.
semanticData.description: The SidebarMenuButton component creates interactive buttons designed for navigation within a sidebar menu. It leverages class-variance-authority for flexible styling via variant and size props, enabling different visual appearances. This component also integrates with the sidebar's state to automatically display tooltips when the sidebar is collapsed, and indicates active states for the current navigation item.

commonUseCases: Creating primary navigation links in a sidebar
Implementing actionable items within a sidebar menu (e.g., "Settings", "Dashboard")
Displaying the currently selected page or section with an active visual indicator
Providing tooltip hints for collapsed sidebar icons

examples.description: Demonstrates how to create active and inactive sidebar menu buttons with icons and text. The second button also shows how to add a tooltip, which would appear when the sidebar is collapsed.

Shows how to use the asChild prop to integrate SidebarMenuButton with a routing component like Next.js Link, allowing it to behave as a link while retaining SidebarMenuButton's styling and active state logic.

limitations: Requires a parent SidebarProvider in the React tree to function correctly due to its reliance on the useSidebar context
Tooltips are automatically hidden on mobile or when the sidebar is expanded, which might not be desirable for all tooltip use cases outside of sidebar collapsing
The asChild prop expects a child component that correctly forwards its ref and accepts standard HTML attributes and event handlers
bestPractices: Always wrap SidebarMenuButton within SidebarMenu and SidebarMenuItem for proper structure and styling
Utilize the isActive prop to visually highlight the currently selected navigation item
Provide concise tooltip strings, especially for items in a collapsible sidebar, to explain icons when the sidebar is collapsed
When using asChild, ensure the child component correctly forwards its ref and accepts the props passed to it for accessibility and styling
antiPatterns: Using SidebarMenuButton outside of a Sidebar and SidebarProvider context, as it relies on useSidebar context
Overriding core styling with className when variant or size props can achieve the desired look, leading to inconsistent UI
Applying the tooltip prop when the sidebar is never collapsible, resulting in unnecessary tooltip rendering

codeMetadata.name: SidebarMenuAction
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<"button"> & { asChild?: boolean; showOnHover?: boolean }): any

semanticData.summary: Renders a secondary action button within a sidebar menu item, with optional hover visibility.
semanticData.description: The SidebarMenuAction component renders a small, actionable button positioned to the right within a SidebarMenuItem. It's designed for secondary actions directly associated with a menu item, such as 'edit' or 'delete'. This component intelligently hides when the sidebar is in a collapsed state and offers a 'showOnHover' prop to reveal the action only when the parent menu item is hovered, enhancing visual clarity for less frequently used functions.

commonUseCases: Adding an 'Edit' or 'Settings' button next to a dashboard link in a sidebar.
Providing a 'Delete' action for a list item in the sidebar's navigation.
Implementing a 'More Options' or 'Info' button for a specific menu entry.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to integrate `SidebarMenuAction` within a `SidebarMenuItem` alongside a `SidebarMenuButton`. It shows a common pattern for adding secondary actions like 'archive' or 'edit' that appear on hover, keeping the main menu clean while providing contextual actions for each item. The `showOnHover` prop ensures these actions only become visible when the user hovers over the menu item, reducing visual clutter.

limitations: The component is always hidden when the parent sidebar is in its `collapsed` (icon-only) state, as indicated by `group-data-[collapsible=icon]:hidden` in its styling.
The `showOnHover` functionality is primarily designed for desktop interactions; its behavior might be less intuitive or require extra taps on touch devices.

While it increases the touch target area on mobile (`after:-inset-2 after:absolute md:after:hidden`), relying solely on `showOnHover` for critical actions on touchscreens can lead to a poor user experience.
bestPractices: Use sparingly for clear, secondary actions directly related to the primary SidebarMenuButton.
Consider `showOnHover={true}` for actions that are not critical or frequently accessed, especially to maintain a clean expanded sidebar.
Ensure the icon or content clearly conveys the action's purpose, optionally adding `sr-only` text for accessibility.
Verify the user experience on touch devices if `showOnHover` is utilized, as hover states are less intuitive.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarMenuAction for primary navigation clicks; SidebarMenuButton is the correct component for direct navigation.
Placing critical, essential actions that must always be visible regardless of sidebar state or hover, as it hides in collapsed mode.
Overloading a single menu item with multiple SidebarMenuActions, which can lead to a cluttered and confusing UI.

semanticData.summary: Renders a non-interactive, style-aware badge for displaying supplementary information alongside a sidebar menu button.
semanticData.description: The `SidebarMenuBadge` component renders a small, non-interactive badge element typically used to display counts, status, or other concise indicators alongside a `SidebarMenuButton`. It automatically positions itself relative to its sibling `SidebarMenuButton` and adjusts styling based on the button's active state or hover, and hides itself when the sidebar is in an icon-only collapsed state. This component helps provide quick visual cues without cluttering the main menu item text.

commonUseCases: Displaying unread notification counts next to a 'Notifications' menu item
Showing the number of pending tasks on a 'Tasks' menu item
Indicating the active status of a feature within a sidebar menu
Highlighting new content available for a specific menu section

examples.code:
<SidebarMenuItem>
  <SidebarMenuButton tooltip="View Notifications">
    Notifications
  </SidebarMenuButton>
  <SidebarMenuBadge>5</SidebarMenuBadge>
</SidebarMenuItem>
examples.description: This example shows a common use case: displaying an unread notification count '5' next to a 'Notifications' menu button. The badge automatically positions itself and changes color on hover/active state of the button.

examples.code:
<SidebarMenuItem>
  <SidebarMenuButton isActive tooltip="Project Dashboard">
    Dashboard
  </SidebarMenuButton>
  <SidebarMenuBadge>Live</SidebarMenuBadge>
</SidebarMenuItem>
examples.description: Demonstrates using the badge to indicate a 'Live' status for an active dashboard menu item. The badge's text color will adapt to the active state of the button.

limitations: The component is purely presentational; it does not handle any interactive logic or events itself.
It is automatically hidden when the parent sidebar is in `collapsible="icon"` mode, meaning its content will not be visible in this compact state.
Designed to work specifically within a `SidebarMenuItem` and alongside a `SidebarMenuButton`; its positioning and styling may not be correct outside this context.
Limited styling customization beyond basic `className` and `React.ComponentProps<'div'>` as its core layout is opinionated for badge functionality.
bestPractices: Keep badge content concise, ideally a single number or a very short status indicator.
Pair `SidebarMenuBadge` exclusively with `SidebarMenuButton` within a `SidebarMenuItem` to leverage its automatic positioning and styling.
Ensure the badge content is secondary information that enhances, rather than replaces, the main menu item's meaning.
Consider using a tooltip on the parent `SidebarMenuButton` to explain the badge's meaning if it's not immediately obvious.
antiPatterns: Using `SidebarMenuBadge` for clickable elements or primary interaction; it has `pointer-events-none` and is purely presentational.
Placing lengthy text or complex content inside the badge, which would break its concise design and purpose.
Overloading menu items with too many badges, leading to visual clutter and reduced readability.
Using the badge to convey critical information that isn't also available through the main menu item or a tooltip, as it hides in collapsed icon mode.

semanticData.summary: Displays a visual placeholder (skeleton) for a single sidebar menu item, indicating content is loading.
semanticData.description: The "SidebarMenuSkeleton" component provides a temporary visual representation of a sidebar menu item while its content is being loaded. It helps improve perceived performance by giving users immediate feedback that data is on its way, rather than showing a blank space. It can optionally display a placeholder for an icon alongside the text, mimicking the final menu item's structure.

commonUseCases: Displaying a loading state for individual items within a sidebar menu list.
Providing visual feedback during initial data fetching for the entire sidebar navigation.
Enhancing user experience by preventing sudden content shifts when menu items load.

examples.description: A basic example demonstrating how to render a single SidebarMenuSkeleton component to represent one loading menu item.

Demonstrates rendering multiple SidebarMenuSkeleton components, some with icons, inside a SidebarMenu to simulate a full loading menu. The skeletons should be conditionally rendered based on a data loading state.

limitations: The component is purely presentational and does not manage any loading logic or data fetching itself; it must be driven by external state.
The randomized width for the text skeleton is generated client-side and will be different on each render unless controlled externally or memoized with a fixed seed.
bestPractices: Render SidebarMenuSkeleton components when fetching menu data, and replace them with actual menu items (e.g., SidebarMenuItem or SidebarMenuButton) once the data is successfully loaded.
Use multiple SidebarMenuSkeleton instances within a SidebarMenu to simulate a list of loading items, providing a more realistic loading experience.
Consider animating the appearance or disappearance of the skeletons for a smoother user transition.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarMenuSkeleton as a permanent placeholder instead of actual menu content once data is available, leading to a broken UI.
Not linking the skeleton's visibility to actual data loading states, causing it to flash or remain visible unnecessarily.

semanticData.summary: Renders an unordered list (<ul>) styled as a sub-menu container within the sidebar, typically used for nested navigation items.
semanticData.description: SidebarMenuSub serves as a container for secondary or nested navigation items within the main sidebar menu. It renders an unordered list (`<ul>`) with specific styling to visually indent and structure sub-menu items, enhancing hierarchical navigation. This component is essential for organizing complex menu structures, automatically hiding its content when the sidebar is collapsed to maintain a clean interface.

commonUseCases: Displaying nested links under a primary menu item in a sidebar.
Organizing multi-level navigation for application features within a sidebar.
Creating hierarchical structures for settings or content categories in a side navigation.

examples.code: import { HomeIcon, SettingsIcon, UsersIcon } from 'lucide-react'; import { Sidebar, SidebarContent, SidebarGroup, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuButton, SidebarMenuItem, SidebarMenuSub, SidebarMenuSubButton, SidebarMenuSubItem, SidebarProvider } from './sidebar'; // Assuming sidebar components are exported from here function MyAppComponent() { return ( Dashboard Settings Profile Security Billing Users ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to create a nested menu structure using `SidebarMenuSub`. The 'Settings' menu item contains a sub-menu with 'Profile', 'Security', and 'Billing' options, all properly indented and styled within the sidebar.

limitations: Relies heavily on its parent Sidebar components and their data attributes for correct styling and responsive behavior. It needs to be part of the `SidebarProvider` and `Sidebar` hierarchy to function as intended.
Its visual appearance, including indentation and borders, is tightly coupled with the CSS variables and Tailwind classes defined within the larger sidebar system.
bestPractices: Always nest SidebarMenuSub within a SidebarMenuItem to ensure correct visual hierarchy and accessibility within the sidebar.
Populate SidebarMenuSub with SidebarMenuSubItem and SidebarMenuSubButton components for consistent styling and behavior.
Keep sub-menus concise to prevent overwhelming users, especially when the main sidebar is in a collapsed state.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarMenuSub directly outside of a SidebarMenu or SidebarMenuItem, as its styling and behavior are designed for specific hierarchical nesting.
Employing SidebarMenuSub for general list purposes not related to navigation, as it applies specific visual treatments for sub-menus.

semanticData.summary: Renders a list item to serve as a container for a sub-menu element within a sidebar navigation.
semanticData.description: The SidebarMenuSubItem component is a foundational building block for creating nested menu structures within the sidebar. It renders a basic list item (<li>) and applies specific data attributes and base styling, preparing it to hold interactive sub-menu components like SidebarMenuSubButton. Its primary role is to provide structural integrity and proper semantic nesting for sub-menu elements, ensuring they are correctly positioned and styled as part of the sub-menu list.

commonUseCases: Creating individual entries within a nested sidebar menu section.
Structuring complex navigation paths with multiple levels of menus.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use SidebarMenuSubItem to wrap SidebarMenuSubButton components, creating a list of sub-menu items within a SidebarMenuSub structure.

limitations: This component is purely structural and does not handle any interactive logic or state management itself; it relies on its children for functionality.
It is specifically designed for sub-menu lists and may not render or behave as expected if used outside the SidebarMenuSub context.
bestPractices: Always use SidebarMenuSubItem as a direct child of SidebarMenuSub to maintain the correct visual and semantic hierarchy.
Nest interactive elements like SidebarMenuSubButton directly within SidebarMenuSubItem to ensure proper click handling and styling.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarMenuSubItem directly inside SidebarMenu instead of SidebarMenuSub as its parent, which breaks the intended nesting hierarchy.
Placing non-menu-related content directly inside SidebarMenuSubItem as it's intended for interactive sub-menu buttons or links.

codeMetadata.name: SidebarMenuSubButton
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<"a"> & { asChild?: boolean; size?: "sm" | "md"; isActive?: boolean }): any

parameters.name: _complex_param
parameters.type: React.ComponentProps<"a"> & { asChild?: boolean; size?: "sm" | "md"; isActive?: boolean }

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled, interactive sub-menu item for nested navigation within the sidebar, supporting active states and dynamic sizing.
semanticData.description: The SidebarMenuSubButton component creates a styled, interactive link or button specifically designed for nested items within a sidebar menu. It provides visual feedback for active states and supports different sizes. This component is crucial for structuring multi-level navigation, ensuring sub-menu items are clearly distinguishable and maintaining consistency with the overall sidebar design, automatically hiding when the parent sidebar collapses to an icon-only view.

commonUseCases: Creating nested navigation links for sub-sections within a main sidebar category
Displaying the currently active sub-page or view within a complex application structure
Implementing secondary actions or detailed navigation options under a primary sidebar entry

examples.code: import { Sidebar, SidebarProvider, SidebarMenu, SidebarMenuItem, SidebarMenuSub, SidebarMenuSubItem, SidebarMenuSubButton, SidebarContent } from "@repo/web/components/ui/sidebar"; import Link from "next/link"; import { SettingsIcon, UserIcon, CreditCardIcon } from "lucide-react"; function AppLayout() { const currentPath = "/settings/profile"; return ( Dashboard Settings Profile Billing ); }
examples.description: This example shows how to use `SidebarMenuSubButton` to create nested navigation links within a sidebar. It demonstrates passing `asChild` to integrate with a `next/link` component, and dynamically setting the `isActive` prop based on the current route to highlight the selected sub-item. Icons are included to enhance visual clarity.

limitations: This component is tightly coupled with the `Sidebar` component system; its full functionality and styling are only guaranteed when used within `SidebarMenuSub`.
It is designed to hide automatically when the main sidebar is in its icon-collapsed state (`group-data-[collapsible=icon]:hidden`), meaning sub-menu items are not accessible in that compact view.
Unlike `SidebarMenuButton`, this component does not include built-in tooltip support, requiring manual implementation if tooltips are needed for sub-menu items.
bestPractices: Always wrap SidebarMenuSubButton within SidebarMenuSubItem and SidebarMenuSub for correct visual hierarchy and responsive behavior.
Utilize the `isActive` prop to clearly indicate the user's current location within the sub-menu, enhancing navigability.
Pass standard `<a>` tag props like `href` or `onClick` when using it for navigation or simple actions, potentially with `asChild` for router links.
Keep the text content concise, especially for smaller `size='sm'` variants, to avoid truncation issues.
antiPatterns: Using SidebarMenuSubButton as a top-level menu item; SidebarMenuButton is intended for primary navigation.
Employing SidebarMenuSubButton outside of a SidebarMenuSub context, as its styling and behavior are dependent on the parent sidebar components.
Overriding the built-in `group-data-[collapsible=icon]:hidden` styling when the intent is to show sub-menu items in a collapsed icon-only sidebar (which is not its design purpose).

semanticData.summary: Creates a styled and responsive HTML table component that automatically handles horizontal overflow.
semanticData.description: This Table component serves as the root container for building semantic HTML tables within a React application. It wraps a native <table> element, applying default styling for a consistent look and feel, and automatically adds horizontal scrolling behavior via an outer div to handle wide table content. Developers should use this component as the primary wrapper for their table structures, composing it with other related components like TableHeader, TableRow, and TableCell to build complete data grids.

commonUseCases: Displaying tabular data in a user interface
Building data grids for dashboards or administration panels
Presenting financial reports or log data in a structured format
Creating components that need to render data in a classic table layout

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic structure of using the Table component along with its sub-components to render a simple list of user data. It shows how to define table headers, rows, and cells, and includes a caption for accessibility.

This example shows how to apply custom styles using the className prop on the Table component itself and on individual TableHead and TableCell components, demonstrating how to customize the appearance beyond the default styling.

limitations: Does not include advanced table features like sorting, filtering, pagination, or row selection out of the box; these must be implemented separately.
For extremely large datasets, performance might degrade without external virtualization libraries, as all rows are rendered simultaneously.
The overflow-x-auto behavior is fixed; custom responsive behaviors (e.g., collapsing columns on small screens) would require additional CSS or logic.
bestPractices: Always use this Table component in conjunction with its sibling components (TableHeader, TableBody, TableRow, TableCell, TableHead, TableFooter, TableCaption) to ensure consistent styling and accessibility.
Provide a TableCaption for accessibility and better context, especially for complex tables.
Consider virtualization for very large datasets to improve performance, as this component itself doesn't offer virtualization out of the box.
Pass className for additional custom styling, ensuring it correctly merges with the default styles.
antiPatterns: Using this component for non-tabular data (e.g., general layout where CSS grid/flexbox would be more appropriate)
Overriding core overflow-x-auto behavior without understanding its implications for responsiveness
Manually applying basic table styles instead of leveraging the provided sub-components (TableHeader, TableRow, etc.)

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled `<thead>` HTML element for defining the header section of a table.
semanticData.description: The `TableHeader` component is a React functional component designed to render the `<thead>` HTML element, which semantically represents the header section of an HTML table. It accepts all standard `<thead>` properties, including `className`, which is merged with default styling classes using a utility function. This component helps maintain consistent styling and structure for table headers across an application, solving the problem of repetitive boilerplate for table UI elements.

commonUseCases: Defining column headers for a data table
Structuring the top section of a financial report table
Creating a static header for a complex grid or spreadsheet-like UI

examples.code:
import { Table, TableHeader, TableBody, TableRow, TableHead, TableCell } from './ui/table'; function MyDataTable() { return ( Name Email Status John Doe john@example.com Active Jane Smith jane@example.com Inactive
); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic usage of `TableHeader` within a `Table` component. It showcases how `TableHeader` is used to wrap `TableRow` and `TableHead` components, effectively defining the header row and its column titles for a data table.

limitations: The `TableHeader` component itself is purely presentational and does not handle sorting, filtering, or other interactive table logic; these features must be implemented at a higher component level.
Its styling relies on a project-specific `cn` utility, meaning direct CSS class names might not always be intuitive without understanding the underlying utility.
bestPractices: Always use `TableHeader` as a direct child of the `Table` component.
Place `TableRow` components directly inside `TableHeader`, and `TableHead` components within those `TableRow`s, to correctly structure table headers.
Leverage the `className` prop to apply additional custom styles without overriding the base styling provided by the component.
antiPatterns: Using `TableHeader` to render table body (`<tbody>`) or footer (`<tfoot>`) content, which violates semantic HTML structure and could lead to accessibility issues.

Attempting to add interactive elements directly inside `TableHeader` that are not appropriate for a `<thead>` context (e.g., complex forms), as its primary role is structural and presentational for headers.

semanticData.summary: A React component that renders a stylized `<tbody>` element, automatically removing the bottom border from the last contained table row.
semanticData.description: The `TableBody` component is a wrapper around the native HTML `<tbody>` element, designed to provide a consistent base styling for the body of a table. It automatically removes the bottom border from the last row within the body, ensuring clean table presentation. This component is crucial for structuring tabular data within a React application, integrating seamlessly with other `Table` family components to build complete and visually coherent data tables.

commonUseCases: Structuring the main content rows of a data table
Applying consistent styling to the body section of a table
Building a reusable table component system

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of `TableBody` within a complete `Table` structure. It maps over an array of data to render multiple `TableRow` components inside `TableBody`, correctly structuring the table's content. Notice how `TableBody` wraps the rows that contain the actual data, inheriting its default styling and prop forwarding capabilities.

limitations: As a purely presentational component, `TableBody` does not handle data fetching, sorting, pagination, or any complex state management.
It relies on the `cn` utility for combining class names; custom styles might need careful consideration to override or extend the utility-based default styles.
Its primary purpose is rendering a `<tbody>` element; it does not introduce any complex logic or advanced table features like virtualized scrolling or column resizing.
bestPractices: Always use `TableBody` in conjunction with `Table`, `TableHeader`, `TableRow`, and `TableCell` for a consistent and semantically correct table structure.
Pass an array of `TableRow` components as children to `TableBody` to populate the table with data.
Leverage the `className` prop for any specific custom styling needed, ensuring it complements rather than conflicts with the base styles.
Keep `TableBody` purely presentational; abstract data handling and logic to parent components.
antiPatterns: Using `TableBody` outside of a `Table` component or a native `<table>` element, which would break semantic HTML structure and likely styling.
Attempting to manage data fetching or complex state directly within `TableBody`, as it is a purely presentational component.
Placing elements other than `TableRow` (or standard `<tr>` elements) directly as children, which can lead to invalid table structure and rendering issues.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled `<tfoot>` element for React tables, supporting custom classes and HTML attributes.
semanticData.description: The TableFooter component provides a styled `<tfoot>` element for React-based tables. It semantically groups footer content within a table, applying default styling for borders, background, and font, while also allowing custom CSS classes and standard `tfoot` HTML attributes to be passed through. This component ensures a consistent and accessible table structure, helping developers clearly define the bottom section of their data tables.

commonUseCases: Displaying summary statistics or totals at the bottom of a data table
Adding pagination controls or action buttons within the table's footer
Providing copyright information or source details for table content
Creating accessible table structures by semantically separating footer content

examples.description: This example demonstrates using TableFooter to display summary information (total items and grand total) at the bottom of a product summary table. It shows how TableFooter encapsulates TableRow and TableCell components for footer-specific content, leveraging the `colSpan` property for layout.

limitations: TableFooter is a presentational component and does not manage data or state internally; it only renders its children within a `<tfoot>` tag.
Its primary purpose is semantic structuring and styling, so it doesn't offer complex layout or behavior beyond what standard HTML `<tfoot>` and CSS can provide.
bestPractices: Always nest TableFooter directly inside the Table component, after TableHeader and TableBody, to maintain semantic order.
Utilize it for aggregated data, totals, or metadata that applies to the entire table, ensuring logical separation from header and body content.
Pass standard `tfoot` attributes or custom classes via the `props` object for accessibility or specific styling needs.
antiPatterns: Using TableFooter for general table content that isn't a footer, which violates semantic HTML and can confuse screen readers.
Placing TableFooter outside of a Table component, as it relies on the table context for correct rendering and styling.

semanticData.summary: A React component for rendering a table row ('<tr>') with standardized styling and attribute propagation.
semanticData.description: The TableRow component provides a styled 'tr' HTML element, incorporating a baseline set of CSS classes for consistent appearance, including borders, hover states, and visual feedback for selected states. It acts as a foundational building block for constructing accessible and visually cohesive tables within the UI library, abstracting common styling concerns and ensuring proper HTML table structure.

commonUseCases: Displaying a single row of data within a table body.
Creating interactive table rows that respond to hover or selection states.
Structuring the header row of a data table alongside TableHead components.

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic usage of TableRow within a TableBody component, iterating over data to render multiple rows with corresponding TableCell components. This is the most common use case for displaying tabular data.

This example shows how to use the `data-state="selected"` attribute to apply visual styling for a selected row. By dynamically setting this attribute based on component state, you can leverage the built-in styling provided by TableRow for interactive selection.

limitations: Designed specifically for '<tr>' rendering; not suitable for purposes outside of HTML table structures.
Relies on the `cn` utility for class merging, implying an underlying utility-first CSS framework (e.g., Tailwind CSS) setup in the project.
Does not handle data fetching, sorting, pagination, or other complex table logic; it is a purely presentational component focused on rendering a single table row.
bestPractices: Always nest TableRow components within TableBody or TableHeader components for proper semantic structure and accessibility.
Populate TableRow with TableCell and TableHead components as its children to ensure correct column rendering and content alignment.
Leverage the `data-state` attribute (e.g., `data-state="selected"`) for programmatic selection states, which TableRow will automatically style.
antiPatterns: Using TableRow outside of TableBody or TableHeader: This component is designed to render valid HTML table rows and should always be a direct child of a '<tbody>' or '<thead>' element (or their respective component wrappers like TableBody or TableHeader) to maintain correct table structure and accessibility.

Overriding critical internal TableRow styles without proper class merging: While the component merges `className`, directly conflicting styles might require more specific selectors or '!important' which can lead to maintainability issues. Prefer extending via `className` or leveraging state-based styles that utilize `data-[state]` attributes.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled and accessible `<th>` element for use within a table header row.
semanticData.description: The TableHead component renders a styled table header cell (`<th>`) designed specifically for use within `TableRow` components inside a `TableHeader`. It automatically applies consistent base styling for alignment, padding, and typography, ensuring visual uniformity across your application's tables. This component simplifies the creation of accessible and well-structured table headers by providing a pre-configured building block.

commonUseCases: Defining column headers in standard data tables
Creating sortable or interactive table headers (by nesting interactive elements)
Structuring the header section of a complex report or dashboard table

examples.code:
import { Table, TableHeader, TableRow, TableHead, TableBody, TableCell } from "./table"; function OrdersTable() { return ( Order ID Customer Amount Status #12345 Alice Smith $250.00 Delivered #12346 Bob Johnson $75.50 Pending
); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of `TableHead` to define the column headers within a `TableHeader` section. It shows how to pass standard HTML attributes like `scope` for accessibility and how to apply additional custom styling using the `className` prop for specific alignments.

limitations: This component is primarily intended for use within this specific component library's `Table` ecosystem. Using it with raw HTML tables outside this system might require manual adjustments to ensure consistent styling.

It is a presentational component and does not inherently provide sorting, filtering, or other table logic. Any such functionality must be implemented by nesting appropriate interactive elements or logic inside the `TableHead`.
bestPractices: Always nest `TableHead` components directly inside `TableRow` components, which should be within `TableHeader`.
Utilize the `scope` attribute (e.g., `scope="col"`) for accessibility purposes when defining column headers, passing it directly as a prop to `TableHead`.
For interactive header functionality (like sorting), wrap interactive elements (buttons, links) inside `TableHead` rather than attempting to make the `TableHead` element itself interactive.
antiPatterns: Using `TableHead` directly outside of a `TableRow` within a `TableHeader`: This will result in an invalid HTML table structure and potential accessibility issues.
Applying raw `<th>` elements directly instead of `TableHead` within this component library's table system: Bypassing the component will lead to inconsistent styling and behavior.

semanticData.summary: A React component that renders a styled table data cell (`<td>`) with default layout and appearance.
semanticData.description: The `TableCell` component renders a styled `<td>` HTML element, serving as an individual data cell within a table. It comes with opinionated default styling for padding, alignment, and whitespace handling, which helps maintain a consistent look across tables. This component simplifies table construction by providing a base for data cells while allowing for full customization through standard HTML attributes and a `className` prop.

commonUseCases: Displaying individual data points in tabular reports or dashboards
Building the content cells for a structured data table
Presenting user-generated content in a grid-like format

examples.code:
import { Table, TableBody, TableCell, TableHead, TableHeader, TableRow } from './table'; function MyDataTable() { return ( Name Email John Doe john.doe@example.com Jane Smith jane.smith@example.com
); }
examples.description: Demonstrates basic usage of `TableCell` within a `TableRow`, showing how to display data and apply a custom font weight to one cell and text alignment to another.

limitations: By default, content in `TableCell` will not wrap due to `whitespace-nowrap`. This might require overriding the `className` if multi-line content is desired.
As a wrapper around a `<td>` element, it inherits all standard HTML `<td>` element behaviors and limitations.
bestPractices: Always nest `TableCell` components directly within a `TableRow` for proper table structure and accessibility.
Utilize the `className` prop to apply additional Tailwind CSS classes for specific cell styling (e.g., text alignment, background color) rather than inline styles.
Consider overriding `whitespace-nowrap` if the cell content is expected to wrap onto multiple lines, ensuring readability.
Pass all other standard HTML `<td>` attributes (like `colSpan`, `rowSpan`) directly to the component, as they are spread onto the underlying DOM element.
antiPatterns: Using `TableCell` for header cells (`<th>`)  always use `TableHead` for semantically correct table headers.
Overriding all default styles when only minor adjustments are needed; instead, extend existing styles via `className`.
Placing `TableCell` directly inside `TableBody` or `TableRow` without wrapping it in a `TableRow` component, as it breaks table structure.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled HTML `<caption>` element for providing a descriptive title or summary to a table.
semanticData.description: The TableCaption component renders a styled HTML `<caption>` element, providing a descriptive title or explanation for a table. It acts as a wrapper around the native `<caption>` tag, applying consistent styling and accepting all standard HTML caption properties. This component is crucial for improving table accessibility by giving context to screen readers and enhancing the overall user experience by clearly labeling tabular data.

commonUseCases: Adding a descriptive title or summary to a data table for better context.
Providing accessibility information for screen readers to understand table content.
Ensuring consistent visual styling for table captions across an application.

examples.code:
import { Table, TableCaption, TableHeader, TableRow, TableHead, TableBody, TableCell } from './ui/table'; function MyDataTable() { return ( A list of recent transactions. Date Description Amount 2023-10-26 Groceries $55.00 2023-10-25 Online Subscription $9.99
); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use the TableCaption component to provide a clear title for a simple data table, improving both visual clarity and accessibility.

limitations: This component is purely presentational; it does not handle any data management, sorting, or filtering logic for the table content.
Its proper rendering and semantic meaning are dependent on being used as a direct child of a `<table>` element (or the provided `Table` component).
bestPractices: Always place TableCaption immediately after the opening `<Table>` tag to ensure semantic correctness and proper rendering.
Keep captions concise and informative, clearly summarizing the table's content.
Utilize TableCaption for all tables that present significant data to enhance accessibility and user understanding.
antiPatterns: Using TableCaption outside of a Table component: It is designed to be a direct child of a `<table>` HTML element, which is encapsulated by the Table component.
Placing multiple TableCaption components within a single Table: An HTML table should only have one caption for semantic correctness.

semanticData.summary: Renders an accessible visual separator line with configurable orientation and custom styling.
semanticData.description: The Separator component provides a visually distinct line to divide content or sections within a user interface. It leverages Radix UI's SeparatorPrimitive for accessibility and correct ARIA attributes, offering configurable orientation (horizontal or vertical) and custom styling. This component helps improve readability and organization by creating clear visual breaks.

commonUseCases: Dividing logical sections within a form or dialog
Separating menu items in a navigation bar or dropdown
Creating visual breaks between different content blocks on a page
Segmenting settings options in a preferences pane

examples.description: This example demonstrates using a horizontal separator to divide sections in a form and a vertical separator inline to separate content horizontally. It shows how to apply custom classes for spacing and height.
This example showcases using vertical separators to visually separate navigation links within a horizontal menu bar, improving readability and hierarchy.

limitations: This component is primarily for visual separation and does not inherently provide interactive capabilities like buttons or links.
While accessible, over-reliance on purely decorative separators can sometimes make content less scannable if not paired with clear headings or labels.
Custom styling requires careful use of Tailwind CSS classes (or equivalent) to override the base styles effectively without conflicting.
bestPractices: Use descriptive `className` props for specific styling needs when overriding defaults.
Ensure consistent spacing around separators using CSS utilities to maintain visual harmony.
Consider the `orientation` prop carefully to match the flow of content (e.g., horizontal for vertical stacks of items, vertical for horizontal stacks).
Leverage the `decorative` prop when the separator is purely visual and does not convey semantic meaning to assistive technologies.
antiPatterns: Using Separator for layout instead of proper CSS flexbox or grid; it's meant for visual division, not structural layout.
Overusing separators excessively, which can clutter the UI and make it look too busy instead of clearer.
Applying complex interactive behaviors to a separator; it's a decorative element and not intended for user interaction beyond its visual role.

semanticData.summary: Defines a set of CSS class variants for styling UI buttons using `class-variance-authority` (cva) with predefined styles and sizes.
semanticData.description: This `const` leverages `class-variance-authority` (cva) to create a flexible and maintainable system for styling buttons. It encapsulates various visual styles (e.g., primary, destructive, outline) and sizes, allowing developers to easily apply consistent button aesthetics across an application. It solves the problem of managing complex, conditional CSS classes by providing a declarative API for button styling, ensuring UI consistency and simplifying development.

commonUseCases: Creating consistent button styles within a design system
Applying different visual states (e.g., primary, destructive, secondary) to buttons
Defining various button sizes (e.g., small, large, icon-only)
Integrating with UI frameworks like React to render dynamic button components
Standardizing button appearance across an application

examples.description: Demonstrates the basic usage of the `Button` component, which internally utilizes `buttonVariants` to apply the default 'default' variant and 'default' size.
Shows how to apply different visual variants and sizes to buttons, leveraging the flexibility provided by `buttonVariants` to change appearance declaratively.
Illustrates how to create an icon-only button using the 'icon' size variant, which is optimized for SVG children, and includes an `aria-label` for accessibility.

limitations: Primarily focused on visual styling; it does not handle button logic (e.g., click handlers, form submissions) directly, which must be managed by the component wrapping `buttonVariants`.

Relies on a compatible CSS framework (e.g., Tailwind CSS, due to utility classes like `bg-primary`, `text-sm`, `rounded-md`) for the utility classes to render correctly; it's not a standalone styling solution.
Styles are defined at development time; runtime customization beyond the defined variants requires manual class overriding or extending the `cva` configuration, which can increase complexity.
bestPractices: Always use the `buttonVariants` utility for defining button styles to ensure consistency and maintainability across the application.
Combine `buttonVariants` with a class utility like `cn` (from `clsx` or similar) to merge additional custom classes cleanly without conflicting with the base styles.
Extend `buttonVariants` or create new `cva` instances for highly custom button types only when existing variants are insufficient, rather than creating one-off styles.
Ensure accessibility for icon-only buttons by providing proper `aria-label` attributes when using the `icon` size variant.
antiPatterns: Hardcoding button styles directly in JSX or separate CSS files instead of using `buttonVariants`, leading to inconsistent UIs and difficult maintenance
Overriding `buttonVariants` classes with overly specific CSS or inline styles in a way that breaks the design system's consistency
Using `buttonVariants` for non-button elements, as its styles are specific to button semantics and may include disabled states or focus rings appropriate for interactive elements

codeMetadata.name: Button
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<"button"> & VariantProps<typeof buttonVariants> & { asChild?: boolean }): any

semanticData.summary: A highly customizable React button component offering various styles, sizes, and composition capabilities.
semanticData.description: The `Button` component provides a flexible and visually consistent way to create interactive buttons with predefined styles and sizes. It leverages `class-variance-authority` (cva) for variant management and integrates `radix-ui/slot` for advanced composition, allowing it to render as a different element while retaining its styles. This component solves the problem of consistent UI element styling across an application, ensuring reusability and maintainability for common button interactions.

commonUseCases: Submitting forms or data
Triggering specific actions (e.g., 'Delete', 'Add to Cart')
Navigating to different pages or sections
Displaying interactive elements within a UI
Toggling states or visibility of other components

examples.description: Demonstrates a basic default `Button` used for form submission.
Shows various button variants and sizes, including an icon alongside the text, and a `link` variant.
Illustrates the `asChild` prop to render the `Button`'s styles onto a custom component (e.g., a router `Link`), preserving semantic HTML.

limitations: The component primarily handles visual styling; complex interaction logic (e.g., debouncing clicks, form validation) must be implemented externally.
While `asChild` provides flexibility, ensure the underlying component (e.g., `Link`, `AlertDialogTrigger`) provides appropriate accessibility attributes.
Icon sizing within the button is opinionated (`size-4` by default for non-sized SVGs); custom icon sizes might require explicit `className` overrides on the icon.
bestPractices: Always provide clear and concise text for button labels.
Utilize the `variant` and `size` props to maintain design system consistency rather than inline styling.
When integrating with other components (e.g., a link or a dropdown trigger), use the `asChild` prop to ensure accessibility and correct semantic HTML rendering.
Ensure the button is properly disabled (`disabled` prop) when an action is not possible or is in progress.
Combine with state management (e.g., `useState` for loading) to visually indicate asynchronous operations within the button.
antiPatterns: Overriding core `buttonVariants` styles directly with `!important` classes instead of using the `className` prop for additions or leveraging `cva`'s extend functionality, which makes maintenance difficult.
Using `Button` for purely decorative elements that don't trigger actions, which is an accessibility anti-pattern.
Not disabling the button when a form is submitting or an action is pending, leading to multiple submissions or unexpected behavior.

semanticData.summary: Defines a CVA function for generating styled CSS classes for a UI toggle component based on its `variant` and `size` props.
semanticData.description: The "toggleVariants" constant is a Class Variance Authority (CVA) function that centralizes the definition of CSS classes for a UI toggle component. It enables the creation of a flexible and consistent styling system for toggle buttons by defining base styles along with variant and size options. This solves the problem of disparate styling by providing a single source of truth for the Toggle component's visual appearance, ensuring reusability and maintainability within a design system.

commonUseCases: Styling an on/off switch or checkbox-like toggle button
Creating toggle buttons with distinct visual styles (e.g., filled, outlined, transparent)
Implementing toggle components with predefined size variations (small, default, large)
Integrating custom and consistent styling for Radix UI Toggle primitives

examples.description: This example demonstrates how `toggleVariants` is consumed by the `Toggle` React component. It shows how the `variant` and `size` props are passed to the `toggleVariants` function via the `cn` utility to generate the appropriate CSS classes for the component's root element. The commented-out section illustrates the internal usage pattern within the `Toggle` component itself, showing how it ties the props to the CVA output.

limitations: This declaration solely defines visual styles; it does not handle the functional logic or state management of the toggle component itself.
Its utility is tightly coupled with `class-variance-authority` and is designed to work within a Tailwind CSS-based project.
The generated classes expect specific HTML attributes and states (e.g., `data-[state=on]`, `aria-invalid`) to be present on the element for styles to apply correctly.
bestPractices: Always use `toggleVariants` via the `Toggle` component for consistent styling of toggle elements.
Pass an external `className` property to the `Toggle` component, allowing `cn` to merge it with `toggleVariants` output for style overrides while retaining base styles.
When new visual states or sizes are required for the toggle, extend the `variants` or `size` definitions within `toggleVariants` instead of creating new CVA instances.
Ensure the base styles handle common states like `disabled`, `focus-visible`, and `aria-invalid` to maintain accessibility and user experience.
antiPatterns: Bypassing `toggleVariants` and applying raw inline styles or ad-hoc Tailwind classes directly to a Toggle component, leading to inconsistent UI.
Creating separate CVA instances for each minor variation of a toggle instead of extending or adding variants to `toggleVariants`.
Hardcoding `variant` or `size` values in components instead of passing them as props, reducing reusability and flexibility.

codeMetadata.name: Toggle
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof TogglePrimitive.Root> & VariantProps<typeof toggleVariants>): any

semanticData.summary: A customizable React component that provides a two-state toggle button with styling variants and sizes, built on Radix UI.
semanticData.description: The "Toggle" component is a flexible React UI element designed to implement a two-state switch or button, such as an 'on/off' control or a selection state. It leverages Radix UI's TogglePrimitive.Root for accessibility and core functionality, while class-variance-authority provides highly customizable styling via variant and size props. This component simplifies building consistent and accessible toggle interactions within a design system.

commonUseCases: Implementing 'bold' or 'italic' formatting toggles in a rich text editor
Creating a light/dark mode switch
Building a filter button that can be active or inactive
Controlling the visibility of a section or feature

examples.description: Demonstrates a basic toggle button with an icon and text, suitable for formatting controls in an editor. The `aria-label` ensures proper accessibility.
Shows how to create a controlled `Toggle` component to manage a boolean state, such as a dark mode switch. It applies the 'outline' variant for distinct styling.

limitations: Primarily designed for binary (on/off) states; not suitable for multi-select or complex selection patterns where checkboxes or radio groups would be more appropriate.

The styling is highly dependent on the `class-variance-authority` configuration; custom styles beyond `variant` and `size` props will require extending the `className` or modifying the `toggleVariants` definition.
bestPractices: Always provide clear `aria-label` or surrounding `<label>` for accessibility, especially if the toggle's purpose isn't immediately obvious from context.
Pair toggles with descriptive text or icons that clearly indicate their 'on' and 'off' states.
Consider using `onPressedChange` to manage the component's state if it's controlled, ensuring predictable behavior.
Utilize the `variant` and `size` props to maintain consistent styling across the application and align with the design system.
antiPatterns: Using Toggle for actions that should trigger immediate, irreversible changes; a standard button is more appropriate for such cases.
Overusing multiple toggles in close proximity without clear labels, which can lead to cognitive overload for users.

semanticData.summary: A styled React component wrapping Radix UI's CheckboxPrimitive.Root for accessible user input.
semanticData.description: This Checkbox component is a wrapper around Radix UI's CheckboxPrimitive.Root, providing a pre-styled, accessible checkbox input field. It leverages Tailwind CSS for styling, offering visual states for checked, unchecked, disabled, focused, and invalid states to ensure consistent UI. It's designed for easy integration into forms, inheriting all standard Radix CheckboxPrimitive.Root properties for flexible control.

commonUseCases: Building interactive forms for user input (e.g., sign-up forms, settings pages)
Implementing multi-selection lists or options (e.g., filtering items, selecting categories)
Creating toggle switches for settings or preferences (e.g., email subscriptions, dark mode)
Allowing users to agree to terms and conditions or privacy policies

examples.description: Demonstrates a basic controlled Checkbox component using React's useState hook, along with an associated Label for improved accessibility and user interaction.
Shows a disabled and pre-checked checkbox, useful for indicating a setting that is currently active but cannot be changed by the user.

limitations: Relies on Radix UI for its core accessibility and behavior; direct manipulation of DOM elements or complex custom animations might require deeper integration with Radix primitives.
Styling is opinionated, using predefined Tailwind CSS classes; extensive visual customization beyond prop-based overrides may require modifying the component's source or extending the 'cn' utility.
Does not inherently provide form state management or validation logic; these concerns must be handled externally with React hooks or dedicated form libraries.
bestPractices: Always associate the Checkbox with a <Label> component (using htmlFor/id or wrapping) to ensure accessibility for screen readers and improve click targets.
Integrate with form management libraries (e.g., React Hook Form, Formik) for robust state management, validation, and submission handling.
Utilize the 'disabled' prop to clearly indicate when an option is not interactable, improving user experience.
Apply 'aria-invalid' prop and corresponding styling (if not managed by a form library) to visually indicate validation errors to the user.
antiPatterns: Using a native HTML input type="checkbox" alongside this component, which leads to inconsistent styling and behavior within the UI.
Manually managing the 'checked' state and 'onCheckedChange' without using React state hooks or a form library, complicating state synchronization.
Overriding core Radix UI props in a way that inadvertently breaks accessibility features or expected keyboard navigation.

semanticData.summary: Renders the root element for a collapsible UI component, powered by Radix UI's primitives.
semanticData.description: The Collapsible component serves as the root container for an interactive UI element that can expand and collapse its content. It wraps the Radix UI Collapsible.Root primitive, providing essential accessibility features and state management for its children (Trigger and Content). Developers should use this component to create expandable sections, such as accordions or 'read more' functionality, ensuring a robust and accessible user experience.

commonUseCases: Creating expandable FAQ sections or accordions
Implementing 'show more' / 'show less' functionality for long text
Building toggleable filter sections in dashboards or search results
Displaying optional detailed information that can be hidden initially

examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic FAQ item using Collapsible. It shows how to use `open` and `onOpenChange` to control the component's state, and how `CollapsibleTrigger` and `CollapsibleContent` are used as children.

limitations: The component itself does not provide animations; smooth transitions for content expansion/collapse must be implemented separately using CSS or an animation library.
Relies entirely on Radix UI's underlying `CollapsiblePrimitive.Root` for core behavior and accessibility, inheriting its design patterns and constraints.
bestPractices: Always pair Collapsible with CollapsibleTrigger and CollapsibleContent for complete functionality and accessibility.
Provide clear visual cues (e.g., icons, text changes) for the trigger to indicate the collapsed/expanded state.
When dynamic control is needed, manage the `open` state externally to make it a controlled component.
Integrate with a CSS-in-JS library or traditional CSS for smooth transition animations on content expansion/collapse.
antiPatterns: Using Collapsible solely for visual hiding without a trigger, negating its core purpose.
Nesting an excessive number of Collapsible components without clear visual hierarchy, leading to a confusing user interface.
Attempting to manage the open state directly via CSS or DOM manipulation instead of using the `open` and `onOpenChange` props or `CollapsibleTrigger`.

semanticData.summary: Renders an accessible trigger button for a Radix UI Collapsible component, toggling the visibility of its content.
semanticData.description: The CollapsibleTrigger component renders the interactive element that controls the open/closed state of its associated CollapsibleContent. It acts as a button that, when clicked, toggles the visibility of the content within a Radix UI Collapsible component. This abstraction simplifies usage by forwarding all standard button props while ensuring proper accessibility attributes and behavior, making it crucial for creating accessible and functional collapsible sections.

commonUseCases: Creating an accordion-like UI to show/hide sections of information
Implementing expandable FAQ sections
Building a 'Show More/Show Less' functionality for long text
Designing responsive navigation menus that collapse on smaller screens

examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic usage of CollapsibleTrigger. It's nested within a Collapsible component and controls the visibility of CollapsibleContent. The trigger's text dynamically updates to reflect the current state, providing clear feedback to the user.

limitations: CollapsibleTrigger is designed specifically for use within a Radix UI Collapsible component and will not function correctly if used independently.
Its primary role is to toggle content; it does not inherently provide styling beyond inheriting standard button/DOM element styles, requiring custom CSS for visual appearance.
bestPractices: Always pair CollapsibleTrigger with a corresponding CollapsibleContent within the same Collapsible root to ensure proper functionality and accessibility.
Provide clear visual feedback (e.g., an arrow icon) to indicate the current state (expanded/collapsed) of the collapsible section to users.
Ensure the trigger text or content clearly describes what will be revealed or hidden upon interaction.
antiPatterns: Using CollapsibleTrigger outside of a Collapsible component, as it relies on the context provided by the root component for its functionality.

Attempting to manually control the open/closed state of the collapsible content via the trigger without using the Collapsible component's `open` and `onOpenChange` props, leading to desynchronized state.

semanticData.summary: Renders the content area of a collapsible UI component, which can be expanded or collapsed.
semanticData.description: CollapsibleContent is a React component that wraps the CollapsiblePrimitive.CollapsibleContent from Radix UI, providing the actual content that gets hidden or revealed when a Collapsible component is toggled. It seamlessly passes through all standard Radix UI CollapsibleContent props, allowing for full customization of the collapsible content's behavior and appearance. This component is essential for building interactive UI sections where information needs to be selectively shown or hidden, such as accordions or expandable details.

commonUseCases: Displaying detailed information that is initially hidden, like FAQs or product specifications
Creating accordions where only one section's content is visible at a time
Implementing expandable navigation menus or sidebars
Building "show more/show less" functionality for long text blocks

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic usage of CollapsibleContent within a Collapsible component. The content inside CollapsibleContent will appear when the trigger is clicked and disappear when clicked again, controlled by the parent Collapsible's state.

This example illustrates how to use the `forceMount` prop on CollapsibleContent to enable CSS-based animations. By keeping the content in the DOM, CSS transitions can smoothly animate properties like height and opacity when the `data-state` attribute changes, providing a more fluid user experience during expansion and collapse.

limitations: The functionality and behavior of CollapsibleContent are inherently tied to and dependent on the underlying Radix UI CollapsiblePrimitive.CollapsibleContent component. Its capabilities are constrained by what Radix UI provides.
CollapsibleContent does not manage its own open/closed state; its visibility is entirely controlled by the `open` state prop of the parent Collapsible component.

Animations and transitions for CollapsibleContent must be handled via CSS or animation libraries, often by targeting the `data-state` attribute provided by Radix UI, as the component itself does not provide built-in animation properties.
bestPractices: Always place CollapsibleContent as a direct child or descendant of a Collapsible component to ensure correct functionality and accessibility wiring
Utilize CSS transitions/animations for smooth expand/collapse effects, typically by styling based on the `data-state` attribute ('open' or 'closed') set by Radix UI
Consider using the `forceMount` prop for animating content entry/exit, as it keeps the content in the DOM even when closed, allowing CSS transitions to apply properly
Ensure the content within CollapsibleContent is structured accessibly, using appropriate semantic HTML elements and ARIA attributes if necessary, especially for complex interactive content
antiPatterns: Using CollapsibleContent outside of a Collapsible component, as it will not function correctly or be accessible
Trying to directly control its visibility via props other than those provided by Radix (e.g., attempting to pass an 'open' prop directly to CollapsibleContent)
Placing interactive elements (like forms) that require focus inside CollapsibleContent without proper focus management, especially if it unmounts when closed, leading to a poor user experience

semanticData.summary: Provides the root context for building a Radix UI-based dropdown menu component.
semanticData.description: This DropdownMenu component serves as the foundational wrapper for constructing interactive dropdown menus based on Radix UI primitives. It encapsulates the DropdownMenuPrimitive.Root component, establishing the necessary context for all nested dropdown elements. Developers use it to build accessible and customizable menu UIs, providing the root of a composite component system for various menu interactions.

commonUseCases: Creating contextual menus for actions on specific elements (e.g., right-click menus).
Implementing navigation menus with sub-menus for complex site structures.
Building user profile dropdowns containing settings, logout, and account management options.
Displaying a list of filtered or sorted items in a compact space.

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic structure of a dropdown menu, using DropdownMenu as the root, DropdownMenuTrigger to open it, and DropdownMenuContent to house various menu items. It shows a common pattern for creating a simple user account menu.

limitations: The DropdownMenu component itself does not render any visible UI elements; it merely provides the context for its children. A complete dropdown requires other components like DropdownMenuTrigger and DropdownMenuContent.
Direct styling or animation effects should be applied to the DropdownMenuContent and its children, not the root DropdownMenu component, as it's a logical container.
bestPractices: Always pair DropdownMenu with DropdownMenuTrigger and DropdownMenuContent to create a functional and visible dropdown.
Nest menu items (DropdownMenuItem, DropdownMenuCheckboxItem, etc.) within DropdownMenuContent to form the actual menu options.
Utilize DropdownMenuPortal when the menu content needs to escape parent element overflow or z-index constraints, ensuring it renders correctly on top of other content.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenu in isolation without its necessary child components like DropdownMenuTrigger and DropdownMenuContent, as it only provides the root context.
Attempting to apply visual styling directly to the DropdownMenu root component instead of its content or item sub-components, where styling is actually rendered.

semanticData.summary: Renders dropdown menu content outside the normal DOM flow using a React Portal, preventing clipping and z-index issues.
semanticData.description: The DropdownMenuPortal component is a thin wrapper around Radix UI's DropdownMenuPrimitive.Portal. Its primary purpose is to render dropdown menu content outside of the normal DOM hierarchy, typically directly under the document body. This solves common issues like content being clipped by parent elements with `overflow: hidden` or `z-index` stacking context problems, ensuring the dropdown always appears on top of other elements.

commonUseCases: Ensuring dropdown menu content is not clipped by parent containers with `overflow: hidden` styles.
Managing `z-index` stacking contexts to ensure dropdowns always appear above other page elements.
Used internally by `DropdownMenuContent` to handle its rendering outside the DOM flow.
Creating highly custom dropdown layouts that require explicit portal control.

examples.description: This example demonstrates explicit usage of `DropdownMenuPortal`. While `DropdownMenuContent` typically handles portaling internally, this shows how you could wrap `DropdownMenuContent` or any other element with `DropdownMenuPortal` if you were building a highly custom dropdown system from scratch or needed to override default portal behavior (though not common for this library's provided `DropdownMenuContent`).

This example shows the most common and recommended way to use the dropdown components. The `DropdownMenuContent` component internally handles the use of a portal, meaning developers usually do not need to explicitly include `DropdownMenuPortal` in their JSX.

limitations: Events propagated through the portal will still follow the React component tree hierarchy, not the physical DOM hierarchy, which can sometimes lead to unexpected event bubbling behavior if not understood.

The portal always mounts to the document body by default, which is generally desired for dropdowns, but advanced use cases requiring a different portal target element are not directly supported by this wrapper (requires using the primitive Radix component directly).
bestPractices: For most standard dropdown implementations, rely on `DropdownMenuContent` which automatically uses a portal, avoiding the need to use `DropdownMenuPortal` directly.
When using `DropdownMenuPortal` explicitly, ensure it wraps content that truly needs to be rendered outside its parent's DOM subtree (e.g., custom tooltips, modals within dropdowns).
antiPatterns: Wrapping `DropdownMenuContent` directly with `DropdownMenuPortal` is redundant, as `DropdownMenuContent` already utilizes a portal internally.
