Using `DropdownMenuPortal` for content that does not need to escape its parent DOM element, as it adds unnecessary DOM complexity.

semanticData.summary: Renders the interactive element that opens and closes a Radix UI dropdown menu.
semanticData.description: The DropdownMenuTrigger component acts as the interactive element that, when activated, toggles the visibility of its associated DropdownMenuContent. It directly wraps the Radix UI `DropdownMenuPrimitive.Trigger`, inheriting all its properties and functionality. Developers use this component to designate which element in their UI (e.g., a button, icon, or link) will serve as the gateway to open and close the dropdown menu.

commonUseCases: Creating a button that opens a context menu or action list.
Implementing a user avatar that, when clicked, reveals a profile management dropdown.
Building a 'more options' ellipsis icon that displays additional actions.
Any scenario requiring a clickable element to reveal an overlaying list of items or actions.

examples.description: This example shows the typical use of `DropdownMenuTrigger` with an `asChild` prop, enabling a custom `Button` component to act as the trigger. Clicking 'Open Profile' will reveal the dropdown menu content.

limitations: DropdownMenuTrigger is specifically designed to work with Radix UI's DropdownMenu system and cannot be used independently as a generic trigger for other UI elements.
It requires a parent DropdownMenu component in the React tree to establish the necessary context for its functionality.
bestPractices: Always wrap DropdownMenuTrigger within a DropdownMenu component to ensure proper context and functionality.
Utilize the `asChild` prop to seamlessly transfer focus, keyboard navigation, and accessibility attributes to your custom interactive child component (e.g., a `Button` or `Link`).
Ensure the triggered element provides clear visual feedback and is semantically appropriate for its function, enhancing user experience and accessibility.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuTrigger outside of a DropdownMenu component, which will prevent it from functioning correctly.

Not providing an interactive child element (e.g., just rendering plain text directly) when using the `asChild` prop, as it relies on the child to provide the necessary DOM node for accessibility and interactions.

semanticData.summary: Renders and styles the content panel for a Radix UI dropdown menu, handling positioning and animations.
semanticData.description: The `DropdownMenuContent` component renders the actual content panel of a dropdown menu, encapsulating items like menu items, groups, or separators. It acts as a styled wrapper around Radix UI's `DropdownMenuPrimitive.Content`, applying pre-defined Tailwind CSS classes for consistent styling, animations, and proper positioning (via a Portal). Developers use this to define the visual appearance and layout of the dropdown's opened state.

commonUseCases: Displaying a list of actionable items when a dropdown trigger is clicked
Structuring complex menus with sub-menus and separators
Implementing context menus for specific UI elements

examples.description: This example shows the basic usage of `DropdownMenuContent` within a `DropdownMenu` and `DropdownMenuTrigger`, containing simple menu items and a separator.
Demonstrates how to apply additional custom Tailwind CSS classes to `DropdownMenuContent` using the `className` prop to modify its appearance, while retaining its base functionality and animations.

limitations: This component relies heavily on Radix UI primitives; its direct usage without the underlying Radix `DropdownMenuPrimitive.Content` context will not function correctly.
The pre-applied animations and positioning are opinionated (based on Tailwind CSS and Radix UI's defaults); significant custom styling might require overriding or re-evaluating the approach.
As a client-side component (`'use client'`), it cannot be rendered purely on the server without a client-side hydration step.
bestPractices: Always wrap `DropdownMenuContent` within a `DropdownMenu` (or `DropdownMenuPrimitive.Root`) and typically place it after a `DropdownMenuTrigger` to ensure proper functionality and accessibility.
Utilize the `sideOffset` prop to adjust the distance between the trigger and the content for better visual alignment or to avoid overlap with other elements.
Nest `DropdownMenuPortal` around `DropdownMenuContent` (as done in the provided component) to ensure the dropdown content renders outside the DOM hierarchy of its trigger, preventing clipping issues.
Use provided sub-components like `DropdownMenuItem`, `DropdownMenuLabel`, `DropdownMenuSeparator`, etc., as direct children to maintain consistent styling and accessibility.
antiPatterns: Using `DropdownMenuContent` outside of a `DropdownMenuPrimitive.Root` or `DropdownMenu` component, as it relies on the context provided by its parent Radix components for functionality.
Overriding essential positioning or animation styles with conflicting `className` values, which might break the intended UI behavior.
Placing non-menu related content directly inside, as it's designed for specific menu primitives like `DropdownMenuItem`.

semanticData.summary: Renders a semantic group container for related items within a dropdown menu.
semanticData.description: The DropdownMenuGroup component provides a semantic grouping for related items within a `DropdownMenuContent`. It wraps the Radix UI `DropdownMenu.Group` primitive, ensuring proper accessibility and structure. This component helps organize menu options into logical categories, improving both visual clarity and navigability for users, particularly those relying on assistive technologies.

commonUseCases: Grouping similar actions within a context menu (e.g., 'Edit', 'Delete' actions)
Organizing sets of related settings or preferences in a dropdown menu
Creating distinct sections within a complex dropdown menu for better readability

examples.code:
import { DropdownMenu, DropdownMenuContent, DropdownMenuGroup, DropdownMenuItem, DropdownMenuLabel, DropdownMenuTrigger } from './dropdown-menu';

function MyComponent() {
  return (
    <DropdownMenu>
      <DropdownMenuTrigger asChild>
        <button>Open Menu</button>
      </DropdownMenuTrigger>
      <DropdownMenuContent>
        <DropdownMenuGroup>
          <DropdownMenuLabel>Actions</DropdownMenuLabel>
          <DropdownMenuItem>New Tab</DropdownMenuItem>
          <DropdownMenuItem>New Window</DropdownMenuItem>
        </DropdownMenuGroup>
        <DropdownMenuGroup>
          <DropdownMenuLabel>Preferences</DropdownMenuLabel>
          <DropdownMenuItem>Settings</DropdownMenuItem>
          <DropdownMenuItem>Keyboard Shortcuts</DropdownMenuItem>
        </DropdownMenuGroup>
      </DropdownMenuContent>
    </DropdownMenu>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `DropdownMenuGroup` to create two distinct sections ('Actions' and 'Preferences') within a dropdown menu, each with its own `DropdownMenuLabel` and associated `DropdownMenuItem`s.

limitations: By itself, DropdownMenuGroup does not apply any visual styling; it is primarily for semantic and accessibility grouping. Visual separation must be achieved through styling of its children or the use of `DropdownMenuSeparator`.
bestPractices: Always include a DropdownMenuLabel within a DropdownMenuGroup to provide a clear heading for the grouped items, enhancing accessibility and usability.
Use DropdownMenuSeparator to visually distinguish between different DropdownMenuGroups or sections.
Ensure all items within a single group are functionally related to maintain logical structure.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuGroup for a single item, as it adds unnecessary semantic overhead without benefit.
Nesting DropdownMenuGroups too deeply, which can lead to complex and confusing accessibility trees.

codeMetadata.name: DropdownMenuItem
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof DropdownMenuPrimitive.Item> & { inset?: boolean; variant?: "default" | "destructive" }): any

semanticData.summary: A styled React component for individual interactive items within a Radix UI Dropdown Menu, supporting indentation and visual variants.
semanticData.description: DropdownMenuItem renders an interactive item within a Radix UI dropdown menu. It extends the base Radix UI item with additional styling options, including an `inset` prop for visual indentation and a `variant` prop for applying 'destructive' styling. This component is essential for building structured and visually distinct menu options, enabling clear user interaction within dropdowns.

commonUseCases: Adding clickable options to a dropdown menu
Creating menu items for actions like 'Edit', 'Delete', or 'Save'
Displaying nested menu options with visual indentation
Highlighting dangerous or critical actions within a dropdown with a destructive style

examples.description: Demonstrates a basic dropdown menu with standard clickable items for common navigation or actions like 'Profile', 'Settings', and 'Logout'.

Shows how to use the 'inset' prop for visual indentation (e.g., 'Open File...') and the 'variant="destructive"' prop to style a critical action like 'Delete Account' with a warning color, separated by a line.

limitations: Primarily designed for text-based menu items; complex custom layouts within an item might require wrapping content in a div or similar element for fine-grained control.
Relies on the 'radix-ui' library for core functionality and accessibility, meaning its behavior is inherently tied to the Radix Dropdown Menu component system.

Styling is opinionated, leveraging Tailwind CSS classes. Extensive custom styling that deviates significantly from the default design system might require overriding a substantial number of classes or adjusting the 'cn' utility.
bestPractices: Always place DropdownMenuItem components inside DropdownMenuContent or DropdownMenuGroup to ensure correct accessibility, keyboard navigation, and styling.
Use the 'inset' prop for visual hierarchy within sub-menus or for items that are conceptually nested, improving readability.
Leverage the 'variant="destructive"' prop for actions that have significant consequences (e.g., deleting data) to provide clear visual cues and prevent accidental clicks.
Combine DropdownMenuItem with DropdownMenuShortcut to display associated keyboard shortcuts, enhancing the user experience for frequent actions.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuItem as a standalone component outside of a DropdownMenuContent or DropdownMenuGroup, as it relies on the Radix UI context for proper behavior and styling.
Overriding essential styling props that are controlled by 'inset' or 'variant' without careful consideration, which can lead to inconsistent UI.
Applying non-interactive content directly within a DropdownMenuItem when DropdownMenuLabel or a custom component would be more semantically appropriate, as MenuItem is designed for actions.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled dropdown menu item with a checkbox indicator, built on Radix UI's CheckboxItem primitive.
semanticData.description: The DropdownMenuCheckboxItem component provides a styled and interactive checkbox item for use within a Radix UI dropdown menu. It extends the functionality of Radix's CheckboxItem by applying predefined Tailwind CSS classes for consistent styling and automatically displaying a checkmark indicator when checked. This component simplifies the creation of accessible and visually integrated multi-selectable options within dropdown interfaces.

commonUseCases: Toggling specific settings or preferences within a dropdown menu
Filtering a list of items based on multiple selected categories
Implementing multi-select options in a context menu
Allowing users to opt-in or out of features directly from a menu

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `DropdownMenuCheckboxItem` to create a menu with togglable options. It showcases controlling the `checked` state using React's `useState` hook and how to disable an item.

limitations: Relies on `radix-ui/react-dropdown-menu` for its core functionality; requires this dependency to be installed.
The default styling is opinionated and uses Tailwind CSS classes. Extensive custom styling may require overriding classes or providing custom `className` props.
Should only be used as a child of `DropdownMenuContent` or `DropdownMenuSubContent` to function correctly within the dropdown structure.
bestPractices: Always manage the `checked` state using a state variable and update it via `onCheckedChange` for controlled behavior.
Nest `DropdownMenuCheckboxItem` within `DropdownMenuContent` to ensure proper positioning and accessibility.
Provide clear and concise children (text label) that accurately describe the checkbox item's purpose for better user experience and accessibility.
Combine with `DropdownMenuLabel` or `DropdownMenuSeparator` to group related checkbox items for improved readability.
antiPatterns: Using it for single-selection scenarios; `DropdownMenuRadioItem` is more appropriate for exclusive choices.
Attempting to render it outside of a `DropdownMenuContent` component, which will lead to rendering issues.
Not controlling its `checked` state, leading to a static or unresponsive checkbox.
Overly customizing its internal structure, as it wraps a Radix primitive and expects a specific internal layout for the checkmark.

semanticData.summary: Renders a container for mutually exclusive radio items within a dropdown menu.
semanticData.description: This component acts as a container for a set of DropdownMenuRadioItem components, enabling users to select a single option from a list of choices within a dropdown menu. It leverages Radix UI's RadioGroup primitive to ensure proper accessibility and keyboard navigation for radio-button-like behavior, providing a standardized way to manage exclusive selections. This simplifies building menus where only one option can be active at a time.

commonUseCases: Allowing users to select a single font size from a predefined list within a dropdown
Choosing a preferred theme (e.g., light, dark, system) from a dropdown menu
Selecting a display density setting (e.g., compact, comfortable) in an application's menu
Switching between different viewing modes (e.g., list view, grid view) exclusively

examples.description: Demonstrates how to create a dropdown menu with a radio group for theme selection. The `value` prop controls the currently selected item, and `onValueChange` updates the state when a new item is selected. This ensures only one theme can be active at a time, providing a clear user choice.

limitations: Strictly designed for mutually exclusive selections; it cannot be used for multi-select scenarios.
Requires DropdownMenuRadioItem as its direct children to function correctly as a radio group.
Requires explicit state management (e.g., via `useState` in React) for its `value` and `onValueChange` props.
Does not automatically render visual indicators or content for the radio items; DropdownMenuRadioItem is responsible for this.
bestPractices: Always nest DropdownMenuRadioItem components directly inside DropdownMenuRadioGroup for correct functionality and accessibility.
Manage the selected value state in the parent component and pass it via the 'value' prop, updating it with 'onValueChange'.
Ensure each DropdownMenuRadioItem has a clear, descriptive label or content to inform the user of its purpose.
Combine with DropdownMenuLabel or DropdownMenuSeparator for better organization within the group if needed.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuRadioGroup for options where multiple selections are allowed; use DropdownMenuCheckboxItem instead.
Placing non-radio items directly inside, as they will not inherit the correct radio group behavior and accessibility.
Attempting to use it for hierarchical or nested menu structures that don't represent a single choice.

semanticData.summary: A styled React component representing a single radio button item within a dropdown menu's radio group.
semanticData.description: DropdownMenuRadioItem is a React component that wraps Radix UI's DropdownMenu.RadioItem, applying custom styling and enhancing its presentation. It is designed to be used within a DropdownMenuRadioGroup to create a set of mutually exclusive options where only one can be selected at a time. This component provides the necessary accessibility attributes and visual feedback for a radio item, including an indicator for the selected state.

commonUseCases: Allowing users to select one option from a list of choices within a dropdown, like selecting a theme (Light, Dark, System)
Configuring a 'sort by' preference where only one sorting criterion can be active at a time
Implementing filter options in a menu where filters are mutually exclusive

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use DropdownMenuRadioItem within a DropdownMenuRadioGroup to allow a user to select a single theme (Light, Dark, or System). The 'value' prop on the radio items, along with the 'value' and 'onValueChange' props on the radio group, ensures proper state management for the mutually exclusive selection.

limitations: Relies on the parent DropdownMenuRadioGroup component to manage the selected state and behavior.
Inherits all limitations and requirements of the underlying Radix UI DropdownMenu.RadioItem component.
bestPractices: Always wrap DropdownMenuRadioItem components within a DropdownMenuRadioGroup to ensure correct radio button behavior and accessibility.
Provide meaningful 'children' (text content) for each radio item to clearly indicate its purpose to the user.
Ensure each DropdownMenuRadioItem within a group has a distinct and unique 'value' prop for proper state management.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuRadioItem outside of a DropdownMenuRadioGroup, as it will not function correctly as a radio button and will lack proper group behavior.
Not providing a unique 'value' prop for each radio item within a group, which can lead to incorrect state management and selection issues.

codeMetadata.name: DropdownMenuLabel
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof DropdownMenuPrimitive.Label> & { inset?: boolean }): any

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled, accessible label within a Radix UI dropdown menu, optionally with an inset.
semanticData.description: The DropdownMenuLabel component provides a semantically correct and visually styled label for sections or groups within a dropdown menu. It wraps the Radix UI DropdownMenuPrimitive.Label and applies base styling for typography and spacing. An optional 'inset' prop allows for visual indentation, aligning with common UI patterns for nested menu items or labels.

commonUseCases: Adding a non-interactive title for a group of related items in a dropdown
Separating sections within a complex dropdown menu
Providing context for a set of options like 'Account Settings' or 'Privacy'

examples.code: <DropdownMenu><DropdownMenuTrigger asChild><Button variant="outline">Open</Button></DropdownMenuTrigger><DropdownMenuContent className="w-56"><DropdownMenuLabel>My Account</DropdownMenuLabel><DropdownMenuItem>Profile</DropdownMenuItem><DropdownMenuItem>Billing</DropdownMenuItem><DropdownMenuItem>Settings</DropdownMenuItem></DropdownMenuContent></DropdownMenu>
examples.description: Demonstrates using DropdownMenuLabel to provide a title for the account-related options within a dropdown menu.

examples.code: <DropdownMenu><DropdownMenuTrigger asChild><Button variant="outline">Open</Button></DropdownMenuTrigger><DropdownMenuContent className="w-56"><DropdownMenuGroup><DropdownMenuLabel>Application</DropdownMenuLabel><DropdownMenuItem>New Tab</DropdownMenuItem><DropdownMenuItem>New Window</DropdownMenuItem></DropdownMenuGroup><DropdownMenuSeparator /><DropdownMenuGroup><DropdownMenuLabel inset>Danger Zone</DropdownMenuLabel><DropdownMenuItem variant="destructive">Delete Account</DropdownMenuItem></DropdownMenuGroup></DropdownMenuContent></DropdownMenu>
examples.description: Illustrates the 'inset' prop, making the 'Danger Zone' label visually aligned with indented menu items, indicating a sub-section or special category.

limitations: Not interactive: This component is purely for labeling and does not support click handlers or keyboard interactions as a menu item would.
Styling is primarily handled via 'className' and the 'inset' prop; extensive custom styling might require deeper overrides.
bestPractices: Place labels at the beginning of a DropdownMenuGroup to clearly define the group's purpose.
Keep label text concise and descriptive to improve scannability.
Utilize the 'inset' prop when the label visually belongs to a nested section or aligns with indented items.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuLabel as an interactive item: It's a label, not a clickable action. Use DropdownMenuItem instead.
Placing interactive elements directly inside a label: Labels should contain only text or simple icons, not buttons or inputs.
Overusing labels: Too many labels can make the dropdown cluttered and hard to navigate; use sparingly for logical grouping.

semanticData.summary: Renders a visual separator line within a dropdown menu to group or separate menu items.
semanticData.description: The DropdownMenuSeparator component renders a visual horizontal line within a dropdown menu, used to logically group related menu items or separate distinct sections. It acts as a visual divider, enhancing the user experience by making long menus more scannable and organized. This component is a styled wrapper around the Radix UI DropdownMenu.Separator primitive, inheriting its accessibility features and basic functionality.

commonUseCases: Visually separating action items from navigation links in a dropdown
Dividing groups of related options, such as 'Edit', 'Delete' from 'Settings', 'Logout'
Improving readability of lengthy dropdown menus by breaking them into sections

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use DropdownMenuSeparator to create a visual break between 'Profile' and 'Settings' (user-related actions) and 'Log out' (an account action), making the menu structure clearer.

limitations: The separator is purely presentational; it does not add any semantic grouping or accessibility roles beyond what its underlying Radix primitive provides.
Customization is primarily through CSS classes; complex interactive separator behaviors are not supported.
bestPractices: Use separators judiciously to denote clear thematic breaks or logical groupings of items.
Place separators between distinct categories of actions or information to improve menu navigability.
Ensure consistent styling of separators across all dropdown menus for a unified UI experience.
antiPatterns: Using multiple separators consecutively without any items in between, which creates unnecessary clutter.
Using separators purely for spacing, instead of logical grouping; use padding or margins on items if spacing is the goal.
Placing a separator as the very first or last item in a dropdown menu, as it serves no functional purpose there.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled span element to display keyboard shortcuts or accessory text within a dropdown menu item.
semanticData.description: The DropdownMenuShortcut component provides a pre-styled <span> element specifically designed to display keyboard shortcuts or accessory text within a DropdownMenuItem. It automatically applies styling to position the text to the right, use smaller text, and apply muted colors, ensuring it visually separates from the main menu item text while maintaining context. This component helps maintain consistent UI for displaying keyboard shortcuts in dropdown menus.

commonUseCases: Displaying keyboard shortcuts (e.g., 'S', 'Ctrl+P') next to a dropdown menu item's label
Adding secondary, muted text to the right side of a menu item
Visually indicating keyboard accessibility for specific menu actions

examples.description: This example shows how to add a keyboard shortcut 'T' to a 'New Tab' dropdown menu item. The DropdownMenuShortcut component automatically positions 'T' to the far right with muted, smaller text, providing a clear visual cue.

limitations: The 'ml-auto' (margin-left: auto) class applied by default positions the shortcut to the far right within its flex parent. Custom positioning requires overriding these default styles.

This component is purely for display; it does not handle the actual detection or execution of keyboard shortcuts. That functionality must be managed by the parent component or a global keydown listener.
It is a simple 'span' element and does not offer complex layout or interactive features beyond displaying text.
bestPractices: Always use DropdownMenuShortcut as a child of DropdownMenuItem to ensure correct visual alignment and styling.
Keep the shortcut text concise and use common, recognizable key combinations (e.g., 'X', 'Shift+Del').
Ensure consistent formatting for shortcuts across your application for better user experience.
Remember that this component only displays the shortcut; the actual keyboard event handling must be implemented separately.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuShortcut for the primary text content of a menu item; it's intended for supplementary text.
Placing it outside of a flex container or a context where 'ml-auto' (margin-left: auto) would not correctly push it to the right.
Attempting to make it interactive; it's a display component, not an input handler for shortcuts.

semanticData.summary: Wraps the Radix UI DropdownMenu.Sub primitive to provide context for nested dropdown menus.
semanticData.description: DropdownMenuSub is a foundational component for creating multi-level dropdown menus. It acts as a context provider for sub-menus, allowing DropdownMenuSubTrigger and DropdownMenuSubContent to function correctly within its scope. This solves the problem of organizing complex menu hierarchies, making it straightforward to build intuitive navigation structures with nested options.

commonUseCases: Creating a multi-level navigation menu with nested categories
Organizing a large number of actions within a single dropdown, grouping related items into sub-menus
Implementing context menus with hierarchical options

examples.code:
import { DropdownMenu, DropdownMenuTrigger, DropdownMenuContent, DropdownMenuItem, DropdownMenuSub, DropdownMenuSubTrigger, DropdownMenuSubContent, DropdownMenuSeparator } from './dropdown-menu';

function MyComponent() {
  return (
    <DropdownMenu>
      <DropdownMenuTrigger>Open Menu</DropdownMenuTrigger>
      <DropdownMenuContent>
        <DropdownMenuItem>New Tab</DropdownMenuItem>
        <DropdownMenuItem>New Window</DropdownMenuItem>
        <DropdownMenuSeparator />
        <DropdownMenuSub>
          <DropdownMenuSubTrigger>Share</DropdownMenuSubTrigger>
          <DropdownMenuSubContent>
            <DropdownMenuItem>Email</DropdownMenuItem>
            <DropdownMenuItem>Messages</DropdownMenuItem>
            <DropdownMenuSeparator />
            <DropdownMenuItem>More...</DropdownMenuItem>
          </DropdownMenuSubContent>
        </DropdownMenuSub>
        <DropdownMenuSeparator />
        <DropdownMenuItem>Print</DropdownMenuItem>
      </DropdownMenuContent>
    </DropdownMenu>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use DropdownMenuSub to create a nested 'Share' menu within a main dropdown. The DropdownMenuSub component wraps the sub-trigger and sub-content, providing the necessary context for the nested menu to appear and function correctly.

limitations: As a wrapper around Radix UI's primitive, its functionality is entirely dependent on the underlying Radix component's capabilities and limitations
It doesn't provide any visual styling on its own; styling is handled by its DropdownMenuSubContent child and other related components
bestPractices: Always pair DropdownMenuSub with DropdownMenuSubTrigger and DropdownMenuSubContent to ensure a functional nested menu
Use DropdownMenuSub sparingly for essential grouping to maintain a shallow and easily navigable menu structure
Consider keyboard navigation and accessibility when designing nested menus
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuSub without a corresponding DropdownMenuSubTrigger and DropdownMenuSubContent, as it requires these children to be functional
Nesting DropdownMenuSub excessively deep, which can lead to a poor user experience and difficult navigation

codeMetadata.name: DropdownMenuSubTrigger
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof DropdownMenuPrimitive.SubTrigger> & { inset?: boolean }): any

semanticData.summary: Renders a trigger component that expands a nested dropdown menu within a larger dropdown.
semanticData.description: The DropdownMenuSubTrigger component acts as the interactive element that, when clicked or hovered, opens a nested dropdown menu (DropdownMenuSubContent). It provides a standard UI for expanding menu hierarchies, allowing users to navigate deeper into menu options. This component is essential for organizing complex menu structures, improving user experience by decluttering main menus and presenting related options only when needed.

commonUseCases: Creating multi-level navigation menus in application headers or sidebars
Organizing a large number of related actions or settings within a single menu into sub-categories
Implementing nested context menus for complex UI elements
Providing progressive disclosure of options to prevent overwhelming users

examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic usage of DropdownMenuSubTrigger within a DropdownMenu. Clicking or hovering 'More Tools' will open a sub-menu with 'Developer Tools' and 'Task Manager' options. The `inset` prop aligns it with other items.

limitations: This component is specifically designed for sub-menus within the Radix UI DropdownMenu system and is not intended for standalone use.
Customizing the chevron icon requires directly passing children or overriding styles, as it's hardcoded into the component's structure.
bestPractices: Always wrap DropdownMenuSubTrigger within a DropdownMenuSub component, and ensure it is followed by a DropdownMenuSubContent.
Use the `inset` prop when the sub-trigger should align visually with other inset items in the parent dropdown.
Keep sub-menu options concise and clearly related to the sub-trigger's label.
Consider using the `children` prop to include an appropriate icon or text label for clear indication of its purpose.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuSubTrigger as a standalone trigger for a primary dropdown; it should always be nested within a DropdownMenuSub component.
Placing a DropdownMenuSubTrigger without a corresponding DropdownMenuSubContent, which would lead to a non-functional sub-menu.
Over-nesting sub-menus (more than 2-3 levels deep) can lead to poor user experience and navigation difficulty.

semanticData.summary: Renders the styled content container for a nested dropdown menu, providing default animations and accessibility.
semanticData.description: The DropdownMenuSubContent component renders the popover content for a nested dropdown menu. It is an extension of Radix UI's DropdownMenu.SubContent primitive, providing default styling, animations for opening and closing (fade, zoom, slide), and accessibility features out of the box. This component ensures that sub-menus appear consistently and smoothly, enhancing the user experience for complex navigational structures.

commonUseCases: Creating multi-level navigation menus where parent items reveal sub-options
Organizing a large number of related actions within a compact dropdown
Implementing contextual menus with hierarchical choices
Building application settings or configuration menus with nested categories

examples.code:
import { DropdownMenu, DropdownMenuContent, DropdownMenuItem, DropdownMenuSeparator, DropdownMenuShortcut, DropdownMenuSub, DropdownMenuSubContent, DropdownMenuSubTrigger, DropdownMenuTrigger } from './dropdown-menu';

function AppMenu() {
  return (
    <DropdownMenu>
      <DropdownMenuTrigger>Open Menu</DropdownMenuTrigger>
      <DropdownMenuContent>
        <DropdownMenuItem>New Tab</DropdownMenuItem>
        <DropdownMenuItem>New Window</DropdownMenuItem>
        <DropdownMenuSeparator />
        <DropdownMenuSub>
          <DropdownMenuSubTrigger>Share</DropdownMenuSubTrigger>
          <DropdownMenuSubContent>
            <DropdownMenuItem>Email link</DropdownMenuItem>
            <DropdownMenuItem>Messages</DropdownMenuItem>
            <DropdownMenuSeparator />
            <DropdownMenuItem>More options...</DropdownMenuItem>
          </DropdownMenuSubContent>
        </DropdownMenuSub>
        <DropdownMenuSeparator />
        <DropdownMenuItem>Print <DropdownMenuShortcut>P</DropdownMenuShortcut></DropdownMenuItem>
      </DropdownMenuContent>
    </DropdownMenu>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to create a basic dropdown menu with a nested 'Share' sub-menu. The `DropdownMenuSubContent` component contains the items specific to the 'Share' option, appearing only when the 'Share' trigger is hovered or clicked.

limitations: Relies on the `position: absolute` context provided by its parent Radix primitives, so custom styling that interferes with positioning might require careful adjustment.
While it provides basic animations, complex custom entry/exit transitions might require overriding the default Tailwind classes or integrating with a dedicated animation library.
Performance can degrade with an extremely large number of items or very deeply nested structures, similar to any complex DOM rendering.
bestPractices: Always wrap DropdownMenuSubContent within a DropdownMenuSub and associate it with a DropdownMenuSubTrigger.
Keep sub-menu content concise and relevant to the trigger item.
Ensure proper keyboard navigation is maintained, which Radix UI handles largely by default, but custom content might require attention.
Use descriptive labels for sub-menu items to clearly indicate their purpose.
Consider the overall depth of your menu structure; aim for shallow hierarchies to maintain usability.
antiPatterns: Using DropdownMenuSubContent without a parent DropdownMenuSub and DropdownMenuSubTrigger, as it relies on this structure for proper functionality and positioning.
Nesting too many levels deep (e.g., more than 2-3 sub-menus), which can lead to a cumbersome and confusing user experience.
Placing unrelated content or complex interactive elements (like forms) directly inside, as it's designed for simple menu items.
Overriding critical positioning or animation classes in a way that breaks the intended user experience or accessibility.

semanticData.summary: Acts as the root container for a customizable and accessible dropdown (select) component, built upon Radix UI primitives.
semanticData.description: The "Select" component is the foundational root for constructing a complete and accessible select (dropdown) UI. It directly wraps Radix UI's "SelectPrimitive.Root", enabling the management of dropdown state and value selection. This component is designed to be composed with other "Select.*" sub-components (like "SelectTrigger", "SelectContent", and "SelectItem") to create a fully functional and styled select input, inheriting Radix UI's robust accessibility features.

commonUseCases: Creating a custom styled dropdown for form inputs
Implementing accessible selection menus for a list of options
Building a component allowing users to pick from a predefined set of values
Integrating a themable select input for application settings or filters

examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic controlled "Select" component. It uses React's "useState" to manage the selected framework, illustrating how "Select", "SelectTrigger", "SelectValue", "SelectContent", "SelectGroup", "SelectLabel", and "SelectItem" are composed together to create a functional dropdown menu. The "placeholder" prop on "SelectValue" provides initial text when no item is selected.

limitations: The "Select" component itself doesn't provide visual styling; styling is applied through its sub-components like "SelectTrigger" and "SelectContent" via Tailwind CSS classes and custom logic.
Does not inherently support multi-select functionality; a separate approach or a different component would be needed for that use case.
Customization of the core Radix UI behavior requires diving into Radix's documentation or extending its primitive components directly, as this component is primarily a styled wrapper.
bestPractices: Always compose "Select" with its required sub-components (e.g., "SelectTrigger", "SelectValue", "SelectContent", "SelectItem") to build a complete and functional dropdown.
Manage the selected value using the "value" and "onValueChange" props on the root "Select" component for controlled state management, ensuring predictable behavior.
Ensure each "SelectItem" has a unique "value" prop to correctly identify and handle selections.
antiPatterns: Attempting to render "SelectContent" or "SelectItem" directly without wrapping them in the root "Select" component, as they depend on the context provided by "SelectPrimitive.Root".
Not providing an "onValueChange" handler when using the "value" prop, leading to an uncontrolled component state where the UI does not reflect the desired application state.

semanticData.summary: A React component that semantically groups related items within a custom select dropdown menu, based on Radix UI's SelectPrimitive.Group.
semanticData.description: The SelectGroup component is a thin wrapper around Radix UI's SelectPrimitive.Group, designed to semantically and visually group related options within a custom select dropdown menu. It helps organize long lists of choices into logical sections, improving user experience and readability. This component is essential for structuring complex select inputs where categories of items need to be clearly delineated.

commonUseCases: Categorizing countries by continent in a location selector
Grouping settings options (e.g., 'General', 'Security', 'Notifications')
Organizing product variants like 'Sizes' or 'Colors' in an e-commerce interface
Structuring a long list of choices into logical sections to improve navigability

examples.code:
import { Select, SelectContent, SelectGroup, SelectItem, SelectLabel, SelectTrigger, SelectValue } from './select';

function MyCategorySelector() {
  return (
    <Select>
      <SelectTrigger className="w-[180px]">
        <SelectValue placeholder="Select a category" />
      </SelectTrigger>
      <SelectContent>
        <SelectGroup>
          <SelectLabel>Fruits</SelectLabel>
          <SelectItem value="apple">Apple</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="banana">Banana</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="grape">Grape</SelectItem>
        </SelectGroup>
        <SelectGroup>
          <SelectLabel>Vegetables</SelectLabel>
          <SelectItem value="carrot">Carrot</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="broccoli">Broccoli</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="spinach">Spinach</SelectItem>
        </SelectGroup>
      </SelectContent>
    </Select>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use SelectGroup to categorize items within a dropdown. 'Fruits' and 'Vegetables' are distinct groups, each with its own label and set of selectable items, making a longer list of options more manageable and intuitive for the user.

limitations: SelectGroup itself does not add any interactive behavior beyond acting as a container; its primary function is structural and semantic.
It inherits limitations from Radix UI's Select.Group, such as not supporting deep nesting of groups.
Relies on sibling components like SelectLabel and SelectItem to be effective and accessible.
bestPractices: Always include a SelectLabel as the first child of SelectGroup for proper labeling and accessibility.
Use SelectGroup only when there's a clear, distinct category of items that benefits from visual separation.
Keep the group labels concise and descriptive to quickly convey the category's content.
Limit the number of groups to avoid overwhelming the user with too many sections.
antiPatterns: Using SelectGroup for only a couple of items, as it can add unnecessary visual clutter.
Nesting SelectGroup components, which is not supported and will lead to an incorrect or confusing UI structure.
Omitting SelectLabel within a SelectGroup, which harms accessibility and makes the group's purpose unclear.

semanticData.summary: Renders the currently selected value within a Radix UI-based Select component's trigger.
semanticData.description: The SelectValue component is a wrapper around Radix UI's SelectPrimitive.Value, designed to display the currently active item within a custom Select dropdown. It automatically reflects the value managed by the parent Select component, providing immediate visual feedback to the user about their selection. This component is crucial for creating accessible and user-friendly select inputs where the chosen option needs to be visible in the trigger.

commonUseCases: Displaying the chosen option in a standard dropdown menu
Showing the active filter value in a data filtering interface
Presenting a selected language, theme, or currency in application settings

examples.description: This example demonstrates how SelectValue is used within a SelectTrigger to display the currently selected framework. The placeholder text is shown when no value is selected, and then replaced by the chosen item's value.

limitations: Cannot be used independently; it must be a child of SelectTrigger within a Select component hierarchy to function correctly.
Does not manage the select's state or value; it only displays the value provided by the parent SelectPrimitive.Root component.
bestPractices: Always embed SelectValue inside a SelectTrigger to ensure proper visual display and accessibility integration with the select input.
Rely on the parent Select component's 'value' prop to manage the displayed value, rather than trying to control SelectValue's content imperatively.
antiPatterns: Attempting to manually set its children or value prop directly; its content is controlled by the parent Select component's state.
Using SelectValue outside of a SelectTrigger component within a Select root, as it expects to be part of that specific component hierarchy for correct functionality.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled and interactive trigger button for a Radix UI Select component, with optional size variations.
semanticData.description: The SelectTrigger component serves as the visible button or element that, when interacted with, toggles the open state of a Radix UI Select component's dropdown menu. It extends the functionality of Radix UI's `SelectPrimitive.Trigger` by applying a default set of robust Tailwind CSS styles for a consistent look and feel, and introduces a `size` prop to easily control its height, offering 'sm' and 'default' options. This component ensures accessibility and integrates seamlessly with other `Select` primitives to create a fully functional dropdown.

commonUseCases: Creating a dropdown menu for selecting a single option from a list in a form
Implementing a filter or sorting control in a data table or list
Building a custom language or theme selector
Providing a user-friendly way to choose from predefined values

examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic usage of SelectTrigger within a `Select` component, showing how to display a placeholder and connect it to a list of `SelectItem`s. The `SelectValue` component dynamically shows the selected option.

examples.code:
import { Select, SelectContent, SelectItem, SelectTrigger, SelectValue } from './select'; function SizeDemo() { return (
); }
examples.description: This example illustrates the use of the `size` prop, showcasing both 'default' and 'sm' trigger sizes. This allows for easy adjustment of the trigger's visual footprint to fit different UI contexts.

limitations: Relies heavily on Radix UI's `SelectPrimitive.Trigger`; it cannot be used as a standalone button for other purposes without significant modification.
Custom styling outside of the provided `className` and `size` prop requires direct manipulation of the underlying Tailwind CSS classes or a more intricate understanding of the component's structure.
The default `ChevronDownIcon` is embedded; replacing it requires providing a different element within `SelectPrimitive.Icon` or conditionally rendering your own icon based on the open state.
bestPractices: Always pair SelectTrigger with a `SelectPrimitive.Root` and `SelectPrimitive.Content` for a complete and functional dropdown.
Use `SelectValue` as a child of SelectTrigger to display the currently selected item, ensuring proper accessibility and dynamic updates.
Leverage the `size` prop (`sm` or `default`) for consistent sizing across your application, minimizing custom CSS for common size variations.
Provide meaningful `children` to the trigger or ensure `SelectValue` displays relevant text to indicate its purpose to users.
Utilize the `aria-label` or `aria-labelledby` props for improved accessibility, especially when the visual label might not be sufficient.
antiPatterns: Using SelectTrigger outside of a Radix UI Select component: It relies on the context provided by `SelectPrimitive.Root` and `SelectPrimitive.Content` to function correctly and display the dropdown.
Attempting to manually manage the open/closed state of the dropdown via the trigger: Radix UI handles this automatically; manual intervention can lead to state desynchronization.
Overriding critical Radix UI data attributes with custom styles: This can interfere with the component's internal state management or accessibility features.

Placing non-value content directly inside the trigger instead of using `SelectValue`: While `children` are rendered, dynamic selected values should typically go inside `SelectValue` for proper display and accessibility.

semanticData.summary: Renders the customizable dropdown content for a Radix UI Select component, including styling, animation, and positioning logic.
semanticData.description: SelectContent is a React component that wraps the Radix UI SelectPrimitive.Content. It is responsible for rendering the actual dropdown menu containing the select options. This component handles advanced styling, animation for opening/closing, and positioning of the content, offering a 'popper' position variant for more flexible placement. It simplifies building accessible and visually consistent select dropdowns by abstracting complex layout and interaction logic.

commonUseCases: Creating a custom select input with a styled dropdown menu
Displaying a list of selectable options for a form element
Implementing a filter dropdown where options appear below a trigger

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to compose a complete select component using SelectContent as the container for selectable items. It shows the use of position="popper" for flexible placement and how SelectGroup, SelectLabel, and SelectItem are nested inside.

limitations: Requires Radix UI's SelectPrimitive context to function correctly, meaning it must be a descendant of SelectPrimitive.Root (or your custom Select wrapper)
Positioning behavior largely depends on the position prop and CSS classes; complex custom positioning might require overriding Radix's default behavior
bestPractices: Always wrap SelectContent with SelectPrimitive.Portal to ensure it renders outside the component tree, preventing z-index issues and allowing it to break out of overflow containers
Utilize the position="popper" prop when you need the content to be positioned relative to the trigger using floating UI libraries, ensuring it stays in view even when scrolling
Pass SelectScrollUpButton and SelectScrollDownButton inside SelectContent when the list of items might exceed the available viewport height, providing smooth navigation for users
antiPatterns: Using SelectContent directly without wrapping it in SelectPrimitive.Portal or outside of a SelectPrimitive.Root context, as it relies on Radix UI's context for correct behavior and accessibility
Trying to manually control its open/closed state via CSS or direct DOM manipulation instead of relying on the parent SelectPrimitive.Root's state

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled, accessible label for grouping options within a Select component's dropdown.
semanticData.description: The SelectLabel component provides a styled, accessible label for grouping related options within a Radix UI Select dropdown. It serves to visually organize and provide context for items, particularly useful in long lists, enhancing both user experience and accessibility by clearly demarcating sections. This component leverages Radix UI's primitive for robust labeling capabilities while applying consistent UI styling.

commonUseCases: Grouping related options within a large dropdown menu
Providing clear visual separation and context for sections of select items
Enhancing accessibility by labeling logical groups of options in a combobox or select.

examples.code:
import { Select, SelectContent, SelectGroup, SelectItem, SelectLabel, SelectTrigger, SelectValue } from './select';

function MySelectComponent() {
  return (
    <Select>
      <SelectTrigger className="w-[180px]">
        <SelectValue placeholder="Select a fruit" />
      </SelectTrigger>
      <SelectContent>
        <SelectGroup>
          <SelectLabel>Tropical Fruits</SelectLabel>
          <SelectItem value="apple">Apple</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="banana">Banana</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="mango">Mango</SelectItem>
        </SelectGroup>
        <SelectGroup>
          <SelectLabel>Citrus Fruits</SelectLabel>
          <SelectItem value="orange">Orange</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="lemon">Lemon</SelectItem>
        </SelectGroup>
      </SelectContent>
    </Select>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use SelectLabel within SelectGroup to categorize select items. 'Tropical Fruits' and 'Citrus Fruits' act as headings, helping users navigate a list of fruits more easily.

limitations: SelectLabel is a presentational component and does not support interactive elements or custom event handlers directly.
It is intended for use within SelectGroup and not as a standalone component or a direct child of SelectContent without a group.
bestPractices: Place SelectLabel inside SelectGroup components to semantically link the label with its associated items.
Keep SelectLabel text concise and descriptive to quickly convey the group's content.
Ensure logical grouping of items under each label for a clear user experience.
antiPatterns: Using SelectLabel as a selectable item: It is purely for display and not interactive.
Using SelectLabel for general text within the dropdown: It should specifically denote a group of options.
Over-using labels: Avoid creating too many small groups as it can make the UI cluttered.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled, interactive item within a Radix UI-based select dropdown, including a selected indicator.
semanticData.description: The SelectItem component renders an individual, selectable option within a dropdown menu. It wraps the Radix UI SelectPrimitive.Item, providing default styling and handling for interactive states like hover, focus, and disabled. This component automatically includes a checkmark indicator for selected items, ensuring a clear visual cue for users when an option is chosen.

commonUseCases: Populating a dropdown list with selectable options
Creating form fields where users choose from a predefined list
Displaying dynamic content as selectable choices in a menu

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use SelectItem within a Select component to create a basic fruit selection dropdown. It shows both an enabled item and a disabled item.

limitations: SelectItem is designed specifically for use within a Radix UI Select component and may not function correctly or provide expected styling when used independently.
The checkmark indicator for selected items is automatically managed by Radix UI's ItemIndicator and cannot be directly controlled or removed without overriding the component's internal structure.
Accessibility features are primarily derived from the underlying Radix UI primitives; custom interactivity within an item might require careful ARIA attribute management.
bestPractices: Provide clear and concise text content (children) for each SelectItem to ensure readability.
Utilize the `disabled` prop for options that are temporarily unavailable or not applicable.
For long lists, ensure the containing SelectContent is scrollable and consider grouping related items with SelectGroup.
antiPatterns: Using SelectItem outside of a SelectContent component, as it relies on the Radix Select context.
Attempting to use SelectItem as a standalone button or link, as its primary purpose is within a select context.
Placing complex interactive elements (like nested forms or extensive rich text) directly inside SelectItem, which can hinder accessibility and user experience.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled horizontal separator within a Radix UI Select dropdown menu.
semanticData.description: The SelectSeparator component renders a styled horizontal line to visually separate items or groups within a Radix UI Select dropdown menu. It wraps the `SelectPrimitive.Separator` component, applying default Tailwind CSS classes to ensure consistent styling and provide clear visual segmentation. This component is essential for improving the readability and organization of dropdown options, especially in long lists.

commonUseCases: Visually separating different categories or groups of options within a select dropdown.
Adding a clear break in a long list of select items to improve user readability.
Differentiating special actions or 'none' options from regular select choices.

examples.code:
import { Select, SelectContent, SelectGroup, SelectItem, SelectLabel, SelectSeparator, SelectTrigger, SelectValue } from "./select";

function MyForm() {
  return (
    <Select>
      <SelectTrigger className="w-[180px]">
        <SelectValue placeholder="Select a fruit" />
      </SelectTrigger>
      <SelectContent>
        <SelectGroup>
          <SelectLabel>Fruits</SelectLabel>
          <SelectItem value="apple">Apple</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="banana">Banana</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="grape">Grape</SelectItem>
        </SelectGroup>
        <SelectSeparator />
        <SelectGroup>
          <SelectLabel>Vegetables</SelectLabel>
          <SelectItem value="carrot">Carrot</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="broccoli">Broccoli</SelectItem>
          <SelectItem value="spinach">Spinach</SelectItem>
        </SelectGroup>
        <SelectSeparator />
        <SelectItem value="other">Other (specify)</SelectItem>
      </SelectContent>
    </Select>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use `SelectSeparator` to divide different categories of items (Fruits, Vegetables) and a general 'Other' option within a dropdown. This improves the visual organization and helps users quickly navigate options.

limitations: The `SelectSeparator` component is purely visual and does not have any interactive behavior or semantic meaning for screen readers beyond its visual role (e.g., it's not a focusable element).
Its styling and behavior are tightly coupled with the Radix UI Select primitive, making it unsuitable as a standalone, general-purpose separator component outside of this context.
bestPractices: Use `SelectSeparator` sparingly to delineate logical sections rather than for every few items.
Always place `SelectSeparator` between distinct groups of `SelectItem`s to maximize its visual impact.
Ensure the visual separation provided by the separator aligns with the logical grouping of your data.
antiPatterns: Using multiple `SelectSeparator` components consecutively without any `SelectItem`s in between, which can lead to a cluttered or confusing UI.
Placing `SelectSeparator` outside of a `SelectContent` component, as it's designed to function within the dropdown's list structure.
Overusing separators, which can fragment the list unnecessarily and hinder quick scanning.

semanticData.summary: Creates a styled scroll-up button component for Radix UI Select, displaying a chevron-up icon.
semanticData.description: This component wraps Radix UI's SelectPrimitive.ScrollUpButton, providing a pre-styled visual indicator for scrolling up within a long select dropdown. It automatically includes a ChevronUpIcon and applies consistent styling to ensure a cohesive look and feel within the UI system. Developers should use this component within a SelectContent when the list of options might overflow and require scrolling.

commonUseCases: Implementing a select dropdown with numerous options that require vertical scrolling
Providing a consistent visual cue for scrolling within a custom Radix UI Select component

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of SelectScrollUpButton within a SelectContent, alongside SelectScrollDownButton and SelectViewport, to handle a large number of selectable items. This setup ensures that scroll indicators appear automatically when needed.

limitations: This component is specifically designed for use within Radix UI's `SelectPrimitive.Content` and its functionality relies on the context provided by the Radix Select primitive. Using it independently or in different contexts may lead to unexpected behavior.
Its visibility is automatically managed by the Radix UI Select primitive based on whether there's scrollable content above, limiting direct control over its display state.
bestPractices: Always include both SelectScrollUpButton and SelectScrollDownButton within a SelectContent when the number of items might exceed the viewport height to provide a complete and intuitive scrolling experience.
Utilize the `className` prop for minor stylistic adjustments or to add utility classes without fundamentally altering the component's primary purpose or visual indicator.
antiPatterns: Using this component outside of a SelectContent component, as it relies on the context provided by Radix UI's Select primitive for proper functionality and visibility.
Attempting to manually control the button's visibility or interaction, which can conflict with the underlying Radix primitive's automatic behavior based on scrollable content.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled scroll-down button for Radix UI's Select component, including a downward chevron icon.
semanticData.description: This component wraps the Radix UI SelectPrimitive.ScrollDownButton to provide a pre-styled scroll button. It automatically includes a ChevronDownIcon and applies default utility classes to center the icon, ensuring consistent visual appearance within a select dropdown when its content exceeds the viewport and requires scrolling. Developers should use this to enable navigation for long lists of select options.

commonUseCases: Implementing a Select component with many options that require vertical scrolling
Providing clear visual indicators for scrollable select dropdown content

examples.description: Demonstrates how to include the SelectScrollDownButton within a SelectContent component. It is typically used alongside a SelectScrollUpButton and SelectPrimitive.Viewport to enable vertical scrolling for a long list of select options, providing a clear visual cue for users.

limitations: Requires Radix UI's Select components as its foundation; it's not a standalone scroll button
Primarily for visual indication and user interaction; the actual scrolling behavior is managed by Radix UI's internal Select logic
bestPractices: Always include SelectScrollDownButton within SelectContent when the list of options might exceed the visible area to improve accessibility and user experience
Ensure its placement is correct within the SelectPrimitive.Content (typically at the bottom, after SelectPrimitive.Viewport)
antiPatterns: Not including this button when the SelectContent can scroll, which hinders user experience as there's no visible way to scroll down
Overriding essential styling that makes the button unusable or invisible, preventing users from interacting with it

semanticData.summary: A styled React component that renders a native HTML textarea element with pre-defined styles and responsiveness.
semanticData.description: The `Textarea` component provides a styled and opinionated HTML textarea element, pre-configured with Tailwind CSS classes for consistent visual appearance, responsiveness, and accessibility states. It solves the problem of needing to repeatedly style textarea inputs across an application, ensuring a unified UI/UX. Developers should use this component when they require a standard multi-line text input field that adheres to the application's design system.

commonUseCases: Collecting multi-line user input in forms (e.g., comments, descriptions)
Allowing users to enter long-form text content
Building message composition interfaces
Creating fields for user feedback or bug reports

examples.description: Demonstrates basic usage of the Textarea component as a controlled input within a form. It shows how to manage its state using `useState` and apply common props like `id`, `placeholder`, `value`, `onChange`, and `rows` for basic functionality and accessibility.

Shows how to render a Textarea in a read-only state using the `readOnly` prop. It also demonstrates custom styling through the `className` prop, applying a light grey background and darker text color for a distinct visual appearance.

limitations: Does not support rich text editing capabilities; it's a plain text input.
The `field-sizing-content` utility class might not behave identically across all browsers for automatic height adjustment, though it provides a good starting point.
Customizing deep internal styles beyond what `className` allows may require overriding the component's internal CSS or using more specific CSS selectors.
bestPractices: Always use `value` and `onChange` to create a controlled component, managing the textarea's state within your React component.
Provide meaningful `placeholder` text to guide users on expected input.
Ensure proper `id` and `aria-labelledby` or `aria-describedby` attributes are used for accessibility, especially when integrating with labels or validation messages.
Utilize standard HTML textarea props like `rows` and `cols` when fixed dimensions are preferred over `min-h-16`.
Apply the `readOnly` or `disabled` props for non-editable states to clearly communicate interaction restrictions to users.
antiPatterns: Using `Textarea` for rich text editing: This component is a basic HTML textarea; it does not support rich text formatting (bold, italics, lists). Use a dedicated rich text editor library instead.
Overriding too many internal styles with `className`: While `className` allows customization, excessive overrides can defeat the purpose of using a pre-styled component and lead to inconsistent UI.
Directly manipulating the DOM element instead of using React state: Always manage the textarea's value through React state (controlled component) for predictable behavior.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled HTML input element with accessible focus, disabled, and invalid states.
semanticData.description: The `Input` component provides a flexible and visually consistent text input field built upon a standard HTML `<input>` element. It applies a set of default Tailwind CSS classes to ensure a unified look and feel across the application, including styles for focus, disabled, and invalid states. Developers should use this component to create user input fields that adhere to the application's design system while benefiting from native browser input features and accessibility considerations.

commonUseCases: Collecting user text input for forms (e.g., username, email, search queries)
Displaying numeric input fields (e.g., age, quantity, price)
Implementing password entry fields with appropriate masking
Creating accessible input fields that visually respond to focus and validation states

examples.description: This example demonstrates basic usage of the `Input` component for a login form. It showcases how to use different `type` props (`text`, `password`), manage input state with `value` and `onChange`, and associate inputs with labels for accessibility.

This example showcases how to use the `Input` component with validation feedback using `aria-invalid`, demonstrating its built-in styling for invalid states. It also includes examples of a numeric input (`type="number"`) and a disabled input, highlighting the component's versatility and adherence to native HTML input attributes.

limitations: No built-in validation logic: The component itself does not perform input validation; it relies on parent components to manage validation state and pass `aria-invalid` accordingly.

Requires `cn` utility (or similar) for combining dynamic class names: The component expects class names to be combined externally if you intend to add conditional styles alongside the default ones. While not a strict limitation, developers should be aware of this dependency if copying the component.

Opinionated styling: The component comes with a strong opinion on its visual appearance based on Tailwind CSS. While `className` can extend or override styles, significant design changes might require modifying the component's internal styles directly or creating a new component.
bestPractices: Always use the appropriate `type` prop (e.g., `email`, `password`, `number`, `url`) to provide better browser-specific behavior, mobile keyboard layouts, and accessibility.

Integrate with `aria-invalid` for validation feedback: Set `aria-invalid={true}` when the input content is invalid to automatically apply the defined error styles and improve accessibility for screen readers.
Pair with a `label` element: Always associate the input with a `<label>` using the `id` and `htmlFor` attributes for improved accessibility and usability.
Manage input value with React state: Use `value` and `onChange` props to control the input's state in a React component (controlled component pattern).
Utilize the `disabled` prop for non-editable states: Set `disabled` to `true` when the input should not be interactive, which also applies the component's built-in disabled styles.
antiPatterns: Overriding core styles excessively: Avoid supplying a `className` prop that negates most of the component's default styling, as it defeats the purpose of a standardized component and leads to inconsistent UI. Instead, create a new component if drastically different styles are needed.

Ignoring the `type` prop for specialized inputs: Forgetting to set `type="password"`, `type="email"`, `type="number"`, etc., can lead to poor user experience, incorrect mobile keyboard layouts, and accessibility issues.

Direct DOM manipulation: Do not directly manipulate the underlying HTML `<input>` element (e.g., via `ref.current.value = ...`) when state and props can be used to control the component, as this can lead to React state desynchronization.

semanticData.summary: Renders a pulsating, rounded placeholder div element to indicate loading states in the UI.
semanticData.description: The Skeleton component provides a visual placeholder for content that is still loading or being fetched, enhancing the user experience by giving immediate feedback. It renders a div element with a pulsating animation, a rounded border, and an accent background color. This prevents abrupt content shifts and improves perceived performance while waiting for data.

commonUseCases: Displaying a temporary placeholder while data is being fetched from an API
Showing a block for images or text that are still loading to prevent layout shifts
Improving perceived performance during initial page loads by providing immediate UI feedback
Indicating a component's content is in a transitional or pending state

examples.description: This example demonstrates conditionally rendering multiple `Skeleton` components to simulate the loading of an article preview. It uses the `className` prop to set specific widths and heights to mimic text lines, and a `useState`/`useEffect` hook to manage the loading state before displaying actual content.

This example shows how to use the `Skeleton` component as a circular placeholder for a user avatar. The `className` prop is used to apply `h-12 w-12 rounded-full` to both the skeleton and the final image, ensuring a consistent size and shape during the loading transition.

limitations: Does not automatically manage data fetching or loading states; developers must manually implement conditional rendering logic to show/hide the Skeleton
Primarily visual; while it improves perceived performance, it doesn't inherently handle accessibility for screen readers. For complex loading indicators, consider `aria-busy` or `aria-live` regions
Its appearance (e.g., shape, dimensions) is defined by its internal styles and `className` prop, requiring manual sizing to accurately match the final content
bestPractices: Conditionally render the Skeleton component based on your data loading state (e.g., using a boolean `isLoading` flag)
Adjust its dimensions (width, height) to mimic the actual content it's replacing for a smoother transition and more natural appearance
Consider using a consistent `data-slot` attribute for easier identification and styling in development or testing environments
Combine with a subtle transition effect when the actual content appears to avoid abrupt visual changes
antiPatterns: Using Skeleton for non-loading states, which can confuse users about the UI's interactivity or content availability
Overusing Skeleton components unnecessarily, leading to a 'flashy' or distracting user interface
Not removing the Skeleton once content is loaded, causing the UI to appear stuck or display incorrect information

semanticData.summary: Provides the root container for a Radix UI context menu component, acting as a styled wrapper around Radix UI's ContextMenu.Root.
semanticData.description: This component serves as the root wrapper for a Radix UI Context Menu, enabling right-click or long-press functionality to display a dropdown menu. It abstracts the core Radix `Root` component, allowing for consistent styling and behavior across the application by applying a data-slot attribute. Developers use it to define the scope and initial state of a context menu, serving as the foundational element for its composition.

commonUseCases: Creating a right-click menu for desktop-like interactions on specific elements.
Providing contextual actions for elements like lists, tables, or images.
Implementing mobile long-press menus for additional options.

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic usage of the ContextMenu component as the root for a right-click menu. It wraps a ContextMenuTrigger and a ContextMenuContent containing several ContextMenuItem components, providing a functional contextual menu.

limitations: As a direct wrapper, its behavior and limitations are largely inherited from Radix UI's ContextMenu.Root component.
Requires explicit children components like ContextMenuTrigger and ContextMenuContent to form a complete and interactive context menu.
bestPractices: Always use this ContextMenu component as the top-level wrapper for any context menu implementation to ensure proper context and styling.
Combine it with ContextMenuTrigger and ContextMenuContent (and other related components) for a complete and functional context menu experience.
Ensure its children are correctly structured according to Radix UI's context menu composition to leverage built-in accessibility and behavior.
antiPatterns: Nesting multiple ContextMenu roots unnecessarily within the same interactive area, which can lead to conflicting behavior or unexpected menu displays.
Attempting to use ContextMenuTrigger or ContextMenuContent outside of a ContextMenu root, as they rely on the context provided by this component.

semanticData.summary: Renders the interactive element that triggers the display of a context menu upon activation.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuTrigger component serves as the interactive element that, when activated (typically via a right-click), opens the associated ContextMenu. It wraps a standard DOM element or React component, enhancing it with the necessary event listeners to trigger the context menu. This component is crucial for defining the clickable area that reveals contextual actions or options.

commonUseCases: Defining the right-clickable area for a list item to show item-specific actions
Creating a context menu for an image or document in a file browser
Adding contextual options to elements within a dashboard or table
Providing quick access to actions on a draggable item in a kanban board

examples.description: This example demonstrates a basic usage of ContextMenuTrigger. When the 'Right-click me' div is right-clicked, the associated context menu with 'Edit', 'Duplicate', and 'Delete' options will appear. The `ContextMenuTrigger` wraps the element that should activate the menu.

limitations: Primarily designed for mouse-based right-click interactions; touch or keyboard activation may require additional handling or be implicitly managed by the underlying Radix UI primitive.
It should only be used as the direct child of a `ContextMenu` component.
Its behavior is tightly coupled with `ContextMenuPrimitive.Trigger` from Radix UI, inheriting its specific event handling and accessibility features.
bestPractices: Always nest ContextMenuTrigger directly within a `ContextMenu` component to ensure proper functionality and accessibility.
Ensure the content wrapped by ContextMenuTrigger is semantically appropriate and conveys its purpose to users.
Use `asChild` prop on `ContextMenuPrimitive.Trigger` (if exposing it) to pass props to its child, preventing unnecessary DOM nodes.
antiPatterns: Using ContextMenuTrigger for a regular click-based dropdown menu; prefer `DropdownMenuTrigger` for such cases.
Placing ContextMenuTrigger outside of a `ContextMenu` component, which will lead to incorrect behavior or errors.
Applying custom click handlers directly to the ContextMenuTrigger that conflict with its built-in context menu logic.

semanticData.summary: Renders a logical grouping container for related context menu items.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuGroup component serves as a direct wrapper around Radix UI's ContextMenu.Group primitive, designed to logically group related menu items within a context menu. It helps in organizing the menu structure, making it more intuitive and scannable for users by visually and semantically separating sets of actions. This component is essential for building well-structured and accessible context menus.

commonUseCases: Organizing common editing actions (e.g., Cut, Copy, Paste) within a context menu
Grouping file management options (e.g., Rename, Delete, Move) in a file explorer context menu
Separating user-specific actions from general application actions in a profile context menu
Creating distinct sections for frequently used commands vs. advanced options

examples.code:
import { ContextMenu, ContextMenuTrigger, ContextMenuContent, ContextMenuItem, ContextMenuSeparator, ContextMenuGroup } from './context-menu';

function MyComponent() {
  return (
    <ContextMenu>
      <ContextMenuTrigger className="flex h-[150px] w-[300px] items-center justify-center rounded-md border border-dashed text-sm">
        Right click here
      </ContextMenuTrigger>
      <ContextMenuContent className="w-64">
        <ContextMenuItem>Undo</ContextMenuItem>
        <ContextMenuItem>Redo</ContextMenuItem>
        <ContextMenuSeparator />
        <ContextMenuGroup>
          <ContextMenuItem>Cut</ContextMenuItem>
          <ContextMenuItem>Copy</ContextMenuItem>
          <ContextMenuItem>Paste</ContextMenuItem>
        </ContextMenuGroup>
        <ContextMenuSeparator />
        <ContextMenuGroup>
          <ContextMenuItem>New Tab</ContextMenuItem>
          <ContextMenuItem>New Window</ContextMenuItem>
        </ContextMenuGroup>
      </ContextMenuContent>
    </ContextMenu>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use ContextMenuGroup to create logical sections within a context menu. The 'Cut, Copy, Paste' actions are grouped together, and 'New Tab, New Window' actions form another group, improving the menu's organization and readability. Separators are used to visually distinguish these groups.

limitations: ContextMenuGroup is a structural component and does not add any interactive behavior (like click events or state management) itself; its purpose is purely for logical grouping.
It must be used as a direct child of ContextMenuContent or ContextMenuSubContent to function correctly within the context menu structure.
Styling and visual appearance are primarily derived from the parent ContextMenuContent and the items within the group, rather than the group itself.
bestPractices: Always include logical sets of ContextMenuItems or other item components within a ContextMenuGroup.
Consider using a ContextMenuSeparator between different ContextMenuGroups to enhance visual distinction.
Keep group names or implied group themes clear and concise to aid user navigation.
Ensure that all items within a group are semantically related to improve accessibility and usability.
antiPatterns: Using ContextMenuGroup solely for styling without any logical grouping of items, which can degrade semantic meaning and accessibility.
Nesting ContextMenuGroups unnecessarily, leading to over-complicated menu structures.
Placing non-item components directly inside ContextMenuGroup, as it expects menu items (e.g., ContextMenuItem, ContextMenuCheckboxItem).

semanticData.summary: Renders context menu content outside the current DOM tree to prevent clipping and z-index issues.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuPortal component is a wrapper around Radix UI's ContextMenuPrimitive.Portal. Its primary purpose is to render the context menu content outside of the current DOM tree, typically directly under the document body. This solves common UI problems like z-index conflicts and content clipping, ensuring the menu always appears correctly on top of other elements, regardless of its parent's styling or position.

commonUseCases: Ensuring context menu content appears above all other elements
Preventing context menus from being clipped by overflow:hidden parents
Handling z-index issues for deeply nested context menus

examples.description: This example shows the standard usage of ContextMenuPortal, wrapping the ContextMenuContent. This ensures the menu's content (Edit, Delete) renders at the document body level, preventing it from being clipped or having z-index issues, especially when the trigger is inside a complex layout.

limitations: While it solves z-index and clipping, complex styling based on parent container's CSS properties might need adjustment if those styles don't propagate to the portal's content.
Event bubbling might behave slightly differently due to the content being in a different DOM subtree, though Radix UI generally handles this gracefully for typical interactions.
bestPractices: Always wrap ContextMenuContent with ContextMenuPortal to ensure robust positioning and layering.
