Leverage the portal's automatic z-index management provided by Radix UI for overlays.
Ensure proper styling for the content itself, as the portal only handles its placement in the DOM, not its visual appearance.
antiPatterns: Omitting ContextMenuPortal when ContextMenuContent is rendered within a container with 'overflow: hidden' or a low z-index, which can cause the menu to be cut off.
Attempting to manually position ContextMenuContent with CSS when ContextMenuPortal should be used to handle global positioning.

semanticData.summary: A React component that acts as a container for creating nested sub-menus within a Radix UI Context Menu.
semanticData.description: ContextMenuSub serves as a container for a sub-menu within a larger context menu system. It acts as the necessary parent element for the ContextMenuSubTrigger and ContextMenuSubContent components, allowing developers to create hierarchical menu structures. This component is crucial for organizing related actions or options into nested menus, enhancing the user experience by providing a clean and navigable interface for complex context-sensitive operations.

commonUseCases: Creating nested menus for advanced or less frequently used options.
Organizing a large number of context menu actions into logical categories.
Implementing multi-level hierarchical menus to improve navigation for complex applications.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use ContextMenuSub to create a nested 'Export As' sub-menu within a main context menu. The ContextMenuSub component wraps the ContextMenuSubTrigger (the item that opens the sub-menu) and ContextMenuSubContent (the container for the sub-menu items like PDF, JSON, CSV).

limitations: As a pure wrapper component, ContextMenuSub itself does not have visible styling or direct interactive behavior; its functionality depends entirely on its children, ContextMenuSubTrigger and ContextMenuSubContent.
Requires the parent ContextMenu component structure to be present for proper rendering and functionality.
bestPractices: Ensure proper nesting within ContextMenuContent to maintain the correct menu hierarchy and accessibility standards.
Utilize ContextMenuSub to group logically related options, thereby improving menu navigability and overall user experience.
Keep sub-menu content concise and relevant to the parent item, making it easier for users to find what they need.
Combine with ContextMenuSubTrigger and ContextMenuSubContent for a complete and accessible nested menu implementation.
antiPatterns: Using ContextMenuSub without its corresponding ContextMenuSubTrigger and ContextMenuSubContent, as it will not render a functional sub-menu.

Placing interactive elements directly inside ContextMenuSub that are not ContextMenuSubTrigger or ContextMenuSubContent, as they might not be properly rendered or accessible within the Radix UI structure.
Creating excessive levels of sub-menus (e.g., more than 2-3 levels deep), which can lead to a cumbersome user experience and poor discoverability.

semanticData.summary: Renders a container for a group of mutually exclusive radio items within a context menu.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuRadioGroup component is a wrapper around the Radix UI ContextMenu.RadioGroup primitive, designed to contain ContextMenuRadioItem components. It ensures that only one radio item within the group can be selected at a time, providing a clear way to manage mutually exclusive options in a context menu. This component simplifies the integration of Radix UI's radio group functionality into a custom context menu system, inheriting all its accessibility features and behaviors.

commonUseCases: Presenting a list of mutually exclusive options in a right-click context menu.
Allowing users to select a single setting from a predefined set within a context-aware interaction.
Implementing different view modes (e.g., "List", "Grid", "Table") selectable via a context menu.

examples.code:
import { ContextMenu, ContextMenuContent, ContextMenuItem, ContextMenuTrigger, ContextMenuRadioGroup, ContextMenuRadioItem, ContextMenuLabel, ContextMenuSeparator } from "./context-menu";

function MyComponent() {
  const [selectedView, setSelectedView] = React.useState("grid");

  return (
    <ContextMenu>
      <ContextMenuTrigger className="flex h-[150px] w-[300px] items-center justify-center rounded-md border border-dashed text-sm">
        Right click here
      </ContextMenuTrigger>
      <ContextMenuContent className="w-64">
        <ContextMenuLabel>View</ContextMenuLabel>
        <ContextMenuSeparator />
        <ContextMenuRadioGroup value={selectedView} onValueChange={setSelectedView}>
          <ContextMenuRadioItem value="list">
            List View
          </ContextMenuRadioItem>
          <ContextMenuRadioItem value="grid">
            Grid View
          </ContextMenuRadioItem>
          <ContextMenuRadioItem value="compact">
            Compact View
          </ContextMenuRadioItem>
        </ContextMenuRadioGroup>
        <ContextMenuSeparator />
        <ContextMenuItem>
          Open in New Tab
        </ContextMenuItem>
      </ContextMenuContent>
    </ContextMenu>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use ContextMenuRadioGroup to create a group of selectable view options within a context menu. Users can select either 'List View', 'Grid View', or 'Compact View', with the selection state managed by React state.

limitations: Primarily acts as a pass-through component; customization beyond Radix UI's props requires direct styling or wrapping.
Relies on ContextMenuRadioItem for actual radio button functionality; cannot contain arbitrary elements as radio options.
bestPractices: Always use ContextMenuRadioItem as direct children to ensure proper radio group behavior and accessibility.
Control the selected value using the 'value' and 'onValueChange' props, similar to standard HTML radio groups.
Nest ContextMenuRadioGroup within ContextMenuContent to ensure it's part of the context menu structure.
antiPatterns: Do not place non-radio items directly inside ContextMenuRadioGroup as they will not participate in the mutual exclusivity logic.
Avoid manually managing the checked state of individual ContextMenuRadioItem components if they are part of a ContextMenuRadioGroup, as the group handles this.

codeMetadata.name: ContextMenuSubTrigger
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof ContextMenuPrimitive.SubTrigger> & { inset?: boolean }): any

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled trigger component for nested context menus, displaying a right chevron icon and supporting indentation.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuSubTrigger component serves as an interactive item within a context menu that, when hovered or clicked, reveals a nested sub-menu. It wraps the Radix UI `SubTrigger` primitive, adding default styling, a visual right arrow icon (ChevronRightIcon), and supports an `inset` prop for consistent left padding with other menu items. This component is essential for organizing complex menu options into logical sub-categories, improving user experience by decluttering the main context menu.

commonUseCases: Creating nested navigation for file or folder operations within an application (e.g., "Move to" -> "Documents", "Trash")
Organizing complex settings or configuration options into hierarchical sub-menus
Providing multi-level actions in a rich text editor's context menu (e.g., "Insert" -> "Table", "Image", "Link")
Grouping related actions to reduce clutter in the main context menu

examples.code:
import { ContextMenu, ContextMenuContent, ContextMenuItem, ContextMenuPortal, ContextMenuSub, ContextMenuSubContent, ContextMenuSubTrigger, ContextMenuTrigger } from './context-menu';

function MyComponent() {
  return (
    <ContextMenu>
      <ContextMenuTrigger className="flex h-[150px] w-[300px] items-center justify-center rounded-md border border-dashed text-sm">
        Right click here
      </ContextMenuTrigger>
      <ContextMenuPortal>
        <ContextMenuContent className="w-64">
          <ContextMenuItem>New File</ContextMenuItem>
          <ContextMenuItem>New Folder</ContextMenuItem>
          <ContextMenuSub>
            <ContextMenuSubTrigger inset>Move To</ContextMenuSubTrigger>
            <ContextMenuPortal>
              <ContextMenuSubContent>
                <ContextMenuItem>Documents</ContextMenuItem>
                <ContextMenuItem>Downloads</ContextMenuItem>
                <ContextMenuItem>Archive</ContextMenuItem>
              </ContextMenuSubContent>
            </ContextMenuPortal>
          </ContextMenuSub>
          <ContextMenuSub>
            <ContextMenuSubTrigger inset>Share</ContextMenuSubTrigger>
            <ContextMenuPortal>
              <ContextMenuSubContent>
                <ContextMenuItem>With Collaborators</ContextMenuItem>
                <ContextMenuItem>Public Link</ContextMenuItem>
              </ContextMenuSubContent>
            </ContextMenuPortal>
          </ContextMenuSub>
          <ContextMenuItem>Delete</ContextMenuItem>
        </ContextMenuContent>
      </ContextMenuPortal>
    </ContextMenu>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to create a nested context menu using ContextMenuSubTrigger. A 'Move To' and 'Share' option, when hovered or clicked, will reveal a secondary menu with further specific actions like 'Documents' or 'Public Link'. The `inset` prop on ContextMenuSubTrigger ensures proper alignment with other menu items.

limitations: When using multiple levels of nested sub-menus, ensure adequate screen space is available to prevent menus from appearing off-screen, especially on smaller viewports.
Deeply nested menus can lead to poor user experience if users have to navigate through many layers to find a common action.
Care should be taken with complex layouts or custom styling that might interfere with the default positioning and appearance of the ChevronRightIcon.
bestPractices: Keep sub-menu content concise and highly relevant to the parent trigger's label to maintain clarity.
Use clear, descriptive labels for sub-triggers to inform users what options they will find in the nested menu.
Ensure sufficient padding and visual distinction between sub-trigger items and regular menu items for better readability.
Consider accessibility by ensuring keyboard navigation and screen reader compatibility for nested menus.
antiPatterns: Over-nesting sub-menus more than 2-3 levels deep, as this can lead to a confusing and hard-to-navigate user experience.
Using a sub-trigger for a simple, single action that could directly be a ContextMenuItem, unnecessarily adding an extra click or hover.
Placing a ContextMenuSubTrigger directly inside a ContextMenuRadioGroup or ContextMenuCheckboxItem, as it alters the expected interactive behavior of those groups.

semanticData.summary: Renders the content container for a nested context menu, applying pre-defined styles for appearance, animations, and positioning.
semanticData.description: ContextMenuSubContent serves as the container for items within a nested context menu, providing the visual wrapper and default styling for sub-menu options. It leverages Radix UI's SubContent primitive, applying pre-defined Tailwind CSS classes for animations, positioning, and visual consistency. This component is crucial for building hierarchical context menus, allowing developers to present additional related actions or categories upon user interaction with a sub-trigger.

commonUseCases: Displaying a nested list of options when hovering over or clicking a menu item in a context menu
Organizing complex context menu structures with multiple levels of related actions
Providing additional context-sensitive actions that are part of a larger menu category

examples.code:
import { ContextMenu, ContextMenuTrigger, ContextMenuContent, ContextMenuItem, ContextMenuSub, ContextMenuSubTrigger, ContextMenuSubContent, ContextMenuSeparator } from "./context-menu";

function AppMenu() {
  return (
    <ContextMenu>
      <ContextMenuTrigger className="flex h-[150px] w-[300px] items-center justify-center rounded-md border border-dashed text-sm">
        Right click here
      </ContextMenuTrigger>
      <ContextMenuContent className="w-64">
        <ContextMenuItem>New File</ContextMenuItem>
        <ContextMenuItem>New Folder</ContextMenuItem>
        <ContextMenuSeparator />
        <ContextMenuSub>
          <ContextMenuSubTrigger>Convert to</ContextMenuSubTrigger>
          <ContextMenuSubContent> {/* Sub-menu content container */}
            <ContextMenuItem>PDF</ContextMenuItem>
            <ContextMenuItem>DOCX</ContextMenuItem>
            <ContextMenuSeparator />
            <ContextMenuItem>JSON</ContextMenuItem>
          </ContextMenuSubContent>
        </ContextMenuSub>
        <ContextMenuItem>Properties</ContextMenuItem>
      </ContextMenuContent>
    </ContextMenu>
  );
}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to create a nested context menu. The `ContextMenuSubContent` component is used to wrap the items ('PDF', 'DOCX', 'JSON') that appear when the 'Convert to' sub-trigger is hovered over or clicked. It automatically applies the necessary styling and animation for the sub-menu panel.

limitations: Its core functionality and accessibility features are inherited directly from Radix UI's ContextMenu.SubContent, meaning any limitations of the underlying primitive apply.
The default styling provided by the component is heavily based on Tailwind CSS; significant deviations from this design system may require extensive custom CSS overrides.
Animations and positioning are pre-configured; complex custom animation sequences or positioning logic may require using the raw Radix UI primitive or custom solutions.
bestPractices: Always wrap ContextMenuSubContent within a ContextMenuSub component to maintain the correct hierarchical structure required by Radix UI.
Populate ContextMenuSubContent with ContextMenuItem, ContextMenuCheckboxItem, ContextMenuRadioItem, ContextMenuLabel, or ContextMenuSeparator components to define the sub-menu's content.
Utilize the className prop for minor visual adjustments while relying on the component's default styling for overall appearance and animations.
antiPatterns: Using ContextMenuSubContent without a parent ContextMenuSub and ContextMenuSubTrigger, as it relies on this hierarchy for proper functioning and accessibility.
Overriding critical Radix UI props that control its behavior, positioning, or accessibility attributes, which can lead to broken functionality or poor user experience.

semanticData.summary: Renders the styled, portal-mounted content area for a context menu, handling its visual presentation and animation.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuContent component serves as the styled container for the items displayed within a context menu. It wraps Radix UI's `ContextMenuPrimitive.Content` and includes it within a `ContextMenuPrimitive.Portal` for correct layering, ensuring the menu appears above other content without clipping. This component applies pre-defined styles for animations, positioning, sizing, background, and text, providing a consistent visual appearance for the context menu dropdown itself.

commonUseCases: Displaying a list of actions or options when a user right-clicks an element
Providing contextual navigation links or commands based on the selected item
Implementing custom right-click menus in web applications

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to set up a basic context menu. The `ContextMenuContent` component wraps the `ContextMenuItem` elements, which appear when the `ContextMenuTrigger` is right-clicked. This showcases the core structure for displaying a context menu.

limitations: This component is a styled wrapper around Radix UI's primitive and is not intended for standalone use; it requires the full `ContextMenu` component structure.
Its default styling assumes a popover-like appearance and animations; significant changes might require overriding a large number of Tailwind classes.
bestPractices: Always nest ContextMenuContent within a ContextMenu component and associate it with a ContextMenuTrigger.
Use ContextMenuItem, ContextMenuCheckboxItem, ContextMenuRadioItem, and other related components from the `ui` library as children for optimal styling and accessibility.
Leverage the `className` prop for custom styling if needed, but prioritize the provided components for structure.
antiPatterns: Using ContextMenuContent without its parent ContextMenu and ContextMenuTrigger components, as it relies on their state and positioning.
Placing non-menu-related, complex interactive elements directly inside it (e.g., forms), as it's optimized for simple item lists.
Overriding core styling in a way that breaks accessibility or expected context menu behavior.

codeMetadata.name: ContextMenuItem
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof ContextMenuPrimitive.Item> & { inset?: boolean; variant?: "default" | "destructive" }): any

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled item for a context menu, supporting visual inset and destructive action variants.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuItem component renders a customizable, interactive item within a context menu. It wraps the Radix UI ContextMenuPrimitive.Item, providing additional styling capabilities like `inset` for visual alignment and `variant` to distinguish between 'default' and 'destructive' actions. This component helps developers create clear and visually hierarchical context menu options that guide user interaction.

commonUseCases: Defining clickable options in a right-click or long-press menu
Implementing 'Delete' or 'Remove' actions with a distinct visual warning
Creating menu items that visually align with sub-triggers or labels using the 'inset' prop

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to create a basic context menu with several menu items. It includes a standard item, an item with `inset` for visual padding, and a `destructive` item clearly indicating a high-impact action.

limitations: As a wrapper around Radix UI's `ContextMenuItem`, its functionality is largely dependent on the underlying Radix component's capabilities and limitations.
Extensive custom styling might require careful management to avoid conflicts with the component's internal `cn` (class name utility) logic and `data-*` attributes.
bestPractices: Always wrap `ContextMenuItem` components within a `ContextMenuContent` or `ContextMenuSubContent` for correct functionality and styling.
Utilize the `variant="destructive"` prop for actions that lead to irreversible changes, such as deleting data, to provide clear visual feedback to the user.
Use the `inset` prop when creating menu items that are visually 'nested' or aligned with other `inset` elements like `ContextMenuSubTrigger` or `ContextMenuLabel`.
antiPatterns: Using `ContextMenuItem` outside of `ContextMenuContent` or `ContextMenuSubContent`, as it relies on the Radix UI structure.
Overriding the `data-inset` or `data-variant` attributes directly via `className` or other props, which can interfere with the component's built-in styling logic.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled and accessible checkbox item for use within a Radix UI-based context menu.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuCheckboxItem component provides a styled and accessible checkbox item for use within a ContextMenu. Built on top of Radix UI's ContextMenuPrimitive.CheckboxItem, it visually indicates a checked or unchecked state, allowing users to toggle boolean settings or options directly from a right-click menu. It ensures consistent styling and behavior across the application's context menus.

commonUseCases: Implementing toggleable settings in a right-click menu, e.g., 'Show Grid' or 'Enable Auto-Save'.
Allowing users to select or deselect multiple independent options from a context menu.
Providing quick access to boolean feature flags within an application's UI.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to create a context menu with two toggleable checkbox items. The 'checked' state of each item is controlled by React's useState hook, allowing users to enable or disable features like a status bar or debugging mode directly from the context menu.

limitations: Primarily designed for toggling simple boolean states; not suitable for complex data input or multi-value selections.
Functionality is tied to Radix UI's underlying `CheckboxItem` component, inheriting any of its behavioral or accessibility constraints.
bestPractices: Always provide clear and concise text as children for the checkbox item, accurately describing the toggled option.
Manage the 'checked' state in a parent component using React state (e.g., useState) to ensure predictable and controlled behavior.
Group related checkbox items within a ContextMenuGroup and use ContextMenuLabel and ContextMenuSeparator for better organization and readability.
antiPatterns: Using ContextMenuCheckboxItem for mutually exclusive choices; use ContextMenuRadioItem for 'one of many' selections.
Employing it for actions that trigger complex workflows or navigate away; it's designed for simple boolean toggles, not command execution.
Not managing the 'checked' state externally, leading to uncontrolled behavior and unpredictable UI.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled radio button item within a Radix UI ContextMenuRadioGroup, indicating its selected state with a circular icon.
semanticData.description: This component wraps the Radix UI ContextMenu.RadioItem to provide a pre-styled radio button option for context menus. It handles visual styling for hover, focus, and disabled states, and displays a filled circle icon when the item is checked. It ensures consistency in look and feel across the application's context menus, fitting within a ContextMenuRadioGroup.

commonUseCases: Creating a context menu with mutually exclusive options, such as selecting a view mode (e.g., list, grid, compact).
Implementing language or theme selection within a context menu where only one option can be active at a time.
Allowing users to pick a single value from a predefined set in a right-click menu.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use ContextMenuRadioItem within a ContextMenuRadioGroup to create a set of mutually exclusive options for a view mode selection. The 'viewMode' state manages which option is currently selected, updated by 'onValueChange' on the radio group.

limitations: This component requires ContextMenuRadioGroup as its direct parent to function correctly as a radio button.
Its styling is opinionated (based on Tailwind CSS classes) and requires customization if a different visual theme is desired.
Relies on Radix UI's internal state management for accessibility and behavior, so direct manipulation of 'checked' state on the item itself is not recommended.
bestPractices: Always wrap ContextMenuRadioItem components within a ContextMenuRadioGroup to ensure proper radio button behavior (mutual exclusion).
Ensure each ContextMenuRadioItem has a unique 'value' prop within its group for correct state management.
Utilize the 'onValueChange' prop of the ContextMenuRadioGroup to update the selected state in your application logic.
Provide meaningful 'children' (labels) for each radio item to enhance user understanding and accessibility.
antiPatterns: Using ContextMenuRadioItem outside of a ContextMenuRadioGroup, which would break its intended radio button functionality and state management.
Not providing a 'value' prop to ContextMenuRadioItem, making it impossible to uniquely identify the selected item within its group.
Attempting to manage the 'checked' state directly on ContextMenuRadioItem instead of relying on the 'value' and 'onValueChange' props of the parent ContextMenuRadioGroup.

codeMetadata.name: ContextMenuLabel
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<typeof ContextMenuPrimitive.Label> & { inset?: boolean }): any

semanticData.summary: Renders a non-interactive, styled label or title within a context menu, with optional indentation.
semanticData.description: ContextMenuLabel provides a visually distinct, non-interactive text label for grouping or titling sections within a ContextMenuContent. It wraps Radix UI's ContextMenu.Label and applies consistent styling, including an optional 'inset' property for visual hierarchy and improved readability. This component helps organize complex context menus, making them easier for users to navigate.

commonUseCases: Adding a main title to a context menu
Labeling distinct groups of related context menu items
Providing instructional or descriptive text within a context menu

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use ContextMenuLabel to add a main title ("Document Actions") and a sub-section label ("Sharing Options") to a context menu. It showcases both standard and 'inset' labels to create visual hierarchy and organize menu items.

limitations: ContextMenuLabel is a non-interactive element; it does not respond to clicks, keyboard events, or have any associated actions. It is purely for display purposes.
It should only contain text or simple inline elements; complex interactive children are not supported or intended for this component.
bestPractices: Use ContextMenuLabel sparingly to avoid clutter; too many labels can make the menu feel busy.
Combine with ContextMenuSeparator and ContextMenuGroup for clear visual organization of menu items.
Utilize the 'inset' prop for labels that act as sub-headings or categories within a larger section, aligning them visually with inset items.
antiPatterns: Using ContextMenuLabel as an interactive button or action item; it is for display only.
Placing a ContextMenuLabel in every section if a ContextMenuGroup with items is self-explanatory, as it can add unnecessary visual noise.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled visual separator element within a ContextMenu component to divide logical groups of items.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuSeparator component renders a styled horizontal line, acting as a visual divider within a ContextMenu. It wraps the `ContextMenuPrimitive.Separator` from Radix UI, applying consistent styling to separate logical groups of menu items. This component is crucial for improving the readability and organization of complex context menus, guiding users through different sections of available actions.

commonUseCases: Separating action categories (e.g., edit actions from delete actions)
Dividing general settings from advanced settings in a context menu
Creating clear visual breaks between different types of commands (e.g., file operations, view options)

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use ContextMenuSeparator to visually group different categories of actions (e.g., 'New' actions, 'Navigation' actions, 'Application' actions) within a context menu for improved organization and user clarity.

limitations: The component's primary function is visual separation; it does not add any interactive behavior.
Styling customization is limited to what can be achieved via the `className` prop for basic CSS adjustments.
bestPractices: Use separators judiciously to enhance readability, placing them only between clearly distinct logical sections of menu items.
Combine with `ContextMenuLabel` for explicit section titling in addition to visual separation when appropriate.
Ensure consistent spacing and styling for separators across all context menus for a cohesive user experience.
antiPatterns: Using multiple separators consecutively without any items in between, which creates redundant visual clutter.
Placing separators at the very beginning or end of a context menu, as they serve no visual purpose there.
Overusing separators, leading to a fragmented and difficult-to-scan menu.

semanticData.summary: Renders a styled span element typically used to display keyboard shortcuts within context menu items.
semanticData.description: The ContextMenuShortcut component is designed to visually represent keyboard shortcuts alongside menu items in a context menu. It renders a span element with pre-defined styles that position it to the right, use muted text, and a smaller font size. This helps users quickly identify associated keyboard commands without cluttering the main menu item text.

commonUseCases: Displaying keyboard shortcuts next to menu options
Enhancing context menu usability with shortcut hints
Providing visual cues for common actions in a context menu

examples.code: import { ContextMenuItem, ContextMenuShortcut } from "./context-menu";function MyComponent() { return ( Copy C );}
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use ContextMenuShortcut within a ContextMenuItem to display 'C' as the shortcut for a 'Copy' action, enhancing user guidance.

limitations: This component is purely presentational and does not implement any keyboard handling logic itself; it only displays the shortcut text.
It is intended for use within Radix UI's ContextMenu system and might not render correctly or semantically outside of it.
bestPractices: Pair ContextMenuShortcut with ContextMenuItem to clearly associate a shortcut with its corresponding action.
Keep the shortcut text concise and consistent with common keyboard notation (e.g., C, Ctrl+S).
Ensure the displayed shortcut functionality is implemented and correctly mapped to the associated menu item's action.
antiPatterns: Using ContextMenuShortcut for arbitrary text or non-shortcut content, as it applies specific styling intended for shortcuts, which could lead to inconsistent UI.
Placing multiple ContextMenuShortcut components within a single menu item, which would disrupt layout and confuse users.

semanticData.summary: Provides the context for a 'react-hook-form' instance, enabling form state management and interaction across form components.
semanticData.description: The 'Form' const is an alias for 'react-hook-form's FormProvider component. It serves as the top-level wrapper for any form built using 'react-hook-form', establishing the context necessary for all child form components to access the form's state, methods, and validation. This component centralizes form management, simplifying the development of complex forms and ensuring consistent interaction across inputs.

commonUseCases: Building complex forms with multiple input types and nested fields
Implementing client-side form validation and displaying error messages
Managing form submission logic and integrating with APIs
Creating dynamic forms where fields appear or disappear based on user input

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to set up a basic form using the 'Form' component (which is 'FormProvider') along with 'FormField' and other related UI components ('FormItem', 'FormLabel', 'FormControl', 'FormDescription', 'FormMessage'). It shows integration with 'react-hook-form' and Zod for schema validation, illustrating how to define a form schema, connect inputs, handle form submission, and display validation messages automatically.

limitations: The 'Form' component itself does not render an HTML '<form>' element; it's a context provider. You must explicitly include an HTML '<form>' element if you need native browser form behaviors or events.
Requires 'react-hook-form' as a peer dependency; it is not a standalone form library.
While flexible, the component system encourages a specific component hierarchy and usage pattern for optimal integration and feature access.
bestPractices: Always wrap your entire form structure with the 'Form' component and pass the 'methods' object obtained from 'react-hook-form's 'useForm' hook.
Utilize 'FormField' for each individual input element to automatically connect it to 'react-hook-form's controller and state.
Combine 'Form' with other components from this UI library (e.g., 'FormItem', 'FormLabel', 'FormControl', 'FormDescription', 'FormMessage') for consistent styling and accessibility.
Implement schema-based validation (e.g., with Zod and 'zodResolver') for robust and maintainable input validation logic.
Place your actual HTML '<form>' element inside the 'Form' component and use 'form.handleSubmit' on its 'onSubmit' prop.
antiPatterns: Using the 'Form' component without providing the 'methods' prop from 'useForm()', which will cause all child components to fail.
Nesting multiple 'Form' components (or 'FormProvider' instances) unnecessarily, which can lead to unpredictable state management.
Attempting to manage form state manually (e.g., with 'useState') within components intended to be children of 'Form', instead of leveraging 'react-hook-form' hooks.

codeMetadata.name: FormFieldContextValue
codeMetadata.typeSignature: type<TFieldValues extends FieldValues = FieldValues, TName extends FieldPath<TFieldValues> = FieldPath<TFieldValues>> = { name: TName }

semanticData.summary: Defines the structure for context data containing the name of a react-hook-form field, used to identify the current form input.
semanticData.description: This type declaration specifies the shape of the context value shared by FormField components to their descendants. It primarily carries the 'name' of a form field, which is critical for react-hook-form to register and manage inputs. By providing the field 'name' via context, it allows related components (like labels, controls, and error messages) to automatically associate themselves with the correct form field without explicit prop drilling, simplifying form UI development and ensuring consistency.

commonUseCases: Creating a custom form input component that needs to know its react-hook-form field name without prop drilling.
Building UI components (e.g., labels, error messages) that automatically connect to the parent FormField.
Developing composable form structures where the field name is implicitly passed to all related child elements.

examples.code: const FormField = <TFieldValues extends FieldValues = FieldValues, TName extends FieldPath<TFieldValues> = FieldPath<TFieldValues>>({ ...props }: ControllerProps<TFieldValues, TName>) => { return ( <FormFieldContext.Provider value={{ name: props.name }}> <Controller {...props} /> </FormFieldContext.Provider> ); };
examples.description: This example shows how 'FormFieldContextValue' is provided to the React context. The 'FormField' component takes a 'name' prop (of type TName, which conforms to FormFieldContextValue) and makes it available to its descendants via 'FormFieldContext.Provider'.

examples.code: const useFormField = () => { const fieldContext = React.useContext(FormFieldContext); // ... return { name: fieldContext.name, // ... }; };
examples.description: This demonstrates how 'FormFieldContextValue' is consumed. The 'useFormField' hook accesses the 'FormFieldContext' to retrieve the 'name' property, allowing child components like FormLabel or FormControl to know which form field they relate to.

limitations: This type definition has no runtime behavior; it solely defines the structure of data passed through 'FormFieldContext'.
Its utility is strictly limited to the context of the 'FormField' component and its integration with 'react-hook-form'.
bestPractices: Always wrap form controls and their associated labels/messages within a '<FormField>' component to establish the context.
Leverage the 'useFormField' hook within custom form components to conveniently access the field name and its associated state.
Ensure the 'name' prop passed to '<FormField>' correctly matches a path within your form's 'FieldValues' type.
antiPatterns: Attempting to use 'useFormField' outside of a '<FormField>' component's children, as it relies on this context value being provided.
Manually passing the 'name' prop to components that are already designed to consume it from 'FormFieldContext' via 'useFormField', leading to redundancy.

semanticData.summary: A React Context for passing the react-hook-form field 'name' down the component tree.
semanticData.description: FormFieldContext is a React Context designed to provide the 'name' of a form field managed by react-hook-form to deeply nested components without explicit prop drilling. It serves as the bridge between the FormField component (which wraps the react-hook-form Controller) and the useFormField hook, allowing form elements like labels, inputs, and error messages to implicitly access the field's identity and derive necessary IDs for accessibility. This significantly simplifies the creation of composite, accessible form components.

commonUseCases: Providing the field name to child components within a composite form field structure.
Enabling the 'useFormField' hook to retrieve field-specific state from react-hook-form.
Facilitating the auto-generation of unique and accessible IDs for related form elements (label, input, description, message).

examples.description: This example demonstrates how 'FormField' implicitly provides the field 'name' to its children via 'FormFieldContext' (and other contexts), allowing components like 'FormLabel', 'FormControl', 'FormDescription', and 'FormMessage' to correctly connect to the field managed by 'react-hook-form'.

This snippet illustrates how a custom component, designed to be used inside a 'FormField', would consume 'FormFieldContext' (and other contexts) through the 'useFormField' hook to access field-specific 'id', 'name', 'error' status, and derived accessibility IDs.

limitations: FormFieldContext itself only provides the 'name' of the field; other field-related data (e.g., value, onChange, onBlur, error) must be obtained via 'react-hook-form's hooks within 'useFormField'.
It is strictly coupled with 'react-hook-form's 'ControllerProps' and 'FieldPath'/'FieldValues' types, making it specific to 'react-hook-form' integrations.
bestPractices: Always wrap form field related components (e.g., FormLabel, FormControl) within a 'FormField' component to ensure 'FormFieldContext' is correctly provided.
Leverage the 'useFormField' hook for accessing all field data, as it consolidates information from 'FormFieldContext', 'FormItemContext', and 'react-hook-form's state.
Design custom form components that require field-specific data to consume 'useFormField' to correctly link them to the associated form field's state and accessibility attributes.
antiPatterns: Attempting to consume FormFieldContext directly without using the 'useFormField' hook, as 'useFormField' integrates it with other crucial context and React Hook Form state.
Using form field components (e.g., FormLabel, FormControl, FormMessage) outside of a 'FormField' component, which will lead to runtime errors due to missing context.

semanticData.summary: Integrates react-hook-form's Controller into a UI component system, providing field context for dependent components.
semanticData.description: The FormField component serves as a bridge between your form UI and react-hook-form's Controller, managing the state and registration of individual form fields. It wraps the react-hook-form Controller, passing all its props and providing the field's name to a React Context. This context allows descendant components like FormLabel, FormControl, FormDescription, and FormMessage to automatically connect to the correct field's state and generate accessible IDs and ARIA attributes.

commonUseCases: Integrating individual form inputs with react-hook-form for state management and validation.
Displaying dynamic validation messages and error states for specific form fields.
Building accessible form elements that automatically link labels, inputs, descriptions, and error messages via IDs and ARIA attributes.
Creating custom form controls that leverage react-hook-form's field state.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use FormField to integrate a simple text input with react-hook-form. It wraps the Input component, passing its props via the 'render' prop, and leverages other form components (FormItem, FormLabel, FormControl, FormDescription, FormMessage) to create a fully functional and accessible form field.

limitations: FormField is tightly coupled with react-hook-form and relies on its FormProvider (exposed as 'Form') for its context.
It requires the 'name' prop to correctly identify and manage the field within the form state.
While it provides context for other form components, the actual rendering of the input element is deferred to the 'render' prop or similar Controller props.
bestPractices: Always wrap FormField components within a FormItem to ensure proper layout and context for useFormField.
Pass all necessary react-hook-form ControllerProps directly to FormField, especially 'name', 'control', and 'render' (or 'Component', 'as', 'render' depending on react-hook-form version).
Utilize the useFormField hook in custom input components or wrappers to retrieve the field's state, errors, and generated IDs for accessibility.
Structure your forms with Form, FormItem, FormLabel, FormControl, FormDescription, and FormMessage around FormField for a cohesive and accessible experience.
antiPatterns: Using FormField outside of a Form (FormProvider) component from react-hook-form, as it relies on the form context.
Trying to access field state (e.g., 'error', 'value') directly from FormField's props or children; instead, use the useFormField hook within its descendants.
Nesting FormField components unnecessarily; FormField should represent a single controllable input.

semanticData.summary: Provides consolidated react-hook-form field state and unique HTML IDs for building accessible form UI components.
semanticData.description: useFormField is a React hook designed to be used within the context of a FormField component. It centralizes the logic for accessing the current form field's state from react-hook-form and generating consistent, accessible HTML IDs for related elements like labels, inputs, and error messages. This hook simplifies the creation of accessible and robust form UIs by ensuring that form UI components are correctly linked to their corresponding form field data.

commonUseCases: Building custom form input components (e.g., FormLabel, FormControl, FormDescription, FormMessage) that need access to the field's name and state
Creating accessible form structures by linking labels to inputs and error messages via unique IDs
Displaying validation errors or field-specific status within a form

examples.description: Demonstrates how useFormField is used within FormLabel to retrieve the field's error state and its unique formItemId, which is then used to link the label to its corresponding input via the htmlFor attribute, ensuring accessibility.

Shows how useFormField provides unique IDs for the input, description, and message, as well as the error state, enabling the FormControl to set crucial id, aria-describedby, and aria-invalid attributes for accessibility.

limitations: Strictly dependent on FormField and FormItem contexts being present in the component tree
Designed for use with react-hook-form and assumes its presence and correct configuration in the component tree
bestPractices: Always wrap components that use useFormField within a <FormField> component
Leverage the returned formItemId, formDescriptionId, and formMessageId for htmlFor, id, and aria-describedby/aria-invalid attributes to ensure proper accessibility
Use the error property from the returned fieldState to conditionally display validation messages and apply error styling
antiPatterns: Using useFormField outside of a FormField component, which will result in a runtime error
Attempting to modify field state directly using the returned values; react-hook-form methods should be used for state mutations
Hardcoding IDs for form elements instead of relying on the IDs provided by useFormField, which can lead to accessibility issues or ID collisions

semanticData.summary: Defines the shape of the unique identifier provided by FormItemContext for a single form field.
semanticData.description: FormItemContextValue defines the structure for the React Context that provides a unique identifier for each form item. This `id` is internally generated by the FormItem component using `React.useId()` and is crucial for linking related form elements such as labels, inputs, descriptions, and error messages via HTML `for` and `aria-describedby`/`aria-invalid` attributes. It ensures proper accessibility and semantic structure for individual form fields.

commonUseCases: Providing a unique and consistent ID for a group of related form elements (label, input, description, error message)
Enabling accessible linking between form labels and their corresponding input controls
Internal mechanism within a custom form component library to manage field-specific identifiers

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage pattern where `FormItem` acts as the parent for a single form field's components. Internally, `FormItem` creates a unique `id` (of type `FormItemContextValue`) and makes it available to `FormLabel`, `FormControl`, `FormDescription`, and `FormMessage` via context, ensuring they are correctly linked for accessibility purposes.

limitations: This type is an internal implementation detail of the `FormItem` component and `useFormField` hook; it is not exposed or intended for direct consumption or manipulation by external developers.
Its utility is strictly within the context of the provided `Form` component system and may not be portable to other form libraries without adaptation.
bestPractices: Always wrap `FormLabel`, `FormControl`, `FormDescription`, and `FormMessage` within a `FormItem` component to ensure they inherit the necessary unique identifier for proper functionality and accessibility.
Leverage the `useFormField` hook within custom form components to correctly access the `id` and other related field state provided by the `FormItemContext` and `FormFieldContext`.
antiPatterns: Attempting to manually create or provide a `FormItemContextValue` directly: This type is managed internally by the `FormItem` component and its associated context provider, not intended for direct instantiation by consumers.

Using `FormLabel`, `FormControl`, `FormDescription`, or `FormMessage` outside of a `FormItem` wrapper: These components rely on the `id` provided by `FormItemContext`, leading to broken accessibility links and potential errors if not wrapped.

semanticData.summary: Provides a unique ID for each form item, enabling linking of form elements for accessibility and internal component management.
semanticData.description: FormItemContext is a React Context that provides a unique identifier ('id') for each FormItem component instance. This ID is automatically generated using React.useId() within the FormItem component. Its primary purpose is to ensure that all related form elements (like labels, inputs, descriptions, and error messages) within a single FormItem can be programmatically associated for improved accessibility (e.g., via htmlFor, id, aria-describedby, aria-invalid attributes).

commonUseCases: Creating individual form field wrappers that require unique identifiers for nested elements.
Building accessible form elements that automatically link labels, inputs, and messages.
Integrating with the useFormField hook to retrieve item-specific IDs for constructing DOM attributes.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how FormItemContext is implicitly used by the FormItem component. When FormItem renders, it generates a unique ID via React.useId() and makes it available through FormItemContext. The useFormField hook then consumes this ID to create unique and linked HTML attributes (e.g., htmlFor, id, aria-describedby) for the label, control, description, and message elements, ensuring proper accessibility. Developers typically interact with FormItem, not the context directly.

limitations: Relies on React's useId hook, which provides stable IDs across server-side rendering (SSR) and client-side hydration, but IDs might change if the component tree structure or component order within a FormItem instance shifts dramatically.

Direct consumption of FormItemContext is generally not recommended for consumers; instead, the useFormField hook aggregates data from FormItemContext and FormFieldContext, providing a more convenient and robust API for accessing form item-specific data.
bestPractices: Always wrap form controls and their related labels/messages within a FormItem component to ensure proper ID generation and context propagation.
Leverage the useFormField hook to safely access the FormItemContext ID and other derived IDs (formItemId, formDescriptionId, formMessageId) rather than consuming the context directly.
antiPatterns: Manually setting IDs for elements within a FormItem instead of relying on the context-provided ID: This defeats the purpose of automatic ID generation and can lead to ID collisions or broken accessibility links.
Attempting to consume FormItemContext directly outside of a FormItem component: The context value will be empty, or lead to errors, as the 'id' is only provided when a FormItem is rendered.

semanticData.summary: A React component that acts as a container for a single form field, providing a unique ID for accessibility linking.
semanticData.description: The `FormItem` component serves as a foundational container for individual form fields within a larger form. It generates a unique ID for its section, which is then made available via React Context to child components like `FormLabel`, `FormControl`, and `FormMessage`. This ensures proper ARIA attributes and linkage between related form elements, improving accessibility and structure.

commonUseCases: Structuring individual form fields (e.g., input, textarea, select) and their associated labels, descriptions, and error messages.
Grouping related form elements for better visual organization and ARIA linking.
Providing a context for child form components to derive unique IDs for accessibility.

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of `FormItem` wrapping a `FormField` component. It acts as the parent container for `FormLabel`, `FormControl` (which includes an `Input`), `FormDescription`, and `FormMessage`, linking them together through the context-provided ID for accessibility.

limitations: Does not directly handle form validation state or logic; it relies on `react-hook-form`'s `FormField` and `useFormField` for this.
Primarily a structural and accessibility component; it doesn't provide visual styles on its own beyond basic grid layout.
bestPractices: Always wrap a `FormField` (or equivalent field-level component) and its related `FormLabel`, `FormControl`, and `FormMessage` components within a `FormItem`.
Utilize the `className` prop to apply custom styling or layout for the entire field group.
Keep the contents of a `FormItem` focused on a single logical form input to maintain clear structure and accessibility.
antiPatterns: Using `FormItem` outside of a `Form` (or `FormProvider`) context, as it relies on the form's overall structure.
Placing non-form-related content directly inside `FormItem` that isn't part of a single field's structure, which can break semantic grouping.
Attempting to handle form state or validation directly within `FormItem`; its purpose is purely structural and context-providing.

semanticData.summary: Renders an accessible form label automatically linked to its control and displaying error states within a React Hook Form context.
semanticData.description: FormLabel is a specialized React component designed to act as a label for form input elements, integrating seamlessly with a React Hook Form setup. It automatically connects to its associated FormField and FormItem to retrieve the correct HTML 'for' attribute and visually indicate validation errors. This component enhances form accessibility and provides consistent styling for labels within the form system.

commonUseCases: Labeling individual input fields within a form managed by React Hook Form
Providing visual cues for validation errors on form labels
Ensuring accessibility by linking labels to form controls via 'htmlFor'

examples.description: This example demonstrates the typical usage of FormLabel within a complete form structure. FormLabel receives its `htmlFor` attribute and error state automatically from the `FormField` and `FormItem` context, ensuring it correctly labels the associated `Input` and changes its style when a validation error occurs for the 'username' field.

limitations: FormLabel is tightly coupled to the internal context providers (FormFieldContext and FormItemContext) and will not function correctly if used outside of the designated FormField and FormItem components.
Its error display functionality relies on the error state provided by `react-hook-form` and may not be suitable for forms not using this library.
The 'htmlFor' attribute is automatically generated; direct control over this attribute is not intended or supported for linking to external elements.
bestPractices: Always nest FormLabel within a FormItem, which is itself contained within a FormField, to ensure proper context and ID generation
Place FormLabel immediately before its corresponding FormControl component for standard form layout and improved accessibility
Utilize the built-in error styling by ensuring your CSS framework handles the 'data-[error=true]' attribute, allowing FormLabel to automatically highlight when its associated field has an error
antiPatterns: Using FormLabel outside of a FormItem or FormField context, which will lead to runtime errors due to missing context
Manually setting the 'htmlFor' prop on FormLabel, as it is automatically managed by the 'formItemId' from useFormField
Attempting to style FormLabel's error state directly with CSS classes instead of relying on the 'data-[error=true]' attribute, which can lead to inconsistent UI

semanticData.summary: Renders an accessible form control element, linking it to form state and related labels/messages via ARIA attributes.
semanticData.description: The FormControl component serves as the wrapper for individual input elements within a form, such as <input>, <select>, or <textarea>. It leverages react-hook-form context via `useFormField` to automatically apply accessibility attributes like `id`, `aria-describedby`, and `aria-invalid` based on the field's state, including error messages. This ensures that form controls are correctly associated with their labels, descriptions, and validation messages, enhancing usability and accessibility.

commonUseCases: Wrapping native HTML input elements (e.g., <input type="text">, <textarea>) within a form field.
Integrating custom form components (e.g., custom dropdowns, date pickers) into the form system while maintaining accessibility.
Automatically handling ARIA attributes for form fields based on validation state provided by react-hook-form.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to wrap a standard `Input` component (or a native `<input>`) with `FormControl`. The `asChild` prop on `FormControl` is implicitly handled by `SlotPrimitive.Slot`, ensuring `Input` receives the accessibility attributes `id`, `aria-describedby`, and `aria-invalid` automatically based on the form field's state. It showcases the integration with other form building blocks like `FormItem`, `FormLabel`, `FormDescription`, and `FormMessage`.

limitations: Requires the surrounding `FormField` and `FormItem` components to provide the necessary context (field name, unique ID) for correct operation.

Primarily designed for standard HTML form elements or custom components that accept typical input props and can be composed via `SlotPrimitive.Slot` (i.e., they are able to forward refs and accept props passed by `FormControl`).
bestPractices: Always place the actual input element (or a custom input component) as a direct child of FormControl.
Ensure FormControl is a direct child of FormItem and within a FormField for proper context propagation and accessibility linking.
Use FormControl in conjunction with FormLabel, FormDescription, and FormMessage for a fully accessible and semantically correct form field.
antiPatterns: Using FormControl outside of a FormField and FormItem context, as it relies on these components for necessary IDs and field state.
Manually setting `id`, `aria-describedby`, or `aria-invalid` attributes on the child element within FormControl, as FormControl manages these automatically.

semanticData.summary: Renders an accessible description text associated with a form field, automatically linking it for accessibility.
semanticData.description: The FormDescription component provides supplementary helper text or a brief description for an individual form field. It automatically retrieves its associated ID from the form context, which is then referenced by the FormControl component via aria-describedby, ensuring proper accessibility. This component helps improve user experience by offering clear guidance without cluttering the main label, explaining field purpose or requirements.

commonUseCases: Adding descriptive hints below a text input to guide user input
Explaining complex field requirements or validation rules briefly
Providing context for a checkbox, radio group, or select field
Offering examples of expected input format or data

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use FormDescription to provide a helper text for a username input field within a react-hook-form setup. The description is automatically linked to the input via accessibility attributes, improving user guidance for the 'username' field.

limitations: FormDescription must be rendered as a child of a FormItem component to correctly inherit its context and ID for accessibility linking.
It is primarily for plain text descriptions and not intended for complex UI elements or interactive content.
Styling is limited to basic text properties; more complex layouts should be handled by custom components.
bestPractices: Keep descriptions concise and to the point to avoid visual clutter.
Use FormDescription for non-critical information that aids understanding, not primary validation feedback.
Ensure the description directly relates to the associated form control.
antiPatterns: Using FormDescription to display validation error messages (use FormMessage instead)
Placing FormDescription outside of a FormItem component, as it relies on its context for ID generation
Using excessively long or complex descriptions that should be part of external documentation

semanticData.summary: Displays a validation error message for a form field managed by react-hook-form.
semanticData.description: FormMessage is a React component designed to display validation error messages associated with a specific form field. It automatically retrieves the error state for its corresponding field using the useFormField hook, which integrates with react-hook-form. This component renders the error message in a styled 'p' tag, ensuring users receive clear feedback when form input is invalid.

commonUseCases: Displaying real-time validation errors for user input fields
Providing immediate feedback on failed form submissions
Implementing accessible error messages for form controls

examples.description: This example demonstrates the standard usage of FormMessage within a FormField and FormItem structure. It automatically displays validation errors for the 'username' and 'email' fields as defined by react-hook-form's 'rules' prop. When an input is invalid, FormMessage will render the corresponding error message extracted from the form state.

limitations: It can only display a single error message per field, typically the first one returned by react-hook-form's validation.
Relies heavily on the context providers (FormFieldContext, FormItemContext) established by FormField and FormItem; it cannot function independently.
Only displays messages when react-hook-form detects an error for the specific field.
bestPractices: Always wrap FormMessage within a FormItem and FormField to ensure it correctly associates with the input field and displays the relevant error.
Ensure your react-hook-form validation rules provide meaningful error messages that can be displayed directly to the user.
Place FormMessage visually close to the corresponding input field for immediate user comprehension.
antiPatterns: Using FormMessage outside of a FormItem and FormField context, as it relies on their context providers for field information; this will lead to runtime errors or incorrect behavior.
Manually passing error messages as children to FormMessage if the field is managed by react-hook-form, as it automatically extracts the error message from the form state.
Styling FormMessage to be invisible or obscure; it defeats its purpose of providing clear user feedback.

semanticData.summary: Defines the programmatic API type for an Embla Carousel instance, enabling direct control and interaction.
semanticData.description: The "CarouselApi" type represents the programmatic interface to an Embla Carousel instance. It provides methods and properties for direct control over the carousel's behavior, such as navigating slides, checking scroll state, and registering event listeners. Developers use this API to create custom navigation controls, respond to carousel events, or implement advanced carousel functionalities beyond basic UI interactions.

commonUseCases: Implementing custom carousel navigation buttons (e.g., next, previous).
Programmatically controlling carousel slides (e.g., auto-play, jump to a specific slide).
Responding to carousel events like slide changes or initialization.
Checking the current scroll state or capabilities of the carousel.
Exposing the internal carousel controls to parent components.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to obtain the `CarouselApi` instance using the `setApi` prop of the `Carousel` component. Once obtained, it shows how to use the API to programmatically scroll to a specific slide (`scrollTo`) and subscribe to carousel events (`on('select')`) for custom logic. It also highlights the importance of cleaning up listeners using `useEffect`'s return function.

limitations: The `CarouselApi` instance might be `undefined` immediately after the component mounts and before Embla Carousel initializes, requiring null checks before use.
The API only provides methods for controlling the carousel itself; it does not directly manage the rendering or styling of individual carousel items, which are handled by the component's structure.
bestPractices: Always perform null or undefined checks on the `CarouselApi` instance before invoking its methods.
Utilize React's `useEffect` hook to manage `CarouselApi` interactions, ensuring methods are called when the API is ready and cleaning up listeners on unmount.
Prefer using `CarouselApi` methods for all carousel manipulations to maintain consistency and leverage Embla Carousel's optimizations.
For complex interactions, consider using the `api.on()` method to subscribe to Embla Carousel events and react to state changes.
Pass the `setApi` prop to the `Carousel` component to receive the `CarouselApi` instance in a parent component for external control.
antiPatterns: Calling API methods without checking if the API instance is defined (null or undefined).
Directly manipulating the carousel's DOM elements instead of using the provided API methods, which can lead to inconsistent behavior or break the carousel's functionality.
Forgetting to unregister event listeners (e.g., `api.off()`) in cleanup functions, which can cause memory leaks or unexpected behavior when components unmount.

semanticData.summary: Defines the tuple type for the parameters accepted by the `useEmblaCarousel` hook.
semanticData.description: The UseCarouselParameters type is a utility type that captures the exact arguments expected by the `useEmblaCarousel` hook from the 'embla-carousel-react' library. It is defined as a tuple where the first element represents the carousel options and the second represents the carousel plugins. This type is primarily used internally within the carousel component to derive more specific types like `CarouselOptions` and `CarouselPlugin`, ensuring type safety and clarity for the underlying carousel configuration.

commonUseCases: Defining the types for the options and plugins passed to the `useEmblaCarousel` hook
Ensuring type safety when integrating with the `embla-carousel-react` library

examples.description: This example demonstrates how `UseCarouselParameters` is used to derive `CarouselOptions` and `CarouselPlugin`, which are then used in the `CarouselProps` type to define the public interface for the Carousel component. This promotes a clear separation of concerns and type safety.

limitations: This type is tightly coupled to the `useEmblaCarousel` hook's signature; any changes to the hook's parameters in the 'embla-carousel-react' library would necessitate an update to this type.
It is an abstract type definition and not meant for direct instantiation or usage as a variable type in application logic, but rather for type inference and derivation.
bestPractices: Derive more semantically meaningful types (e.g., `CarouselOptions`, `CarouselPlugin`) from `UseCarouselParameters` for improved readability and clarity in component APIs.
Treat `UseCarouselParameters` as an internal helper type for defining other configuration-related types.
antiPatterns: Directly using `UseCarouselParameters` in public API surfaces (e.g., component props) instead of its more specific derived types like `CarouselOptions` or `CarouselPlugin`, which can make the API less readable and explicit.

semanticData.summary: Defines the configuration parameters for the underlying Embla Carousel instance used by the `Carousel` component.
semanticData.description: CarouselOptions is a type alias that represents the configuration object for the underlying Embla Carousel instance used by the `Carousel` component. It provides a direct way to pass a wide range of options to Embla Carousel, allowing developers to customize the carousel's behavior such as looping, alignment, axis, drag sensitivity, and more. This type enables fine-grained control over the carousel's functionality and visual presentation.

commonUseCases: Configuring the carousel for infinite looping or finite scrolling
Adjusting the carousel's alignment of slides (e.g., start, center, end)
Controlling scroll speed or animation behavior between slides
Disabling or enabling user interaction like free dragging
Setting up responsive options for different screen sizes

examples.description: Demonstrates how to pass `loop: true` and `align: "center"` via `opts` to create a carousel that loops infinitely and centers its slides within the viewport.

Shows how to configure a vertical carousel using the `orientation` prop, and then apply Embla-specific options like `dragFree`, `skipSnaps`, and custom `duration` via `opts` for a distinct scrolling experience.

limitations: The options available are directly tied to the capabilities and version of the underlying `embla-carousel-react` library.
Certain options (e.g., 'axis') passed via `CarouselOptions` might be overridden by explicit props on the `Carousel` component, such as the `orientation` prop.
bestPractices: Consult the official Embla Carousel documentation for a comprehensive list and detailed explanations of all available options.
Prefer using the `orientation` prop on the `Carousel` component for setting the axis (horizontal/vertical) when simple axis control is needed, as it's more explicit for this component.
Use `opts` for more advanced Embla-specific configurations not directly exposed as props on the main `Carousel` component.
antiPatterns: Setting the 'axis' property within `opts` if the 'orientation' prop on the `Carousel` component is also used, as `orientation` will explicitly override 'axis' in most cases.

Attempting to dynamically change `CarouselOptions` after the component mounts and expecting all underlying Embla instance behaviors to update without explicit re-initialization logic (some options might not be reactive after initial render).

semanticData.summary: Represents the type definition for plugins compatible with the "embla-carousel-react" library, used to extend carousel functionality.
semanticData.description: The "CarouselPlugin" type defines the structure for plugins that can be passed to the "embla-carousel-react" hook. These plugins allow developers to extend the core carousel behavior, enabling features like auto-play, lazy loading, accessibility enhancements, or custom navigation. It ensures type safety when providing custom or pre-built Embla Carousel plugins to the "Carousel" component.

commonUseCases: Adding advanced features to a carousel, such as autoplay or fade effects
Integrating custom logic or external libraries with the core carousel
Enhancing accessibility or navigation beyond basic left/right controls

examples.description: Demonstrates how to provide an "Autoplay" plugin to the "Carousel" component using the "plugins" prop, ensuring the type safety provided by "CarouselPlugin".

limitations: Directly dependent on the "embla-carousel-react" library's plugin system and its specific API
Does not define the actual plugin logic; it only types the input for the carousel component
Plugin availability and functionality are dictated by the Embla Carousel ecosystem
bestPractices: Always consult the "embla-carousel-react" documentation for official and community-contributed plugins
Ensure any custom plugins adhere to the "EmblaCarouselType" plugin interface
Use an array when providing multiple plugins to the "plugins" prop
antiPatterns: Passing non-Embla plugin objects or incorrectly structured objects, which will result in runtime errors
Expecting the "CarouselPlugin" type itself to define behavior; it only defines the shape of a plugin

codeMetadata.name: CarouselProps
codeMetadata.typeSignature: type = { opts?: CarouselOptions; plugins?: CarouselPlugin; orientation?: "horizontal" | "vertical"; setApi?: (api: CarouselApi) => void }

semanticData.summary: Defines the configurable properties for a React carousel component, including Embla Carousel options, plugins, orientation, and an API callback.
semanticData.description: CarouselProps defines the configurable properties for the custom Carousel React component, built on top of the `embla-carousel-react` library. It allows developers to customize the carousel's behavior and appearance by passing options and plugins directly to the underlying Embla Carousel instance. This type facilitates setting the carousel's orientation and provides a mechanism to access the Embla API for programmatic control.

commonUseCases: Creating image carousels or slideshows with custom navigation
Displaying testimonials or product features in a scrollable format
Implementing responsive and accessible content sliders
Integrating third-party Embla Carousel plugins like autoplay or pagination

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use CarouselProps to configure a looping carousel with custom alignment and how to access the underlying Embla Carousel API using the `setApi` callback for advanced control or debugging.
This example shows how to easily change the carousel's scroll direction using the `orientation` prop, making it a vertical carousel instead of the default horizontal.

limitations: The `CarouselProps` type is a wrapper around Embla Carousel's options and plugins; its functionality is limited by the capabilities of the underlying `embla-carousel-react` library.
Custom CSS styling for items and content often requires overriding the default utility classes, which might be less intuitive than direct CSS.
While `setApi` provides access to the Embla API, it's not designed for deep customizations that might require extending the core Embla Carousel logic itself.
bestPractices: Use the `orientation` prop for simple horizontal/vertical axis control, as it's more declarative than `opts.axis`.
Pass Embla Carousel options via `opts` for detailed configuration, such as looping, custom starting indexes, or drag sensitivity.
Utilize the `setApi` prop when you need direct programmatic access to the Embla Carousel instance, for example, to jump to a specific slide or listen to custom events.
Combine `CarouselProps` with `React.ComponentProps<'div'>` when defining the full component props, as seen in the Carousel component itself, to allow standard HTML attributes.
antiPatterns: Avoid setting both `orientation` and `opts.axis` simultaneously; `orientation` takes precedence and might lead to confusion.
Do not rely solely on `setApi` for basic navigation; use the `CarouselPrevious` and `CarouselNext` components for standard controls.
Avoid modifying the carousel API directly within `setApi`'s callback, as it should primarily be used for reading the API instance.

codeMetadata.name: CarouselContextProps
codeMetadata.typeSignature: type = { carouselRef: ReturnType<typeof useEmblaCarousel>[0]; api: ReturnType<typeof useEmblaCarousel>[1]; scrollPrev: () => void; scrollNext: () => void; canScrollPrev: boolean; canScrollNext: boolean } & CarouselProps

semanticData.summary: Defines the properties available through the Carousel context, enabling child components to interact with the carousel's state and controls.
semanticData.description: CarouselContextProps defines the interface for the context provided by the Carousel component. It encapsulates the core state and control functions derived from the underlying Embla Carousel instance, such as the carousel's DOM reference, API object, navigation methods, and scroll capabilities. This enables descendant components (like navigation buttons or content wrappers) to access and manipulate the carousel's behavior without prop drilling, promoting modularity and reusability within the carousel system.

commonUseCases: Creating custom navigation buttons for the carousel
Conditionally rendering UI elements based on carousel scroll state (e.g., hiding prev/next buttons at ends)
Attaching the Embla Carousel instance to content wrappers
Displaying custom indicators for current slide and total slides
Programmatically controlling carousel movement from an external component within the carousel's scope

examples.description: This example shows how the `CarouselPrevious` component consumes `scrollPrev` to trigger backward navigation and `canScrollPrev` to disable the button when the carousel is at its beginning, ensuring correct UI state and functionality.

This example demonstrates how `CarouselContent` uses `carouselRef` to attach the `embla-carousel` instance to its DOM element, allowing Embla to manage the scrolling behavior of its children. It also uses `orientation` for proper styling.

limitations: The `CarouselContextProps` values are only available to components rendered within the `Carousel` component's provider tree.

While the `api` object from `embla-carousel` is exposed, direct manipulation of its internal state should be done with caution to avoid conflicts with the `Carousel` component's own state management (e.g., `canScrollPrev`/`canScrollNext` updates).
bestPractices: Always use the `useCarousel` hook to access these properties, as it includes necessary checks for context availability.
Utilize `canScrollPrev` and `canScrollNext` to disable navigation controls when the carousel cannot scroll further, improving user experience.
Prefer `scrollPrev` and `scrollNext` for programmatically moving the carousel within child components, as they are part of the managed context API.
Ensure any custom components consuming this context are rendered as descendants of the `Carousel` component to receive the context value.
antiPatterns: Attempting to use the `useCarousel` hook (which consumes this context) outside of the `Carousel` component tree, leading to runtime errors.

Directly modifying `carouselRef` or the `api` object from child components instead of using the provided `scrollPrev` or `scrollNext` methods, which could cause unexpected behavior or state inconsistencies.
Ignoring the `canScrollPrev` or `canScrollNext` flags when building custom navigation, leading to enabled but non-functional buttons.

semanticData.summary: Provides the Embla Carousel API, scroll functions, and current scroll state to descendant React components via context.
semanticData.description: This React Context centralizes the state and control functions for a carousel component, including the Embla Carousel API instance, scroll methods, and scrollability flags. It simplifies prop drilling by allowing descendant components like CarouselContent or navigation buttons to access the carousel's core functionality and state directly. Developers use this context to build a rich and interactive carousel experience with consistent behavior across its sub-components.

commonUseCases: Providing carousel state and API to deeply nested carousel sub-components like content wrappers or individual items
Implementing custom navigation buttons (e.g., 'Previous', 'Next') for a carousel
Accessing the underlying Embla Carousel API for advanced interactions or event handling within children
Synchronizing external UI elements (e.g., pagination dots) with the carousel's current slide

examples.description: This example demonstrates how a custom component (`MyCustomCarouselNavigator`) can easily access carousel navigation functions (`scrollPrev`, `scrollNext`) and state (`canScrollPrev`, `canScrollNext`) using the `useCarousel` hook (which consumes `CarouselContext`). This allows for flexible placement and styling of navigation controls without prop drilling.

This example demonstrates how to use the raw `api` object provided by the `CarouselContext` (via `useCarousel`) to implement more complex UI features like pagination dot indicators. It shows subscribing to `select` and `reInit` events on the Embla Carousel API and using `scrollTo` for direct navigation.

limitations: The context is specifically designed for the `Carousel` component built with `embla-carousel-react` and is not a generic, standalone carousel context for other implementations.

While the `api` instance is exposed, direct manipulation of its state (e.g., using internal `embla-carousel` methods not exposed via `CarouselContextProps`) could lead to desynchronization if not handled carefully and could break the intended behavior provided by the `Carousel` component.

This context provides state for a single carousel instance. To manage multiple independent carousels, each `Carousel` component creates its own context provider, meaning components consuming `useCarousel` will implicitly refer to the nearest parent `Carousel`.
bestPractices: Always wrap consuming components (like `CarouselContent`, `CarouselPrevious`, etc.) within the `Carousel` component to ensure the context is available.

Leverage the provided `scrollPrev`, `scrollNext`, `canScrollPrev`, and `canScrollNext` from the context for standard navigation rather than directly manipulating the `api` instance unless necessary for advanced features.
For custom or advanced behavior, use the `api` instance (from the context) which is the Embla Carousel API, ensuring consistency with the parent carousel's state.
Ensure components consuming the context are pure and only react to context changes, avoiding side effects that modify the carousel state directly outside of the provided functions.
antiPatterns: Attempting to use `useCarousel` (which consumes this context) outside of a `Carousel` component, which will throw an error due to no provider being found.
