Modifying the context values directly from a consumer component; the context is primarily for read-only access and calling provided control functions.
Recreating the `CarouselContext.Provider` multiple times within the same `Carousel` component hierarchy, which can lead to unpredictable behavior.

semanticData.summary: A React hook that provides access to the current carousel's API, scroll functions, and state (e.g., scrollability) within its child components.
semanticData.description: The useCarousel hook allows child components nested within a <Carousel /> to access its internal state and control functions. It leverages React Context to provide the EmblaCarousel instance (API), methods for scrolling, and flags indicating if scrolling is possible in either direction. This hook is essential for building custom carousel navigation controls, indicators, or any feature that needs to interact with or react to the carousel's current state.

commonUseCases: Creating custom navigation buttons (e.g., next/previous, specific slide buttons)
Building slide indicators that reflect the current slide and total slides
Accessing the underlying Embla Carousel API for advanced interactions or event listeners
Displaying current slide index or total slide count

examples.description: Demonstrates how to use useCarousel to create custom 'Previous' and 'Next' navigation buttons, disabling them when scrolling is not possible.
Shows how to use the api object returned by useCarousel to build custom slide indicators. It tracks the selected slide and allows direct navigation to any slide.

limitations: This hook must be a direct or indirect descendant of a <Carousel /> component in the React component tree. If used elsewhere, it will throw an error.

It only exposes the EmblaCarousel instance and its derived state; it does not provide direct access to the useEmblaCarousel hook's initial options or plugins, which are configured at the Carousel component level.
bestPractices: Always use useCarousel within components that are direct or indirect children of the Carousel component
Destructure only the properties you need from the returned context to improve readability
Utilize canScrollPrev and canScrollNext to conditionally disable navigation controls
antiPatterns: Calling useCarousel outside of a component rendered within a <Carousel /> instance, as it will throw an error
Attempting to modify the carousel's state directly without using the provided scrollPrev, scrollNext, or the api methods

codeMetadata.name: Carousel
codeMetadata.typeSignature: function(_complex_param: React.ComponentProps<"div"> & CarouselProps): () => any | any | void

semanticData.summary: A React component for building accessible and customizable carousels with horizontal or vertical orientation using Embla Carousel.
semanticData.description: The Carousel component serves as a robust wrapper around the `embla-carousel-react` library, facilitating the creation of accessible and highly customizable content carousels. It handles core carousel logic, state management, and provides directional controls, solving the problem of implementing interactive sliders with consistent behavior and styling. It exposes an API context, allowing its sub-components (CarouselContent, CarouselItem, CarouselPrevious, CarouselNext) to seamlessly integrate and contribute to the overall carousel functionality.

commonUseCases: Displaying image galleries or product showcases on e-commerce sites
Creating horizontal content sections like news feeds or article previews
Building testimonial sliders or featured content carousels
Implementing multi-step onboarding or tutorial flows

examples.description: This example demonstrates a simple image gallery using the `Carousel` component with looping enabled. It shows how to structure the `Carousel`, `CarouselContent`, and `CarouselItem` components, along with the navigation buttons, providing a basic functional setup for displaying scrollable content.

limitations: Requires a client-side rendering environment due to the "use client" directive and reliance on browser-specific APIs.
Inherits limitations and specific API patterns from its underlying `embla-carousel-react` library.
The styling and base components (e.g., `Button` and `cn` utility) assume a specific design system structure defined by `@repo/web`, requiring adaptation if used in a different project setup.
Does not include built-in features like dot navigation, progress indicators, or automatic slide transitions; these would need to be implemented separately using the exposed `CarouselApi`.
bestPractices: Always use CarouselContent and CarouselItem as direct children within the Carousel for proper styling and functionality.
Leverage the opts prop to configure Embla Carousel behavior, such as loop, drag, or responsiveness, according to your needs.
Utilize the setApi prop to gain direct access to the Embla Carousel instance for advanced interactions, custom navigation, or integration with external controls.
Ensure all CarouselItem components have consistent sizing, especially if opts.containScroll is not used, to maintain visual alignment.
Consider adding visual indicators (e.g., dot navigation) or custom progress bars, which can be built using the exposed CarouselApi, to enhance user experience.
antiPatterns: Using CarouselContent, CarouselItem, CarouselPrevious, or CarouselNext components outside of a Carousel component, as they rely on its context.
Attempting to directly manipulate Embla Carousel state without using the provided setApi prop or the CarouselApi from the context.
Forgetting to wrap CarouselItem(s) within CarouselContent, which is essential for the carousel's layout and functionality.

semanticData.summary: Renders the scrollable content area for a carousel, containing individual slides and managing layout based on orientation.
semanticData.description: CarouselContent serves as the primary container for individual carousel slides, designed to be a direct child of the Carousel component. It leverages the internal `carouselRef` from the `useCarousel` hook to connect to the Embla Carousel instance, managing the overflow and applying flexible box layout based on the carousel's orientation. This component is crucial for correctly displaying and enabling the horizontal or vertical scrolling of carousel items.

commonUseCases: Containing a series of CarouselItem components within a Carousel
Creating a scrollable strip of content like image galleries or product showcases
Providing the viewport for slides in a responsive carousel

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic usage of CarouselContent. It is nested within a Carousel component and acts as the container for multiple CarouselItem components, each representing a distinct slide within the carousel.

limitations: CarouselContent must be a direct child of the Carousel component to access the necessary context (carouselRef, orientation).
It primarily handles the wrapping and initial layout of slides; individual slide styling and content are managed by CarouselItem.
Relies on the `embla-carousel-react` library's DOM structure for proper functionality and styling.
bestPractices: Always nest CarouselItem components directly within CarouselContent for proper slide rendering and functionality.
Use the 'className' prop for custom styling that augments, rather than overrides, the component's base layout.
Ensure the content within each CarouselItem is suitable for its 'basis-full' sizing.
antiPatterns: Placing non-CarouselItem elements directly inside CarouselContent, as it expects specific item structures.
Applying conflicting CSS properties like 'overflow' or 'display' that override the component's internal layout logic.
Using CarouselContent outside of a Carousel component, as it relies on the CarouselContext.

semanticData.summary: Renders an individual, responsive slide item for a carousel component.
semanticData.description: The CarouselItem component serves as a container for individual slides within a CarouselContent. It automatically adjusts its styling based on the carousel's orientation, ensuring proper layout and responsiveness for each slide. Developers use it to wrap the content that should be displayed as a single item in the carousel sequence, contributing to a fully accessible and functional carousel.

commonUseCases: Displaying a sequence of images in a slideshow
Presenting testimonials or feature highlights as individual navigable cards
Creating a product gallery where each item is a distinct product view

examples.code:
import { Carousel, CarouselContent, CarouselItem, CarouselNext, CarouselPrevious } from "@repo/web/components/ui/carousel"; function MyImageCarousel() { return (

Image 1

 ); }
examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use CarouselItem within a CarouselContent to display a series of images as individual slides. Each CarouselItem wraps a div containing an image and a caption, forming a distinct, navigable slide within the overall carousel structure.

limitations: CarouselItem must always be a direct child of CarouselContent to function correctly due to its reliance on the carousel context and specific layout properties applied by the parent component.

Its core styling ('basis-full', 'min-w-0', 'shrink-0', 'grow-0') is specifically designed for full-width slides within the carousel viewport, making it unsuitable for components that require different foundational sizing or positioning within the carousel.
bestPractices: Ensure each CarouselItem contains a distinct piece of content that conceptually represents a single 'slide' within the carousel.
For accessibility, ensure content within CarouselItem is properly structured with appropriate ARIA attributes if it contains interactive elements.
Utilize the 'className' prop to add custom styling or override default styles for specific items without conflicting with the core carousel layout.
antiPatterns: Using CarouselItem outside of CarouselContent: It relies on CarouselContext, which will cause an error if not rendered as a child of CarouselContent.
Applying fixed dimensions that conflict with the default 'basis-full' or 'min-w-0' styles, potentially breaking responsiveness.
Placing non-visual or non-slide content directly within CarouselItem, as it is intended for distinct, visually separate carousel slides.

semanticData.summary: Renders a button to navigate to the previous slide in a Carousel, automatically managing its disabled state.
semanticData.description: The CarouselPrevious component renders a button that allows users to navigate to the preceding slide within a carousel. It automatically integrates with the parent Carousel component's state via the `useCarousel` hook to enable or disable itself based on whether there's a previous slide available. This ensures a seamless and intuitive navigation experience for the user.

commonUseCases: Adding a 'previous' navigation button to a photo gallery carousel.
Providing backward navigation for a product showcase carousel on an e-commerce site.
Implementing slide-by-slide navigation in a presentation component.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to use the CarouselPrevious component alongside Carousel, CarouselContent, and CarouselItem to create a basic image carousel. The CarouselPrevious button will automatically appear and become interactive, allowing users to navigate backward through the slides. Its disabled state will be managed automatically.

limitations: Must be used as a descendant of the Carousel component to function correctly, as it consumes the CarouselContext.
Its functionality is tightly coupled with the `embla-carousel-react` library used internally by the Carousel component.
bestPractices: Always render CarouselPrevious as a child of the Carousel component to ensure it has access to the necessary context.
Customize its appearance using the `className`, `variant`, and `size` props for consistent styling within your application.
Consider its placement relative to the CarouselContent to ensure it's easily discoverable and accessible to users.
Ensure proper ARIA attributes are maintained for accessibility, though the component handles 'sr-only' text by default.
antiPatterns: Using CarouselPrevious outside of a Carousel component: This will result in an error because it relies on the CarouselContext.

Attempting to manually manage the 'disabled' prop when using it within a Carousel: The component automatically disables itself when `canScrollPrev` is false, overriding manual control could lead to inconsistent UI/UX.

semanticData.summary: Renders a button to navigate to the next slide in a carousel, automatically handling disabled states and adapting to carousel orientation.
semanticData.description: This React component provides a navigation button for advancing the carousel to the next slide. It dynamically manages its disabled state based on whether there are more slides to scroll to, leveraging the `useCarousel` context. The component automatically adjusts its positioning and rotation to fit both horizontal and vertical carousel orientations, offering a ready-to-use solution for interactive carousel controls.

commonUseCases: Adding a 'next slide' button to a responsive image or content carousel
Providing interactive navigation for product galleries or showcases
Implementing control buttons for featured content sliders on a homepage

examples.description: This example demonstrates the basic integration of `CarouselNext` within a `Carousel` component. It shows a simple image gallery where `CarouselNext` is placed alongside `CarouselPrevious` to provide standard navigation controls for cycling through slides.

limitations: The component's default positioning relies on absolute CSS; custom layouts may require overriding the `className` prop for different placement strategies
Functionality is entirely dependent on the presence and proper setup of the `CarouselContext` provided by its parent `Carousel` component
bestPractices: Always ensure `CarouselNext` is rendered as a child of the `Carousel` component to access necessary context
For custom styling, leverage the `className` prop to override default absolute positioning and sizing without re-implementing core functionality
Pair with `CarouselPrevious` for complete and intuitive user navigation controls
antiPatterns: Using `CarouselNext` outside of a `Carousel` component, as it relies on the `CarouselContext` and will throw an error
Overriding the `onClick` prop without calling `scrollNext` if the intention is to retain default navigation behavior

semanticData.summary: Defines the prop types for a React Error Boundary component, including error details and a reset mechanism.
semanticData.description: This interface defines the properties expected by a React Error Boundary component. It specifies the 'error' object that caused the boundary to activate, an optional 'reset' function to attempt recovery, and optional 'info' for additional debugging details like the component stack. Its purpose is to standardize the data passed to an error UI, enabling robust error display and recovery mechanisms.

commonUseCases: Displaying a fallback UI when a React component tree encounters a rendering error
Providing options for users to refresh the page or navigate away after an error
Logging client-side React errors to a monitoring service

examples.description: This example shows how `ErrorBoundaryProps` are consumed by the `ErrorBoundary` component to render a fallback UI when an error occurs within its children. The `error` prop is mandatory, while `reset` and `info` are optional.

Demonstrates the use of `ErrorBoundaryProps` with both `error` and `info` (for component stack details) as well as a `reset` function that reloads the page. This setup is useful for comprehensive debugging and user recovery.

limitations: React Error Boundaries only catch errors that occur during rendering, in lifecycle methods, and inside constructors. They do not catch errors in event handlers, asynchronous code (e.g., `setTimeout`, `Promise.then`), or server-side rendering errors.

The `reset` function provided by `ErrorBoundaryProps` needs to manage the state that caused the error to be re-rendered; simply calling `reset` may not always fix the underlying issue without proper state management.
The `info.componentStack` property might not always be available or comprehensive, depending on the React version and build environment.
bestPractices: Wrap specific parts of your application or individual components with `ErrorBoundary` to provide more localized error recovery.
Implement a `reset` function that clears the error state and potentially re-renders the faulty component, allowing users to 'try again'.

Integrate with an error logging service (e.g., Sentry, Bugsnag) within the `ErrorBoundary`'s lifecycle methods (e.g., `componentDidCatch` or `useEffect` for function components) to capture errors in production.
Display user-friendly messages for errors and provide clear actions, while exposing technical details only in development environments.
antiPatterns: Using `ErrorBoundaryProps` (or the `ErrorBoundary` component) to catch errors outside of React's render phase (e.g., network requests, Promises not thrown within a component's lifecycle) as it's specifically for React component tree errors.
Not providing a meaningful `reset` function when the error is potentially recoverable, leaving users without a clear path forward.
Over-wrapping entire applications in a single ErrorBoundary, which can make it harder to pinpoint error sources or offer granular recovery options.

semanticData.summary: Renders a user-friendly fallback UI for React error boundaries, displaying error details and recovery options.
semanticData.description: This `ErrorBoundary` component serves as a user-friendly fallback UI for React error boundaries. It displays a clear message when an unexpected error occurs, offers options to retry, navigate home, or go back, and provides detailed error information (message, stack trace, component stack) in development mode for debugging. Its purpose is to improve user experience by preventing unhandled runtime errors from crashing the entire application, offering a path to recovery and aiding developers in diagnosing issues.

commonUseCases: Providing a global error fallback for an entire application or a major route.
Displaying a graceful error message for an isolated, unstable section of the UI.
Enhancing the user experience by offering recovery options (retry, home, back) instead of a blank screen on error.
Aiding developers in debugging production issues by displaying detailed error information in development environments.

examples.description: Demonstrates integrating `ErrorBoundary` as the `errorComponent` for a TanStack Router root route. This ensures that any unhandled errors within child routes will render this user-friendly fallback UI.

Shows how to use this `ErrorBoundary` component as the `FallbackComponent` prop of a third-party `react-error-boundary` package. This setup allows it to catch and display errors from `MyProblematicComponent`.

limitations: This `ErrorBoundary` component itself does not catch errors; it is designed to be the visual fallback UI for a higher-level React error boundary implementation (e.g., `componentDidCatch` or `useErrorBoundary`).
Does not catch errors that occur in event handlers (e.g., `onClick`), asynchronous code (`setTimeout`, `fetch`), server-side rendering, or within the error boundary component itself.

The `info?.componentStack` prop is typically provided by legacy React class component error boundaries or specific third-party libraries, and might not always be available or comprehensive with modern hooks-based error boundary patterns.

Relies on `process.env.NODE_ENV` for showing detailed error information, which means detailed errors are not visible in production builds by default. This is a feature, not a bug, for security and user experience.
bestPractices: Wrap this component with an actual React Error Boundary (e.g., from `@tanstack/react-router`, `react-error-boundary`, or a custom class component) to ensure errors are caught and passed correctly.
Place error boundaries strategically around logical sections or entire routes of your application to provide meaningful recovery contexts.
Integrate with an external error tracking service (e.g., Sentry, Bugsnag) to capture and report errors in production environments for proactive monitoring.
Customize the fallback UI to match your application's branding and provide clear, actionable instructions to the user.
Ensure the `reset` prop is correctly wired to allow the error boundary to reset its state, enabling users to 'Try Again'.
antiPatterns: Using this component directly as an error boundary without a parent React Error Boundary (e.g., a class component with `componentDidCatch` or a hook like `useErrorBoundary` from `@tanstack/react-router` or `@sentry/react`). This component is a display, not the catcher.
Implementing individual ErrorBoundary instances for every small component, leading to fragmented error experiences and increased boilerplate.
Relying solely on `console.error` for error logging in production; this should be supplemented with a robust error monitoring service.
Treating expected validation errors or API responses (e.g., 404s, 500s) as unhandled runtime errors for this component; use specific UI for those cases.

semanticData.summary: Renders a dynamic application header providing navigation and authentication controls (sign-in, sign-up, sign-out) based on user session status.
semanticData.description: The Header component displays the main navigation and user authentication status in the application's header. It dynamically renders navigation links and authentication options (sign-in, sign-up, or sign-out) based on whether a user session is active. This component provides a robust sign-out mechanism with loading indicators, error handling via toasts, and router invalidation upon successful logout, ensuring a cohesive user experience.

commonUseCases: Displaying top-level application navigation across all pages.
Providing dynamic authentication controls (sign in/out) in the UI.
Integrating with a global authentication state and routing system (e.g., React Router).
Building a consistent and responsive top navigation bar for web applications.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to implement a dynamic application header that displays different navigation options and authentication controls based on the user's session status. It integrates with `@tanstack/react-router` for navigation, a custom `authClient` for user sign-out, and includes state management for loading indicators and toast notifications for user feedback during the sign-out process.

limitations: The component is tightly coupled with `@tanstack/react-router` for navigation and session data retrieval via `useLoaderData({ from: '__root__' })`, requiring adaptation if a different routing library or session management approach is used.
Relies on the presence of a global `authClient` and specific UI components (`Button`, `ModeToggle`, `buttonVariants`), which need to be defined and available in the project.
bestPractices: Ensure the session data is reliably provided via a global loader (e.g., `useLoaderData` from `__root__`) to maintain consistent authentication status.
Utilize UI component libraries (like Shadcn UI for `Button`) for consistent styling, accessibility, and maintainability of UI elements.
Always provide clear user feedback for asynchronous operations (e.g., sign-out) by showing loading states, success messages, and error toasts.
Keep header logic focused on navigation and session display, delegating complex authentication logic to dedicated services or hooks.
antiPatterns: Embedding overly complex business logic or data fetching directly into the Header component, as it should primarily focus on navigation and user state display.
Handling authentication state directly within the Header without using a centralized auth client or context, leading to inconsistent session management.
Failing to handle the `isSigningOut` state, which could allow multiple sign-out requests or provide a poor user experience during asynchronous operations.

semanticData.summary: Provides a UI component to toggle between light, dark, and system themes using a dropdown menu.
semanticData.description: The ModeToggle component provides a user-friendly interface, typically a dropdown menu, that allows users to seamlessly switch between light, dark, and system-preferred themes within a web application. It integrates with the 'next-themes' library to manage the global theme state and offers dynamic icon changes to reflect the current mode. This component solves the common problem of providing an accessible and visually appealing theme selection mechanism for a better user experience.

commonUseCases: Implementing a theme switcher in a web application's header or navigation bar.
Providing user preference options for visual appearance settings.
Integrating dark mode functionality into a Next.js or React application.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to integrate the ModeToggle component into a typical application header or navigation bar. By placing it in a prominent location, users can easily access the theme switching functionality.

limitations: Relies heavily on the 'next-themes' library for theme state management and configuration.
Requires 'lucide-react' for the default icons and assumes the presence of 'Button' and 'DropdownMenu' components, likely from a UI library like Shadcn UI.
Primarily designed for React applications, particularly those using Next.js due to the 'next-themes' library's common usage pattern within that framework.
bestPractices: Always ensure 'next-themes' is properly configured in your application's root (e.g., _app.tsx or layout.tsx in Next.js) to manage theme state globally.
Place the ModeToggle in a consistent, easily discoverable location within the UI, such as the top-right corner of a header or a settings menu.
Ensure all necessary UI component dependencies (Button, DropdownMenu) and icon libraries (lucide-react) are correctly installed and imported.
antiPatterns: Attempting to override the component's internal theme logic or styling directly instead of using 'next-themes' configuration.
Using this component without 'next-themes' configured correctly in the application's root, leading to non-functional theme switching.

semanticData.summary: A React component that displays a comprehensive '404 Page Not Found' error message with intuitive navigation options.
semanticData.description: This NotFound component provides a user-friendly interface for pages that do not exist within the application. It informs the user about the missing page, offers options to navigate back to the homepage or the previous page in history, and helps improve the user experience during navigation errors. It integrates with @tanstack/react-router to provide dynamic navigation capabilities, ensuring a consistent and helpful error state for users.

commonUseCases: Displaying a fallback page when a user navigates to an unknown URL or an invalid route.
Providing a clear error message for broken or moved links within an application.
Improving user experience by offering simple navigation options (back/home) on invalid routes.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to configure `@tanstack/react-router` to use the `NotFound` component as the default fallback for any routes that do not match defined paths. This ensures a consistent and user-friendly 404 experience across the application without manual route handling for missing pages.

limitations: Primarily designed for client-side routing solutions like `@tanstack/react-router`; requires additional server-side configuration for full SEO-friendly 404 handling for direct server requests.
Relies on specific UI components (`@repo/web/components/ui`) and icons (`lucide-react`), requiring these dependencies to be available in the project.
bestPractices: Integrate `NotFound` as the `notFoundComponent` in your router's configuration (e.g., `@tanstack/react-router`) to automatically handle unmatched routes.
Keep the 404 message concise and helpful, guiding users to relevant parts of the application rather than just stating an error.
Ensure the 'Go Back' button is conditionally rendered only when a valid browser history entry exists, as implemented, to avoid broken navigation.
antiPatterns: Using this component for non-404 specific errors (e.g., server errors, authentication failures), as it's specifically designed for page not found scenarios.
Overloading the 404 page with excessive or irrelevant information, which can overwhelm users and detract from its primary purpose.

semanticData.summary: Initializes and configures a TanStack React Router instance, integrating it with React Query for data fetching and providing default UI components for loading, errors, and not-found states.
semanticData.description: This `createRouter` function sets up a complete client-side routing solution using TanStack Router. It seamlessly integrates with React Query by injecting a `QueryClient` into the router's context, enabling data fetching capabilities within route loaders. Furthermore, it defines default UI components for common routing states like loading, errors, and 404 pages, providing a consistent user experience out-of-the-box.

commonUseCases: Setting up the primary routing mechanism for a single-page application
Integrating client-side data fetching with routing using React Query
Providing consistent UI feedback for pending routes, errors, and missing pages
Centralizing router configuration and context

examples.description: This example demonstrates how to initialize the router created by `createRouter` and pass it to the `RouterProvider` component, which is essential for making the router available throughout your React application. This is the standard entry point for integrating the router.

This example shows how the `queryClient` initialized within `createRouter` becomes accessible through the `context` object in a TanStack Router route loader. This allows for declarative data fetching for routes, benefiting from React Query's caching and background fetching capabilities.

limitations: Primarily designed for client-side routing; server-side rendering (SSR) setup might require additional configuration beyond this function.
Relies on `@tanstack/react-router-with-query` for direct integration; if you need a different data fetching library, the `queryClient` injection pattern would need to be adapted or removed.
The `routeTree.gen` file implies a code-generation step for routes, which needs to be configured and run as part of the build process.
bestPractices: Call `createRouter` once at the application's entry point (e.g., `main.tsx` or `App.tsx`) and provide the instance to the `RouterProvider`.
Leverage the `queryClient` available in the router context for all data fetching needs within route loaders and actions.
Customize the `defaultPendingComponent`, `defaultErrorComponent`, and `defaultNotFoundComponent` to match the application's design system.
Ensure `routeTree` is correctly generated and imported to define all application routes.
antiPatterns: Creating multiple router instances: Only one root router instance should typically exist to avoid unexpected routing behavior and state management issues.
Modifying the router instance directly after creation for common configurations: Most configurations should be done within the `createTanstackRouter` call to ensure consistency.

Overriding default components unnecessarily: Avoid replacing `defaultNotFoundComponent`, `defaultErrorComponent`, or `defaultPendingComponent` with simple placeholders if the provided ones already meet basic needs, as it adds boilerplate.

semanticData.summary: Defines a file-based route for the root path using @tanstack/react-router.
semanticData.description: This "Route" constant, created with "createFileRoute", defines the root path (/) route for a React application using "@tanstack/react-router". It serves as the primary mechanism to associate a specific URL path with a React component, streamlining route declaration and leveraging file system conventions for automatic route generation. This declaration is crucial for establishing the base entry point of a web application's navigation structure.

commonUseCases: Defining the root or index page of a web application
Setting up the initial entry point for user navigation
Associating a main layout component with the application's base path

examples.description: This example demonstrates defining the most basic root route (/) which renders a simple 'Hello World' component. It's the standard way to set up the entry point for your application.

limitations: Primarily designed for file-based routing; less flexible for highly dynamic route generation outside of file conventions.
Requires adherence to specific file naming conventions for automatic route inference.
Does not directly handle URL parameters within its own file name (though paths can).
bestPractices: Organize route files logically within the 'src/routes' directory to leverage file-based routing benefits.
Ensure the component associated with the root route handles any global layouts or context providers.
Utilize features like 'loader' or 'errorComponent' within the route definition for data fetching or error handling at the root level.
antiPatterns: Overloading the root component with too many unrelated concerns; prefer breaking down into nested routes or separate components.
Manually defining paths that conflict with file-based conventions, leading to confusion or unexpected routing behavior.
Placing the Route constant outside of a file structure that React Router can automatically discover.

semanticData.summary: Defines the global context object available to all routes in a TanStack Router application, specifically including a QueryClient.
semanticData.description: The "MyRouterContext" interface specifies the global context object that is made available to all routes within a TanStack Router application. It solves the problem of needing to access common application resources, such as a QueryClient for data fetching and caching, without explicitly passing them down through props or creating separate React contexts. This interface ensures that all components rendered by the router have consistent access to shared utilities and services.

commonUseCases: Making a QueryClient instance accessible throughout the router for data fetching and caching.
Injecting global services or utilities (e.g., authentication, logging) into the router context.
Providing application-wide configuration settings to all routes.

examples.description: This example demonstrates how `MyRouterContext` is declared to specify that a `QueryClient` will be available in the router's context. It then shows how this interface is passed as a generic type argument to `createRootRouteWithContext` to inform the router of the expected context shape. The actual `queryClient` instance would be provided when initializing the router with `createRouter`.

limitations: Primarily intended for static or slow-changing global dependencies; it's not a substitute for dedicated state management libraries (e.g., Redux, Zustand) for highly dynamic or complex application state.
Context values are typically initialized once at the root; updating them frequently might not be performant or idiomatic for router contexts, as it can trigger widespread re-renders.
bestPractices: Keep the router context lean, containing only truly global and stable dependencies like API clients, query clients, or authentication services.
Ensure the context is properly typed with interfaces or types to leverage TypeScript's compile-time checks and improve developer experience.
Initialize the context values at the root of your application, ensuring they are stable and don't change unnecessarily on re-renders.
antiPatterns: Including highly dynamic or frequently changing state directly in the router context, as it can lead to unnecessary re-renders of dependent components; prefer local React state or more granular contexts for such cases.
Adding excessive or unrelated dependencies to the root context, making it bloated and harder to manage; only include truly global and stable resources.

semanticData.summary: Configures the root route for a `@tanstack/react-router` application, defining global layout, error handling, loading states, and HTML head content with context provision.
semanticData.description: The 'Route' constant defines the foundational configuration for a `@tanstack/react-router` application's root route. It centralizes critical global elements such as HTML <head> content for SEO and styling, specifies application-wide error handling components for 404s and general errors, and provides a default loading state for route transitions. This declaration is crucial for establishing a consistent look, feel, and user experience across the entire application while also allowing shared context, like a QueryClient, to be passed down to all nested routes.

commonUseCases: Defining the primary layout structure for a single-page application (SPA)
Centralizing application-wide SEO metadata, favicons, and global stylesheet links
Implementing consistent error boundaries for unhandled route errors and 404 pages
Displaying a global loading indicator during route data fetching or transitions
Providing a shared context (e.g., React Query client) to all descendant routes

examples.description: This example demonstrates the complete configuration of the root route. It sets up global meta tags, links for SEO and fonts, specifies custom components for 404 and error states, defines a loading spinner for pending routes, and establishes the main document structure with a theme provider and toast notifications. It also provides a `QueryClient` via context to all nested routes.

limitations: The `head` content defined in the root route is global; for specific page titles or meta descriptions, child routes must override or extend this configuration using their own `head` property.
The `MyRouterContext` defined here is fixed; if a deeper nested context is required for specific routes, it must be provided at a lower level in the route hierarchy or within components.

While `errorComponent` provides a global error boundary, it might not catch all application-level JavaScript errors outside of routing, requiring additional global error handling mechanisms if needed.
bestPractices: Keep the root `component` lean, primarily containing the `Outlet` and essential global providers (e.g., ThemeProvider, Toaster).
Utilize `errorComponent` and `notFoundComponent` to provide consistent and user-friendly feedback during unexpected navigation or application errors.
Leverage the `head` configuration for static, application-wide SEO properties and essential external resource links like fonts or global CSS.
Use `createRootRouteWithContext` to efficiently pass global instances, such as a `QueryClient`, to all nested routes and their loaders/components.
Ensure all necessary global scripts are included via the `Scripts` component within `RootDocument` to maintain client-side functionality.
antiPatterns: Placing highly specific or dynamic UI elements directly in the root route's `component` that should belong to a nested route, leading to unnecessary re-renders.
Overloading the root route's `head` configuration with content that varies per page, as this should be managed by child routes for better specificity and performance.
Omitting the `Outlet` component within the root route's `component` renders, preventing any child routes from being displayed.
Not handling potential errors gracefully within `errorComponent`, leading to a poor user experience on application failures.

semanticData.summary: Renders the foundational HTML structure for a React application, including html, head, body, and integrates router-specific content, global theme provisioning, and scripts.
semanticData.description: The RootDocument function serves as the primary HTML wrapper for the entire application, establishing the html, head, and body elements. It integrates router-specific components like HeadContent and Scripts from @tanstack/react-router and global UI providers such as ThemeProvider and Toaster. This component solves the problem of consistently providing a base HTML structure, configuring essential metadata, and ensuring all routes share a common document foundation and global utilities.

commonUseCases: Defining the root HTML structure for a single-page application built with @tanstack/react-router
Integrating global UI providers like theme providers or notification systems at the application root
Centralizing metadata, SEO, and external script/stylesheet links for the entire application
Providing a consistent base HTML shell for all route components, including error and pending states

examples.code: component: () => ( <RootDocument><Outlet /></RootDocument>)
examples.description: This example demonstrates how RootDocument wraps the main Outlet of @tanstack/react-router, ensuring all routed content is rendered within the defined HTML shell and benefits from global providers.

examples.code: errorComponent: ({ error }) => ( <RootDocument><ErrorBoundary error={error} /></RootDocument>)
examples.description: This shows RootDocument being used to provide a consistent HTML context even for error pages, allowing the ErrorBoundary component to render within the application's standard layout and access global providers like the theme.

limitations: Primarily designed for server-side rendering (SSR) frameworks or @tanstack/react-router's specific hydration model, relying on router-specific HeadContent and Scripts.
Not directly usable as a standalone React component without the context of a router that handles HeadContent and Scripts, as these components need router context to function.
Customization beyond its current prop types would require modifying the component itself, as it is a fixed structural component.
bestPractices: Use RootDocument as the top-level wrapper for your application's routes to ensure consistent HTML structure and behavior across all pages.
Place all application-wide context providers (e.g., ThemeProvider, AuthenticationProvider) within RootDocument to make them universally available.

Leverage the router's head configuration (e.g., createRootRouteWithContext's head option) to manage all SEO, meta tags, and external link definitions, ensuring all dynamic head content is properly handled.
antiPatterns: Duplicating HTML <html>, <head>, or <body> tags in other components: RootDocument should be the single source for these, otherwise it leads to invalid HTML and unpredictable rendering.
Rendering global providers outside RootDocument if they are meant to wrap the entire application: This can lead to providers not being available to all components or requiring redundant wrapping.
Attempting to manually inject or manipulate meta tags, links, or scripts that conflict with HeadContent or Scripts components managed by the router.
